webTitle: BG goes volatile again

fields.headline: BG goes volatile again
fields.trailText: Recent movements of BG, the international gas exploration and production group, are starting to puzzle dealers.
fields.body:
Recent movements of BG, the international gas exploration and production group, are starting to puzzle dealers.

There is a buzz around the company about renewed bid speculation. Supporters of the tale - which does have a certain logic - claim an offer for BG is on the way from North America and its shares rose 9p to 271p yesterday.

But dealers have heard it all before. The bid from Shell, expected to follow BG's split from pipeline business Transco last year, failed to materialise and yesterday's gain might have more to do with technical factors.

On Friday, BG shares closed 10p lower 262p after erratic trading in the closing auction process. Many dealers believe this was a rogue price and yesterday's rise was down to those technical factors.

webTitle: Shrinking Westminster

fields.headline: Shrinking Westminster
fields.standfirst: With the House of Commons losing many of its powers since devolution, how long until it becomes a purely English parliament?
fields.trailText: With the House of Commons losing many of its powers since devolution, how long until it becomes a purely English parliament?
fields.body:
The Guardian's monarchy debate has opened up a raft of wider constitutional questions, including not just the role of the monarchy but also the role of parliament in the light of devolution . How much is Westminster still the parliament for the whole of the UK and how much a parliament for England? Our new book, The State and the Nations, exposes for the first time the extent to which Westminster already operates as an English parliament, and its potential to develop this role further.

Post- devolution , some have suggested that there should be a separate English parliament to match the Scottish parliament and the Welsh and Northern Ireland assemblies. This is not a realistic option. Those who demand one are in effect demanding a full-blown federation, in which the four historic nations would form the component parts. But there is no successful federation in the world where one of the parts is greater than around one-third of the whole. England, with four-fifths of the population, would be hugely dominant: even more dominant than Prussia in the old Germany. Nor would it meet the demands for representation coming from the English regions: to them, an English parliament looks like another form of London dominance.

Nor is there any strong public demand: the Campaign for an English Parliament has attracted little public following during its weekly vigils in Parliament Square. When asked in last year's British Social Attitudes survey, 62% of the English said it would be best for England to be governed as it is now, with laws made by the UK parliament, while only 18% said it would be best for England to have its own parliament. And, intriguingly, 30% said they viewed the Houses of Parliament as English, or more English than British: while 27% viewed parliament as equally English and British.

The English may have been uttering a greater constitutional truth than they knew. For buried within Westminster is an English parliament which devolution is beginning to disclose. Before devolution we had a three-in-one parliament, and it was clear when Westminster was operating as the legislature for Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. Post- devolution we are developing a four-in-one parliament, and it will need to become clearer when Westminster is operating in English mode. English business is transacted through the work of the select committees through the new standing committee on regional affairs (which will be open only to English MPs) through questions to ministers on English matters through Westminster Hall, which provides a further forum for English debates and through English legislation.

At present, this English business is mixed up with other business. But if we just take the scrutiny function of Westminster, we can see how parliament is developing a sharper territorial focus. Among the select committees we have found four committees whose membership consists solely of English MPs. Three are on subjects you would expect - education and employment, health, and home affairs - matters in which Scottish, Welsh and Northern Ireland MPs no longer have an interest, because these subjects are now largely devolved. And if we look at the government departments which those select committees scrutinise, we find that their ministers are all MPs from English constituencies. Eight Whitehall home departments are now "English" ministries, and the only departments with ministers from Scotland and Wales (apart from the Scottish and Welsh Offices) are the all-UK departments: the Treasury, Foreign Office, DfID, Social Security, DTI. In terms of English business, the main committees whose work included a significant English element are health, education and employment, environment, transport and the regions, and home affairs.

Scotland, Wales and North ern Ireland not only have their select committees each also has a grand committee consisting of all the MPs for the territory. Up to now there has been no English equivalent to the territorial grand committees. But in April the House of Commons agreed to revive the standing committee on regional affairs, consisting of 13 members from English constituencies, with power to consider "any matter relating to regional affairs in England". Not a big or powerful committee but it would be the first English committee. And Margaret Beckett has indicated that the committee could expand its role if pressure for English forums at Westminster grows.

I do not want to over-state these developments. What our book describes is a series of tentative and sometimes unwitting steps in which Westminster is responding to devolution . There has been no strong lead from the gov ernment, and no clear sense of Westminster's new role. The clearest vision so far has come from the Wakeham commission on Lords reform , which proposed that a reformed House of Lords could represent the nations and regions of the UK, like the second chamber in federal systems. If further reform of the Lords takes place on these lines, the Lords could claim to be the chamber representing the nations of the UK, including elected members from the regions of England. We would have created a quasi-federal parliament, with an English parliament nestling within it but we dare not yet speak its name.

 Robert Hazell is director of the Constitution Unit, School of Public Policy, University College, London. The State and the Nations: The First Year of Devolution in the UK, is published by Imprint Academic, £14.95.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Deirdre
fields.trailText: When you're in Singapore try not to spend all your time in the city - the countryside is absolutely spectacular and hardly ever mentioned for some reason. Also, definitely visit the Night Safari - it is a wonderful experience.
fields.body:
When you're changing money in Bali, be really careful; each time my husband and I changed money we were short changed by about £20. Visit Ubud if you want a bit of culture - the art and crafts and restaurants are great (and cheap) - and make sure you visit the monkey forest!

If you're staying for longer than a night in Bangkok, I recommend forking out a bit more cash to stay in a decent place - it's extremely hot and humid and you will definitely need air conditioning if you want to sleep - and stay as near to the centre as you can as you won't be able to get around easily! The traffic is bad, the transport iffy (apart from the sky train which is brilliant and cheap) and you can't walk any where for too long because of the humidity - you will exhaust yourself. Try to stay somewhere near the skytrain stations as this is the most convenient way to travel. However, you'll have to take a tuk-tuk at night because it's such a laugh!

When you're in Singapore - (our honeymoon last year followed almost exactly the same itinerary as yours!) - try not to spend all your time in the city - the countryside is absolutely spectacular and hardly ever mentioned for some reason. Also, definitely visit the Night Safari - it is a wonderful experience.

webTitle: Where did it all go wrong, Winona?

fields.headline: Where did it all go wrong, Winona?
fields.standfirst: In the late 1980s, she was a star in the making. Now Winona Ryder is taking too many wrong turns. Michael Atkinson reports
fields.trailText: In the late 1980s, she was a star in the making. Now Winona Ryder is taking too many wrong turns.
fields.body:
Whatever happened to Winona Ryder? Once the great doe-eyed hope of the post-Brat generation in Hollywood, Ryder has slowly receded into one of the least crucial stars still claiming marquee status. Her slip into inconsequentiality has occurred almost without notice. The past four years have seen one notable vehicle, 1999's Girl, Interrupted, which proved to be more of a boon to Angelina Jolie's career than Ryder's. In the past 12 months, Ryder's output has been the lamentable satanic thriller Lost Souls and the dreary May-September weepie Autumn in New York, both virtually unwatchable and both box-office flops in America. If there ever was a time when people went to and talked about Winona Ryder movies, that time has passed.

Her rise to fame seem destined: born with the innocent-decadent visage of a Sade heroine, an all-American sense of everyday modesty, and a voice that cracked in all the wrong places, Ryder was a natural in a time when Michelle Pfeiffer was still dewy and Tom Hanks was still funny. Hitting screens at about the same time as River Phoenix, Michael J Fox, Julia Roberts and John Cusack, Ryder was immediately a hot property. She was confirmed as a teen icon both by Tim Burton's Beetlejuice, and Michael Lehmann's Heathers in 1988, and Jim McBride's Great Balls of Fire the following year. In the latter movie, she seemed the only possible choice to play Jerry Lee Lewis's child bride, opposite Dennis Quaid. From there, she was a name people knew, unforgettable in Tim Burton's 1990 Edward Scissorhands despite a preposterous blonde wig, and in Francis Ford Coppola's Bram Stoker's Dracula in 1992. She took her place amiably in Jim Jarmusch's 1991 ensemble piece Night on Earth (breathing the same air as Cassavetes legend Gena Rowlands), but you knew Ryder was a heavyweight when she co-starred in precious flops - Welcome Home, Roxy Carmichael, Mermaids and The House of the Spirits - that never dimmed her fire.

We sympathised with the Jewish starlet from the very beginning. We wanted her characters to win love and happiness nearly as much as we wanted little Montana-born Winona Horowitz to get all the breaks and stay a star. It helps that when she did attain stardom, she didn't abuse it. Rather, she used it to explore her classic-lit interests: to land the plum role in Martin Scorsese's 1993 The Age of Innocence (and with it an Oscar nomination), and to lead the way in Gillian Armstrong's Little Women. Though she doesn't have a producer's credit, Ryder enlisted most of that film's main cast and crew. She cast Christian Bale as Laurie, raising his profile from bit-part actor to major Hollywood player.

But fortunes fall with dizzying speed in Tinseltown, just as often as they linger for decades with no visible means of support. The kind of career you get seems to be largely a sum of blind chance and unholy factors. There are many simple considerations that we, the public, rarely imagine to be elements in the stardom equation. Some stars go crazy, some disappear because of drug addiction (James Caan most famously), some quit to have families or pursue origami or write novels. Some, like William Hurt in the late 1980s dwindle and vanish simply because the actor "doesn't like being a movie star". Hurt went to Europe to escape Hollywood's tail-wagging mentality.

As consumers of stardom, we assume that access to the inner sanctum is some sort of ultimate goal, and that with stardom comes unlimited, unreasonable bliss. But if we squint through the layers of lacquer the public relations industry has applied over the years, it's easy to see that being a Hollywood god or goddess can be misery incarnate. Robert Downey Jr knows the LA penal system intimately for a reason - being rich and famous can often mean being wretched and lost. Not that we should feel sorry for any of them - they could just leave and live normal lives for a while.

Acting careers can also be subject to another phantom force: the competence, incompetence, intelligence, brainlessness, sanity and/or ingrown madness of agents. What may look to the outside world like an actor's bad choice or decline may in fact be the work of a cackhanded agent. It's clear that, for example, Ashley Judd desperately needs the extremely smart and forceful agent that Tobey Maguire clearly has. And so on.

So, what's the deal with Winona? It's impossible to know for sure, but there are visible potholes in her career track. Everything seemed to be going smoothly in 1994 with Little Women and Reality Bites, both projects reflecting a knack Ryder has seemed to have lost since: surrounding herself with superb and underused talent. The next year's How to Make an American Quilt was overlooked as a well-meant, shame-free career blip, but 1996's Boys was not: that miserable boys school drama marked the point at which Ryder's star began to wane. After Little Women, there was the unspoken and somewhat correct belief that Ryder picked and nurtured her own projects; unlike, say, Cameron Diaz, Ryder gets blamed if her films bomb, so she began to play safe by taking third leads, such as the horny bitch in Nicholas Hytner's The Crucible in 1996 and the mousy android in Jean-Pierre Jeunet's Alien Resurrection the following year, the first as perfect a choice for CV-constructing as the second was utterly pointless. Was it necessary to play second banana to Sigourney Weaver's aging intergalactic Mother Courage? It's a role clearly made for someone starting out, not an established name.

Ryder disappeared for a couple of years, then resurfaced in another carefully shepherded project, Girl, Interrupted, which this time bore an official Ryder producer credit. For some, that tame girls-in- the-nut-house movie was worth the wait, and Ryder's reputation was untainted. But it did little to restore her earlier promise. Autumn in New York (as yet unreleased in the UK) and Lost Souls were evidently bids to regain visibility. All that's been visible, however, is Ryder's enormous, age-saddened eyes staring out at us from posters of movies no one wants to see.

Don't underestimate her recent weight loss and waif routine as she approaches 30. In any case, Ryder's slow fade to black will only get worse: this year, besides a mere cameo in Simone, the new Andrew (The Truman Show) Niccol film about a digitally created film star, she's co-starring with Andy Garcia in Just to Be Together, the new film by a stroke-impaired 88-year-old Michelangelo Antonioni. Hardly a sharp career move. Even in Antonioni's heyday, an American star looking for prestige in Euro art-films was an American star at the end of his or her tether. Today, it's a detour so far off the comeback trail that Ryder may never find her way back to civilisation.

 Lost Souls is released on January 12.

webTitle: Number of boys held on remand doubles

fields.headline: Number of boys held on remand doubles
fields.trailText: More than 1,000 boys aged 15 and 16 have been remanded in custody in the past eight months despite a 10-year-old government pledge, enshrined in legislation, to end the much-criticised practice.
fields.body:
More than 1,000 boys aged 15 and 16 have been remanded in custody in the past eight months despite a 10-year-old government pledge, enshrined in legislation, to end the much-criticised practice.

Some 1,068 unconvicted boys under 17 were remanded to young offenders' institutions between April and November, more than double the 440 who were held on remand in 1992 when the practice was supposed to be phased out. About 300 of those held this year were aged just 15 and were remanded for an average of six weeks while waiting for their cases to come to court.

The practice of sending teenage girls to youth prisons to await trial was abolished in the early 1980s.

There has been concern for more than 20 years about the use of custody for such young boys, triggered by a series of scandals in young offender jails involving persistent bullying and teenage suicides.

The appalling conditions in which some unconvicted teenagers are held were highlighted recently by Sir David Ramsbotham, the chief inspector of prisons, in his reports on Feltham and Portland young offender institutions and by the lord chief justice, Lord Woolf's criticism last month of the "corrosive" atmosphere inside some youth jails.

The latest Home Office figures show that a pledge to phase out the use of custody for such teenagers, first made by the Conservative government in 1991 and repeated by every successive home secretary, has been left on the shelf. The promise was enshrined in the 1991 Criminal Justice Act which said that unless the boy was charged with a serious violent or sexual offence, or had a history of absconding, they should be held in local authority secure units. Ministers hoped to build extra units to ensure the practice was abolished by 1996. There are only 441 places in local authority secure units and the National Association of Probation Officers claims that their expansion has not been a priority for successive ministers.

But new figures obtained by Napo show that far from ending the scandal it is now twice as bad. Previous studies have shown that about 30% of those remanded in custody are held for serious violent offences such as robbery or for being involved in sex crimes. Most have been charged with burglary, stealing cars or other types of theft.

A recent study by the youth justice board has also shown there is wide inconsistency between magistrates' benches over their use of custody for teenage offenders.

Harry Fletcher, assistant general secretary of the probation union, said: "Successive governments' records on remanding 15 and 16 year olds to prison custody is quite scandalous. It is now 10 years since the initial pledge was given to end the practice. The conditions are wholly unacceptable. Successive prison inspectorate reports have condemned the conditions in young offenders' institutions as being conducive to bullying, self injury and further crime. Ending the practice must be a priority after the next election."

webTitle: Why didn't they just publish and be damned?

fields.headline: Why didn't they just publish and be damned?
fields.standfirst: Paul Hamlyn's donation to Labour should never have caused such a fuss
fields.trailText:
So, it ended more as a tale of naivety than knavery, another classic lesson for a
         political party in how not to conduct its affairs. After three days of procrastination,
         Labour yesterday finally identified its latest pounds 2m donor. The truth - Lord
         Hamlyn, publisher, philanthropist and long-time Labour supporter - was far less
         painful than the speculation. So why did they try to hide it? Why did they try to
         slip this one in before the deadline of February 16, after which the identity and
         sum of all large gifts will have to be declared?
fields.body:
So, it ended more as a tale of naivety than knavery, another classic lesson for a political party in how not to conduct its affairs. After three days of procrastination, Labour yesterday finally identified its latest pounds 2m donor. The truth - Lord Hamlyn, publisher, philanthropist and long-time Labour supporter - was far less painful than the speculation. So why did they try to hide it? Why did they try to slip this one in before the deadline of February 16, after which the identity and sum of all large gifts will have to be declared?

It falls into that very human impulse - getting away with it, while breaking no rules. Thousands of people do it all the time - it's the difference between tax avoidance and tax evasion. Paul Hamlyn has certainly done nothing wrong. He thinks his beneficence is helping democracy. He thought, especially in the light of a serious illness, that he was entitled to anonymity. His friends in the party should have told him this was no longer possible.

The problem is expectation. After years of Tory sleaze, this Labour government was expected to be more ethical and more transparent. This is what the prime minister said in August 1997, issuing a new code of conduct for ministers: "We are all here to serve, and we must all serve honestly, and in the interests of those who gave us our positions of trust." Three months later the Bernie Ecclestone and the formula one tobacco saga was revealed.

It is harder to be open when you're running short of money - or when you think you're running short of money. At Millbank Tower and at the Tories' Smith Square HQ, they have been trying to devise ever more intricate ways of balancing the books. Long before they lost power, the Conservatives were finding it harder to convince blue chip companies there was anything to be gained from opening their coffers. Hence the reliance on Michael Ashcroft and a few other individuals. Tony Blair's complicated relationship with the trade unions has made life harder for Millbank's money-gatherers. Union donations are coming in again for the election, but not as quickly or as generously as the party would like. New Labour's wooing of the City in the mid-90s still leaves a number of generously-minded big companies, but fewer than before. Hence, the reliance on Lord Sainsbury and a few other individuals.

A year ago, Labour came clean with David Sainsbury 's pounds 2m, and that story died within a day. Part of the reason for acting so promptly was the knowledge - in the light of the Ecclestone revelations - that Millbank is a leaky place. "Anyone who thinks that we could carry another pounds 2m donation all the way to the election without it getting out is guilty of gross naivety," said one minister.

It was Tony Blair who asked Lord Neill's committee on standards in public life to investigate the funding of political parties. John Major had refused to do this. The committee's report of October 1998 was largely accepted by the government, and it is this legislation which comes into effect in six weeks time. Three measures stand out - the formation of an electoral commission, a limit of pounds 20m per party in election spending, and the requirement that the names and amounts of all donations over pounds 5,000 be declared.

Laudable though the changes are, they won't be enough. In the long-term, state funding will be the only option. The committee looked at state funding in a number of countries, concluding that although the issue is "finely balanced", it thought best to hold off. In their submission to the committee, the Liberal Democrats came up with a scheme - artfully designed to help medium-sized parties - in which any party with more than 5% of the vote would get pounds 2m, with a further pounds 10m distributed between the parties in proportion to the national vote.

The Tories and Labour opposed the idea of state funding. But now in Down ing Street and at Millbank there are signs of change. Several key figures who were opposed to state funding are now wavering. Intriguingly, Labour's general secretary, Margaret McDonagh - no great advocate of constitutional reform - is now suggesting there is a "persuasive argument for state funding of political parties". Tony Blair is said to be, "on balance against, but persuadable".

He can be persuaded. One of the arguments against state funding is that it divorces politics from voters - no more community tombolas, no more effort to bring new members on board. Yet, apart from a blip before the last election, membership is on a steady downward spiral. The reasons for people deserting political parties are many, but not being able to give money is hardly one of them. In any case, small contributions would not necessarily have to be banned. Schemes could be devised allowing parties to top up the money they get from the state with membership dues, or by other local means. There could be an element of matching funding - as long as the private money was openly declared. There could be extra money for research, or as in Germany for party-based think tanks.

As for the biggest objection - that taxpayers' money should not go to political activity - it would surely be less invidious than seeing the major parties dependent on the largesse of a few people. If these individuals are motivated purely by philanthropy, let them donate to the thousands of charities whose needs are greater than a political party rustling up the cash for another billboard advert. When Lord Hamlyn said in his statement: "Our democracy depends on vibrant political parties and for years the Conservatives had a virtual monopoly on large donations from individuals", he was missing the point. Labour supporters did not want their party to emulate the Tories.

One of Tony Blair's unique selling points in 1997 was his pledge to reinvent politics. That required constitutional and behavioural change. Progress, to put it charitably, has been patchy. Now he is letting it be known that too much of the first term's agenda was devoted to the constitution the second term will all be about public service delivery. Yet the two are linked. The government expresses constant frustration that its achievements in, say, education and employment, are not appreciated enough. They blame that on the media. Maybe, instead, they should look inwards, and ask themselves why the government's credibility ratings, in opinion polls, are not as high as they might be.

Voters are more likely to believe a claim by a minister, on any issue, if they feel the government to be fundamentally honest. If anything is to be learned from this maladroit episode it is that open politics and successful politics are one and the same thing.

webTitle: Shrinking Westminster

fields.headline: Shrinking Westminster
fields.standfirst:
With the House of Commons losing many of its powers
        since devolution, how long until it becomes a purely
        English parliament?
fields.trailText:
The Guardian's monarchy debate has opened up a raft of wider
        constitutional questions, including not just the role of the monarchy but
        also the role of parliament in the light of devolution. How much is
        Westminster still the parliament for the whole of the UK and how much a
        parliament for England? Our new book, The State and the Nations,
        exposes for the first time the extent to which Westminster already
        operates as an English parliament, and its potential to develop this role
        further.
fields.body:
The Guardian's monarchy debate has opened up a raft of wider constitutional questions, including not just the role of the monarchy but also the role of parliament in the light of devolution. How much is Westminster still the parliament for the whole of the UK and how much a parliament for England? Our new book, The State and the Nations, exposes for the first time the extent to which Westminster already operates as an English parliament, and its potential to develop this role further.

Post-devolution, some have suggested that there should be a separate English parliament to match the Scottish parliament and the Welsh and Northern Ireland assemblies. This is not a realistic option. Those who demand one are in effect demanding a full-blown federation, in which the four historic nations would form the component parts. But there is no successful federation in the world where one of the parts is greater than around one-third of the whole. England, with four-fifths of the population, would be hugely dominant: even more dominant than Prussia in the old Germany. Nor would it meet the demands for representation coming from the English regions: to them, an English parliament looks like another form of London dominance.

Nor is there any strong public demand: the Campaign for an English Parliament has attracted little public following during its weekly vigils in Parliament Square. When asked in last year's British Social Attitudes survey, 62% of the English said it would be best for England to be governed as it is now, with laws made by the UK parliament, while only 18% said it would be best for England to have its own parliament. And, intriguingly, 30% said they viewed the Houses of Parliament as English, or more English than British: while 27% viewed parliament as equally English and British.

The English may have been uttering a greater constitutional truth than they knew. For buried within Westminster is an English parliament which devolution is beginning to disclose. Before devolution we had a three-in-one parliament, and it was clear when Westminster was operating as the legislature for Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. Post-devolution we are developing a four-in-one parliament, and it will need to become clearer when Westminster is operating in English mode. English business is transacted through the work of the select committees through the new standing committee on regional affairs (which will be open only to English MPs) through questions to ministers on English matters through Westminster Hall, which provides a further forum for English debates and through English legislation.

At present, this English business is mixed up with other business. But if we just take the scrutiny function of Westminster, we can see how parliament is developing a sharper territorial focus. Among the select committees we have found four committees whose membership consists solely of English MPs. Three are on subjects you would expect - education and employment, health, and home affairs - matters in which Scottish, Welsh and Northern Ireland MPs no longer have an interest, because these subjects are now largely devolved. And if we look at the government departments which those select committees scrutinise, we find that their ministers are all MPs from English constituencies. Eight Whitehall home departments are now "English" ministries, and the only departments with ministers from Scotland and Wales (apart from the Scottish and Welsh Offices) are the all-UK departments: the Treasury, Foreign Office, DfID, Social Security, DTI. In terms of English business, the main committees whose work included a significant English element are health, education and employment, environment, transport and the regions, and home affairs.

Scotland, Wales and North ern Ireland not only have their select committees each also has a grand committee consisting of all the MPs for the territory. Up to now there has been no English equivalent to the territorial grand committees. But in April the House of Commons agreed to revive the standing committee on regional affairs, consisting of 13 members from English constituencies, with power to consider "any matter relating to regional affairs in England". Not a big or powerful committee but it would be the first English committee. And Margaret Beckett has indicated that the committee could expand its role if pressure for English forums at Westminster grows.

I do not want to over-state these developments. What our book describes is a series of tentative and sometimes unwitting steps in which Westminster is responding to devolution. There has been no strong lead from the gov ernment, and no clear sense of Westminster's new role. The clearest vision so far has come from the Wakeham commission on Lords reform, which proposed that a reformed House of Lords could represent the nations and regions of the UK, like the second chamber in federal systems. If further reform of the Lords takes place on these lines, the Lords could claim to be the chamber representing the nations of the UK, including elected members from the regions of England. We would have created a quasi-federal parliament, with an English parliament nestling within it but we dare not yet speak its name.

Robert Hazell is director of the Constitution Unit, School of Public Policy, University College, London. The State and the Nations: The First Year of Devolution in the UK, is published by Imprint Academic, pounds 14.95.

webTitle: Intel inside the portable gadget market

fields.headline: Intel inside the portable gadget market
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Intel launched its portable audio player yesterday, marking a strategic departure for the world's largest semiconductor manufacturer. Pocket Concert is expected to be the first of several consumer products from the company.
fields.body:
Intel launched its portable audio player yesterday, marking a strategic departure for the world's largest semiconductor manufacturer. Pocket Concert is expected to be the first of several consumer products from the company.

Craig Barrett, Intel's chief executive, is due to demonstrate two more gadgets this week at his first keynote address at a consumer electronics trade show in Las Vegas.

Several Wall Street analysts yesterday welcomed the strategy as a way of mitigating the impact of a slowing personal computer market. Shares in Intel rose 3%, or almost $1, yesterday morning.

The shares have more than halved in the last three months as a series of profits warnings focused attention on weakening demand for personal computers around the world.

Gartner Dataquest is among several research groups to have lowered its revenues estimates for the semiconductor sector this year from 27% to the low 20s.

Other evidence of slowing demand came when Dell and Compaq, computer manufacturers which account for about a quarter of Intel's sales, issued profits warnings towards the end of last year.

Intel faces an uphill battle in the highly competitive market for portable devices in the US. In launching Pocket Concert, Don Whiteside, general manager of the company's connected products division, said the use of Intel technology in portable music devices would "provide consumers with a trusted brand option and an enhanced audio experience". The company also hopes to increase the use of personal computers through the adoption of more portable devices which need material to be downloaded to them.

Last year, Intel increased its advertising to raise awareness of its brand using its "Intel Inside" slogan. The push into the consumer electronics market, which is expected to include an instant messaging and email device and a wireless mini-laptop, is an attempt to capitalise on this increased consumer awareness.

The new products, expected to be launched this year, have been called a ChatPad and WebTablet.

The Pocket Concert, which has 128 megabytes of memory, will provide up to four hours of music and more than 20 hours of spoken-word audio. It will also have an FM radio. With an accessory kit, the device is expected to cost $349.99 (about £240).

webTitle: Malcolm  Dean: Cheques and balances

fields.headline: Cheques and balances
fields.trailText: Malcolm Dean: Have you written your cheque yet? There are only two more days to go in the charity world's high season of giving
fields.body:
Have you written your cheque yet? There are only two more days to go in the charity world's high season of giving. Last Christmas, coinciding with the new millennium, saw a flurry of new era campaigns - Children's Promise seeking the final hour of earnings; five smaller charities seeking the first cheque of 2000; NSPCC's Full Stop appeal.

This Christmas was preceded by the row over the NSPCC's spending priorities - just 37% of its £75m budget going on children's services, compared to 46% on fundraising, publicity, policy and public education. The debate which its annual report raised was never properly resolved.

The initial reaction from the NSPCC was naive. Neil Hunt, director of child protection, said he did not understand the criticism. Later, Mary Marsh, the new chief executive, more intelligently pointed to the charity's long history of campaigning. Certainly there is still a lot to campaign about - hundreds of thousands of children suffering physical, emotional or sexual abuse. But from the start there were three things wrong with the NSPCC's Full Stop campaign.

First was its unobtainable goal. Cruelty to children is never going to be ended. It is as old as man. Given its complex causes - social, cultural, economic, pathological - it would be an impossible task for a government, let alone a charity. Better control, yes; but eradication, no. As disease eradication has demonstrated, setting unachievable goals only sets back achievable control projects.

Second was the hype. Like earlier NSPCC campaigns, the facts were distorted to add drama to the appeal. Its "stranger danger" warnings only fanned anxieties in parents who were already over-protective. Contrary to the message, there has been a steep drop in child murders. A child under four has a one in a million chance of being killed by a stranger - and children five to 15 even less chance.

The third thing wrong was the confusion it caused with the other big children's appeal, the Children's Promise, in which the NSPCC was already participating, along with six other charities.

What emerges are three lessons. First, more transparency by charities on how donations are spent is a must. Second, marketing departments should be kept under firmer control; the NSPCC's exaggerations have become notorious - and counter productive. Third, we need more systematic auditing of accounts. The Directory of Social Change demonstrated over a year ago what could be done - and how far short the Charity Commission's monitoring fell. Average fundraising costs 20% of receipts, but some charity campaigns cost over 80%. Will the Charity Commission please step in?

webTitle: Commuter trains in near-collision

fields.headline: Commuter trains in near-collision
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack today began an investigation into a near-collision between two commuter trains, as a rail chief warned it could be May before services return to normal.
fields.body:
Railtrack today began an investigation into a near-collision between two commuter trains, as a rail chief warned it could be May before services return to normal.

Last night's near-collision involved two Sussex-bound Connex South Central trains at Victoria station in central London.

As a signal failure had led to signals at Victoria remaining red, one of the trains was allowed through a red light by a signalman.

The other train departed without permission and only prompt action by the signalman, who cut the power to both trains, prevented a collision.

The two trains finished only feet from each other and Railtrack and Connex launched an immediate inquiry.

As Railtrack strove to meet the 18 January deadline set by the rail regulator, Tom Winsor, for producing a route by route recovery plan for the railways, a passenger group said that public confidence in the railways had sunk to "probably its lowest point ever".

webTitle: BBC Worldwide Christmas sales reach £20m

fields.headline: BBC Worldwide Christmas sales reach £20m
fields.trailText: 5.30pm: Pop chart-topper Bob the Builder helped BBC Worldwide to its best-ever Christmas with merchandising sales worth £20m, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Pop chart-topper Bob the Builder helped BBC Worldwide to its best-ever Christmas, with total merchandising sales of around £20m.

Other bestsellers for the BBC's commercial arm included merchandising for another hit children's show, The Tweenies, and videos for anarchic comedy League of Gentlemen.

BBC books alone accounted for an estimated £10m in sales, led by top-selling autobiographies by Terry Wogan and Sir Steve Redgrave.

Total sales for BBC Worldwide over Christmas are understood to be worth around £20m.

Bob the Builder's successes included CD-Roms and computer games and his Can We Fix It? single, which was the best-seller of 2000 as well as the Christmas number one.

The Tweenies similarly notched up a big pop hit with their single, which spent eight weeks in the top 10, as well as an educational CD-Rom, a Christmas video and talking figures.

A 'buy one, get one free' offer meant 1m Only Fools and Horses videos were sold to retailers, although figures for how many were snapped up by fans are not available.

Rupert Gavin, BBC Worldwide chief executive, said: "It's wonderful to see how popular BBC products are and, because we reinvest the profits in BBC programmes, it's a wonderful boost for the licence payer as well."

webTitle: Young carers are shameful reminder of system's failings

fields.headline: Young carers are shameful reminder of system's failings
fields.standfirst: Rather than supporting young carers, politicians should find ways to provide better services for disabled parents
fields.trailText: Rather than supporting young carers, politicians should find ways to provide better services for disabled parents, says Michele Wates
fields.body:
The past 10 years have seen the mushrooming of a veritable service industry around providing support for young carers. Hundreds of thousands of pounds have been invested in projects, clubs, research groups and initiatives spearheaded by children's charities.

The subject attracts constant media attention. Politicians delight in telling us how much they are doing to help young carers, oblivious to the fact that the fact that so many young people are trapped in inappropriate family roles is shameful evidence of the failure to provide appropriate services to disabled people.

Further evidence is provided by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation's research on poverty and social exclusion, published in September 2000, which shows that 24% of children living in poverty have parents who are ill or disabled.

The development of services to young carers has to an extent happened in place of recognising the rights and service entitlement of disabled adults in their role as parents. This has led to skewed development of policy and practice.

In some cases, the only way for disabled parents to secure support has been by having their children identify themselves as young carers, even though this was the very outcome that the parents were seeking to avoid.

The age at which people can apply for direct payments in respect of the carers' role has been reduced to 16. This is a worrying development in the light of research showing the adverse long-term effects upon young people of being caught in the role of young carer.

Why have disabled adults' parenting support needs been consistently and persistently overlooked? Perhaps it's because the idea of disabled people as parents is too much of a challenge to assumptions about the vulnerability of disabled people.

In reality, many of the skills disabled people acquire in the course of dealing with inaccessible environments, unwelcoming attitudes and social structures that take little account of their needs, make disabled people particularly well suited to the task of parenting. Adaptability, patience and problem solving capacity are all qualities that are recognised features of competent parenting.

Rather than seeing this, officialdom has a predisposition to regard the children of disabled people as "in need" or "at risk". The interests of the parents are seen as being potentially at odds with those of their children.

It has been understood for a long time by governments and in the child support sector that children's needs and rights are best met within the context of the family and that the best way to ensure this is by supporting parents to fulfil their responsibilities. This must apply to disabled parents the same as to any others. The needs of children are served when disabled adults are supported in carrying out their parenting responsibilities.

The rights of disabled adults to found families and the rights of children to live in families that provide for their needs as children are compatible with each other and both are upheld by the Human Rights Act.

Disabled parents' organisations based at the new national centre for disabled parents are working with service providers and voluntary organisations to develop services that are flexible enough to support family lifestyles, that strengthen rather than undermine the parenting role, that are available when needed and not when things have reached crisis point and that do not involve young people in taking on inappropriate care roles.

 Michele Wates is vice-chairwoman of the Disabled Parents Network

Feedback: how can we improve services for disabled parents and their children? Please send your comments to editor@societytheguardian.com

webTitle: Councils may lose housing duties under Tory plan

fields.headline: Councils may lose housing duties under Tory plan
fields.trailText: Underperforming councils could be stripped of their housing benefit responsibilities under a future Conservative government in a bid to raise the performance of the troubled system.
fields.body:
Underperforming councils could be stripped of their housing benefit responsibilities under a future Conservative government in a bid to raise the performance of the troubled system.

The central benefits agency will take over when council services fall below as yet undecided minimum service standards.

Shadow social security minister David Willetts announced the move today as part of a four-point plan to tighten up the benefit - including proposals for a cash lump sum to be paid to families to encourage them to move to smaller accommodation if appropriate.

Social security secretary Alistair Darling last month claimed some councils were "failing miserably" on housing benefit, creating backlogs and delays in the system. He threatened to send in "action teams" to tackle problems in the worst authorities, and promised to streamline the system to make it easier for councils to administer.

Mr Willetts said Labour had introduced 85 new regulations covering housing benefit since 1997.

"After nearly a decade of steady decline the number of homeless families is now rising again," Mr Willetts told a Westminster news conference.

"A major reason for this is that the housing benefit system is in deep crisis, and that is because Labour have been introducing new housing benefit rules at the rate of one a fortnight."

The Tory proposals involve:

 Laying down minimum standards for the administration of benefit
 Reducing the burden of regulation
 Allowing claimants to keep part of any savings that result from a move into more appropriate accommodation.

That would save £425m a year by 2003-04, said Mr Willetts, bringing total savings identified by his party on the social security budget to £2.5bn by then.

Labour's proposals for improving housing benefit also include:

 Long-term fundamental reform of the system
 Simplifying rules to make it faster and easier to claim housing benefit
 Developing a new process for claiming the benefit to cut down on red tape.

webTitle: WH Smith abandons distribution plans

fields.headline: WH Smith abandons distribution plans
fields.standfirst: Jan 2: Compromise solution in WHS row
fields.trailText:
5pm: WH Smith has announced it is backing out of its national distribution plans, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Jan 2: Compromise solution in WHS distribution row
fields.body:
WH Smith has announced it is backing out of its national distribution plans, adopting an "industry solution" for magazine and newspaper distribution.

The settlement ends months of high-profile wrangling between the newsagent, distributors and publishers.

Publishers had accused WH Smith bosses of "bully-boy" tactics amid fears that the plans could put small retailers out of business and damage copy sales.

In a statement today, WH Smith spelt out an eight-point plan to be adopted by the industry.

Its proposals follow many of the recommendations put forward in the Blueprint solution suggested last year by industry groups the Newspaper Publishers Association and the Periodical Publishers Association.

The plan includes both a commitment to keep the existing distribution networks as well as a promise to safeguard the interests of small retailers.

The proposed central publications unit recommended in the plan is also to get the go-ahead.

And as a concession to WH Smith, retailers will get a beefed up role in newspaper and magazine supply-chain management.

Nevertheless, the decision represents a climbdown for WH Smith.

A spokeswoman for the PPA said: "We're delighted that WH Smith has agreed to work with the industry to create a consensual solution."

As part of the deal, Associated Newspapers, which had given notice on its supply contract with WH Smith's wholesale arm WH Smith news, has withdrawn its notice to end the deal.

WH Smith has agreed to suspend its national distribution programme by January 27.

webTitle: Obituary: George Carman

fields.headline: George Carman
fields.standfirst: The most celebrated barrister of his generation, he enjoyed matchless success across all branches of the law
fields.trailText: The most celebrated barrister of his generation, he enjoyed matchless success across all branches of the law.
fields.body:
When George Carman, who has died aged 71, announced last August that he was retiring from the bar because of ill health, his home in Wimbledon was immediately besieged by the press. Carman, visibly sick and walking with difficulty, granted all an audience. He claimed to dislike the limelight, but he knew he was a star, and he enjoyed the fame that a string of sensational cases in the last 20 years of his career gave him.

Carman's case list was matchless: Jeremy Thorpe, the spy Geoffrey Prime, the Sun against Gillian Taylforth, Elton John, Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman, Ken Dodd on charges of tax evasion, Imran Khan against Ian Botham, the Guardian against Jonathan Aitken, Mohamed Al Fayed against Neil Hamilton. He said that other QCs, in tax and shipping for example, were equally adept, but the difference was that his cases were the stuff of life, each one an unmissable piece of theatre.

He knew that was where his interest and his talent lay. "I would not like to practise in areas of the law remote from the human condition and the human problem," he once said. His view of cases was psychologically based: he sought to persuade his clients to "remove their mental veils", and a key tactic was to observe each member of the jury and pick out individuals to whom he could appeal.

Carman was frequently criticised for character assassination in court - one victim, Jani Allan, whose sex life was held up to universal derision - told him that "whatever award is given for libel, being cross-examined by you would not make it enough money". But he had no regrets about the way lives withered in the face of his attacks. "That's a matter of judgment for people who decide to involve themselves in the luxury of litigation," he said brusquely.

There were also dark suggestions of skulduggery concerning the way in which last-minute pieces of evidence would suddenly appear. Carman put it down to good fortune. "A lot of things turned up by chance. The Jani Allan diary [detailing her sex life] turned up in the course of the case; it wasn't as if I kept it back. If we'd had it, we would have had to disclose it. Equally, with the Gillian Taylforth video ['I give good head,' she declaimed to her fellow partygoers while suggestively brandishing a sausage], two people arrived at a newspaper in the middle of the case."

In the Taylforth case, in 1994, Carman successfully defended the Sun's allegation that the EastEnders actress had had oral sex with her fiancé Geoff Knights in a Range Rover on a slipway off the A1. The case had everything: soap opera, sex and the plaintiff's delightful explanation that her fiancé had had to loosen his trousers because of an acute attack of pancreatitis. It made Carman a household name and the barrister who everyone wanted on their side in a libel action.

In 1996, the Pakistani cricketer Imran Khan hired Carman to defend him in a libel case brought by England cricket stars Ian Botham and Allan Lamb. The two England players sued Khan after he said that illegal ball-tampering was common among fast bowlers, and over a newspaper article in which he allegedly accused them of racism. Again, Carman won the day.

The following year, he represented the Guardian against Jonathan Aitken, who had sued the paper over allegations of improper contacts with middle eastern arms dealers. Aitken's case collapsed following another of Carman's trademark 11th-hour revelations. "The records of his wife and daughter's air trip to Switzerland emerged in the course of the case. We didn't have them at the start. We didn't know it was coming. More importantly, neither did he."

His last major case was at the end of 1998, when another former Tory minister, Neil Hamilton, failed in his libel battle with Mohamed Al Fayed. By then, however, Carman was already fighting prostate cancer, and showed less sparkle in court than in the cases on which his reputation rests.

Carman became the best-known QC in the country, but he was hardly the barrister that central casting would have chosen; he once said that in a biopic of his life, he would like the foursquare John Thaw to play him. He was 5ft 3in, paunchy, and had a plummy voice that he had manufactured at Oxford, where he studied law after doing national service.

The northern accent of which he divested himself came from his native Blackpool. Both his parents worked in retailing, his father in furniture and his mother selling women's clothes. His mother was ambitious, both for herself and her son, and pushed the young Carman hard. He was educated at Upholland College in Lancashire, a Roman Catholic seminary, and briefly considered becoming a priest, though he later said it was only because he was attracted by the idea of delivering sermons. In any case, he discovered girls.

When he went up to Balliol College, Oxford, the accent had to go. "I made a conscious effort to divest myself of a regional accent as soon as I realised I wanted to go into public life," he later admitted. He also lost his Christian faith at Oxford, and found it difficult to cope with the death of his mother when he was in his 20s.

He practised on the northern circuit and found the early years a struggle. "After five years, I was earning as much as a Manchester bus driver without overtime. I almost left the bar three times," he recalled. But he resented suggestions that his 25 years in the north were merely a preparation for his fame in London. "I wasn't some little country boy who came here," he said. "I'd studied law at Oxford, done my pupillage in London, and built up a successful practice on a great circuit that had produced many great advocates." He became a QC in 1971.

Nevertheless, he accepted that the Jeremy Thorpe case, in which he successfully defended the former Liberal leader against charges of conspiracy to murder the model Norman Scott, was the watershed in his career. It brought him south and put him on the front pages for the first time.

Carman remembered the career-changing moment precisely. "I had met David Napley [Thorpe's solicitor] in the early 70s and worked for him intermittently," he recalled. "He rang me in 1978 to say that Thorpe was probably going to be committed for trial on charges of conspiracy to murder and that he was going to retain me. Thorpe was committed for trial - I heard it on the one o'clock news in Cornwall - and I realised that it would be the greatest professional challenge I had faced, and that it might affect my career. It did. Thorpe was tried in May 1979 and it was a sensation. The case had everything, including the dog Rinka."

Success in the Thorpe case projected Carman into the super-league and, now based in London, a string of headline-grabbing cases cemented his reputation. He defended Geoffrey Prime, the GCHQ spy; a scion of the Vestey family who had beheaded his wife and put her head in the freezer (Carman secured a verdict of "diminished responsibility"); Maria Aitken - the sister of Jonathan - against charges of smuggling cocaine; and Ken Dodd against charges of tax evasion. His reputation as a coiner of bons mots is exaggerated, but here he did produce a memorable line when he declared that "some accountants are comedians, but comedians are never accountants". His brother-in-law was an accountant, so he knew what he was talking about.

Carman was proud of winning Dodd's acquittal, and even prouder of securing the freedom of Dr Leonard Arthur, the paediatrician charged with attempted murder after prescribing "nursing care only" for a Down's syndrome baby. Carman's summing-up was a masterpiece. "He [Arthur] could, like Pontius Pilate, have washed his hands of the matter," Carman told the jury. "He did not, because good doctors do not turn away. Are we to condemn him as a criminal because he helped two people at the time of their greatest need? Are we to condemn a doctor because he cared?"

He prepared his closing speeches carefully, but did not, as critics suggested, practise them in front of a mirror. He had the first three or four sentences and the all-important peroration written down, and delivered them verbatim, but for the middle section he would work from notes to allow for some degree of spontaneity.

Carman is likely to be remembered primarily as a libel barrister, but his remarkable run of successes in criminal cases in the 80s should be given due weight. He described libel as the "last chapter" in his career, and did not make his first serious incursion into the field until the Sonia Sutcliffe case in 1990. Before that, he had done civil cases, personal injury and contract, as well as criminal cases. He was invited to become a judge in Hong Kong in the 1980s, but declined. His excuse then was that his wife was unwell, but he later said that he would have found it hard to keep quiet on the bench, and preferred the "blood and sand of the arena".

Carman married three times, though only listed two of his marriages in Who's Who. When pursued on this point by the Daily Mail, which was attempting to "carmanise" Carman, he said that he had suppressed the details of his first marriage to protect his wife, who he had married very young, and that the general public did not have to submit to the same rules as litigants. Each of his marriages ended in divorce. He is survived by his son Dominic, and four grandchildren.

 George Alfred Carman, barrister, born October 6 1929; died January 2 2001

He was educated at Upholland College in Lancashire, a Roman Catholic seminary, and briefly considered becoming a priest, though he later said it was only because he was attracted by the idea of delivering sermons. In any case, he discovered girls. When he went up to Balliol College, Oxford, the accent had to go. "I made a conscious effort to divest myself of a regional accent as soon as I realised I wanted to go into public life," he later admitted. He also lost his Christian faith at Oxford, and found it difficult to cope with the death of his mother when he was in his 20s. He practised on the northern circuit and found the early years a struggle. "After five years, I was earning as much as a Manchester bus driver without overtime. I almost left the bar three times," he recalled. But he resented suggestions that his 25 years in the north were merely a preparation for his fame in London. "I wasn't some little country boy who came here," he said. "I'd studied law at Oxford, done my pupillage in London, and built up a successful practice on a great circuit that had produced many great advocates." He became a QC in 1971. Nevertheless, he accepted that the Jeremy Thorpe case, in which he successfully defended the former Liberal leader against charges of conspiracy to murder the model Norman Scott, was the watershed in his career. It brought him south and put him on the front pages for the first time. Carman remembered the career-changing moment precisely. "I had met David Napley [Thorpe's solicitor] in the early 70s and worked for him intermittently," he recalled. "He rang me in 1978 to say that Thorpe was probably going to be committed for trial on charges of conspiracy to murder and that he was going to retain me. Thorpe was committed for trial - I heard it on the one o'clock news in Cornwall - and I realised that it would be the greatest professional challenge I had faced, and that it might affect my career. It did. Thorpe was tried in May 1979 and it was a sensation. The case had everything, including the dog Rinka." Success in the Thorpe case projected Carman into the super-league and, now based in London, a string of headline-grabbing cases cemented his reputation. He defended Geoffrey Prime, the GCHQ spy; a scion of the Vestey family who had beheaded his wife and put her head in the freezer (Carman secured a verdict of "diminished responsibility"); Maria Aitken - the sister of Jonathan - against charges of smuggling cocaine; and Ken Dodd against charges of tax evasion. His reputation as a coiner of bons mots is exaggerated, but here he did produce a memorable line when he declared that "some accountants are comedians, but comedians are never accountants". His brother-in-law was an accountant, so he knew what he was talking about. Carman was proud of winning Dodd's acquittal, and even prouder of securing the freedom of Dr Leonard Arthur, the paediatrician charged with attempted murder after prescribing "nursing care only" for a Down's syndrome baby. Carman's summing-up was a masterpiece. "He [Arthur] could, like Pontius Pilate, have washed his hands of the matter," Carman told the jury. "He did not, because good doctors do not turn away. Are we to condemn him as a criminal because he helped two people at the time of their greatest need? Are we to condemn a doctor because he cared?" He prepared his closing speeches carefully, but did not, as critics suggested, practise them in front of a mirror. He had the first three or four sentences and the all-important peroration written down, and delivered them verbatim, but for the middle section he would work from notes to allow for some degree of spontaneity. Carman is likely to be remembered primarily as a libel barrister, but his remarkable run of successes in criminal cases in the 80s should be given due weight. He described libel as the "last chapter" in his career, and did not make his first serious incursion into the field until the Sonia Sutcliffe case in 1990. Before that, he had done civil cases, personal injury and contract, as well as criminal cases. He was invited to become a judge in Hong Kong in the 1980s, but declined. His excuse then was that his wife was unwell, but he later said that he would have found it hard to keep quiet on the bench, and preferred the "blood and sand of the arena". Carman married three times, though only listed two of his marriages in Who's Who. When pursued on this point by the Daily Mail, which was attempting to "carmanise" Carman, he said that he had suppressed the details of his first marriage to protect his wife, who he had married very young, and that the general public did not have to submit to the same rules as litigants. Each of his marriages ended in divorce. He is survived by his son Dominic, and four grandchildren.  George Alfred Carman, barrister, born October 6 1929; died January 2 2001 Related stories George Carman QC: a life in quotations 4 September: George Carman reveals he has cancer 30 August: the great defender

webTitle: Letsbuyit.com on the brink

fields.headline: Letsbuyit.com on the brink
fields.standfirst: Jan 2: investors flee Letsbuyit.com
fields.trailText:
5pm: Letsbuyit.com is set to announce its fate following two days of bankruptcy talks, writes Dan Milmo.
Jan 2: investors flee Letsbuyit.com
fields.body:
Letsbuyit.com is set to announce its fate following two days of talks with bankruptcy trustees.

A spokeswoman for the stricken online retailer said a statement will be issued this evening or early tomorrow following reports that negotiations had failed to rescue the company.

The Dutch-registered firm has already won protection from its creditors at an Amsterdam court, but if it fails to find additional funding it will be wound up.

Its London offices were shut this afternoon, with the telephones answered by a message asking callers to call back on Monday.

Letsbuyit.com's shares tumbled a further 9.3% on the Neuer Markt index in Frankfurt, following yesterday's catastrophic fall of 50%.

Analysts have described the company's chances of finding a buyer as "hopeless".

Letsbuyit.com, which allows consumers to pool their purchasing power and buy goods in bulk, is reported to have just £11.4m in the bank. It needs £50m to stay afloat.

webTitle: Sykes takes up reins at Imperial

fields.headline: Sykes takes up reins at Imperial
fields.trailText: Former head of Glaxo Wellcome, Sir Richard Sykes, took up office today as the new rector of Imperial College, London. Sykes succeeds Lord Ronald Oxburgh, who held the post from 1993-2000. He will be the college's 13th rector.
fields.body:
Former head of Glaxo Wellcome, Sir Richard Sykes, took up office today as the new rector of Imperial College, London. Sykes succeeds Lord Ronald Oxburgh, who held the post from 1993-2000. He will be the college's 13th rector.

The appointment of a university head from the business world bucks the traditional academic trend of selecting a vice-chancellor from the internal university ranks. But many universities are now seeking figures experienced both in the commercial and academic worlds to lead their institutions. Another recent high profile academic appointment was Sir Alec Broers, the former IBM director who is now Cambridge University's vice-chancellor.

While heading the world's largest pharmaceutical company though, Sykes found time to play a part in many academic debates. He was a member of the government commissioned Dearing team for example who reviewed the university system in 1997. He has been a prominent member of the Council of Science and Technology, the government's premier science advisory body.

Imperial College is one of the four research powerhouses among UK universities - with only University College London, Oxford and Cambridge Universities challenging it in terms of attracting reseach funds. Imperial's annual trunover was £330m in 1998-99, with a research income of £122m.

A particular interest for Sykes is likely to be the translation of research discoveries and developments into business opportunities - a current priority for universities.

Sykes graduated at the University of London with a first class Honours degree in Microbiology. He obtained his Doctorate in Microbial Biochemistry at Bristol University and his Doctor of Science degree from the University of London. He is a Fellow of the Royal Society, an Honorary Fellow of the Royal Society of Chemistry and a Fellow of the Academy of Medical Sciences.

Sykes was appointed Deputy Chairman and Chief Executive of the Glaxo pharmaceutical company in March 1993. Following the acquisition of Wellcome, Glaxo was renamed Glaxo Wellcome in May 1995. He was appointed Chairman and Chief Executive of Glaxo Wellcome in May 1997. He is currently non-executive chairman of GlaxoSmithKline.

He received his knighthood, for services to the pharmaceutical industry, in the 1994.

webTitle: Get well soon, Welcome back, and Goodbye for ever

fields.headline: Get well soon, Welcome back, and Goodbye for ever
fields.trailText: BAD NIGHT
fields.body:
BAD NIGHT

Last night wasn't a healthy one for footballers. Fulham captain Chris Coleman seriously injured his right leg after crashing his sports car, while Liverpool striker Robbie Fowler was assaulted outside a bar in Liverpool.

At about 9.15pm last night, Coleman's car ended up in a ditch near his home in Surrey. He sustained multiple fractures to his right leg and had to be sedated by paramedics before fireman were able to free him from the mangled wreck of his Jaguar. Coleman, who is out for the season, was rushed to hospital for emergency surgery. "His condition is satisfactory," said a hospital spokesperson. "He is comfortable and in good spirits." Police are investigating the accident.

Fowler's latest woe - he last year suffered a broken nose, chipped tooth, black eye and bruising to the back of his head after being attacked in the toilets of a Liverpool hotel - began shortly after 2am outside the Wonder Bar pub in Liverpool. According to a Merseyside Police spokesperson, the striker was "seen outside the premises having been assaulted. He was suffering slight injuries to his face". Luckily, the Liverpool player did not require hospital treatment. A 39-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of having inflicted Fowler's injuries.

GOOD MORNING

If anybody deserves a bit of good fortune, it's Dave Jones. As we all know, poor Dave was edged out of his job at Southampton after some fairly heavy - and false - accusations were levelled at him. So it's good to see him return to the world of football after coming through such a hellish time. Whether he'll actually enjoy himself now he's back is another matter, mind you - he's just taken charge of 100% promotion-proof Wolves. And he's been promising everyone promotion. Oh dear.

"I'm here to bring back the good times and take the club back where it belongs, and that's the Premiership," he whooped like a Kinnock at a Sheffield rally. "What's gone on has gone on. That's history now. I just want to look forward and build Wolverhampton Wanderers into a Premiership force."

Seeing that's something even top promotion guru Graham Taylor couldn't manage, the next few months should be interesting. "We believe we have found a manager with Premiership credentials," insisted Jez Moxey, who is either Wolves' chief executive or the arsonist from Auf Wiedersehen, Pet. "We had over 50 applicants, but Dave is a man with Premiership credentials. He is determined to show to everyone that he can get Wolves into the Premiership and become a Premiership manager again." Premiership, Premiership, Premiership ... are this lot obsessed or what?

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"London is very special, there is always something to do. I like it" - Nicolas Anelk ... no, hold on ... Thierry Henry waxes lyrical about the smoky hole he lives in.

IBROX: A CORRECTION

In yesterday's Fiver, we wrote that the 1971 Ibrox disaster was caused by spectators stumbling immediately after Colin Stein's late equaliser for Rangers against Celtic. However, the official inquiry into the tragedy found that the crush developed 10 minutes after the final whistle. We're sorry to have caused any confusion.

LOVELY LUNCHTIME

Judging by his gigantic jaw-line, Telegraph journalist Matt Lawson loves nothing more than sinking his teeth into a nice fat succulent story. So we weren't surprised to read his back-page exclusive this morning which revealed that Aberdeen are trying to lure Imperial Lord Ferg back to Pittodrie.

According to his meaty report, Aberdeen were preparing to offer Imperial Lord Ferg a 50.1% controlling stake in the club when he retires from Manchester United next season - which would be worth an impressive £3.1m. There was even a quote from a boardroom insider who said: "There is nobody involved with Aberdeen who would not like to see [Imperial Lord Ferg] back at this club. If he did he would be welcomed with open arms and offered any position."

Unfortunately, an Aberdeen spokesman this afternoon poured a large glass of uisge beatha over the whole story (before dampening down the resulting steam with an oatcake): "The board wishes to make it clear that it has had no discussions whatsoever with [Imperial Lord Ferg] regarding either his engagement in the management of the club or of his becoming an investor in Aberdeen Football Club plc.

"[Imperial Lord Ferg] obviously still has many friends at Pittodrie and, because of this and the fact he attended our game against Hearts yesterday, this type of unfounded speculation is not entirely surprising. However, all this is doing is creating false hopes in the minds of our supporters, which is disappointing." Unlike the deep-fried Angus cattle, which we hear went down very well.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Spurs have denied reports they are about to sign Argentine playmaker Juan Fernandez di Alessio. "No-one from our scouting staff has been to Argentina in the last two months," David Pleat told the official Spurs website. "Although we are aware of this club, and a couple of their players have come under scrutiny, we have not looked at this player. This story is false."

Aston Villa have been offered River Plate's 24-year-old defender Mario Yepes, reports Planet Football. But the website warns: "Parma and Internazionale lined up moves for the 24-year-old in 2000, and he would not come cheaply."

Martin O'Neill heads the shortlist to succeed Imperial Lord Ferg at Manchester United, reports the Mirror. They quote outgoing Celtic chief Alan McDonald, who claims United's plc chairman Roland Smith has a short-list of three to replace Ferg - consisting of David O'Leary, Alan Curbishley ... and favourite O'Neill.

Lazio are set to sign former Manchester United winger Karel Poborsky for £3.5m, according reports in the Italian press.

Blackburn striker Egil Ostenstad is in talks with Primera Liga club Las Palmas over a possible transfer.

Bolton are hoping to sign Sunderland winger Nicky Summerbee.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Darren Anderton has followed in the footsteps of Sol Campbell by announcing he wants to stay at Spurs. Anderton said: "I know that because my contract is up in the summer I could talk to foreign clubs now, but I would rather stay at Spurs. I'm not just saying I want to stay, I really do want to. I feel I am part of the family here."

Michael Knighton has sold his controlling interest in Carlisle United to a consortium of investors led by property company Mamcarr Investments Limited.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: Football Extra (3.40am)
"I got whacked in the face when playing a five-a-side game against Anglia TV and had to go to A&E for a few stitches," writes Adam Fletcher.

Sky Sports 1: The Last Word (6.30pm, 11pm SS1)
"Their sports presenter (who I think was called Kevin although I cannot remember) was good enough to give me a lift up there."

You're On Sky Sports! (10pm, 12.30am)
"When we arrived, the staff on reception completely ignored me bleeding all over their carpet and started asking Keith (or was it Karl) sports trivia questions."

Sky Sports 2: Futbol Mundial (7.30pm, 12midnight SS1, 2.30am SS1)
"Mind you, he did get them all right."

Radio 5 Live: Sport on 5 with Ian Payne (7pm)
We reckon you're talking about Kevin Piper, head of sport at Anglia and main presenter of Anglia's popular football series Kick Off!

Midweek 6-0-6 with Adrian Chiles (10pm)
By the way, Adam, was Richard Futter playing as well?

Talksport: Football First (7pm)
Were you once upended by Roger Tames? Has Jim Delahunt ever caught you in an off-the-ball incident? Or did Elton Welsby rake the back of your legs with a trolley in a supermarket queue? Email the.boss@theguardian.com with your best regional television presenter story and we'll publish the best (if we get any).

webTitle: Ikea ad voted 'most irritating' of the year

fields.headline: Ikea ad voted 'most irritating' of the year
fields.trailText: 4.30pm: Ikea's latest TV campaign has been voted the most irritating of the year. By Jason Deans and Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
Ikea's latest TV campaign featuring staff sniffing each other's armpits has been voted the most irritating of last year.

Half the people polled in the NOP survey of around 500 adults said they found the Ikea ad infuriating.

The campaign follows in the wake of other controversial adverts for the Scandinavian furniture store, including those exhorting consumers to "chuck out their chintz" and to "stop being so English".

It first hit the screens in the spring, but reappeared before Christmas.

Created by the maverick advertising agency St Luke's, the ad also featured a mysterious tattooed man stripping off in the collection zone of the superstore.

Marketing magazine, which commissioned the survey, said: "You have to have a grudging admiration for an agency that can convince a client that body odour and locking staff in a storeroom are the best way to communicate a brand's essence."

Alan Young, creative director on the Ikea campaign for St Luke's, said: "We hope it did irritate some people and get people talking down the pub.

"The lack of service is the only practical thing going for it. Ikea is very, very stretched. It is almost anti-service.

"Most companies have a very north-American attitude where the customer is always king. Ikea doesn't. Its philosophy is pro-sumerism, which means the consumer does everything - picking the sofa out, lugging it down to the till, paying for it and taking it home."

Mr Young added that it was his intention to create a splash.

"Ikea spends a fifth or a seventh of the amount spent on advertising by other furniture stores such as DFS or Courts.

"Being controversial is the only practical way forward to make an impact. People say 'how can you do that, you are really brave'.

"But we aren't - trying to do something that isn't going to be an event is the riskiest strategy of all."

Ads for PC World and Dixons, both created by M&C Saatchi, took second and third place in the survey, polling 42% and 36% respectively.

The controversial Marks & Spencer commercial featuring a size 16 woman running up a hill and stripping off, created by Rainey Kelley Campbell Roalfe Y&R, came in at number 11 in the survey.

webTitle: ITV misses peak-time target

fields.headline: ITV misses peak-time target
fields.trailText: 8.30am: ITV missed its peak-time viewing target for 2000 despite beating BBC1 on most nights over Christmas, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
ITV failed to meet its peak-time share target for 2000 despite beating BBC1 on most nights over the Christmas period.

Despite the huge success of Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?, the network is expected to finish with a 37.1% share of peak-time viewing - 7-10.30pm - when the unofficial ratings figures for the final week of the year are confirmed by Barb.

This falls well short of the 38.5% target ITV set itself at the beginning of the year. But the station has been telling advertisers since July that it was unlikely to hit the peak-time target.

ITV executives will still receive end-of-year bonuses, because their performance-related packages are linked to an incremental set of audience goals, rather than specifically hitting the 38.5% target.
