webTitle: Arms and the (innocent) man

fields.headline: Arms and the (innocent) man
fields.trailText: At least one famous suspect is happy with a new French law which presumes innocence, reports Jon Henley in Paris
fields.body:
It came into force at midnight on New Year's Eve, and already France's brand-new, long-awaited, much-debated law on the presumption of innocence has made its mark: no less a person than a former president's son, banged up two weeks ago on suspicion of arms-dealing, is free to leave jail.

There is the minor matter of £500,000 of bail to come up with, of course, but it is the principle that counts: Jean-Christophe Mitterrand, elder son and senior adviser to the late Francois, may no longer be held in custody because, as the new law puts it, "his continued incarceration is not indispensable to the proper functioning of justice".

For those who have not followed the story, J-C, his father's top Africa strategist, was arrested on December 21 on suspicion of using his voluminous address book to help an accused arms trafficker, Pierre Falcone, illegally sell some £350m of Russian-made arms to Angola in 1993-94 - allegedly in exchange for some £1.3m of Falcone's company's money paid into a Swiss bank account.

The affair is highly explosive. It involves the son of a former president and a colourful alleged arms dealer who also happened at the time to be a leading agent of Sofremi, the shadowy French government organisation that dealt, among other things, with official arms sales to Africa.

But others who have been dragged in - if only as witnesses, or because their offices have been searched - include a best-selling author, a mysterious and deeply dodgy Russian-born billionaire, a former French interior minister, a retired prefect (or senior state official), and various other government agents.

The Mitterrand-Falcone scandal, in short, threatens to blow the lid once and for all off the shady, semi-official and often downright illegal deals hatched between France and many African countries up to the late 1990s, and it threatens to implicate some very senior figures indeed, right the way up to the Elysee palace.

This makes it as good a test as any for France's creaking and largely Napoleonic judicial system, currently emerging from a radical and wide-ranging overhaul launched by the former justice minister Elisabeth Guigou.

Aimed at rectifying "a profound lack of confidence on the part of the French people in French justice", the reforms included major investment in the country's prisons, ensuring public prosecutors are immune from political pressure, and guaranteeing citizens a full right of redress for decisions they are not satisfied with.

But one of the most important elements of the reform package is Ms Guigou's core legislation aimed at humanising the system and reinforcing the principle, battered but crucial, of the presumption of innocence.

This means that since New Year's Day, suspects held in custody in French police or prison cells are entitled to see a lawyer within an hour of their detention, rather than 20 hours as was previously the case.

People called in for questioning as witnesses will no longer find themselves suddenly placed under arrest as suspects - a favourite trick of France's all-powerful investigating magistrates - without the existence of "clear and concrete evidence" against them.

From now on, too, magistrates must keep suspects informed of the progress of their probes.

Nor, more particularly, is it any longer up to the investigating magistrate in charge of the case to decide on the desirability of pre-trial detention - that is now the job of an independent, newly-created specialist whom the investigating magistrate must convince at a public hearing.

Ms Guigou's legislation came in handy for Francois Mitterrand's elder son. Both the public prosecutor and the investigating magistrate had argued for his continued detention.

But despite the explosiveness of the case and despite the vast sums that J-C has admitted receiving for some very ill-defined work (though he has denied knowledge of any arms deal), the independent court ruled that in this case, pre-trial incarceration was not justified.

That may not be a particularly popular decision in a country used to the high-handed and unanswerable ways of a justice system that has not, hitherto, proved notably efficient at dealing with cases of high-level corruption.

But it does, finally, bring French judicial practice into line with almost every other liberal democracy in the western world - and if the same principle is also applied to people a little less important that an ex-president's son, France's hitherto opaque and antiquated judicial procedures will have taken a major step forward.

webTitle: Dreaming of a slack Christmas

fields.headline: Dreaming of a slack Christmas
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard's festive break lacked one vital ingredient - idleness
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard's festive break lacked one vital ingredient - idleness.
fields.body:
Christmas is a bad time for the slack father. He reads with a dyspeptic and suspicious eye the claims of one Cary Cooper, professor of organisational psychology and health at the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology, that there exists such a thing as "post-bank holiday depression syndrome". What the slack father has is acute post-bank holiday relief syndrome.

The pattern of his life, like a photographic negative of normality, involves calm and ordered weekdays but frenetic and exhausting weekends. At this time of year, the differences are vividly heightened. In the spirit of the ancient Saturnalia, when authority was inverted and slaves were allowed flagrantly to inconvenience their masters, the au pair has, unreasonably, gone back to her own family for the holidays. Every year, one useful labour-saving device decides to die; this year, it is the dishwasher. Suddenly, there is all this stuff the slack father has to do - much, much more than usual - and he finds he can no longer make irksome chores disappear with the serene and powerful magic of sloth.

The slack father is a shy and peaceable beast, preferring above all else to be left alone, especially at this time of year. But it simply ain't going to happen. Trusty excuses such as "Work" and "Not really feeling like it" no longer hack it. He has to muck in. He now does 5% of household duties, which may not sound like much to you, but represents a fivefold increase on what he normally does. As I write, I notice that I have acquired an ugly blister on my left hand. It can only have developed from unaccustomed exposure to effort: lifting things, I think, probably something to do with the two Big Shops done on consecutive days before Christmas. (The idea was to turn one unimaginably vast and high- pressure shopping trip into two much more manageable ones. Don't try this at home: what you get is two unimaginably vast and high-pressure shopping trips, and a blister.) Where is your underpaid and semi-traumatised help when you need it most?

It is disturbing how readily one accepts one's status as an employer. "I have an au pair" is, in its way, even more unforeseeable to the younger mind than "I have a child". ("I have three children" isn't something I'd ever imagined I'd be saying either, but there they are.) I remember how my friend Toby once caught me out. It was around the time the minimum wage was coming on stream. He asked me what I thought about it. A nice start, I said, but the rate is insultingly low.

"So remind me," said my friend, "how much you're paying the au pair."

"That's different," I said, slamming my glass down, but also quite keen not to air the risible sum we have to be reminded to pay her on Fridays.

Nice, middle-class herbivores go strangely Thatcherite around the subject. I recall them getting into a kerfuffle when plans were announced to get the Inland Revenue involved in the traffic of 22-year-old women who mystifyingly presume that au pairing is a good way to learn English. What, exactly, are they going to learn to say? Phrases like "Eat your greens", "Stop that" and, to the parents, "Excuse please, where is sugar/bread/my money" pretty much cover everything. "Stop that" also comes in handy with the cheesier kind of male parent. Slack Dad, I should hardly need to stress, does not make passes at the au pair; not only does he simply not have the energy, or as much confidence in his looks as he used to, but he appreciates the value of an extra pair of hands, and will not imperil the smooth running of the house by acting like Chris Evans around Billie Piper.

The thing about au pairs is that they offer an idea of how the middle classes evaded tiresome quotidian demands through every era of humanity except the modern one: they had servants. This is a deeply troubling thought per se for Guardian readers, who are naturally suspicious of hierarchies; but believe me, even if fitting another person into your household is a tight squeeze, it really helps.

We always try to make the au pairs feel part of the family, not so much to make them happy as to crush their individuality beneath a barrage of demands, insults, and bitterly appropriate sarcasm. One fosters familial loyalty by making the newcomer utterly incapable of routine interaction with the external world. The big risk, though, is when the door of the cage swings open. Does the au pair hop away to freedom or return, with a shudder, to the bowl of water, the little pile of lettuce and heap of torn-up newspaper that is now her home? I confess to being worried this time. I scan the skies and pray for her return.

webTitle: Finding a perfect nanny

fields.headline: Mary Poppins - or the minder from hell?
fields.standfirst: Adam Kidd on finding a perfect nanny
fields.trailText: Adam Kidd on finding a perfect nanny.
fields.body:
'I make it a point never to give references. It's an old-fashioned idea." Not the best way to impress a potential employer, but probably unproblematic if you are "practically perfect in every way", as was that old faithful, Mary Poppins, back on the box on New Year's Day.

But take up references we do, as more and more of us are having to use paid childcare of one kind or another. And while there may still be a reassuring ring about that almost anachronistic word "nanny", a certain unease is inevitable in entrusting your little ones to the arms of strangers. After all, behind that seemingly calm and pleasant exterior may lurk a secret smacker, a baby-shaker or worse.

Thoroughness pays in trying to find the right carer, and few are likely to breeze so easily into the job as Poppins with her carpetbag and brolly. It is important not only to inspect references but to follow them up by actually speaking to two or three referees, according to The Nanny Handbook, a new guide to hiring and handling nannies and au pairs that covers not only the nitty-gritty of tax arrangements and contracts, but also more emotional issues such as coping with the jealousy of someone else looking after your children.

Its authors, Karen House and Louise Shephard, are management consultants in their late 30s who live in Wakefield and Wimbledon respectively, with seven children and 10 nannies' worth of experience between them. Shephard, who has worked full time apart from a brief maternity leave for each of her four children, says she has been "quite lucky" with her six nannies, none of whom has been a "complete disaster".

Minor mishaps there were. One nanny, on her first day, reversed the Volvo into a neighbour's wall but, rather than immediately showing the red card, Shephard booked her some driving lessons. Benevolence paid off: "She was a great nanny; she stayed for three years."

But she recalls a narrow escape with one candidate she almost employed, who had impressed at interview and brought good references. "I was going to offer her the job, so I thought, 'We'll have a cup of tea and an informal chat.' It's impor tant to go on intuition as well. As we went into the kitchen, I noticed she had this watch with a picture of Elton John on the face, which struck me as unusual. She told me she was absolutely bonkers about him. I asked if she went to his concerts. She said, 'Yes, I do, but I've got this terrible problem because I'm infatuated with him and every time I see him or hear his music, I pass out. I've been going to hypnotherapy for it.'"

Nannies are most commonly recruited through agencies, ads in magazines such as the Lady or, increasingly, the internet. While there is no registration system, you may, for a small charge, ask for a police check. But even diligent homework can sometimes fail to uncover a rogue nanny. Samantha Young (not her real name), returning to her job as a high-powered executive after maternity leave for her first child, recruited a day nanny from an ad in The Lady, confident in her choice because she knew two of the referees. But then she heard reports of "strange things".

"My cleaning lady told me the nanny had put the baby in the cot and closed the door with the room as hot as a sauna," she says. "On another occasion, my parents tried to visit but the nanny wouldn't let them in. So one day I went out, pretending to go to work, and came back an hour later to find her naked, wearing only my husband's dressing gown. She said the baby had been sick on her."

The next time Young returned unexpected, she found a bruise on her baby's face. Exit nanny. "The funny thing was that afterwards I spoke to the two referees and they admitted she had seemed a bit odd and had stolen things," she continues. "Then I saw her in the high street one day, wearing a cardigan exactly like one I had but couldn't find. The last I saw of her was a story I read in the local paper. She was looking after a baby when the family was away and the house had burned down."

Returning to The Lady for a replacement, Young took on someone even though her last reference was not particularly good: "I phoned her previous employers a couple of times and they agreed they had had a row, but that she was a good nanny." And that is what nanny number two proved to be.

The most common cause of problems is a mismatch between parental requirements and a nanny's expectations. Wendy Pins, a mother of three from north London, has been frustrated by the inability of agencies to send her suitable candidates, although she recognises that she has special requirements in being at home full time and having eight-month-old twins: "Most nannies won't work with a mother at home. They want sole charge."

Her first live-in nanny, recruited from Australia via an agency, lasted all of three weeks. "In one incident, she took the wrong turning out of the tube home and got lost," says Pins. "Instead of phoning me on the mobile I had given her, she phoned her mother in Australia in the middle of the night, who then rang me."

Turning to various temporary daytime nannies, she found that several, despite glowing references on paper, were "all at sea with twins". Salvation eventually came, via an ad, in the form of a mother's help who, though unqualified as a nanny, had two sets of twins herself and proved a "guardian angel" before leaving suddenly to go to university.

Pins is still seeking a part-time nanny, which is harder to find, she says, than a full-time one. Meanwhile, she relies on a couple of mornings a week from a trained maternity nurse and help from a 22-year-old Czech au pair recruited from the internet by her husband Anthony. "But I would never feel comfortable using an au pair for childcare," she says.

Au pairs are, of course, a cheaper option than nannies, although they generally do not expect to be left in charge of children under three. Peter Radcliffe, who employs a 19-year-old Hungarian au pair, says he heard about one au pair who dropped a baby: "She managed to catch the baby by the legs but broke both of them in the process."

He is happy to leave James, who is three-and-a-half, with the au pair for an hour or two, since she has been with them for some time, but would generally never leave a young child with an au pair until she had shown herself trustworthy. Hungarian-speaking Radcliffe and his wife took unusual precautions in screening the candidate, travelling to Budapest to interview her.

Unlike nannies and au pairs, childminders are subject to registration and supervision - by local authorities. They are a fast-growing workforce, numbering more than 82,000, with more than 16,000 new childminders registered each year. The fact of registration, however, does not remove the need for parents to be careful. My wife took our two-year-old son to a childminder recommended by a friend. At first, my wife seemed happy enough to let him join the toddlers scampering downstairs. But back home, she began to harbour doubts about the apparent ratio of one adult to four children.

When she checked with the local authority, it confirmed that the maximum for under-fives was three per childminder. Call us overprotective, but while a nursery school may be purpose-built for children's play, a home is still a home, with all the attendant hazards.

Our local authority issues childminders with a registration certificate stating the maximum number of children permitted, which it advises potential users to inspect. But practice differs from council to council - one reason why, from September, the regulation of childminders will pass to Ofsted, with the introduction of national standards that, the government promises, "will focus on children's safety and well-being".

The new controls naturally raise the question of why there is still no registration scheme for nannies. Shephard believes that there "should be some way of striking them off if children are endangered or if they have been abusive or have revealed confidential information".

In Mary Poppins, a whole squadron of unsuitable nannies, with faces as grim as executioners, are blown away by a miraculous gust, scattered like so many black-hatted crows. Unfortunately, we cannot rely for our children's protection on the intervention of magical figures who descend by umbrella from the clouds, snapping their fingers.

"The funny thing was that afterwards I spoke to the two referees and they admitted she had seemed a bit odd and had stolen things," she continues. "Then I saw her in the high street one day, wearing a cardigan exactly like one I had but couldn't find. The last I saw of her was a story I read in the local paper. She was looking after a baby when the family was away and the house had burned down." Returning to The Lady for a replacement, Young took on someone even though her last reference was not particularly good: "I phoned her previous employers a couple of times and they agreed they had had a row, but that she was a good nanny." And that is what nanny number two proved to be. The most common cause of problems is a mismatch between parental requirements and a nanny's expectations. Wendy Pins, a mother of three from north London, has been frustrated by the inability of agencies to send her suitable candidates, although she recognises that she has special requirements in being at home full time and having eight-month-old twins: "Most nannies won't work with a mother at home. They want sole charge." Her first live-in nanny, recruited from Australia via an agency, lasted all of three weeks. "In one incident, she took the wrong turning out of the tube home and got lost," says Pins. "Instead of phoning me on the mobile I had given her, she phoned her mother in Australia in the middle of the night, who then rang me." Turning to various temporary daytime nannies, she found that several, despite glowing references on paper, were "all at sea with twins". Salvation eventually came, via an ad, in the form of a mother's help who, though unqualified as a nanny, had two sets of twins herself and proved a "guardian angel" before leaving suddenly to go to university. Pins is still seeking a part-time nanny, which is harder to find, she says, than a full-time one. Meanwhile, she relies on a couple of mornings a week from a trained maternity nurse and help from a 22-year-old Czech au pair recruited from the internet by her husband Anthony. "But I would never feel comfortable using an au pair for childcare," she says. Au pairs are, of course, a cheaper option than nannies, although they generally do not expect to be left in charge of children under three. Peter Radcliffe, who employs a 19-year-old Hungarian au pair, says he heard about one au pair who dropped a baby: "She managed to catch the baby by the legs but broke both of them in the process." He is happy to leave James, who is three-and-a-half, with the au pair for an hour or two, since she has been with them for some time, but would generally never leave a young child with an au pair until she had shown herself trustworthy. Hungarian-speaking Radcliffe and his wife took unusual precautions in screening the candidate, travelling to Budapest to interview her. Unlike nannies and au pairs, childminders are subject to registration and supervision - by local authorities. They are a fast-growing workforce, numbering more than 82,000, with more than 16,000 new childminders registered each year. The fact of registration, however, does not remove the need for parents to be careful. My wife took our two-year-old son to a childminder recommended by a friend. At first, my wife seemed happy enough to let him join the toddlers scampering downstairs. But back home, she began to harbour doubts about the apparent ratio of one adult to four children. When she checked with the local authority, it confirmed that the maximum for under-fives was three per childminder. Call us overprotective, but while a nursery school may be purpose-built for children's play, a home is still a home, with all the attendant hazards. Our local authority issues childminders with a registration certificate stating the maximum number of children permitted, which it advises potential users to inspect. But practice differs from council to council - one reason why, from September, the regulation of childminders will pass to Ofsted, with the introduction of national standards that, the government promises, "will focus on children's safety and well-being". The new controls naturally raise the question of why there is still no registration scheme for nannies. Shephard believes that there "should be some way of striking them off if children are endangered or if they have been abusive or have revealed confidential information". In Mary Poppins, a whole squadron of unsuitable nannies, with faces as grim as executioners, are blown away by a miraculous gust, scattered like so many black-hatted crows. Unfortunately, we cannot rely for our children's protection on the intervention of magical figures who descend by umbrella from the clouds, snapping their fingers.

webTitle: The panel: toddler tax credit

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: The latest proposal from Harriet Harman's childcare commission is a 'toddler tax credit' to encourage women to stay at home with pre-school children. Is this a good idea?
fields.trailText: The Question: The latest proposal from Harriet Harman's childcare commission is a 'toddler tax credit' to encourage women to stay at home with pre-school children. Is this a good idea?
fields.body:
Marice Cumber Working mother of two

If parents who have been highly trained take three years out of the workplace, the world moves at such a fast pace now that they will have to be retrained when they return to work. If a parent gains satisfaction from their career, they are less likely to harbour resentment against their children who are taking them away from a mentally stimulating occupation. If the government has money to spend, I would rather see it spent on increasing flexibility of work and childcare, so that parents can combine work and childcare better in their children's early years.

Verdict: Yes and no

Stephen Burke Director, Daycare Trust

Parents want more work and family choices when their children are young. Improving paid parental leave needs to be matched by greater flexibility from employers, particularly on part-time working, and more affordable, quality childcare for children under three. Many parents with young children don't have a choice at the moment, because they can't afford or find quality childcare in their area. The government's neighbourhood nurseries initiative is crucial in giving parents on lower incomes more childcare choices - and their children a good start in life.

Verdict: No

Christine Gowdridge Director, the Maternity Alliance

Anything that genuinely enables people to choose between work and home without losing too much income would be really helpful. I'm not totally convinced that we need to invent something new. Maybe we ought to target resources at paying for parental leave, increasing child benefit and increasing the earnings-related bit of maternity pay. I think we can achieve those things with the structures we have at the moment. We have a good system right now: what we need to do is put more money into it to make it work effectively for parents.

Verdict: No

Eamonn Butler Director, Adam Smith Institute

You can make parental leave and other benefits as generous as you want, but someone has to pay for them - either the taxpayer or the employer - and then it costs people more to work, which becomes a powerful disincentive. If employers have to pay too much, it becomes less attractive for them to employ people. At the moment, the UK workplace is very flexible and has relatively low taxes. If that tax burden increases, it won't be good for anyone. When taxes become too high, it's the poorer families, not the better-off ones, who get squeezed out of the labour force.

Verdict: No

Julie Bindel Spokesperson, Justice for Women

I think the money would be better spent on paying women not to have children at all. Women need some education to take them away from the romantic vision of the nuclear family. I don't think there's a woman alive, unless she's extremely privileged, who wouldn't acknowledge that the quality of her life has in some way diminished as a result of having children. The government needs to think about breaking down the myths surrounding family life. What it really means is confining women to nuclear-family hell for the rest of their lives.

Verdict: Yes and no

webTitle: Erin Gill on being brought up by her father

fields.headline: After Jacquie
fields.standfirst: Erin Gill was just a year old when her mother died. Her grandparents offered to bring her up, but her father insisted on keeping her - and now she's glad he did
fields.trailText: Erin Gill was just a year old when her mother died. Her grandparents offered to bring her up, but her father insisted on keeping her - and now she's glad he did.
fields.body:
Once in a blue moon my father and I admit that we saved each other's lives. One morning in 1973, my mother set off for work and never got there. Killed in a car accident. My father was 28 and I was a year and a half.

My maternal grandparents offered to raise me, but my father decided that he wouldn't have much reason to get up in the morning if I wasn't there. I dread to think what would have become of me if I had been immediately separated from my father after losing my mother. Such a set of circumstances tends to be written up in psychology textbooks as a worst-case scenario.

So there we were: a young, grieving man who had only recently left behind a conventional career as an architect to risk his hand at sculpture, and a toddler so traumatised by her mother's disappearance that she temporarily stopped speaking. What developed from that sorry state was a relationship between father and daughter that is so deep that one friend describes the bond between my dad and I as "palpable".

In the years after Jacquie's death, my father and I got to know each other in a way that is usually impossible in a two-parent family. The "daddy's girl" model did not apply, because it relies on daddy being the bearer only of good news and treats - usually to make up for being home so seldom. And daddy's girls generally respond by playing up to the atten tion and being extra-specially nice or gloriously naughty.

If he wasn't the classic doting daddy, what was he? Did my father metamorphose into a mother? That is often the perception of what single dads do, but I disagree. I think single dads who rise to the occasion become more of a dad. In my father's case, he had to confront parenting issues that he had been able to avoid while my mother was alive. How should you react when a child won't do what you want her to? Do you hit her? This question proved a watershed in my father's approach to parenting. He says that one night he happened upon a television programme about child abuse and realised that I was a delicate creature and vowed not to hit me. If my mother had lived, my father might have avoided for years being in a position where he was angry with me, and would not have been prepared. But it was just the two of us, so his decision to turn his back on his own history - his father had certainly beaten him - was a victory for us both.

There were more light-hearted conundrums. Food is the one I remember best. My father was determined that his lack of feminine skills in the kitchen should not lead to malnutrition in his daughter. As a result, I put up with some horrendous experiments. There was the teaspoon of dry, vile-tasting wheatgerm to be eaten every morning. That gave way eventually to a tablespoon of blackstrap molasses. But worst of all was the fish. Richard read that fish was very nutritious and set about boiling some type of low-grade, frozen white fish every other night for years. He boiled it thoroughly and never once thought that sauce might make it more appealing. I responded by pretending to eat it, but deposited most of it along a ledge that ran under our dining room table. The fish didn't smell because it had been boiled for too long; it sat there until my father decided to move the table for a party. I still remember the shock of watching a wave of desiccated fish tumble to the floor.

Although much of the love Richard and I feel for each is obviously the result of the single parent-single child unit created during those crucial years when my personality was forming, there is an element to our bond that has nothing to do with day-to-day closeness and everything to do with the death of Jacquie. It is a painful, slightly desperate love, and it can erupt with a ferocity that alarms people around us. It makes us leap to defend each other more powerfully - and sometimes more irrationally - than we would anyone else. But we sometimes turn that love inwards and become each other's fiercest critic. Knowing that we can't hide from each other can be uncomfortable and we tend to avoid each other when we're struggling with something we aren't sure the other will understand.

When people hear about the circumstances of my childhood, they are often curious about my mother's death, but shy about asking questions. I don't blame them for being shy, although I'm perfectly happy to relay details of how my mother died. I am less inclined to discuss what impact her death had on me. I know I should not be surprised that Jacquie's death remains a gaping, painful wound that I stumble over from time to time, but I am surprised all the same. Until my late teens, I rationalised that because I have no visual memory of my mother, her dying didn't have any negative effects on me. When I finally admitted the weakness of this argument I began to piece together what may have happened to me.

These days, I believe that a piece of my heart froze when Jacquie died. Or maybe it was like losing a lung. Whatever metaphor I choose, the result is the same - the remaining parts of me had to work that much harder to compensate. For a child to "bounce back" from such a loss, she has to become tough, like a weed. I did that, and I'm glad, even proud, that I did. But bouncing back was a short-term solution; for the rest of my life there will be moments when my "tough" persona will give way to a much more troubled person. It is a scary prospect, but having a sculptor for a father has helped: I was brought up to accept that messy emotions can fuel creativity.

A part of my grief that I express more easily is respect for death's role in life. Most people are sheltered from mortality well into adulthood, but I know death is all around us. Accidents happen, people fall ill. I don't avoid physical risks and don't ask my loved ones to live risk-free lives either, but I can't help myself from saying things such as "Careful when you're cycling home" or "Go and get that checked out". People who know me realise that these aren't empty words, but that they convey my fervent hope that they will live long, healthy, happy lives. That is what my mother's death, when she was just 25, has taught me - that there is nothing romantic about an early death. It's a loss, pure and simple. And as my father moves through his 50s and I stare 30 in the face, thinking of Jacquie evokes in me the most powerful desire to see my father live to a ripe old age, and for me to do the same. Not quite in Jacquie's honour, but almost.

 Cruse Bereavement Care has just launched a new booklet, Has Someone Died? - Helping Children. To contact the Cruse helpline call 0870-1671677, or visit www.crusebereavementcare.org.uk

webTitle: Can you praise your children too much?

fields.headline: 'Well done, kids. That was absolutely brilliant'
fields.standfirst: Can you praise your children too much? A US psychologist says yes, but UK child experts disagree. Nikki Sheehan investigates
fields.trailText: Can you praise your children too much? A US psychologist says yes, but UK child experts disagree. Nikki Sheehan investigates.
fields.body:
Along with the old adage that you can't be too thin or too rich, American parents have, until now, believed you can't praise your kids too much. But now New York psychologist Dr Ron Taffel has thrown them into turmoil by declaring that too much praise lowers children's motivation and may turn them into "praise junkies".

Taffel, author of Nurturing Good Children Now, describes watching children sledding in Central Park. "Their parents were screaming, 'Great job! Phenomenal sledding! That's the best I've ever seen,'" said Taffel in the New York Times. As he points out, the children were being praised for obeying the laws of gravity. "It cheapens the praise, and children may become dependent."

Parents in the US have enthusiastically adopted the teachings of positive parenting, but for some the phrase "good job" has become a nervous tic. It is repeated as a mantra in response to their child's most ordinary accomplishments to prevent undesirable behaviour and to save their child from low self-esteem.

Schools in the US have joined in, too. Some even display posters exhorting teachers to "Praise every child every day". Lilian Katz, from the University of Illinois, claims that saying "good painting" will keep children at task while you are watching, but once adult attention is withdrawn, many lose interest in the activity. She believes that demotivation may occur as the child's focus moves from enjoyment of the task at hand to the search for more praise: the more we reward, the more likely the child is to lose intrinsic interest in whatever they were doing to get the reward.

This is backed up by research from Joan Grusec at the University of Toronto. Young children who were regularly praised for their generosity in giving to charity became slightly less generous. But the generosity of their peers who were not being praised did not decline.

Research in the classroom by Mary Bud Rowe, at the University of Florida, found that students who were praised lavishly were more hesitant in their responses, less likely to persist with difficult tasks and did not share ideas with fellow students. Creativity may also be affected as they take fewer risks in their work.

One explanation for the apparent loss of confidence and motivation is that over-praised children feel under pressure to keep it up. "What kids need is unconditional support," avers Alfie Kohn, author of Hooked on Praise. "That's not just different from praise - it's the opposite of praise. 'Good job!' is conditional. It means we're offering attention and acknowledgement and approval for jumping through our hoops."

Kohn suggests instead that a simple, evaluation-free description of what the child is doing tells them that you noticed, and lets them take pride in their actions. So should we worry about over-praising here in the UK?

Clinical psychologist Sue Jenner, author of The Parent/Child Game, is adamant that over-praising is not an issue. "In my work, I see many struggling adult personalities, and I have never come across anyone who says they can't cope because of too much praise as a child. Praise is vital for forming a strong child-parent attachment. Yes, describing what the child is doing is good, but if you give descriptions plus praise, it is a wonderful experience for a child."

Could there be a more personal reason for the appeal of this theory to some psychologists and parents? "Adults who were not praised as children are often uncomfortable with praise," explains Jenner. "We have to ask what the backgrounds are of the people who are cot toning on to this. Taffel is in danger of adding to transgenerational cycles of emotional abuse."

So is it safe to heap limitless praise on our little ones? Dr Sandra Scott, senior psychiatric registrar at the Maudsley Children's Hospital, is unhappy at the suggestion that praise can be detrimental. "A child is far more likely to be damaged through too little praise," she argues, "but effective praise should be genuine."

In childhood, many aspects of life are challenging, so what appears to be over-praising may help to acknowledge the child's learning and development, as well as reminding them they are loved.

"The children described by Taffel were probably a bit scared, but had conquered their fears. It's right for parents to praise that," says Scott. "Most of us are pretty ordinary and if we only praise special achievements, there won't be much praise at all. What's wrong with making a child feel special?"

webTitle: WPP snaps up US PR firm

fields.headline: WPP snaps up US PR firm
fields.trailText: 4pm: UK ad giant WPP has shrugged off fears for the year ahead by starting 2001 with an acquisition, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
UK advertising giant WPP has shrugged off fears for the year ahead by starting 2001 with an acquisition.

Its Ogilvy Public Relations Worldwide operation has snapped up California-based PR firm Deen + Black for an undisclosed sum, a day after fears of an advertising slowdown sent its shares down by 5.2%.

However, a jittery market ignored the news and the stock fell a further 3.7% today, despite a positive note from analysts at Credit Lyonnais.

Bob Seltzer, Ogilvy PR chairman, said: "We see great synergies between Deen + Black and Ogilvy PR.

"Their leadership in California and public affairs skills mesh perfectly with our local expertise in technology, marketing, corporate, healthcare and entertainment, and our global strength in public affairs."

WPP has been earmarked as a stock to watch over the coming months, as its strong US presence makes it susceptible to any downturn in the economy across the Atlantic.

It acquired US rival Young & Rubicam last year, and 19% of WPP's turnover comes from north America.

In October last year, WPP reported a 26% rise in third-quarter revenues, although it admitted that growth in the global advertising market for 2001 would be around 6-7% rather than the 7-8% forecast.

webTitle: Arafat 'accepts' Clinton peace plan

fields.headline: Arafat 'accepts' Clinton peace plan
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, has given the US president, Bill Clinton, his qualified acceptance of a US formula for a negotiated settlement with Israel, a senior Palestinian official said today, according to the Associated Press.
fields.body:
The Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, has given the US president, Bill Clinton, his qualified acceptance of a US formula for a negotiated settlement with Israel, a senior Palestinian official said today, according to the Associated Press.

Hassan Abdel Rahman, the Palestine Liberation Organization's Washington representative, told the news agency that the next move in the peace process is up to the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak.

In two meetings at the White House, Mr Arafat "presented our position in a positive way," Mr Rahman said. "These were received by President Clinton, and it is now up to Mr Barak."

Several Palestinian officials, speaking on condition they not be identified, said Mr Arafat had also agreed to 12 days of intensive negotiations with Israel.

There was no immediate reaction from Clinton administration officials, who gave no indication after the talks ended near midnight last night that the huge gaps between Mr Arafat's position on key issues and Mr Clinton's outline had been bridged.

However, White House spokesman Jake Siewert told reporters at the end of the talks that Mr Clinton had clarified his proposals in more than three hours of meetings with Mr Arafat.

Mr Barak said earlier yesterday that with the violence persisting he was shifting his attention from Mr Clinton's outline, which he had accepted last week, conditioned on Mr Arafat's approval, to guarding Israel's security against attacks.

Mr Clinton is up against a tight deadline, with only 17 days remaining in his term to try to conclude a peace accord between the two sides. It is his primary foreign policy goal.

The proposal, presented to negotiators for the two sides before Christmas, was designed as a basis for another round of negotiations, and not as an agreement itself.

A senior US official said there was no clear-cut outcome. The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said it will depend on Clinton's follow-up talks with Mr Barak and Mr Arafat.

Mr Siewert said last night that Mr Clinton would call the prime minister early today and telephone Mr Arafat in a day or two for more discussion.

Edward Abington, a former US diplomat and now political consultant to the Palestinians, said: "My understanding is President Arafat has said he is accepting President Clinton's proposal with reservations."

Mr Abington told the AP: "I think it is a positive development if it sets the stage for intensive negotiations."

Stressing that an accord may still be hard to conclude, Mr Abington said the issues facing the two sides remain very difficult.

At the end of yesterday's meetings, Mr Siewert said Mr Arafat had renewed a promise to try to curb the violence that had swept away the good will needed for an accord.

He said: "In the end, words don't matter here. Deeds do."

In focusing on security, Mr Barak had said he saw no real chance of reaching a negotiated settlement in the next few weeks.

On containing conflict with Israel, Mr Clinton scored some gains as Mr Arafat "specifically agreed to end or stop or reduce acts of violence", Mr Siewert said.

Specifically, he said Mr Arafat had promised co-operation in countering terrorism, to intensify efforts to stop the shootings and to arrest those responsible.

Since Middle East violence broke out three months ago, more than 350 people have died, mostly Palestinians.

In respect to stemming the violence, Mr Siewert said, Mr Clinton's meetings with Mr Arafat, one in the Oval Office and the other in a ground-floor library, were "particularly productive."

Mr Arafat made no statement to reporters.

Palestinian officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Mr Arafat concentrated on the issues of Jerusalem and Palestinian refugees, insisting also on reconfiguring the Palestinian state that would emerge from an accord.

State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said the incoming Bush administration was being kept informed of developments.

At a news conference in Austin, Texas, the president-elect said Mr Clinton "is giving it the very best shot he can, and I certainly hope it works."

The Oval Office meeting gave Arafat another chance to seek more control in East Jerusalem than the US plan suggested, a right for millions of Palestinian refugees to live in Israel and a more favourable configuration for a state.

And Mr Siewert said the president "was able to give him a clear understanding of what those parameters are".

"He answered the questions that were asked in a way that was consistent with the parameters that we've laid down," the spokesman said, suggesting Mr Clinton had not retreated on any front.

Lawrence Eagleburger, a former US secretary of state, said he did not think Mr Clinton and Mr Arafat could reach an agreement.

"In a way, I don't even hope I am wrong because if they reach an agreement now, I think it will be a very flawed agreement and not one that can stand the test of time," Mr Eagleburger said on CNN.

webTitle: Supportive approach helps learners flourish

fields.headline: Supportive approach helps learners flourish
fields.standfirst: Nicola Hill meets Workforce client Lee Bokembe, a former asylum seeker and rough sleeper, who has overcome problems with language, numeracy and literacy to acquire the skills he needs to compete in the jobs market
fields.trailText: Nicola Hill meets Workforce client Lee Bokembe, a former asylum seeker and rough sleeper, who has overcome problems with language, numeracy and literacy to acquire the skills he needs to compete in the jobs market
fields.body:
Lee Bokembe came to England from Zaire as an asylum seeker at the age of nine. As a result his education was severely disrupted and he had to cope with langauage problems as well as difficulties with literacy and numeracy.

Other obstacles also cluttered Lee's path, including being put into care and later having to sleep rough for a time. He hasn't had much contact with his family since he came to the UK. These factors resulted in him having little inclination or motivation to get skills and a job. There was too much else on his mind.

Nonetheless, since joining Workforce he has made fantastic progress and has gone from to strength to strength in his goal of getting a qualification and ultimately a job.

Lee was referred to Workforce by the careers service, which felt he would benefit from its innovative training and supportive approach and make best use of his skills. In consultation with a training assessment worker from the charity's unique assessment and guidance service, Lee was enrolled on Workforce's life skills training programme while working towards an NVQ in IT.

Despite having to cope with many outside pressures, Lee made rapid progress with his work and impressed his trainers with his dedication and enthusiasm as well as his determination to build a positive future for himself. So much so that was presented with an award for outstanding achievement in the face of significant obstacles at Workforce's achievement awards 2000 in recognition of his hard work and development.

Currently Lee is part of Workforce's innovative recruitment services programme. He has been working within Workforce's marketing and development team where as a database administrator and an equal opportunities review officer he has been able to use and develop new skills and get used to the demands of a real job.

He has now progressed into working for an external agency on a temporary basis organising a major mailshot to its customers and suppliers, coordinating the activities of a number of his peers.

His time at Workforce has provided some unique opportunities. Following his assistance in a Workforce presentation he was invited to spend the day on UBS Warburg's trading floor, an experience which made him even more determined to do well with his training and get a good job.

He also organised Workforce's annual achievement awards liaising with suppliers, ensuring necessary equipment was secured and contributing to the creative way in which Workforce's services were demonstrated.

Through all of these experiences he has learnt a great deal about working with others, applying IT, the importance of punctuality and meeting objectives and has also raised his expectations in terms of what may be possible for him.

The future looks bright for Lee, ultimately he wants to go into entertainment management and set up his own company. Workforce knows that with his dedication and enthusiasm Lee can achieve anything.

Lee also knows how much he owes the charity; when asked about his time there he shrugs and says: "Workforce is the future of training. It has to be."

webTitle: Handbook shares secrets of charity's success

fields.headline: Handbook shares secrets of charity's success
fields.standfirst: Workforce has become a European leader in helping young people at risk of exclusion from the labour market in their transition from school to training and work - now it is sharing its expertise
fields.trailText: Workforce has become a European leader in helping young people at risk of exclusion from the labour market in their transition from school to training and work - now it is sharing its expertise
fields.body:
Workforce has developed a handbook of good practice in assessment and guidance of young people. Funded by the European Social Fund, the handbook examines new ways of assisting young people at risk of exclusion from the labour market in the transition from school to training or work.

Many young people who have had bad experiences of education or training in the past do not respond well to exam situations or anything that reminds them of school.

Their bad experiences can be due to a range of problems from learning difficulties and disability, through emotional and behavioural problems often linked to family breakdown and trauma, through to language barriers and cultural problems.

Workforce has developed a specialist method of working with disaffected young people to ascertain their skills and offer them a pathway to gaining skills, qualifications and employment, without alienating them further. This method is client centred assessment and guidance that does not set young people tests to enter training but instead aims to ascertain the clients' needs and then to find training that meets those needs.

Assessments are made in an informal environment with assistance available and no time limits to enable the clients to display their skills and staff to find out where difficulties lie. Some assessments are written, others are verbal, practical or IT based.

Guidance about what training is available and appropriate is delivered through the same service so guidance is much better informed and assessment more relevant.

Workforce has worked with a variety of pilots of more "exam based" assessment methods but have found that young people in this client group will refuse to do them and sometimes drop out of the system.

With the client centred model, clients get to discover their own strengths and weaknesses and determine the best way of overcoming their obstacles, gaining qualifications and skills and entering work.

By making this commitment, they make their first step towards reintegration into education, training and employment. As a result of this method, 97% of young people are referred successfully into training.

Workforce provides assessment and guidance to more than 2000 clients a year and has been developing this method of work since 1994 when it won a national award to develop better ways of working with disaffected young people. Since 1997 it has worked with partners in Ireland and Italy to produce a handbook of good practice.

The lessons that Workforce has learned through the development of this process is the integral role of all of the following elements in the process:

Marketing: As a client based system it is essential to develop appropriate marketing of the service to attract young people disaffected from education training and other intervention.

Initial contact: Initial contact is crucial to a positive relationship with the client. This must include sensitive and effective initial screening processes to identify potential barriers to communication.

The assessment and guidance worker (AGW): Staff delivering the service need to have a good awareness of their own attitudes, values and limitations, and to set boundaries to deliver an impartial service.

Relationships: The relationship between staff and clients is the key to success. This relationship must be trusting and carefully developed through group induction, one-to-one work, and a genuine response to the clients' aspirations, desires and goals.

Motivation and inspiration: The process must inspire and motivate young people who have low self esteem and are disenchanted. The service must be personalised by using selected materials, helping to make young people feel valued and ensures that results are specific to the individual.

Assessment and guidance together: Guidance alone can be ill informed without knowledge of skill levels. Assessment alone can be irrelevant if it does not relate to the young person's aspirations and the opportunities available.

Participation: Young people must be offered "reality feedback" to ensure that their aspirations are realistic but they must be helped to identify their own goals, training needs and path to employment.

webTitle: Charity inspires a passion for learning

fields.headline: Charity inspires a passion for learning
fields.standfirst: Munira Omar was jobless, unmotivated and only interested in the extra cash she was entitled to when she first contacted Workforce - but the charity has helped her find enthusiasm and ambition
fields.trailText: Munira Omar was jobless, unmotivated and only interested in the extra cash she was entitled to when she first contacted Workforce - but the charity has helped her find enthusiasm and ambition
fields.body:
Munira Omar is happy to admit that she initially only came to Workforce in May 1999 for the extra allowance she receives as a trainee, and had no interest in learning or gaining a qualification.

Two of her cousins trained with Workforce, one of whom is now studying business finance at university. It was they who persuaded her that she could get a qualification, skills and a job rather than sitting at home all day.

As a result she contacted the charity for an interview, still thinking more about the extra income from the training allowance, rather than a job.

Her assessment with the training guidance service showed that she needed intensive English language support as well as assistance with literacy and numeracy. Working closely with a training assessment worker, Munira decided that she would like to follow in her cousin's footsteps and work towards an NVQ level 1 in admin.

However, it proved difficult to engage Munira in training, she would often fall asleep at her desk and cause disruptions in class. Nonetheless, she made some progress and started on a placement with Unison.

Munira had a supportive supervisor who worked closely with her making sure she gained a wide breadth of experience, helping her see the benefit of gaining a qualification and ultimately a job. Workforce staff visited her frequently at work to ensure that both she and her employer gained as much as possible from the experience.

Munira returned to her training with new found enthusiasm and ambition. Over the past six months she has made terrific progress and has completed an NVQ level 1 in business administration.

However, this is not enough for Munira. Having overcome her basic English language and literacy problems, she has signed up for a computing and English language course with a local college for two days a week starting this month. She intends to continue studying with Workforce the rest of the week to gain further qualifications and with a view to going to university to study business administration.

In the meantime, Munira is one of the first clients to join Workforce's new recruitment services programme, through it she is employed to work as an administration assistant with the training programme ensuring that paperwork on trainees is kept up to date and contact is kept with ex-trainees.

In this way she is learning about the real demands of a real job. She is learning the importance of accuracy and diligence in keeping records, she is working co-operatively with others and completing tasks to exact specifications.

Munira's trainers are delighted by the change in her and the way in which she has made the best possible use of all her opportunities. However, no one is more delighted than Munira herself, who is looking forward to a bright future.

When asked about her hopes for the future, Munira laughs: "I now know that training is what it's all about. If you want to get somewhere you've got to work hard and get the skills and qualifications. Workforce has helped so many people and it's helped me, it's a great place and I'm going to be really sad to leave."

webTitle: EToys shuts down European operations

fields.headline: EToys shuts down European operations
fields.trailText: 3.30pm: Online toy retailer eToys closed down its European operations today with the loss of 74 jobs, writes Polly Sprenger.
fields.body:
Online toy retailer eToys has closed down its European operations with the loss of 74 jobs.

In a bizarre goodbye note, the company chose Bob the Builder to announce the closure of its UK site today.

Beneath a picture of the happy-go-lucky, dungaree-clad children's favourite, the company stated: "Can we fix it? No we can't! Sadly, eToys packs up its toy chest on January 19th".

The company tactlessly added: "But to thank-you for all your custom, we're offering 50% off the original price of all stock! Click here to find out more".

The news comes only two weeks after internet research firm NetValue named eToys as the most successful online toy retailer this Christmas, grabbing 370,000 unique visitors in November and December.

EToys, which launched in the UK in October 1999, blamed its "disappointing recent performance" for the decision to shut down its UK business. The site will cease trading on January 19.

Christmas customers wishing to return purchases are recommended to contact eToys before February 9 if they want a refund.

EToys had warned that such a move was possible as early as December, saying that projections for future sales were poor, and that it would probably be forced to explore a merger or restructuring.

The Californian company said at the time it would soon run out of money, perhaps by spring, and called for "additional, substantial capital infusion".

Its share price sank to 25 cents on the December announcement, valuing the group at $31m.

The company launched a shutdown sale for all items on its UK site on December 29, knocking down prices by at least 50%.
fields.bodyText: Online toy retailer eToys has closed down its European operations with the loss of 74 jobs. In a bizarre goodbye note, the company chose Bob the Builder to announce the closure of its UK site today. Beneath a picture of the happy-go-lucky, dungaree-clad children's favourite, the company stated: "Can we fix it? No we can't! Sadly, eToys packs up its toy chest on January 19th". The company tactlessly added: "But to thank-you for all your custom, we're offering 50% off the original price of all stock! Click here to find out more". The news comes only two weeks after internet research firm NetValue named eToys as the most successful online toy retailer this Christmas, grabbing 370,000 unique visitors in November and December. EToys, which launched in the UK in October 1999, blamed its "disappointing recent performance" for the decision to shut down its UK business. The site will cease trading on January 19. Christmas customers wishing to return purchases are recommended to contact eToys before February 9 if they want a refund. EToys had warned that such a move was possible as early as December, saying that projections for future sales were poor, and that it would probably be forced to explore a merger or restructuring. The Californian company said at the time it would soon run out of money, perhaps by spring, and called for "additional, substantial capital infusion". Its share price sank to 25 cents on the December announcement, valuing the group at $31m. The company launched a shutdown sale for all items on its UK site on December 29, knocking down prices by at least 50%.

webTitle: Differences will make the difference

fields.headline: Differences will make the difference
fields.standfirst: Successful joined-up working can only be achieved by clearly defining and exploiting the differences that exist between working practices and skills throughout the social care sector
fields.trailText: Successful joined-up working can only be achieved by clearly defining and exploiting the differences that exist between working practices and skills throughout the social care sector, writes Daphne Statham
fields.body:
The past years have set the foundations for the reconstruction of social care to link it more closely with health, education, housing and employment. Care trusts are already on the way to being set up in some places. What is this likely to mean for front-line workers?

Making better use of existing human and financial resources has remained a broad objective for some years, but 'better use' has meant different things. In the past, services have targeted people with the highest need assessments of eligibility based on proving high levels of dependency. The result, whatever the original intention, is a requirement on service users and carers to demonstrate weaknesses rather than strengths, expertise and resourcefulness.

A focus on individual deficits underestimates the impact of poverty, poor health, housing, education and unemployment on people's life chances. Social work and social care were treated as interchangeable and identical with what social services departments do, although the vast majority of support for adults is now in the private and voluntary sector.

Stirring it all up like a cake mix led to confusion. In their paper Holding on While Letting Go, David Behan and Ann James argue that thinking through the differences is essential to the modernising agenda.

Their test of success is not new structures, but ensuring that complex vulnerability and new areas of need are addressed. As some groups of service users return to mainstream services, through for example Direct Payments or Sure Start, new needs groups emerge such as refugees, people with HIV/AIDs, drug users and homeless people.

Returning people to mainstream services is critical to tackling poverty and social exclusion and has to be an objective for social services. Adapting housing, accessible transport and local environments reduce isolation and, its all too often consequence, depression. The policies relevant to front-line workers and their managers come from the Department of the Environment, the Department for Education and Employment and the Department of Health.

Jobs are being reconstructed. Joined-up working means that increasingly teams with different skill mixes and workers are coming from different organisations. This makes it even more important that front-line workers and front-line managers are consulted from the planning through to the implementation stages of policy changes. Quite apart from using their expertise and experience and accessing people using services, it is part of 'road testing' innovations to make sure they are workable at the front line.

Social workers and social care staff make different contributions. In all sectors social care staff are the great majority of the workforce. Most social care staff work part-time, do not have relevant qualifications, are women and are employed in the private and voluntary sector. They are not a homogeneous group.

Some are people filling in time until they can train or get another job, while many have a patchwork of jobs in health or social care or in an unrelated area. A growing number are employed under Direct Payments as personal assistants. They support people to live in their own homes or with relatives rather than in hospital or in residential care, they enable disabled people to work and get qualifications.

Their contribution to health, education and employment targets has not been assessed, but should be. The push for appropriately qualified workers will begin to identify who takes on more complicated tasks and who will focus on essential, specific tasks.

Skills are shifting between one group and another. In some places social care staff are giving injections and administering medicines and medical procedures - as indeed are patients and relatives. Shifts in skills and tasks are normal in all workforces and will increase in the social care sector.

Social workers are a tiny minority - some 50-80,000 out of more than a million social sector workers. The new century has seen human rights legislation, an emphasis on citizenship, independence, good outcomes for service users and knowledge defined to include the expertise and experience of service users and practitioners as well as research.

Social work should be a flourishing part of social regeneration, rediscover its skills in capacity building in local communities and with individuals and families. This requires a high level of skill and the ability to work outside social services departments. Called upon when mainstream solutions have failed, the work is complex and highly skilled.

Service users value their experience, expertise, culture and religion being looked at in the round instead of as a collection of problems. They value the time taken to find the best available option. Our evidence is that these skills are crucial in joining up services from different organisations so that by the time they reach the service user they are tailored to their needs.

Ironically, it is through clarity about different contributions and skills that we will be able to deliver a joined-up service for service users and carers.

webTitle: Charity transforms the lives of educationally excluded

fields.headline: Charity transforms the lives of educationally excluded
fields.standfirst: Set up 21 years ago, Workforce is a charity which helps young people with special needs develop their skills and move into the jobs market.  Nicola Hill reports
fields.trailText: Set up 21 years ago, Workforce is a charity which helps young people with special needs develop their skills and move into the jobs market. Nicola Hill reports
fields.body:
In London today, at least 8% of school leavers have no qualifications. The government's drive to tackle basic skills is testimony to the fact that many more lack basic literacy and numeracy skills.

Without basic skills training, young people face disaffection, unemployment and exclusion from mainstream society. They feel alienated by their experience of education and feel that they have been labelled a failure. Most have very low self-esteem and consequently, the motivation to take up education and or training opportunities is in many cases virtually non-existent.

Workforce is a charitable trust, set up 21 years ago, which assists people along every stage of developing skills and finding the right job. Clients of Workforce are young people with special needs such as learning difficulties, physical disability and emotional and behavioural difficulties - 95% need basic literacy and numeracy support.

Graham Finegold, chief executive of Workforce, said: "The two things that all Workforce trainees have in common is that they have all experienced failure and they all want a job."

Based in Shoreditch in east London, Workforce helps more than 2000 people each year to identify and achieve their employment goals. The charity supports people from initial assessment of need into their first job and beyond.

As one of the few organisations in the UK to offer training assessment and guidance to people with special needs, Workforce has developed best practice in these areas.

Mr Finegold added: "This client group can be easily alienated from training, so Workforce's assessment methods are highly specialised to determine skill levels without putting the client off. That's why 97% of assessment and guidance clients are referred successfully into training."

The specialist training programme caters for the needs of up to 80 people at any one time. It offers national qualifications in literacy and numeracy and national vocational qualifications in administration, IT, retail and warehousing.

Workforce has also developed innovative multimedia software to make gaining qualifications more interesting and accessible to clients. Every trainee is able to select elements of training to develop a plan that exactly matches their needs. There are welfare support, life skills training, personal development and confidence building residential activities to help address all clients' needs.

Workforce offers financial support to help clients as they train: an enhanced weekly allowance, travel costs, lunch, childcare, emergency loans, interview and work clothes and a wage subsidy.

Many of Workforce's clients simply cannot get training anywhere else; yet 99% leave training with a qualification - usually the first they have ever received.

Workforce also operates a variety of employment preparation programmes, including one in which trainees learn some key skills "on the job". They are employed by Workforce to deliver work inside the organisation and to complete specific tasks for external agencies as temps.

During this time they continue to train to reinforce the skills they learn in work such as working with others, meeting targets, punctuality and reliability. In addition, trainees can access customised training leading to job opportunities with identifed employers.

Crucially, Workforce keeps in contact with trainees during their time with an employer, offering advice and trying to resolve difficulties. Some 65% of trainees leave training straight into work.

Last year Workforce's training excellence was recognised when it was awarded over £500,000 towards a new centre for learning excellence as part of the government's UK On-Line initiative. The new money will be used by the charity to help build the first centre of training excellence for people with special needs in London - a unique, purpose built centre, with professional staff, specialist multimedia facilities and unrivalled training expertise.

The centre of excellence will combine up to the minute technology, excellent facilities, client centred guidance and inspiring training. A place where young people with special needs are comfortable and stimulated, where they can realise their potential without physical or psychological barriers, where they can get the skills, experience and qualifications to get a job. Workforce has extensive experience in making training work for clients with specialsupport needs but in order to achieve all of this, the charity is seeking additional funds.

Chief executive Mr Finegold said: "Workforce empowers people and destroys myths. For many years it was accepted that people with special needs could not gain qualifications. Now 99% of Workforce's clients gain qualifications. Workforce shows disaffected and disenchanted people with low self esteem that they can control their own lives and achieve a bright future."

webTitle: Bylaw banning public drinking to go national

fields.headline: Bylaw banning public drinking to go national
fields.trailText: An innovative bylaw aimed at reducing drunken assaults has been hailed such a success it will be used as a blueprint for countrywide legislation.
fields.body:
An innovative bylaw aimed at reducing drunken assaults has been hailed such a success it will be used as a blueprint for countrywide legislation.

Police in Manchester said the bylaw, which allows them to seize bottles and glasses of alcohol from people drinking in public places, has led to a reduction in assaults over Christmas and new year and contributed to a 10% drop in crime in the city centre.

On New Year's Eve, police took alcohol from 56 people. It was the first time the bylaw, introduced in September, was tested in Manchester at a big event.

There were 16 arrests, mostly for minor offences and at least 20,000 people were on the streets. All 56 people who were challenged gave up their drinks without protest. If they had refused, they could have been prosecuted and fined up to £1,000.

A Home Office spokeswoman said legislation would be introduced in the police and criminal justice bill, which has yet to be published, which will replace the bylaws by banning the consumption of alcohol in specific public places.

She said the aim was to simplify the bylaws introduced by local authorities, which would make it easier to enforce. The police would also be given powers to arrest people consuming alcohol in public places who refused to hand it over.

The bylaws have been more successful than other law and order initiatives introduced over the past 18 months, such as anti-social behaviour orders and child curfew orders.

Chief Inspector Garry Shewan, of Greater Manchester police, said: "It definitely made a big difference on New Year's Eve. The bylaw was incredibly well observed ... We feel it was a tremendous success."

"Nobody refused to hand over their drink when they were challenged by the police. People understood the relevance of the bylaw."

He said in previous years in Albert Square, where 8,500 people gathered, there had been problems with broken glass as a result of drinking in public.

This year he said there was less drunken loutish behaviour and no one used bottles as offensive weapons. He said there were 47 assaults reported this year compared with 52 assaults during the same period, December 22 to January 2, last year.

"In the last three or four months we have seen a tremendous change and we do not see gangs of young people roaming round from bar to bar with bottles in their hands," he added.

He was encouraged that the Home Office was planning to introduce similar legislation across the country.

Pat Karney, Manchester city councillor, said the message was getting through to the minority of trouble makers - that they would not be tolerated.

"For the first time, I could detect a growing maturity of young people who were celebrating the new year," he said. "Although we want to encourage people to celebrate, we don't want Manchester to become an urban Ibiza.

"We are prepared to go further and to ban people from the city for life if they cause problems such as drinking and fighting."

He said the city centre felt less threatening at midnight on New Year's Eve because of the bylaw.

"Jack Straw has lavished praise on this effort to try to stamp out the yob culture. He knows our approach is working," he added.

Liverpool city council was the first local authority to give police the powers to seize open bottles, cans and glasses of alcohol in specific public places. The bylaw was introduced in July last year and hailed a success by police.

webTitle: TV overnights

fields.headline: Deep Impact slams into competition
fields.trailText: 3pm TV overnights: BBC1 movie premiere Deep Impact pulled in more than 10m viewers, giving ITV's Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? a run for its money. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Movie premiere Deep Impact on BBC1 pulled in more than 10m viewers, giving ITV's Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? a run for its money.

The movie, which is about attempts to destroy an earth-bound asteroid, got a lukewarm critical reception on its theatrical release.

But Deep Impact was just what partied-out new year viewers wanted last night, with an average of 10.5m - 38% of the available audience.

Millionaire pulled in 10.4m on ITV from 8-9pm on a heavy viewing night.

But the show outrated the BBC1 movie for the 55 minutes they were both on air, pulling in 11.7m in its final quarter-hour

Elsewhere last night, Sword of Honour, Channel 4's ambitious adaptation of Evelyn Waugh's second world war trilogy, pulled in a respectable audience of 2.2m and a 9% share over nearly two hours from 9pm.

Sword of Honour, which concludes tonight, was preceded on Channel 4 by The 1940s House, a documentary series following a modern family living for two months in conditions designed to recreate the experiences of a second world war family.

The 1940s House, which has the same format as Channel 4's earlier 1900 House, opened its five-part account with 2.2m and an 8% share.

webTitle: Taxman thought only of poet's royalties

fields.headline: Taxman thought only of poet's royalties
fields.standfirst: Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: Papers released yesterday at the public record office show how the inland revenue, noticing the popularity of Rupert Brooke's poems after he died in the first world war, decided to look again at the taxes he had paid
fields.body:
"If I should die", wrote Rupert Brooke, in his poem, The Soldier, "think only this of me:

"That there's some corner of a foreign field
"That is for ever England".

The poet did not take into account the inland revenue, the agency which above all can bring the most romantic down to earth.

Papers released yesterday at the public record office show how the revenue, noticing the popularity of Brooke's poems after he died in the first world war, decided to look again at the taxes he had paid.

The family's solicitors asked for permission to wind up the estate in 1916, the year after the poet died of blood poisoning abord a naval ship off Greece.

The revenue promptly wrote back noticing that "no mention appears to have been made in the original affidavit or in the present account of the deceased's copyrights and royalties".

The solicitor replied: "There was no value as regards any such assets at the time of the deceased's death.

"We have seen Mrs Parker Brooke, mother of the deceased, and she confirms ... that the copyrights and royalties in existence on her son's death were of no value".

The only book published at his death was a "small volume published in 1911 [called, simply, Poems] and that no profits accrued to the deceased in respect of these nor has she received any."

Brooke's publishers, Sidgwick and Jackson, confirmed "the profit was so trifling that the copyright cannot hardly be said to have any value at the time of his death".

The publishers added: "It is not too much to say that all the pecuniary value of his poetry arose in the first instance out of the circumstances of his death and therefore at the time of his death was non-existent."

The correspondence continued until 1925, 10 years after the poet's death. The revenue finally agreed the "sum of £3 3s 0d for duty".

By then the family had had enough, its solicitor telling the inland revenue it would cost more to reclaim the sum.
