"We have seen Mrs Parker Brooke, mother of the deceased, and she confirms ... that the copyrights and royalties in existence on her son's death were of no value". The only book published at his death was a "small volume published in 1911 [called, simply, Poems] and that no profits accrued to the deceased in respect of these nor has she received any." Brooke's publishers, Sidgwick and Jackson, confirmed "the profit was so trifling that the copyright cannot hardly be said to have any value at the time of his death". The publishers added: "It is not too much to say that all the pecuniary value of his poetry arose in the first instance out of the circumstances of his death and therefore at the time of his death was non-existent." The correspondence continued until 1925, 10 years after the poet's death. The revenue finally agreed the "sum of £3 3s 0d for duty". By then the family had had enough, its solicitor telling the inland revenue it would cost more to reclaim the sum. Useful link Public records office: news and new document releases

webTitle: Email fraudsters jailed

fields.headline: Email fraudsters jailed
fields.standfirst: Special report: Net news
fields.trailText: Two men have been jailed for their part in an email scam that threatened the systems of major internet providers, US authorities said yesterday.
fields.body:
Two men have been jailed for their part in an email scam that threatened the systems of major internet providers, US authorities said yesterday.

Steve Shklovskiy and Yan Shtok, both 23, devised a way to use personal computers to harvest email addresses in September 1999.

They then sent over 50 million emails asking recipients for a $35 (£23) "processing fee", in exchange for a chance to work at home stuffing envelopes. More than 12,000 people were fooled.

Major internet providers - including AOL and AT&T - were besieged by customer complaints and their systems were threatened by the overload.

The two men were sentenced to two years in jail on 27 December - just over a year after they pleaded guilty to fraud charges. Two others were sentenced to probation in July.

Shklovskiy and Shtok were also ordered to pay more than $100,000 (£67,000) in "restitution" - and, under the terms of their plea agreements, required to reveal to the internet providers how the scheme was accomplished.

webTitle: BBC fails to exploit 9pm programming window

fields.headline: BBC under fire for failing to exploit 9pm programming window
fields.standfirst: BBC special report
fields.trailText: 8.45am: The BBC lacks the 'wit or wonga' to exploit the opportunities created by switching its main news bulletin to 10pm, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The BBC lacks the "wit or wonga" to exploit the opportunities created by switching its main news bulletin to 10pm, according to a new TV report.

Media buyers Zenith Media attacked the corporation's decision, made last year, to go head-to-head with ITV's main news programme, which has been moved back to 10pm by watchdogs.

"You've got to wonder just how great an idea it was to move the Nine O'Clock News, which is creating opportunities the BBC hasn't got the wit or wonga to exploit," said Zenith in its quarterly review of TV schedules.

The report said that the BBC will have to wait for months before enough new programmes are stockpiled for the vacant 9pm slot, and has been forced to use star weekend attractions such as the Scarlet Pimpernel.

In the meantime, ITV is expected to capitalise on the BBC's uncertainty with Caroline Quentin drama The Innocent, which will broadcast on Sunday and Monday nights at 9pm.

"If ITV keeps this sort of pressure up for another four months, Greg Dyke will have some explaining to do when the Department for Culture, Media & Sport asks where the BBC news ratings went," it added.

Zenith also attacked Culture secretary Chris Smith, or "Captain Cave-In", for failing to scrap the BBC's board of governors in the communications white paper.

The BBC's board has come under attack from all angles for switching the Nine O'Clock News, and for its lack of independence.

"Presumably the government will await the results of 'consultation' before doing anything as rash as committing to policy or, heavens forfend, principle," Zenith said.

ITV's Popstars, which will create a boyband and follow its quest for fame, is tipped by Zenith to be the winter ratings smash.

"Pop Stars will be huge. It gives the tabloids the biggest ITV story since Millionaire and the best since Big Brother," said the report.

Other programmes that come under Zenith's microscope include:

 Sam's Game, a sitcom starring Davina McCall. "Well worth a punt" because "Davina is a good crowd puller and entirely credible to the 16-34s."

 Crossroads. An early plotline involving disputed ownership of a midlands hotel is "unlikely to kick 16-24-year-olds' butts."

 The Hunt, a new ITV drama starring Amanda Holden. "As safe as IBM and beige" but "will win its segment".

webTitle: 'Why I've not had my baby vaccinated'

fields.headline: 'Why I've not had my baby vaccinated'
fields.trailText: Nurse Ruth Lowles explains her concerns about vaccination:
fields.body:
Nurse Ruth Lowles explains her concerns about vaccination:

"My daughter, Maya, was due to have her first vaccination at the age of eight weeks.

The DPT vaccine is meant to immunise against diphtheria, whooping cough and tetanus, and children are supposed to have it at two, three and four months.

I had heard about possible links between the DPT vaccine and cot death and I wanted to know more before I agreed to have Maya vaccinated. I have major reservations about pumping so many chemicals into such a young child.

I went away to research it and the more I have found out, the more concerns I have. Maya is nearly a year old and I've still not had her vaccinated as I'm still not convinced that it's safe.

My GP said the vaccine is perfectly safe. As a nurse, I know that doctors don't know everything. I spoke to my health visitor about it as well but I felt both she and the doctor were giving out advice which just came from a Department of Health, pharmacological and drug company perspective. I didn't feel I was getting the whole story. I wanted to know about the statistical risk of side effects and long-term effects.

I've been a nurse for the last four years; I do research work in ageing so I've no specialist knowledge of paediatrics or vaccination research. I've done all this as a concerned parent rather than an expert.

If it wasn't for the internet, I don't know where I would have found any information to challenge what the medical profession says. I would particularly recommend the Vaccine Awareness Network (VAN) website, which offers parents all the research findings in an impartial way.

Through VAN, I have found out more about the risks of the DPT vaccine, as well as the links between MMR (the measles, mumps and rubella vaccine) and autism and Crohn's disease - children who have been vaccinated are just as likely to catch measles as those who haven't.

Vaccines have been linked with asthma, eczema, ME, MS and diabetes. Also, there are major concerns about the meningitis C vaccine, which has only been available for a year, so there's not much known about long-term effects.

There is so much pressure put on parents to have their children vaccinated, especially against meningitis because it is such a scary disease.

I have come under pressure from the GP and health visitor to have Maya vaccinated and I have kept asking for longer to think about it - I've still not decided I definitely don't want her vaccinated, I just want to get as many facts together before I choose.

My mum really wants to have her vaccinated and has put pressure on me; she respects my opinion but does not agree with it. And my partner has agreed to live with my decision - but if it was left up to him, he would have had Maya vaccinated.

I am not totally happy about not having Maya vaccinated and I would never say to other parents 'don't have your child vaccinated'. But I would advise parents to find out as much as they can and to not just listen to their doctors, who are actually paid bonuses according to how many children they vaccinate."

 Interview by Clare Horton

webTitle: Meningitis vaccine 'may have saved up to 50 lives'

fields.headline: Meningitis vaccine 'may have saved up to 50 lives'
fields.trailText: The lives of up to 50 children have been saved in the last year by the introduction of a revolutionary new vaccine for meningitis C, the government has announced.
fields.body:
The lives of up to 50 children have been saved in the last year by the introduction of a revolutionary new vaccine for meningitis C, the government has announced.

Cases of the potentially fatal brain disease have fallen by 75% since all under-18s in England and Wales have been immunised.

Experts said they eventually hoped to prevent up to 150 deaths from the C strain of meningitis every year and almost obliterate the disease.

The UK is the first country in the world to develop and introduce a meningitis C vaccine and 18m infants, children and teenagers have been vaccinated since its introduction in November 1999.

New figures released by the Department of Health today showed that cases of the disease have fallen by 90% among 15 to 17 year olds in England and Wales, from 50 in 1999 to five last year.

Just six babies under a year old contracted the disease in 2000 compared with 32 in 1999 - a reduction of 82%.

Overall, the incidence of the disease among under-18s has fallen by 75%, with experts estimating that 500 cases and 50 deaths have been prevented.

Chief medical officer Professor Liam Donaldson said: "This is a wonderful achievement and has dealt a hammer blow to meningitis C - an extremely serious illness if not prevented by the measures we have taken.

"I urge any parent of children and young people under 18 not yet vaccinated to take advantage of the safe and effective protection the vaccine offers and make an appointment to see their GP. There is no need for any child to go unprotected."

Children have been targeted in the immunisation campaign because they are the highest risk group and as yet there are no firm plans to offer the jab to adults, although experts are investigating patterns of the disease in those over 18.

Around 40% of meningitis cases relate to the C strain of the disease, with 60% accounted for by the B strain.

There is still no vaccine for the B strain, although experts in the Netherlands have developed a prototype which British scientists are now looking at. A B strain vaccine developed in Cuba does not work in under-fives and it targets a different strain of the disease from the one prevalent in the UK.

Experts also dismissed fears over the meningitis C vaccine, saying the risks were minimal.

Dr David Salisbury, the government's head of immunisation, said: "With this vaccine we are seeing the disappearance of a disease.

"I believe the vaccine has been shown to be highly effective and completely safe. Any risks associated with the vaccine are nothing compared to the risks associated with the disease."

Sixteen children have died after having the vaccine, but none of the deaths have been found to be related to the jab.

Ministers hailed the news as a success story for the NHS. The Health Minister, Yvette Cooper, said: "It shows that the government was right to bring this vaccine in as rapidly as possible and vaccinate so many children, once it was shown that the vaccine was safe and effective."

In the last six months of 2000, England and Wales went for 22 weeks without a single case of meningitis C in babies under one, compared to just five weeks with no cases in the last six months of the previous year.

From now on only babies of two, three and four months will be vaccinated as routine because all other children should now be protected. Experts believe that once given, the jab should protect from the disease for life.

Denise Vaughan, chief executive of the Meningitis Research Foundation said: "We congratulate the government on the success of the vaccination programme which has been produced through the commitment of all concerned to vital scientific research.

"The foundation is delighted at the impact the vaccine has had in the age groups immunised but believes this reinforces the importance of continued awareness and further research until vaccines are available to protect against all forms of meningitis and septicaemia."

webTitle: US internet losses exceed £1bn

fields.headline: US internet losses exceed £1bn
fields.standfirst: Dot.com deaths: high profile casualties of 2000
fields.trailText: 1.45pm: More than £1bn was lost on US internet ventures last year, writes Polly Sprenger.
fields.body:
More than £1bn was lost on US internet ventures in 2000, says a report on the full scale of last year's online disasters.

According to Californian research, some 210 US internet firm went bust during 2000, with 60% of the companies folding between October and December.

The closures were spread across various sectors in the internet industry, with e-commerce and online content companies making up the bulk of the felled businesses.

Falling along with them were infrastructure and service companies that fed off the dot.com boom. Some 15,000 staff lost their jobs directly because of the company closures, but the real figure could be double that.

Far from being a US phenomenon, a report on MediaGuardian.co.uk - Dec 18: Bankers left reeling - showed that nearly half a billion pounds was spent and lost on internet ventures in this country last year.

webTitle: Coleman in car crash

fields.headline: Coleman in car crash
fields.trailText: Fulham captain Chris Coleman is recovering in hospital after breaking his leg in a car crash.
fields.body:
Fulham captain Chris Coleman is recovering in hospital after breaking his leg in a car crash.

The 30-year-old Welsh international was alone in his Jaguar when it crashed near his Surrey home last night. No other vehicles were involved.

Coleman was taken to the East Surrey Hospital in Redhill where he underwent emergency surgery. A spokeswoman there confirmed he had broken his right leg but would not go into any more detail about his injuries.

She said: "His condition is satisfactory. He is comfortable and in good spirits. He is in good hands and receiving the best care he can."

Coleman is likely to be out of action for the rest of the season.

Meanwhile, Fulham have promised to give the player their full support during the recovery process. Managing director Michael Fiddy said: "Everyone at the club is deeply concerned about the incident involving Chris Coleman.

"At this stage our thoughts are with Chris and we wish him a speedy and full recovery. Chris will be given the best possible care to aid this recovery."

The accident is being investigated by police.

webTitle: Commercial TV giants challenge BBC

fields.headline: Commercial TV giants challenge BBC
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: Commercial broadcasters have got together to fight the BBC's rapid expansion into digital TV, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Commercial broadcasters have forged a powerful alliance to fight the BBC's rapid expansion into digital television.

Seven TV giants including BSkyB, MTV, and Turner Broadcasting have formally linked up and are seeking a summit with culture secretary Chris Smith to air their concerns over the BBC's proposed services.

They say they desperately need to raise awareness among government ministers and MPs about the potentially negative impact of the BBC's plans on its commercial rivals.

The broadcasters are also concerned about the process by which the BBC's proposals, including plans for two new children's services and turning BBC Choice and BBC Knowledge into BBC 3 and 4, are being approved by the government.

Last year Chris Smith introduced new rules requiring the BBC to get approval from the government before proceeding with plans for any new channels.

Commercial rivals say the BBC is ignoring the rules and pressing ahead with its plans to launch services or change its existing services before final approval has been granted by the Department of Culture, Media and Sport.

One source close to the alliance said: "There is a great deal of activity around the BBC's new services, with people being recruited before the consultation process has even begun."

"We're simply seeking to have the level of consultation and transparency that's been indicated by Chris Smith and doesn't seem to be happening."

Greg Dyke, BBC director general, has argued that the BBC's five new services on the two children's channels is a justifiable use of the licence fee because the output is significantly different to that offered elsewhere.

But commercial rivals say the BBC does not even have to stick to "guarantees on minimum UK origination quotas and programming specifications".

The alliance is also expected to lobby culture department officials and MPs. "Everything is being considered," said a senior insider from another broadcaster involved.

The heavyweight lobbying group includes BSkyB, Telewest - whose programming arm Flextech is involved in the UKTV pay-TV channels joint venture with the BBC - and Artsworld, the recently launched arts channel headed by Sir Jeremy Isaacs and backed by investors including the Guardian Media Group.

MTV and Nickelodeon, which are both owned by US broadcasting giant Viacom; Turner Broadcasting, which is the parent company for CNN International and Cartoon Network; and Discovery have also joined the informal alliance.

Disney and ITV companies Granada Media and Carlton Communications were involved in some of the discussions about commercial broadcasters' concerns with the BBC's digital proposals, but have not joined the core lobbying group.

The BBC proposals are expected to be formally submitted to the government in the next fortnight, with a consultation period to follow in which interested parties can submit comments and objections.

But commercial broadcasters are also concerned that they will only be given a limited window, possibly as short as 20 days, to air their worries about the BBC's plans.

"Nobody knows what the timetable is. It hasn't been published," commented a source close to the commercial alliance.

Confusion about the consultation process has raised concerns among the BBC's commercial rivals that they will be presented with a fait accompli over its digital plans.

The informal lobbying alliance is being coordinated by communications firm Lexington, which also worked on the anti-digital licence fee campaign in 1999.

That lobbying effort was launched after the publication in August 1999 of the Davies committee report into the BBC's future funding, which recommended a digital licence fee to finance the corporation's plans for digital expansion.

The digital licence fee proposal was eventually discarded by the government, with Mr Smith instead announcing an across the board hike in the BBC licence fee in February last year.

The individual companies involved in the latest anti-BBC alliance are also conducting their own lobbying over the issue.

MTV and Nickelodeon, which are both owned by US broadcasting giant Viacom; Turner Broadcasting, which is the parent company for CNN International and Cartoon Network; and Discovery have also joined the informal alliance. Disney and ITV companies Granada Media and Carlton Communications were involved in some of the discussions about commercial broadcasters' concerns with the BBC's digital proposals, but have not joined the core lobbying group. The BBC proposals are expected to be formally submitted to the government in the next fortnight, with a consultation period to follow in which interested parties can submit comments and objections. But commercial broadcasters are also concerned that they will only be given a limited window, possibly as short as 20 days, to air their worries about the BBC's plans. "Nobody knows what the timetable is. It hasn't been published," commented a source close to the commercial alliance. Confusion about the consultation process has raised concerns among the BBC's commercial rivals that they will be presented with a fait accompli over its digital plans. The informal lobbying alliance is being coordinated by communications firm Lexington, which also worked on the anti-digital licence fee campaign in 1999. That lobbying effort was launched after the publication in August 1999 of the Davies committee report into the BBC's future funding, which recommended a digital licence fee to finance the corporation's plans for digital expansion. The digital licence fee proposal was eventually discarded by the government, with Mr Smith instead announcing an across the board hike in the BBC licence fee in February last year. The individual companies involved in the latest anti-BBC alliance are also conducting their own lobbying over the issue.

webTitle: UK media firms will survive market tremors say analysts

fields.headline: UK media firms will survive market tremors say analysts
fields.trailText: 2pm: Beleaguered UK media companies including BSkyB and Emap will survive the current stock market battering, according to analysts. By Dan Milmo
fields.body:
Beleaguered UK media companies have received a timely boost from analysts, as fears of an economic meltdown in the US batter European stock markets.

The media team at Credit Lyonnais Securities Europe picked out magazine publisher Emap, music group EMI and satellite broadcaster BSkyB as companies likely to survive the panic that has swamped the sector over the past six months.

"There may still be a need to trim estimates in the short-term, but we very much favour these stocks," said Derek Terrington, media analyst at Credit Lyonnais.

"If you are looking for recovery you have to play spot the bottom line."

The Credit Lyonnais team believe that a flood of profit warnings from US technology and telecoms companies created stock market turbulence that swept up media companies in its wake.

"We believe that the correction last autumn was totally unfounded, failing as it did to differentiate between stocks and going too far," said the research note

"It thus represents an opportunity to move back into the sector on a selective basis."

According to the Datastream index of European media stocks, frantic dumping of media shares in March and October last year sent stock prices down to the level of October 1999.

"We believe that the correction last autumn was totally unfounded, failing as it did to differentiate between stocks and going too far.

"It thus represents an opportunity to move back into the sector on a selective basis," added the research note.

Emap is described as "substantially undervalued" despite mounting speculation that it must sell its trade titles to finance further acquisitions.

EMI is rated as a buy, with a higher share price recommendation if its proposed merger with Bertelsmann's BMG label goes ahead.

Other companies on the 13-strong list include WPP, the world-leading advertising firm that has seen its share price affected over the last few days due to its strong presence in the US market.

However, Credit Lyonnais says WPP is "best placed to benefit from structural changes in the industry" as the advertising market continues to consolidate.

webTitle: Nazi coins and combat games - on sale now at Yahoo

fields.headline: Nazi coins and combat games - on sale now at Yahoo
fields.standfirst:
Jan 3: Yahoo acts on Nazi auctions
Why all the fuss: a print-out-and-keep guide
fields.trailText:
More than 2,000 items of Nazi memorabilia are up for sale on Yahoo's auction site, writes Polly Sprenger.
Jan 3: Yahoo acts on Nazi auctions
Why all the fuss: a print-out-and-keep guide
fields.body:
When Yahoo begins to purge its auction site of material related to hate groups such as the Ku Klux Klan and the Nazis, it will certainly have its work cut out.

For there are more than 2,000 items of Nazi memorabilia up for sale, with 16 lots relating to the Ku Klux Klan.

Nazi items range from a smattering of Hitler coins to propaganda posters promoting the Third Reich. One seller is pitching an authentic Nazi newspaper for $15.50 while another is floggin a rare Nazi combat game for $75.00.

Ku Klux Klan items are mostly patches advocating membership of different regional Klan groups.

There are 325 items relating to Nazi and fascist leaders, including a set of three colour portraits of Hitler, Goering and Mussolini.

"These are great-looking in person," says the seller, "very vibrant colour and suitable for framing".

Yahoo is halting the auctions at the behest of US lobby groups. At the same time it has announced it is will charge sellers a small fee for items sold through its auction site.

In an oversight, the company notified the world's media but neglected to tell customers about the decision to begin censoring auctions on January 10,. A notice on the auction site today only told viewers about the new fees.

webTitle: Dangerous talk of war

fields.headline: Dangerous talk of war
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel & Middle East
fields.trailText: Ehud Barak has instructed his military commanders to draw up contingency   plans for a regional war, as the smaller but still uglier conflict between   Israel and the Palestinians rages unchecked.
fields.body:
Ehud Barak has instructed his military commanders to draw up contingency plans for a regional war, as the smaller but still uglier conflict between Israel and the Palestinians rages unchecked.

To some extent, no doubt, the Israeli prime minister is sabre-rattling. As a former army chief himself, he can't resist reminding his Arab neighbours who is top dog in the Middle East.

But there is a real danger that the talk of war will turn into something more substantial and infinitely more horrible.

It is fairly clear now that the peace process in its present form is dying, if not dead. It has been mortally wounded by the Palestinian intifada (uprising), now in its fourth bloody month. The coup de grace is likely to be administered by the incoming George W Bush administration in Washington.

Bush's line on the Middle East is likely to be markedly different from that of his predecessor. Bill Clinton devoted huge amounts of time, energy and emotion to the region. Bush, in his election campaign, paid scant attention to foreign affairs.

When Bush takes over the White House, his attention is likely to be dominated by domestic concerns. He will, according to US commentators, be happy to delegate diplomatic policy to his Secretary of State, Colin Powell, and Powell's deputy, Edward Djerijian.

Both men have widespread knowledge of, and interest in, the Middle East. But - and this could be a vital factor in the coming months and years - their primary concern is to shore up US interests in the oil-producing nations of the Arabian peninsula, and contain the perceived threat to those interests posed by Iran and Iraq.

In the perception of the Bush team, the Israel-Palestine dispute is a second-division issue.

It is unthinkable that any Washington administration would cut America's umbilical link with Israel, which US taxpayers subsidises to the tune of some $3bn a year. But the Israelis, after eight years of fawning reassurances from the White House, are going to have to work much harder for presidential patronage.

They are already trying. Israel is loudly crying wolf over the latest boast by Saddam Hussain that he will "solve the Zionist problem once and for all".

The threat is bombastic, almost comically so, but Israelis who remember Iraq's Scud missile bombardment of their cities during the Desert Storm war ten years ago are not likely to see the joke. Nor, of course, is ex-general Colin Powell, who led the Desert Storm allies.

Saddam is once again assuming the mantle he loves best: that of leader of the entire Arab nation. There lies the real threat. To most Westerners, he may seem a clown, albeit a bloody-handed one. To many Arabs, he is indeed a leader; one who not only articulates their hatred of Israel, but is prepared to take on the might of the USA.

Saddam is a threat not only to Israel, but to its neighbours, especially Egypt and Jordan. They are the only Arab nations with embassies in Tel Aviv, the result of peace treaties which are searingly unpopular still.

The Egyptian president who came to terms with Israel, Anwar Sadat, paid for it with his life, and the militant Islamist movement remains a constant threat to his authoritarian successor, Hosni Mubarak.

In Jordan, Palestinian refugees and their descendants make up more than half the population. The regime of King Abdullah, benign and tolerant by regional standards, lives in the perpetual twin shadows cast by Saddam Hussain to the east, and simmering unrest among the refugees.

That is why both Egypt and Jordan are discreetly nudging Yasser Arafat towards a peace settlement, with as much honour as he can retain. But Arafat too must take acount of his own 2m subjects in the Gaza Strip and on the West Bank.

More than 300 Palestinians have died since the end of September, and countless thousands have been wounded. Most live in squalor, and their misery has been compounded by Israel's strict military blockade.

If their leader comes to terms with Israel now, he cannot expect to retain their devotion, which has been remarkably constant through seven years of uncertainty and sacrifice.

The blockade of the Palestinian territories is also, oddly enough, one of the main reasons for Israel to redouble its efforts for peace. The country's economy, which grew last year by an impressive 5.9%, has been hammered by the sudden unavailability of cheap Palestinian labour, particularly in the agriculture and construction industries.

But Ehud Barak's main motivation for one last tilt at peace is that he needs a deal desperately if he is to have any chance of holding on to his job.

Israelis go to the polls on February 6 to choose their prime minister. As things now miserably stand, they will go for the fire-breathing rightwing challenger, Ariel Sharon.

Sharon, who has threatened to bomb the Palestinians of the occupied territories into submission, is by far the Arabs' most hated Israeli. His election as prime minister would be seen widely in the region as a declaration of that war which until now has been only a talking point.

webTitle: Public records: British envoy scorned Evita 'pantomime'

fields.headline: Evita 'pantomime' scorned by our man in Buenos Aires
fields.standfirst:
Diplomat's view at odds with later images of Eva Peron

Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: Diplomat's view at odds with later images of Eva Peron.
fields.body:
Eva Peron, the populist heroine of Argentine post-war politics, was secretly regarded by the Foreign Office as "a dangerous but very remarkable woman" whose mass appeal owed more to pantomime than to politics, according to confidential Whitehall papers released at the public record office today under the 50 year rule.

The secret dispatches from the British ambassador in Buenos Aires sent while she and her husband, Juan Peron, occupied the presidential palace, were scathing in their assessment of the Peronist regime - a judgment fully supported in London by the foreign secretary, Ernest Bevin, and his Foreign Office civil servants.

The dispatches paint a picture at odds with the glamorous image portrayed in Andrew Lloyd Webber's musical, Evita, and by Madonna's film of her life.

In January 1950 a dispatch from the ambassador, Sir John Balfour, reporting rumours that an operation for appendicitis might actually have been something more serious is greeted in London by the hostile comment: "Whatever the truth of these rumours, nothing but good could result from a prolonged spell of ill health."

A second file reveals that in October 1950 she instructed Argentine diplomats in Europe to approach the Belgian, Dutch and Swedish governments to request she be given their highest decorations.

She turned down the offer of an honour from Belgium on the grounds that it was of not a high enough category and officials in London feared that it might soon be Britain's turn.

"I would not put it past her to ask for the Order of the Garter! Evita's ambitions are apparently unbounded. The next feelers, I estimate, are likely to be put out in Norway, Denmark and the Vatican! ... This is really getting beyond a joke," warned a note on the Foreign Office file by a senior civil servant in London.

The bulk of the files released today cover an account by the ambassador of a luncheon held in honour of the maiden voyage of a British built liner, the Eva Peron, at which Sir John sat next to the president's wife and had a "tete a tete". He reported that the main fixture in the lounge aboard the liner was a "full length, theatrically-painted portrait of the senora in a golden decollete evening dress. Her admirers having drawn attention to this garish picture, she and the president gazed upon it with admiration".

When the band struck up the "march of the Peronist youth" praising the president, the senora "intoned the words with the gusto of a schoolgirl on holiday".

The ambassador told the Foreign Office in London that in the case of Eva Peron "all the symptoms are present of a fatal self-preoccupation". She portrayed herself as the "tireless handmaiden of her husband" but in reality she was the mainspring of national activities and largely responsible for "making the welfare of the workers the foremost preoccupation of the state". But alongside this achievement lay "prodigal expenditure and demagogic propaganda with an eye to vote catching, the haphazard grant of favours, vindictive appeals to class hatred, corruption and the enrichment of persons in high places by dubious means".

This was not the worst of her character, according to Sir John. "Above all the projection on to the stage of national politics of the technique of the vaudeville - not to say pantomime - by a woman who, until her meeting with the Peron, had had no knowledge of public life other than that vouchsafed to a minor actress or film star ... bodes ill for the future."

The ambassador described Evita as the "embodiment of Latin American adolescence". Like Argentina itself she was vainglorious, self-assertive and childishly irrational, Sir John said, adding that her emotional appeal was based on promoting her compatriots from the pit to seats of unaccustomed privilege in the stalls.

He predicted that the spectacular success of this leading actress, as he called her, was only likely to last as long as "tickets can be procured from the official box office at popular prices".

webTitle: Iraq denies Saddam heart attack rumour

fields.headline: Iraq denies Saddam heart attack rumour
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: The Iraqi government today dismissed rumours that President Saddam Hussein is seriously ill after suffering a heart attack or stroke.
fields.body:
The Iraqi government today dismissed rumours that President Saddam Hussein is seriously ill after suffering a heart attack or stroke.

The 63-year-old Iraqi dictator is said to be in hospital after collapsing at a military parade in Baghdad.

Rumours have been rife since Sunday, when television screens went blank without explanation as he appeared in a live broadcast holding a rifle during the parade.

London-based independent opposition spokesman Dr Mowaffak Al-Rubaie said that "unusual" activity had been reported on the streets of Baghdad.

"Something unusual has happened but we do not know exactly what has gone on," he said. "There has been a heightened security presence on the street. There are more police and military units around."

But an Iraqi government spokesman said the president was in good health. "The whole world saw President Saddam Hussein who, for more than five hours, stood strong in saluting the units of our valiant army during the parade" on Sunday, the spokesman said.

webTitle: Nasdaq decline impacts on European stocks

fields.headline: European stocks suffer as Nasdaq falls
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: A 7.2% decline in the US-based Nasdaq index has triggered falls in European stocks, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The relentless decline of the US-based Nasdaq index sent another wave of tremors through European stocks this morning.

Fears of a crash landing for the US economy, combined with a series of profits warnings from US technology and telecoms companies, are sowing seeds of panic in brokers' offices across the Atlantic.

Latest figures from the US show a deepening downturn in manufacturing, causing the Nasdaq to plunge by 7.2% overnight.

"The rapid deceleration of the US economy is making people very worried about the short term outlook for technology stocks. Until we see how deep the slow-down is, it will be difficult to tell how far stocks will fall," said Alan Torry, technology fund manager at SG Securities.

As the UK and Europe absorbed the news, advertising giant WPP fell a further 1.8% after recent declines, while Finnish mobile company Nokia fell nearly 6% and the high-tech Neuer Markt 50 index in Germany shed 5.4%.

"The market has just started to take on the fact that the US economy might be slowing down more rapidly than we thought. Any media stock with exposure to the US, such as WPP, is going to be hit," added Colin McLean, fund manager at Scottish Value Management.

Other fund managers pointed out that UK telecoms, media and technology companies have stronger links with US firms than other European companies, and so are likely to be seriously affected by a US downturn.

However, the drastic situation with the Neuer Markt is the latest blow for an index reeling from a series of points losses, sparked by profits warnings from technology stocks.

But UK markets fared little better in early trading, with the FTSE TechMark list losing 2.7% and the flagship 100 list dropping 0.9%.

Any media stock with exposure to the US, such as WPP, is going to be hit," added Colin McLean, fund manager at Scottish Value Management. Other fund managers pointed out that UK telecoms, media and technology companies have stronger links with US firms than other European companies, and so are likely to be seriously affected by a US downturn. However, the drastic situation with the Neuer Markt is the latest blow for an index reeling from a series of points losses, sparked by profits warnings from technology stocks. But UK markets fared little better in early trading, with the FTSE TechMark list losing 2.7% and the flagship 100 list dropping 0.9%.

webTitle: Yahoo! to stop auctions of Nazi memorabilia

fields.headline: Yahoo! to stop auctions of Nazi memorabilia
fields.standfirst: Special report: Net news
fields.trailText: Yahoo! is to stop carrying online auctions of Nazi artifacts and other hate-related materials.
fields.body:
Yahoo! is to stop carrying online auctions of Nazi artifacts and other hate-related materials.

The new restrictions, which take effect a week from Wednesday, follow November's court ruling from France requiring Yahoo! to block such items from French users.

Although Yahoo! has insisted it cannot limit access to certain geographic regions, as the French court ordered, Yahoo! may effectively comply by blocking the items from everyone.

The new guidelines will also apply to the site's classified listings and its e-commerce partners. Yahoo! search directories, chat rooms and other areas are not affected.

The senior auction producer at Yahoo!, Brian Fitzgerald, said the court order played no role in the new policy, other than to raise awareness internally and speed the decision.

"We decided we don't necessarily want to profit from items that promote hatred or glorify hatred and violence," Fitzgerald said.

He said that while some users support the trade of such items on free speech grounds, the majority of comments received by Yahoo! were in opposition.

When the new policy takes effect, Yahoo! will also begin screening items before they are listed. Computer software will reject any item that appears to violate the site's policies. Users will be able to appeal rejections to a human being.

Auction sites have typically rejected items only after they are posted.

Beginning next Wednesday, Yahoo! will also charge sellers to list an item - although it will not collect a commission on sales. Other auction sites, including eBay and Amazon, already charge for both.

The newly banned items at Yahoo! include medals, weapons, uniforms, official documents and other items that carry swastikas or other symbols associated with hate groups. They join a banned list that now includes cigarettes, live animals and used underwear.

The leading online auction site, eBay, bans hate materials only in Germany, France, Austria and Italy - countries where such items are illegal. Sellers may not ship such items there, and buyers from those countries may not bid on them.

In April, two French groups sued Yahoo! under its old policies, accusing the US company of violating French law barring the display or sale of racist material.

A French judge ruled in November that Yahoo! must prevent French users from auctions of such items, or face $13,000 a day in fines. On December 21, the company asked a US court to block the order, saying France doesn't have jurisdiction.

webTitle: Taiwan's little ships sail into China, and history

fields.headline: Taiwan's little ships sail into China, and history
fields.standfirst: Special report: Taiwan and China
fields.trailText: Having arrived in China on the first ships to sail in legally from Taiwan in 51 years, the Taiwanese visitors yesterday set about promoting the kind of exchanges they hope will now gain pace.
fields.body:
Having arrived in China on the first ships to sail in legally from Taiwan in 51 years, the Taiwanese visitors yesterday set about promoting the kind of exchanges they hope will now gain pace.

Chen Shui-tsai, who led a delegation of Taiwanese officials to the southern Chinese city of Xiamen, lunched with Chinese officials responsible for Taiwan relations and met the mayor.

These contacts mark a breakthrough. Unofficial trade with the mainland has been brisk for some time, but the three ships that arrived yesterday morning from the Taiwanese-controlled islands of Quemoy and Matsu are the first allowed to cross legally since 1949, when Taiwan split from China amid civil war.

The opening of formal transport links with China is limited to Quemoy and Matsu. Direct travel from Taiwan's main island is still prohibited by Taipei. Although China's communist rulers have never governed Taiwan, they claim it as part of their territory and threaten to use military force if it insists on pressing its independent statehood.

Taiwanese hope that even yesterday's small opening will stabilise their problematic relationship with China. They also hope it will put a damper on the booming illicit trade in seafood, produce and consumer goods between the islands and the mainland, so that legitimate business and investment take over.

China wants direct contacts with Taiwan proper and only grudgingly agreed to the routes from the lesser islands. China's main state-run media ignored the visits.

In Taipei, however, the mood was buoyant. The stock exchange closed 4.13 percentage points up yesterday and Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said the links could be "a very important step to herald the end of confrontations that have prevailed for 51 years".

"We hope this presents a new opportunity to establish stable, peaceful and mutually prosperous relations," he said.

Crowds of well-wishers with firecrackers and dragon dancers saw the vessels off from Quemoy and Matsu, which lie just off the Chinese coast.

A few hours later they docked to low-key greetings in Xiamen and Mawei, ports in China's Fujian province.

In Xiamen, some 200 onlookers climbed on top of piles of building materials and clambered up a fence for a better view of the two ships that arrived there. Many had heard about the visit from Taiwanese television, easily received in Xiamen. Some returned waves from the Taiwanese, others simply stared.

A third ship travelling from Matsu arrived almost simultaneously in Mawei. On board were worshippers of the deity Matsu, the patron of fishermen popular in Taiwan and south-eastern China. They planned to carry her image to a nearby shrine.

Taiwan opened the routes without consulting Beijing, which officially labels the move an insignificant publicity stunt.

China wants Taiwan instead to make political concessions to allow talks on comprehensive links, but Taiwan worries that could cost it bargaining power in future negotiations over its status.
AP

webTitle: Yahoo acts on Nazi auctions

fields.headline: Yahoo acts on Nazi auctions
fields.standfirst:
Why all the fuss: a print-out-and-keep guide
Nov 20: Yahoo ruling hailed as landmark case
fields.trailText:
12.30pm: Yahoo is to halt the sale of Nazi memorabilia on its websites in the wake of a French court ruling, writes Polly Sprenger.
Why all the fuss: a print-out-and-keep guide
Nov 20: Yahoo ruling hailed as landmark case
fields.body:
Yahoo is to halt the sale of Nazi memorabilia on its websites in the wake of a ruling from a French court.

For the first time the company will employ staff and use software to actively monitor what is posted on its site in a bid to stamp out "hateful and offensive" material.

The move comes after pressure was applied on Yahoo by lobby groups including the Simon Wiesenthal Centre. Starting on January 10, Yahoo will be preventing the auction of items related to groups including the Ku Klux Klan and the Nazi party, said Sue Jackson, spokeswoman for Yahoo Europe.

"We didn"t want to help people profit from the sale of these items," Ms Jackson said.

Yahoo has come under fire for allowing the sale of items including a swastika T-shirt, an SS recruitment poster and a print of a watercolour painted by Adolf Hitler.

Ms Jackson acknowledged that there would be grey areas, which is why staff have been appointed to consider specific cases.

But the company denied that the decision to monitor auctions was a result of November's court ruling, in which French judges decided that the auction of Nazi memorabilia violated French law.

Ms Jackson said that while the case had brought the issue to Yahoo's attention, the company would still appeal the court's decision.

French judges ruled that even though the company is incorporated in the US, it should be held accountable under the same rules that govern the activities of French internet companies.

Yahoo believes that holding foreign companies accountable to local laws sets a dangerous precedent.

Yahoo appealed to a US district court on December 21 to overturn the ruling. if the judge finds in the company's favour, the French organisations that brought the original charge could appeal.

Legal experts fear that that contradictory rulings from US and French courts could leave the dispute ending in a stalemate, with no international body having the authority to resolve the issue.

Yesterday's announcement comes as part of a number of modifications to Yahoo's online auction service, including the introduction of a listing fee for all sales made through the site.

Yahoo lists around 150,000 new auction items every day and has until now let sellers advertise those items at no charge.

In a statement last night, the company said: "We believe a nominal listing fee will ultimately further improve the quality of our auctions service, thereby providing our buyers and sellers with an even more compelling experience."

Yahoo relies heavily on online advertising for its revenue, which totalled nearly $300m in the third quarter of 2000.

The move to charge for auctions reflects falling confidence in the internet advertising market, which accounts for about 80% of Yahoo's revenue.

webTitle: The unofficial winter crisis best practice guide

fields.headline: The unofficial winter crisis best practice guide
fields.trailText: A good practice guide on tackling the pressures of winter as outlined in the Department of Health winter plan. By Juliet Shedden
fields.body:
Ensuring the NHS does not slip into winter crisis is top of the priority list for the service. This guide draws upon the examples of good practice in tackling winter pressures contained in the Department of Health winter plan published in November.

The examples cover good practice in intermediate care; primary care; ambulance services; hospital services; critical care; accident and emergency modernisation, and joint working in social care.

It supplies all the relevant contact information for those trusts mentioned in the plan, so whatever your winter pressures problem, discovering a good practice solution is just a click or phonecall away.

Good practice: intermediate care

Nelson and West Merton primary care group in south London has an intermediate care service that offers a 24-hour immediate response to crises and pre-planned packages of care. The care team comprises health and social care professionals delivering care in a range of settings - the patient's home, a residential or nursing home, or in a community hospital. A computerised "alert register" accessible to GP practices, social services and accident and emergency departments identifies patients who are judged to be "at risk" and helps plan their care and treatment. The aim is to reduce or eliminate the revolving door syndrome through active management and contingency planning.
Nelson & West Merton Primary Care Trust
Organisations code: 4MQ34
Address: Hamilton Wing, Nelson Hospital, Kingston Road, London SW20 8DB
Telephone: 020-8251 1111
Fax: 020-8251 1122
Chief executive: Ian Ayres
Contact: Ian Ayres, 020-8251 1118

Good practice: primary care

East Surrey PCG is introducing primary care centres adjacent to A&E. These will act as a walk-in centre during the day, assisting local practices in meeting their access targets. In the out of hours period the centres will act as part of the primary care out of hours cover working with practices and the local deputising service. The centres will also work with A&E. The new structure will result in a much more effective use of resources and improve access. The GP home visiting service should be used more effectively.

East Surrey Health Authority

Fax: 01372 729841

Good practice: ambulance services

Joint working between Carlisle hospitals, Cumbria ambulance service and a recent health action zone (HAZ) bid has allowed the emergency department to place a nurse practitioner on front-line vehicles. This allows the nurse practitioner service to deliver care directly to people in more isolated rural areas. It is aimed at preventing avoidable attendance at A&E departments, particularly in the minor injury category of patients. So far, figures show one in three patients are assessed, treated and discharged at the scene by the practitioner.

Address: Salkeld Hall, Infirmary Street, Carlisle CA2 7AN
Telephone: 01228 596909

Fax: 01228520382

Staff working in the West Yorkshire ambulance service patient transport service have undertaken additional training to provide an A&E support service. They will work double-handed to support the A&E service with the transport of less acute transfers between hospitals and will also handle some of the less acute admissions.

Good practice: hospital services

At Trafford General Hospital the A&E department has been rebuilt providing additional capacity and a larger resuscitation area. The unit includes dedicated space for a GP and there is a mental health liaison area as well as special facilities for children. The hospital has made available an additional 12 beds to cope with winter pressures as part of the trust's contribution to the Greater Manchester emergency admissions plan.

Trafford General Hospital
Address: Moorside Road, Urnston, Manchester M41 5SL
Telephone: 0161 748 4022
Chief executive: Dave Cain
Contact: Roy Harding, general manager for surgery, 0161 746 2431

The King's Mill Centre in Mansfield has developed an augmented care assessment tool (ACAT), which allows all medical and surgical patients to be monitored by the intensive care outreach scheme. All patients are monitored using a simple but objective scoring tool which acts as early warning system. If the patient's condition begins to deteriorate, they are identified quickly and senior medical staff are contacted. This helps prevent further deterioration and ultimately prevents avoidable intensive care admissions and further complications.

The Kings Mill Centre For Health Care Services NHS Trust
Organisations code: RK5
Address: Mansfield Acute Unit, Kings Mill Hospital, Mansfield Road, Sutton-in-Ashfield, Nottingham NG17 4JL
Telephone: 01623 622515, x4157
Contact: John McCulloch, community relations manager 01623 622515, x4157
Chief executive: John Watkinson

Frimley Park Hospital in Surrey has introduced a medical emergencies team (MET) which respond to medical emergencies. This ensures senior medical involvement at an early stage through the use of a medical scoring tool. This system helps prevent morbidity and mortality and shows early but promising results. This system is a good working example of a district general hospital being able to improve dramatically medical response to illness. The audit system and the way in which it is disseminated throughout the trust is a good example of how clinical audit can be used, and has the potential for use in other district general hospitals.

Address: Frimley Park Hospital, Portsmouth Road, Frimley, Surrey GU16 5UJ
Telephone: 01276 604604
Contact: David Price 01276 604313, media and communications manager (pager 07659 129987)

The paediatric outreach nursing initiative (PONI) at the Royal Liverpool Hospital was developed to meet the needs for short stay medical admissions and provide enough nursing support to prevent a hospital admission. A common type of caseload is respiratory illness, gastroenteritis, and fever. The total number of patients who have been referred to this service to date is 196. The average length of stay during a hospital admission is approximately three days. Therefore this service alone, has resulted in a prevention of 588 inpatient bed days within the first 12 months.

Alderhay, Royal Liverpool Children's Hospital
Address: Eton Road, Liverpool L12 2AT
Chief executive: Tony Bell
Contact: Lesley Chesworth, outreach lead nurse, 0151 252 5064
Telephone: 0151 228 4811

Good practice: critical care

Leeds Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust has made an additional 12 critical care beds available this winter compared with last. In Hull, the Hull and East Yorkshire Hospitals NHS Trust, is making an additional 21 critical care beds available. These hospitals are the key units for the delivery of specialised services in developing networks for West and East Yorkshire. This will reduce the need for transfers of patients away from their home areas and ensure specialist staff and their equipment can be fully utilised over the winter.

Address: St James's University Hospital, Beckett Street, Leeds LS9 7TF

Contact: Alison Guy, director of performance management, 01482 674922

Birmingham Heartlands and Solihull NHS Trust is staffed to support a nine-bed intensive care unit and a four-bedded high dependency unit (HDU). Over the next six weeks the HDU bed numbers will increase to eight. Six months ago the unit employed a number of international recruits from the Philippines and Malaysia, in the knowledge that following a six-month preceptorship period they would be able to register with the UKCC and work as D/E grade staff nurses within the unit. The unit is fully staffed at present and anticipates a more productive winter period because of the strategic planning.

East Gloucestershire NHS Trust has appointed a nurse consultant with the object of developing and implementing a critical outreach service to wards. This will encompass pre and post-critical care helping to avert admissions, enable the earlier but safe and appropriate discharge of patients from critical care units and share specialist skills with general ward practitioners. Crucially, it will free beds for extremely urgent patients with complex needs.

East Gloucestershire NHS Trust
Address: 14 Royal Crescent, Cheltenham, Gloucestershire GL50 3DA
Telephone: 01242 222222
Contact: Yvonne Ray, communications manager, 01242 274733

Good practice: A&E modernisation

Ealing NHS Trust has improved facilities including an upgrade of the acute assessment unit, provision of dedicated children's services and facilities for GP cooperatives and social services. £400,000 was invested in modernisation work which was completed in November 1999.

Ealing Hospital NHS Trust
Organisations code: RC3 Address: Uxbridge Road, Southall, Middlesex UB1 3HW
Telephone: 020-8967 5000
Contact: Dr Simon Payne, clinical director of A&E, 020-8967 5403

In St Mary's Hospital, Isle of Wight refurbishment has included the development of an eight-bedded assessment unit, improved treatment areas for A&E attendees and the installation of CCTV to improve security for both patients and staff. This will enable better management of patients and future integration with primary care and out of hours services. £300,000 has been invested with the overall aims of reducing waiting periods and inappropriate admissions, and improving communications between primary and secondary care and better security. The modernisation scheme was completed in May 2000.

Telephone: 01983 524081
Fax: 01983 822569
Website: www.iowht.org.uk

Contact: Viv Bennett, 01983 534184

Good Practice: intermediate care/social care

Manchester and North Essex have trained nursing staff to carry out care needs assessments on behalf of social service departments in order to overcome delays due to staff shortages. North Essex Health Authority

Telephone: 0161 237 2000
Fax: 0161 237 2001
Website: www.manchesterhealth.co.uk
Chief executive: Neil Goodwin
Contact: Bridgit Smith, care task force manager, 0161 237 2466

Hinchingbrooke Hospital in Cambridgeshire has introduced staff rotation schemes with the local social service department to improve liaison over elderly placements and understand better what may be achieved in a community setting.

Hinchingbrooke Hospital
Address: Hinchingbrooke Park, Huntingdon, Cambridgeshire PE18 8NT
Telephone: 01480 416416

webTitle: Yahoo: a print-out-and-keep guide

fields.headline: Yahoo's legal treacle
fields.standfirst: Today's decision by Yahoo to block the sale of nazi memorabilia follows a ruling by a Paris court that Yahoo must stop French internet users from buying Nazi memorabilia on its site. Yahoo is challenging the decision in the US in a case that could have widespread ramifactions for the freedom of speech and flow of information across continents. Amy Vickers provides a print-out-and-keep guide to what it all means.
fields.trailText: Yahoo's Nazi auction row: a print-out-and-keep guide
fields.body:
What's all the fuss about?
Selling Nazi-related items, such as books, daggers, SS badges and uniforms, is illegal in France. The case was brought to court by the Paris-based International League against Racism & Anti-Semitism (LICRA) and the Union of French Jewish Students (UEJF). A third French anti-racist group, MRAP, joined the action at a later stage. As in Germany and several other European countries, the law prohibits profiteering from anything to do with the Nazis and the holocaust. While Yahoo's French-language portal, Yahoo.fr, does not host such auctions, French internet users can log on to Yahoo.com and bid for Nazi memorabilia.

Nazism is offensive, so why didn't the upstanding officers of Yahoo concede?
Yahoo believes a wider principle is at stake that could affect all sorts of services in future. It argues that its English language Yahoo.com services are US-governed and that auctions of Nazi material cannot be barred because of US constitutional rights to freedom of speech. The ruling marks the first time that a judge has accepted a technological solution as a way to enforce a domestic law on the internet.

And...
Yahoo is saying that the ruling has disastrous implications for free expression around the world. Greg Wrenn, Yahoo's associate general counsel for international affairs, said the case questioned the sanctity of the internet as a conduit for free speech. He said the ruling set a very dangerous precedent. Today he said the monitoring initiative might have some bearing on Yahoo's case with the French court. "I would hope that it would show to them that we have thought about these issues in good faith," he said.

What do the American internet kings think?
They are watching nervously. The ruling could have repercussions on other big US internet businesses that tap into local markets, especially Amazon.com and eBay, who also operate auction-type operations in France. However, to date, the two have eluded nasty lawsuits over sales of Nazi items in France mainly because they have always toed the line.

EBay has technology that can detect internet users' French language browsers so as to prevent online auctions of Nazi memorabilia in France. And eBay's French site, launched last month, prevents searches for Nazi-related auction items. Amazon also says it uses proprietary software to flag mailing addresses in France and block the sale of anything that violates French law.

Quentin Archer, partner at Lovell White Durrant, said he wouldn't be surprised if Germany got in on the act now. "Yahoo should now take advice on German law so as not to invite any more litigation," he said. Despite the ruling, Mr Archer says it is still uncertain ground. "Blocking access is the main worry, but it's expensive, awkward and irritating." He says the best thing to do when faced with any form of litigation is to take immediate action and, when appropriate, remove offending articles.

What's the big deal?
Yahoo's big French adventure has gone belly up. Yahoo has effectively been kicked into touch and the whole world is watching to see how it will react. The reason why Yahoo is not going to shy away from this issue is that it says it is technically difficult to identify the computer address of users visiting its sites. An international panel of internet experts appointed by the court testified that there was no foolproof remedy to screen all French users, and that possibly some 70% of users could be detected. Yahoo disputes even that figure because it distributes user traffic from several global locations, a fact that can mask users' actual location if they're routed outside of France.

What are the laws governing the internet?
There aren't any. It's governed by national laws but obviously problems arise when cross-border boundaries are infringed. According to Kannan Arunasalam, a partner at law firm Biddle, international internet law would never work.

"I can't see how individual countries, such as China, Saudi Arabia and India, would ever be happy with an international law as there are far too many national conflicts," he said, citing a case in Saudi Arabia where Yahoo had to pull out because of the very strict laws on porn.

Talking about the implications of the Yahoo France case, Mr Arunasalam said: "It's not really a legal precedent. The reason why it's problematic is that Yahoo can't technically do what the court has ordered it to do. Even if it manages to steer 90% of traffic away from offending material on Yahoo.com, it is still breaching French law by allowing 10% of traffic through."

He added that he thought it would prompt others to follow suit: "People have largely ignored these issues before but this case has brought them to the forefront. They're going to have to deal with it now."

What happens now?
Yahoo is now in a difficult situation as it is standing by the US right to freedom of speech, which means that it doesn't have to remove the offending content from Yahoo.com, while arguing that it is not technically impossible to restrict French users from certain areas of its flagship site. The irony is that given the size and breadth of the web, it's rather futile to penalise Yahoo as any French users who really wanted to get hold of Nazi memorabilia could easily find a way. On December 22 Yahoo contested the ruling in the US district court of San Jose. This could end up going all the way to the European Convention of Human Rights, which deals with freedom of expression. European legal experts said it could be months, if not years, before a final decision if Yahoo does appeal.

webTitle: Attlee's secret shelters against atomic war

fields.headline: Attlee's secret shelters against atomic war
fields.standfirst: Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: The post war Labour government secretly drew up a register of tunnels, mines, and caves to see how many people could survive in the event of a nuclear war, according to papers released yesterday at the public record office.
fields.body:
The post war Labour government secretly drew up a register of tunnels, mines, and caves to see how many people could survive in the event of a nuclear war, according to papers released yesterday at the public record office.

The Home Office even suggested that shallow shelters used to protect people in the second world war "would seem to provide complete protection against all the effects of the atomic bomb as used at Hiroshima and Nagasaki".

One unidentified official added: "If the bomb were of the penetrating type there would be a calamity, but it seems unlikely that the atomic bomb would be used for a deliberate attack with these shelters as targets."

The survey of "shelters" was carried out by Clement Attlee's government at the beginning of the cold war as the Soviet Union was developing its atom bomb.

The government tried to reassure the public in 1948 by telling the Commons that "deep shelters which seem prima facie to provide good protection even against atomic warfare were still in existence and there was no question of their being allowed to go to ruin or destruction".

However, ministers imposed a blackout on all publicity about the register of shelters it drew up in 1948, a year before the Soviet Union first tested an atom bomb. They did not want the public to know which shelters they were identifying.

"A serious problem might well arise if the civil population trekked out of the city under raiding conditions," one official noted.

While the government publicly tried to reassure parliament, privately the Home Office made clear that the survey should remain secret. "The general public", wrote one official, "would probably react strongly to a suggestion that in a future war no effective provision can be made for the protection of the public on account of the high cost."

The government's register of shelters consisted of five closely typed pages listing more than 150 locations. Some of the largest sites included old railway tunnels at Ramsgate which could hold 33,000 people, Chislehurst caves in south-east London which could hold 10,000, tunnels at Dover which could contain 10,000, various facilities at Stockport for more than 13,000 and others in Newcastle, Portsmouth and Birkenhead. The register's list included "Dick Turpin's cave" in Bostall woods in Woolwich and the 80-ft deep Corsham quarries near Bath.

Secret papers released yesterday also disclosed that Home Office civil defence officials had discussions at the time with a US expert on "psychological factors and the control of panic".

Covert preparations for a nuclear war became a matter of public controversy in the late 1970s and 1980s when a secret network of "regional centres of government" - underground shelters, including Corsham, reserved for the royal family and senior officials - were exposed by the media.

webTitle: Jones appointed Wolves  manager

fields.headline: Jones appointed Wolves  manager
fields.trailText: Dave Jones has promised to "bring back the good times" at Wolves after being appointed manager of the club this morning.
fields.body:
Dave Jones has promised to "bring back the good times" at Wolves after being appointed manager of the club this morning.

The 44-year-old former Southampton and Stockport manager signed a three-and-a-half-year contract today, and immediately pledged to bring Premiership football to Molineux, which last staged top-flight football back in 1984.

"I'm here to bring back the good times and take the club back where it belongs, and that's the Premiership," Jones insisted.

"Everyone at Wolves is hungry for success and when I spoke to the club's chairman Sir Jack Hayward he told me that what he wants is to get Wolves into the Premiership. I will be as hungry to achieve that as the fans. I want it as much as them."

Jones returns to football management only a month after being declared innocent of child abuse charges. He added: "I never wanted to leave the Premiership in the first place, but Southampton felt that they had a decision to make.

"But what's gone on has gone on. That's history now. I just want to look forward and build Wolverhampton Wanderers into a Premiership force. I am just very pleased to be here."

Club owner Sir Jack Hayward has spent millions on the ailing Black Country club over the past decade, but has seen successive managers - Graham Turner, Graham Taylor, Mark McGhee and then Colin Lee - fail to win promotion.

But Wolves' chief executive Jez Moxey said: "We believe we have found a manager with Premiership credentials."

"Appointing Dave was a unanimous decision by the board after a very thorough search," he added. "He has a desire to make Wolves a success and has an excellent pedigree."

Jones' first match in charge will be against Nottingham Forest in the third round of the FA Cup at the City Ground on Sunday.

webTitle: Dome was UK's most popular visitor attraction

fields.headline: Dome was UK's most popular visitor attraction
fields.standfirst:
 Dome firm claims visitor success
 Site owners claim land is worth twice the £125m price
 PY still wants the dome
 Get a job demolishing the dome
Special report: Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: The Millennium Dome was the UK's most popular admission-paying attraction last year with more than twice as many visitors as its closest rival, it was announced today.
fields.body:
The Millennium Dome was the UK's most popular admission-paying attraction last year with more than twice as many visitors as its closest rival, it was announced today.

As political and legal wrangling continued over the future of the Greenwich site, dome operators the New Millennium Experience Company expressed satisfaction with their year-long visitor total of 6.5m.

Alton Towers, in Staffordshire, was closest with less than half that figure and a spokesman for NMEC said: "This confirms the dome's place as the most popular visitor attraction in the UK in the year 2000."

The 6.5m includes more than one million non-paying visitors, the majority of whom were children on school trips, but the dome still had more than twice as many fee-paying visitors than Alton Towers.

The final month was also the dome's busiest, with 737,300 passing through the doors of the south London attraction in December, it was announced today.

The December figure took the provisional annual visitor numbers to 6,517,000 - well short of the original target of 12m.

Visitors to the dome spent just over £400m on travel, accommodation and food and drink outside the dome and more than 750,000 visitors were foreign tourists, the spokesman added.

Lighting and sound equipment leased for the year 2000 for the central show would also have to be returned before the auction.

Showforce, one of the dome's contractors, is looking for workers to help it dismantle and demolish the dome. It is taking down three of the zones and is looking for 100 workers.

webTitle: In brief: Disney make sequel to first virtual reality movie

fields.headline: Disney make sequel to first virtual reality movie
fields.standfirst: Plus: Veteran star Ray Walston dies aged 86; Paul Newman to join star cast for Sam Mendes; Ray Park takes on another masked role
fields.trailText: Plus: Veteran star Ray Walston dies aged 86; Paul Newman to join star cast for Sam Mendes; Ray Park takes on another masked role
fields.body:
 Disney are in the early stages of developing a sequel to Tron (pictured), the 1982 computer-game thriller that is widely regarded as the world's first virtual reality movie. Written and directed by Steven Lisberger, the film, which starred Jeff Bridges, tells the story of a whizz kid computer programmer who must battle his way through the games he himself helped to create. A flop on release, with critics complaining of its claustrophobic atmosphere and migraine-inducing visuals, the film has since come to be regarded as a cult classic and was re-issued in the States to revisionist raves in 1999. Lisberger is currently working on a script to the sequel with the aid of writer Richard Jefferies.

 Veteran stage and screen actor Ray Walston died on Monday following a short illness at his home in Beverly Hills. The 86-year-old actor forged a career in quirky character roles after making his debut opposite Cary Grant in the comedy Kiss Them From Me. Among Walston's most memorable roles was his turn as the Devil in Damn Yankees, co-star slots in South Pacific and Paint Your Wagon and a splendidly oily turn as a lecherous businessman in Billy Wilder's recently re-released The Apartment. On TV, Walston was best known as the extraterrestrial uncle in My Favourite Martian. He cropped up in a poignant cameo in the 1999 film version of the series, in what was to be his final film role.

 Paul Newman looks set to become the latest big name to sign up to The Road to Perdition, the next film from American Beauty director Sam Mendes. The 75-year-old star is currently in final negotiations to take a high-profile cameo in the DreamWorks production, based on Max Collins' graphic novel about a vengeful hitman in Prohibition-era Chicago. Newman would join Tom Hanks, who stars as "the Angel of Death", Jude Law, who will play an enigmatic rival assassin, and Tom Sizemore, who tackles a meaty supporting role as Al Capone.

 You may not recognise him on the street, but Ray Park is fast becoming one of Hollywood's more sought after players. Having appeared behind a viperish face mask as Darth Maul in The Phantom Menace and thick make-up as Toad in X-Men, the actor has signed up to play the title role in Iron Fist, a joint venture between Marvel Comics and Artisan Entertainment. Based on one of the lesser known comics in the Marvel oeuvre, the film follows the adventures of Danny Rand, an American raised in a Far Eastern temple and tutored in Martial Arts.

webTitle: Vinterberg snares Danes for Brit-set production

fields.headline: Vinterberg snares Danes for Brit-set production
fields.trailText: The Romeo + Juliet star will play a figure skater in the Dogme director's follow-up to the award-winning Festen
fields.body:
Danish wonderkid Thomas Vinterberg has secured Claire Danes to star in It's All About Love, an English-language drama that will be filmed in the UK in April.

Danes will play the role of Elena, a successful figure skater struggling to repair a damaged marriage in a future landscape where the world is menaced by the melting of the polar icecaps. The role of her husband has yet to be cast. "I am extremely happy that Claire Danes has signed to play Elena," Vinterberg told Variety. "To me Claire is one of the best actresses of our time Together I am sure that we can bring the character of Elena to life."

Vinterberg established his credentials as one of cinema's most exciting new voices when his debut film, Festen, shot under the rigorous Dogme "vow of chastity" that he developed in tandem with countryman Lars von Trier, won the Jury Prize at the 1998 Cannes Film Festival.

After making her name in the cult TV series, My So-Called Life, American actress Danes rose to fame in 1994's Little Women and co-starred opposite Leonardo DiCaprio in Baz Lurhmann's brilliantly modernised take on Romeo and Juliet in 1996. But the 21-year-old actress failed to build on the movie's huge success and has not made a film since the prison drama Brokedown Palace in 1998. She recently signed on to play the lead role in Flora Plum, to be directed by Jodie Foster, but the production has been delayed due to an injury suffered by co-star Russell Crowe. As a result, the Vinterberg film now takes priority.

webTitle: Sky to bid for pay-per-view soccer

fields.headline: Sky to bid for pay-per-view soccer
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Sky is lining up a bid for pay-per-view football following the collapse of NTL's PPV package, writes Jessica Hodgson .
fields.body:
BSkyB is preparing a bid for pay-per-view Premier League football, months after the high-profile collapse of NTL's PPV rights package.

Bosses at Sky have already held talks with the Premier League and lawyers at the football body are assessing the legality of the move.

Under the tendering process that led to last year's football rights handout, BSkyB was forbidden from bidding for pay-per-view rights because it already held exclusive rights to live matches.

But a Premier League spokesman said: "It's being looked at by our lawyers. There are two issues here: can they bid for the rights and do we want them to bid for it if they can?

"There is interest, but as far as I'm aware no decision has been made."

BSkyB has announced a trial for Scottish pay-per-view football matches that will go live on January 31.

The trial, which kicks off with a Celtic versus St Johnstone match, is being treated as an experiment by both parties to measure demand for pay-per-view football.

BSkyB will charge armchair football fans £7.95 per game. As part of the trial, Saturday football matches will also be moved from 3pm to just before 1pm to protect gate receipts at any live matches that clash.

A Sky spokesman said that the Scottish Premier League project was only a trial, and had no bearing on the broadcaster's thoughts about pay-per-view rights south of the border.

After the high-profile collapse last year of NTL's pay-per-view rights deal, worth £328m, broadcasters have expressed scepticism about the viability of pay-per-view.

NTL has also rebid for the cable-only pay-per-view rights to Premier League football.

There was also speculation before Christmas that U Direct, a company run by former BSkyB finance director Richard Brooke, was poised to make a bid.

Meanwhile, ONdigital refused to comment on its interest in pay-per-view.

A spokesman said: "Pay-per-view remains a very unproven project. It works up to a point for big events but whether it could work on a week-in, week-out basis remains to be seen."

Other interest has come from merchant bank Investec, which wants to bid for all Premier League pay-per-view rights and sell them on to different broadcasters and telecoms companies.
