webTitle: An innovative way of teaching literacy and numeracy to adults

fields.headline: The basics instinct
fields.standfirst: Jane Feinmann on an innovative way of teaching literacy and numeracy to adults
fields.trailText: Jane Feinmann on an innovative way of teaching literacy and numeracy to adults
fields.body:
Colm Kearn has just earned his first certificate in a training that will open up a career as a youth worker. At 23, it may not sound that impressive. But six months ago, Kearn had nothing going for him, spending his time "hanging around" when not appearing in court on charges of drug-related crimes, car theft, burglary and one instance of racial abuse.

Then a probation officer told Kearn about free football coaching at Birmingham City football club, a scheme financed by the basic skills agency (BSA). A key role of this organisation has been to hand out the £20m adult and community fund, set up by the government three years ago to combat the low literacy and numeracy skills which limit the lives of 7m people. Its approach is unusual in that it recognises that the people most in need of basic skills training may not be able to look up telephone numbers, read advertisements or fill in application forms.

The fund works, says BSA director Alan Wells, because it recognises that "potential clients face urgent problems with how to get a roof over their head, or get off drugs, or look after their children, and so wouldn't necessarily join a college course to improve their skills".

Kearn was an unlikely candidate for further education. But having been pulled into a programme through football, and been given the chance to meet other people "like me", he was encouraged - during coaching in tackling - to develop skills in teamwork, negotiation and communication.

"I was treated with respect; my views were worth hearing," he says of the programme, which Fairbridge, a leading charity supporting young disadvantaged adults, has run in Liverpool, Middlesbrough and Newcastle upon Tyne, as well as Birmingham, over the past 18 months. Literacy training came in the form of working on football reports and articles in the project's newspaper. After touring Scotland in a boat in October, Kearn also studied IT and numeracy skills.

"The work is done in a low key way - there's no big deal about it," says Fairbridge development tutor Steve Belcher. "People on the course are helped to identify their own needs and then buy into whichever training programme fits."

Among other approaches being tested, Nottingham has "barefoot" mentors, all of them sex workers who provide early basic skills training for other local prostitutes that take account of work patterns, childcare and problems related to drug addiction. Lisa, a 27-year-old prostitute, says group learning previously was frustrating. "I wasn't able to get the support I required and would feel embarrassed about asking for help from people I didn't yet trust," she says. Now planning to study for a certificate, she says the prostitute outreach workers project offers "peace of mind, support and the opportunity to plan for the future and deal with life issues now".

The schemes are successful, says Wells, because the agency works on the basis that literacy programmes work by targeting people where and how they want to learn. "Organisations working with target groups - young mums, ex-offenders, drug misusers and the homeless - all have their own agendas," he says. "But often they can't make a long-lasting impact on people's lives without improving the literacy and numeracy skills which enable all of us to function fully in society."

Not surprisingly, the adult and community fund has proved a huge success. The BSA is currently preparing to announce the final 60 projects - chosen from 750 applications - that will be funded with the last £3m of the original £20m adult and community fund. Most projects become self-financing (from other sources) within a year. But the commitment to extending this unique form of support for those deprived of literacy skills is uncertain.

In November, the government's new adult basic skills strategy unit within the Department for Education and Employment was launched. At the time, Wells expressed concern that the unit would take a traditional line and limit provision largely to college courses. "People think there's an audience out there and all you have to do is give them a bit of childcare and they will come in," he says. "They won't."

Publication last month of the unit's first strategy document has allayed many concerns. And a formal evaluation of the basic skills agency's work is due later in the year.

Meanwhile, says Hunt, basic skills training has to be provided in different ways because one size will not fit all. "There has to be provision for supporting literacy in colleges and the workplace, as well as through distance learning and off-the-shelf self-help packs. But there is clearly a place for focusing on groups that won't access literacy in the usual ways -and that's why our approach to basic skills must continue to be a priority."

A new life story

Writing newspaper reports acted as a catalyst for David Braithwaite, 45. A year ago, he was busking in Manchester, living in a hostel after his marriage had ended - a double blow as he had poor literacy skills and relied on his wife to fill in forms for him. A decision to become a Big Issue seller led to him writing for a newsletter for vendors that he also helped produce, and which acts as a "front" for literacy courses run by the Big Issue Foundation with finance from the adult and community fund.

At his previous college, Braithwaite was regarded as having special needs. At the foundation, which operates in Manchester and Leeds, he discovered that his reading and writing problems stem from a dyslexic confusion over words that sound the same but are spelled differently. He now writes fluently and has experience in researching and writing stories. He has also taken a drumming course and is currently studying classical guitar at Leeds College of Music.

Writing for magazines provides "a distraction so that people don't realise they're sharpening their literacy skills", says BSA spokeswoman Claire Hunt.

fields.headline: Front...to back
fields.trailText: Lap of luxury
fields.body:
Lap of luxury A woman from Spennymoor, County Durham, has bought the semi next door for £60,000 as a home for her 12 pet cats.
Worcester Evening Mail, 2.12.00 (Simon Harley, Redditch)

Unaccountable A Plymouth schoolboy who has yet to deposit any money in the bank account he opened recently has already received 500 statements.
News North West, 14.12.00 (Nasira Asghar, Stockport)

webTitle: Bolivian tribal leader's struggle to protect his homeland

fields.headline: Burning the book of life
fields.standfirst: Bolivian tribal leader's struggle to protect his homeland
fields.trailText: Bolivian tribal leader's struggle to protect his homeland
fields.body:
Sure-Yani Eduardo Poroso Flores is leader of the Leco Aguachile peoples in Bolivia. He was arrested and tortured in Bolivia, fled to Ecuador, then London to claim refugee status, aided by human rights workers and with support from Amnesty and Survival. He became homeless, until he was taken in by the St Mungo's charity. His claim for asylum has been rejected, but he lodged an appeal last week. This is his story:

We Leco people don't write our history, but we sing it and dance it. The dance is a rich literature, containing more knowledge than a mountain of books. One of these dances records the rubber era. Between 1880 and 1925, there was a holocaust and we were exterminated. The European rubber barons stole our children, killing our sons and raping our daughters. We were treated like animals. Big multinationals founded their wealth on rubber, but the knowledge itself came from indigenous peoples.

Every year, the European rubber barons celebrated the 12th of October, when Christopher Colombus "discovered" South America, so on that day in 1910 my great-grandfather, leader of my people, led an attack on them. They were having a huge fiesta; their whisky was Scottish, their chocolate was Austrian, and their beer was German. By 4pm, everyone was very drunk. My people fired burning arrows, setting light to their town. The flames were 40 metres high and the town burnt for a week and a half. In our dances, we remember the 12th of October.

My grandfather, too, was the leader of the Leco people. When he was old, he passed on to me his tiger necklace and his feathers - and with them the duty of looking after our people. The first thing was to recuperate our identity, to show how we are a nation which existed before the Europeans, before the invasion of the Incas, before the empire of the Tihuanacu.

We survived them all, but now we are being destroyed by the empire of neo-liberalism, and capitalism, under the rule of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. I am against the globalisation of the economy because it eliminates our identity and destroys the rainforest. The World Bank, and neo-liberalism in general, are the forces behind changes in the law - from agrarian law to laws concerning mining and oil extraction.

Take, for example, the laws over water. We share water with our ancestors, who didn't pay tax on water. But now our large rivers have been privatised for hydro-electric dams and our land privatised for mining exploration; Shell is there and Platinium Canada. I began to protest to the government about the cattle ranching and the mining, about the theft of our territories, because this land is our land.

From 1570, indigenous territory was marked on maps of Bolivia, but from 1920, the territory of the Leco community was wiped off the map. I showed my people examples of these two maps and they started crying. My people don't know how to read and write, but they understand things. We gave the white invaders an entire country, and then they stole our own land too. So our people began to make dances about this, too. The land is our home and it is our past, our present and our future. It is our cultural heritage. It is not for private companies, it is territorio sanctuario - sacred land.

We are defending our lives, but we are also defending the lives of humanity. This is our vision. The environment is in a state of collapse. Those responsible for pollution are the first-world countries. The Amazon is the last lung of the world, and we protect it for everyone. Yet we are attacked. It is not justice.

I was imprisoned for a week for being a political activist. I was blindfolded and taken away and tortured. I have these scars from that time. They tried to make me give them names of other leaders. I didn't. They try to break your morale. It's psychological. They put water on the ground and told me to take off my shoes. Then they sent electric shocks through the water. They had a baton to send electric shocks, and put it on my testicles. The ideology of persecution is to silence leaders; my people are beaten if they speak my name.

I come from a biological forest, where our god is the cosmology, the universe. I fled to London, a concrete forest, which has one god - money. All the world moves through this god. The power of money moves through houses, institutions and political power.

Two years ago, I became homeless and I was in despair, sleeping on the streets and in police stations. I felt all that I had promised to my grandfather, as he lay dying, was gone - lost in the air.

Now I am studying the history of my people, and I also analyse things here like an anthropologist. Britain has tribes, too - the party political tribes, tribes of non-conformists, football tribes and the tribe of hooligans. And the IMF and the World Bank are tribes - tribes which crush people. But of all tribes the international elite is the money tribe.

London's streets are a cold cemetery, but London has its soul, and it's called the British Library. In my country, they burnt books about the Leco people, to castrate our identity, memory and history. But here I discovered the story - prohibited, rejected and despised - of my people. And what these books tell coincides with the history in the dances of my people. Here I feel free and I grow in spirit. Reading books, my soul asks questions of wise authors. And then I send their wisdom back by fax to my people at home, and they grow in spirit.

My forest, too, speaks like a library - a breathing library - of all you want to know: the air, biology, medicine, plants, hydrotherapy from pre-Inca times. The library of the forest is literature and botany, biology and the spiritual world, and it is a library which only indigenous people know how to read. For these reasons, the Amazon should be conserved like the libraries of Alexandria.

webTitle: Readers' letters

fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.trailText: Other side of asylum
fields.body:
Other side of asylum

What a shame for the people of Wath upon Dearne, being denied the absolute joy of getting to know and working with asylum seekers (Gripes of Wath, December 20). I come from the small, ex-cotton industry mill town of Nelson in Lancashire and we have around 200 asylum seekers (mainly young men) dispersed here, housed in residential areas in local housing provided by private landlords. Having these lovely young people living among us has brought nothing but joy, and their presence continues to enrich the local community.

Many small, local shops have applied to take vouchers and this extra business has been greatly appreciated. The local schools and college report enthusiastic, well motivated students who study diligently and this has rubbed off on the local youngsters and helped motivate them in their lessons too.

The community formed a support group and has opened a drop-in centre every afternoon where asylum seekers can come and get clothing, just sit and chat and have a cup of tea. This has had an unexpected benefit in that other vulnerable, lonely local people have also started availing themselves of this centre.

We are a small town, we have no paid workers nor any public money, yet we provide social and cultural events and help with legal, education and medical problems. It has resulted in various religious denominations working together and forged a strong link with non-religious people who just want to come together and help in any way they can. Their presence has strengthened and rejuvenated this community in many ways we would not have thought possible.

There has not been an increase in crime (the local police are very supportive - even to the point of donating unclaimed stolen bicyles to enable asylum seekers to cycle to the nearby larger towns where better services are available), and these people are less trouble than many of our local youngsters. I have only met kindness, helpfulness, dignity, respect, and youngsters with good hearts and good minds.

I feel humble and privileged to work with them and I feel I am a better person from having known them. It is such a pity that the people of Wath will not be able to experience the joy of working with, and the friendship of, these young men.

Mary Thomas
Legal co-ordinator, Pendle Asylum SeekersÍ Support Group, Colne, Lancashire

 Your article could lead to the conclusion that only a handful of people in Rotherham support asylum seekers. Our experience has been very different. We have had very successful and well supported protests against the voucher scheme at Rotherham supermarkets and collected hundreds of signatures to scrap the voucher scheme. At the second public meeting in Wath, people queued to argue for the rights of asylum seekers.

The blame for the failure of the hostel application lies a long way from the people of Wath. When William Hague spews his race hate lies, when the media peddle myths about asylum seekers and New Labour refuses to challenge either, then the root cause is clear.

Brian Todd
Rotherham Committee to Support Asylum Seekers

Scope for improvement

Chris Ball raises some points about Scope's restructuring plans that require clarification (Letters, December 13).

The timing of our announcements was difficult for all involved, although we did brief affected staff members present at the November conference prior to the announcements being made. None the less, we know the decisions have caused discomfort and uncertainty to some staff and we are sorry that this was made worse by the circumstances of the communication.

Members of the national works council attended a briefing and consultation meeting in advance of the announcements and their views were duly taken back to Scope's executive council. This meeting was arranged as a point of good practice and, of course, had to remain confidential prior to the general announcements.

Scope is having to cut some services in large part because of a drop in voluntary income. For the same reason, we must also review the charity's redundancy policy. However, these changes are not anticipated to disadvantage staff affected by the current round of redundancies.

Regarding our Churchtown outdoor adventure centre in Cornwall, Ball is wrong. Scope's plan and wish is to negotiate an alternative management body for this important service. We do not want to see it close, and staff and management have been working hard for two months in order to see it succeed long into the future.

The decisions made by council have not been easy ones, and will inevitably mean a certain amount of uncertainty, but we believe that by taking these steps now we will be able to focus resources on achieving our long-term priorities.

Richard Brewster
Chief executive, Scope

The name sticks

Malcolm Dean is right: the only thing wrong with the "no blame" approach to bullying is the name (No blame is not a soft option, December 6).

We regret this choice, made in 1991 when we published the programme. Unfortunately, we are now stuck with it. It is used extensively, worldwide, and a change would be confusing.

Michele Elliott (Letters, December 13) writes in inflammatory terms that the approach allows the bully to "get away with it". We can only conclude that she has not even read the book or seen the video, let alone attended a training session.

Barbara Maines and George Robinson
Lucky Duck Publishing, Bristol

webTitle: What will Bush do to the environment?

fields.headline: Gloom watch
fields.standfirst: Al Gore won the green vote, but still lost the US presidential race. As the world waits to see what George W Bush will do for - or to - the global environment,  Polly Ghazi checks his record
fields.trailText: Al Gore won the green vote, but still lost the US presidential race. As the world waits to see what George W Bush will do for - or to - the global environment, Polly Ghazi checks his record
fields.body:
America's environmentalists are in mourning. They were among Al Gore's most ardent supporters, citing a "Grand Canyon of difference" between his green credentials and those of presidential rival George W Bush. Millions were poured into television ads demonising Bush's poor environmental record as governor of Texas. But still he triumphed in the end, so what can the world now expect from his stewardship of the global environment?

Based on Bush's record and campaign pledges, it doesn't look good, say gloomy US observers. Under Bush's tenure, Texas's air became the most polluted in the country, while oil company executives were appointed to state boards regulating their own industries. On the campaign trail, the president-elect infuriated the green lobby by pledging to allow oil drilling in Alaska's Arctic National Wildlife Refuge and to double logging in national forests. His presidential bid was bankrolled by the fossil fuel lobby, and he denounced the Kyoto climate protection treaty as "unfair".

"People around the world should be gravely concerned about President-elect Bush's energy and environment policies," warns Brent Blackwelder, president of Friends of the Earth US. "I think he is deeply sympathetic to the oil industry agenda and will open up the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge very quickly, perhaps in the next few months. He is hostile to a climate change agreement and believes in unfettered free trade. It could all add up to more fossil fuel use than ever in the US - and more global warming around the world."

Daniel Weiss, political director of the Sierra Club environmental campaign group, agrees that Bush will be under pressure from some rightwing Republicans and industry backers to pursue an anti-environmental agenda, both at home and abroad.

"Bush has said he wants to be a uniter and a healer and his attitude to the environment will test that claim more than maybe any other issue," he says. "Unlike abortion or gun control, where the public is pretty evenly split, most Americans say they want cleaner air and water and protected wild places. If he continues with the kind of negative environmental policies he pursued in Texas, he will end up dividing the nation."

Other leading environmentalists, however, point to silver linings in the cloud. Bush's first major test on international environmental policy will come in May, when 180 countries try to pick up the pieces of the stalled negotiations to implement the Kyoto protocol on curbing climate change. While Bush has been hostile to the protocol as it stands, he now accepts that global warming is a reality. And some believe he would have a better chance at getting a modified treaty past Congress than a Democratic president.

"This is a time of considerable uncertainty, but also of opportunity," says Jonathan Lash, president of the non-partisan World Resources Institute, a Washington-based think-tank. "If he could be persuaded that the Kyoto protocol was in the national interest then I believe that, as a Republican president, he could get it ratified".

Lash adds that Tony Blair and other European leaders should play their part by quickly impressing on the new president the importance of securing a global climate treaty. He says: "I think there are very good reasons for Bush to view ratifying the Kyoto protocol as an important plank of foreign policy, crucial to America's transatlantic relationship with Europe. That's the way to sell it to him."

There was also cautious optimism among some environmentalists last week about Bush's early cabinet appointments. His main advisers on the campaign trail were rightwingers such as Senator Slade Gorton, notorious for blocking salmon runs in Washington state. But his expected choice of Christine Todd Whitman, governor of New Jersey, as the new head of the US Environmental Protection Agency, has relieved the green lobby. While Whitman's state record is mixed - she weakened fines for polluters, while introducing a 10-year plan to preserve a million acres of open space - environmentalists had feared a hardline appointee who would emasculate the national agency. "We can work with her," was the Sierra Club's reaction.

Bush's moderate choice for treasury secretary, aluminium magnate Paul O'Neill, is also encouraging, say Washington-based green lobbyists, as he supported Gore's abortive plans for carbon taxes in the early 90s. On the other hand, the commerce secretary will be Don Evans, a rightwing former oil baron who can be expected to strongly oppose environmental safeguards in trade agreements.

Climate change apart, free trade will be the biggest environmental banana skin waiting to trip Bush on the world stage. Last week he pledged to expand free trade across the globe and maintain American dominance as the "engine of the world's economy". A Nafta-like trade agreement with 34 Latin and Central American countries is already in the pipeline.

Bill Clinton, responding to the past year's eruption of anti-globalisation protests, recently signed a presidential order instructing that mild environmental provisions be inserted into all new trade agreements. Bush will be under strong pressure to ditch these. But by doing so he could alienate America's labour, environment and student lobbies, anger his European allies - and trigger more Seattle-scale riots. "These new trade agreements will have potentially very large environmental impacts," says one senior European diplomat in the US capital. "If Bush were to try to remove the environmental provisions we would be concerned."

On the home front, Bush's first environmental challenge will be fulfilling his pledge to open up the Arctic refuge - pristine home to wolves, walrus, polar bears, tens of thousands of wild caribou and millions of migratory birds. President Clinton blocked several Republican attempts to approve drilling there - most notably in 1995, when his veto helped to trigger the dramatic shutdown of the federal government. Although Congress is now more finely balanced between Republicans and Democrats, Bush will almost certainly use his presidential powers to approve exploration as part of his drive for less reliance on foreign energy sources.

Clinton has protected more public land than any president since Theodore Roosevelt almost a century ago, infuriating Republicans in the process. His successor could use presidential powers to de-list some of the monuments, but would risk a huge public backlash.

Weiss, of the Sierra Club, believes a wholesale assault on Clinton's considerable environmental legacy is unlikely. "The Republicans suffered a lot of self-inflicted wounds through their efforts to block clean air and water safeguards in the mid-90s," he says. webTitle: NHS success in speeding cancer cases

fields.headline: NHS success in speeding cancer cases
fields.trailText: Waiting times for diagnosis and treatment of various types of cancer have been slashed in some areas by cutting bureaucratic delays and inefficiencies, according to a government report.
fields.body:
Waiting times for diagnosis and treatment of various types of cancer have been slashed in some areas by cutting bureaucratic delays and inefficiencies, according to a government report.

Pilot schemes have shown how much can be done by taking a rational look at the way patients are referred through the system - from GP to a consultant for diagnosis and then for treatment. In Birmingham, patients who used to wait for eight weeks for the results of a bowel cancer biopsy now get them within a fortnight.

But the big improvements in the nine pilot areas indicate how much there still is to do elsewhere. Gordon McVie, director general of the Cancer Research Campaign, said the report showed that the waiting times for certain treatments in some hospitals had been "truly shocking".

In West London, women with breast cancer used to wait for eight to 11 weeks to see a consultant. Now they can see one at the next available clinic.

The health secretary, Alan Milburn, said the progress made in the nine areas meant that the UK would soon lose its reputation as the laggard of Europe for cancer treatment. "By 2010 our five year survival rates will compare with the best in Europe," he said

Prof McVie said: "I applaud the government for telling it as it is, warts and all," in going public on the "sorry situation" in the UK, as well as on the improvements. "There is now nothing to stop this plan being rolled out to all cancer centres."

The report, by the national patients' action team, was published on the Department of Health website as Mr Milburn announced at Newcastle general hospital how the next tranche of cancer funding, heralded in the national cancer plan last year, will be spent.

The government has promised £570m a year more for cancer care by 2004. Mr Milburn said £87.5m of this would be spent on following guidance on treatment of cancers of the stomach, pancreas and oesophagus. That guidance aims to save 18,000 lives through earlier diagnosis and better, more efficient treatment.

"By December 2001 there will be a maximum one month wait from urgent referral by a GP to treatment for testicular cancer, all children's cancers and leukaemia," he pledged. "There will be a maximum one month wait from diagnosis to treatment for breast cancer."

webTitle: The change in British holidays

fields.headline: Waves of optimism
fields.standfirst: The digs were often spartan, the landladies could be dragons. But the war was over, there was guaranteed paid leave, and the seaside promised fresh air and fun.  Peter Lennon traces the change in British holidays
fields.trailText: The digs were often spartan, the landladies could be dragons. But the war was over, there was guaranteed paid leave, and the seaside promised fresh air and fun. Peter Lennon traces the change in British holidays
fields.body:
When the Holidays with Pay Act of 1948 was passed, guaranteeing the British worker two weeks' paid holidays, the rush to the seaside - which had already been building up from VE Day in May, 1945 - became a human tidal wave, as regular and vast as the coastal sea itself. Entire industries shut down and headed for Blackpool; the cotton towns in Lancashire would be deserted for Wakes Weeks as everyone decamped to the seaside. The streets of London's east end transferred their communities to Margate.

Dad, in his Sunday best collar and tie, sat on the beach and rarely got into swimming togs. Mother wore her best frock, while the kids went wild with bucket and spade. Occasionally, Dad would roll up his trouser legs and have a paddle. Mother might daringly stuff her dress into her knickers, the frock copiously overlapping for reasons of decency, and paddle with the kids. Dress etiquette on and off the beach was strict. The uncouth might sport a knotted handkerchief in lieu of a soft hat. But some wore their bowlers on the beach.

Josephine Roffey's family, from Streatham, south London, favoured Margate. Those were the days of the stingy landladies. "The moment we arrived the old girl took all our meat ration coupons," Josephine recalls. "But all we got was diabolical fish cakes and suet pudding with nothing in it.

"There was me and my two brothers and my mum and dad all in the same room with three beds. You had to go through the old girl's kitchen to get to the toilet, but we had a pot and when my little brother, who was always wanting to go, started my mother would say: 'Tilt it up and wee on the side so the people in the next room can't hear.' But we didn't mind any of this - a holiday by the sea was a revelation."

Then the Roffeys graduated to a guest-house. "The difference was enormous," Josephine says. "Once again we were all in the same room, but there was a bathroom and toilet on the landing, and you had your own table in the dining room. Your dinner was brought in on a trolley - I can still see the waitress, she had such a high pile of curls on her head my brother thought it was a bunch of grapes."

The seaside boarding house was a favourite spot for honeymooners, but the shy ones were likely to remain virginal throughout the holiday. In ITV's two-part series, Some Liked It Hot, which begins on Friday, one woman tells how, when her new husband came to bed, the springs made such a racket that she lay rigid. "Don't move," she told him. "The landlady will wonder what we are doing."

Josephine laughs. "I would have done it on the floor, or standing up," she says.

They were very tribal in those days; the holidaymakers in Blackpool rarely met "a Scotchman". The Scots had their own Blackpool at Whitley Bay.

The great liberation for mothers was Butlin's holiday camp, with its free babysitters and guarantees against a dreary, eventless wet August week. The young mothers could dance until late, their handbags swinging on their arms, while a "nurse" looked in regularly on the chalets where the kids slept.

The entertainment was relentlessly Hi-De-Hi: corny comic turns, sack races, beauty contests; competitions for knobbly knees, shiniest bald head and a competition sponsored by Lux soap to find the loveliest complexion.

The war had dislocated home life so badly - dad at the front; mother nursing or in munitions factories; the children evacuated - that right across the class structure there was an enormous will to recreate the family. Holidays was the ideal time.

Christine Fagg and her husband, a consultant paediatrician, took an old army ambulance and converted it for the newest holiday experience - caravanning.

"We went to Blakeney Marshes on the Norfolk coast," Christine says. "There was only one bunk, so we brought along an old army bell tent for the overflow. [The overflow was four children, aged four to nine.] We were so many years locked at home in the war it was a miracle to get away from inland towns and see this wonderful sea."

The wartime ban on using beaches had hidden a secret passion of her husband's. "I never knew he was a sailing fanatic," she says. "When I met my husband, the whole coastline around East Anglia was barbed wired, off limits. Then he got a sailing boat. But sailing terrified me, so we reached an agreement. We bought a second-hand Sprite Alpine caravan and I learned to hitch the thing up. He went on his sailing holidays with the two eldest boys and I went off with the other two in a caravan".

Christine was one of the earliest British lady caravanners. She had a regular column in Caravan Magazine and wrote The Caravan Book: A Guide to Adventure and Fun on Wheels. "None of my children would be seen dead in a caravan now," she says.

What these holidaymakers of the 40s and 50s all remember was the huge sense of joy that little things brought. "I was ecstatic just to see the sea," Christine says. "When I had a fall once," Josephine says, "a nurse told me that if I was a good girl and didn't make a fuss, she would give me a sweet. I can even remember the colour of the sweet, they were so precious - a green fruit drop. Nowadays, kids would tell her to sod off or ask for a Jack Daniel's."

But already in 1947 a blight had struck the holidaymakers. Alex Rowell thought it was great that he lived only a mile from the seaside at Seaburn, Sunderland. Every day during the six weeks of school holidays in 1947 they would make their jam sandwiches, roll their togs in their towels and go to their favourite spot on the beach.

"It was by a sewer," he says. "We loved to run along the pipe into the sea. We just thought it was funny when there was a stink every time the wind changed." Alex got polio, which permanently paralysed one side of his face. His cousin, Josephine, was paralysed from the waist down.

Alex Rowell is now leading a campaign against the local council, who, he claims, never warned of the danger on the beaches although they were planning, in the 1947 epidemic, to close swimming baths. In Sunderland alone 80 were affected.

By the 60s, holidays abroad diluted this huge, tribal, inward-looking migrations in search of pleasure. The British turned to Spain in their millions and created their own Blackpools, Margates and Brightons on the Mediterranean. In 1970, more than five million Britons went to Spain.

From Blackpool to Benidorm

On the first post war Saturday of July 1945, trains carried a record 102,889 trippers to Blackpool. Beaches had been off-limits since the start of the war in 1939.

The Holidays with Pay Act of 1948 turned this weekend exodus into a two-week annual adventure for workers.

The working class went to Blackpool and Margate or, to earn a little extra, went hop-picking in Kent. The middle classes preferred the more select beaches of Bournemouth and Eastbourne.

In the summer of 1947, there were almost 8,000 cases of polio in Britain. Many swimming pools were closed down, but polluted beaches - later believed to have been partly responsible for the spread of the disease - remained unrestricted.

In 1948, one in 20 British holidaymakers went to a Butlin's camp.

But fashions changed and, by 1970, 5.7m British people chose to go to Spain on holiday.

webTitle: Asda to create 5,000 jobs

fields.headline: Asda to create 5,000 jobs
fields.trailText: Asda today confirmed plans to create 5,000 jobs this year and said it would invest £450 million in store development in 2001.
fields.body:
Asda today confirmed plans to create 5,000 jobs this year and said it would invest £450 million in store development in 2001.

The group, bought by US giant Wal-Mart in August 1999, said it would create the jobs by building 13 stores over the year, including four 'resites' or rebuilds.

It also plans to extend six existing stores, refurbish a quarter of its sites and open a distribution depot at Bedford, creating 600 jobs.

The company, which has more than 240 stores in the UK, said each new store opening created around 400 jobs while a resite or rebuild created 100 jobs - a mixture of part-time and full-time.

Paul Mason, Asda's chief operating officer, said: "This record level of investment by Wal-Mart in the UK is in line with our strategy of long-term market-share growth and good news for British customers who know that, when Wal-Mart comes to town, prices come down and stay down."

The plans are part of Asda's expansion drive announced a year ago when it said it would create 27,000 jobs over five years.

Today's plans will see it open nine new stores at Swindon, Bodmin in Cornwall, Dumbarton in Scotland, Hull, Cambridge, Hyde in Greater Manchester, Leyton in east London, Sefton in Liverpool, and Dunstable.

Stores are being rebuilt at Livingston in Scotland, and Coventry, while stores at Cwmbran and Peterlee are set for resiting.

Asda will also extend six shops, including sites in Dundee and Brighton.

The Livingston store, which will create 250 jobs and is costing Asda £30 million, is set to become Scotland's largest store and the country's first Asda Wal-Mart supercentre, said the group.

The store will open in two stages, with the first stage in November and the second next year.

Asda added that, in 2002, the group would also become the anchor store in the Commonwealth Games regeneration development at Eastlands, Manchester.

webTitle: Fowler attacked in Liverpool city centre

fields.headline: Fowler attacked in Liverpool city centre
fields.trailText: Robbie Fowler is recovering today after being attacked last night in Liverpool city centre.
fields.body:
Robbie Fowler is recovering today after being attacked last night in Liverpool city centre.

Fowler was seen with facial injuries shortly after 2am outside the Wonder Bar, in the heart of the city's clubland.

The 25-year-old Liverpool striker did not need hospital treatment according to police, who have since arrested a 39-year-old man in connection with the attack.

webTitle: Move on, Sir Richard

fields.headline: Move on, Sir Richard
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson should establish a Virgin charitable foundation instead of contesting Camelot's successful bid to run the National Lottery, according to a leading brand consultancy.Jill Treanor and John Cassy
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson should establish a Virgin charitable foundation instead of contesting Camelot's successful bid to run the National Lottery, according to a leading brand consultancy.

Wolff Olins believes Sir Richard risks damaging his brand if he mounts a legal challenge to the decision.

The warning comes as Sir Richard faces several setbacks in his sprawling business empire. As well as his People's Lottery syndicate's failure to win the lottery licence, Virgin's bid to run the east coast mainline appears to have been scuppered and his airline is in dispute with unions over recognition.

Robert Jones, the consultant director at Wolff Olins, ranks Virgin as one of the best brands in the world and believes the millionaire entrepreneur should forget his ambition to run the lottery.

"There's an opportunity to seize the high ground and do something new and different and exciting," he said. Setting up a Virgin Foundation could be an answer.

"This would attach the Virgin name to other good causes. He needs to do it quickly," Mr Jones said, cautioning Sir Richard against taking on Camelot in the courts.

Virgin has one charitable foundation, Virgin Healthcare, which hands out around £500,000 a year to causes supporting the wellbeing of young people, such as Parents against Tobacco.

A Virgin spokesman said it was unlikely Sir Richard would set up a high profile fund because of Virgin's existing foundation. He denied that the failed lottery bid had damaged the Virgin brand, emphasising that the People's Lottery has been Sir Richard's personal interest.

"If anything, losing the lottery has actually enhanced the Virgin brand and Sir Richard's image because people thought it was a very honourable defeat," the spokesman said.

"Research carried out before the lottery commission's decision showed only 13% of people wanted Camelot to win but 67% wanted the People's Lottery to win.

"The decision on whether to appeal or not will be based on rational legal ad vice and have nothing to do with how it may or may not affect the Virgin brand."

The People's Lottery expects answers on Friday to questions it submitted to the lottery commission as to why Camelot was awarded the licence. It will make a decision about whether to appeal based on those responses, and a formal announcement is expected over the weekend or early next week.

webTitle: Real Lives: Manchester United

fields.headline: Boring, boring United
fields.standfirst:
They're heading for yet another championship, playing the greatest football ever seen at the club. But does so much success mean that even their own fans find Manchester United dull? Jim White should know

Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: They're heading for yet another championship, playing the greatest football ever seen at the club. But does so much success mean that even their own fans find Manchester United dull? Jim White should know.
fields.body:
Midway through the second half of their team's coruscating demolition of West Ham on Monday night, the crowd in a section of Manchester United's Old Trafford stadium struck up a song. Surprising in itself, some might say, in a stadium which has lately generated all the passion and atmosphere of the reading room at the British Museum. But it was the words of the chant that were intriguing. As Paul Scholes and Ryan Giggs, David Beckham and Wes Brown passed and moved their way to brilliant effect around the pitch, the crowd was singing a parody Christmas song - The Twelve Days of Cantona.

There, confronted by what many observers reckon to be the most efficient, ruthless and impressive football ever seen at Old Trafford, were the crowd getting all nostalgic about a former hero, Eric Cantona, who hung up his swagger nearly five years ago. For a non-United supporting friend of mine, this was a defining moment. "You know why they're singing that, don't you?" he said. "Because people get nostalgic for their past when their present is boring."

This is the latest dismissal of Manchester United by the legions of supporters of other clubs who have been obliged to live in their shadow for a decade: that they are boring. Not in the style of their play, universally admired even in the most grudging of circles. But in their success. Eleven points clear of everybody else at the start of January, they are charged with killing competition in England, of turning our league into the one-horse boreathon endured in Scotland for years. What's more, they've done it with a machine-like team so short of individual charisma, there's not even anyone worthwhile to hate any more.

United supporters like me are used to years of abuse. I have been accused of being a glory hunter, a bandwagon jumper, a man who fails to understand the fundamental purpose of football support. I have had to listen as people accuse my team's players of everything from treachery through sodomy to paedophilia. Someone once dismissed me of being incapable of applying intellectual rigour to any subject solely because I supported Manchester United. He wasn't joking. But boring? That's a new one.

"It must be boring watching your team win every week," is the standard question of the moment. To which the only answer is: you should be so lucky. Every football fan loves to see their team win; in my experience there is no such thing as someone enthusiastic for the good of the game. Club is more important than football in every true fan's heart. You cannot tell me that a supporter of Carlisle United, currently bottom of the league, would find it remotely boring if his team were 11 points clear at the top. The editor who asked me to write about boring, boring United is an Arsenal fan: boring would not be the word on his lips were his team 11 points ahead rather than 11 points behind. Every single fan of every other club would love it if it were happening to them. Unfortunately it is happening to someone else. And since nasty, ugly, cynical or malicious would be wholly inappropriate adjectives to describe this United team, boring is the one applied to justify their all-consuming envy.

But even so, it is interesting to test your own convictions against the new orthodoxy. Do I find this United team dull? In the way they play, the answer is emphatically no. Frankly, the football at times on Monday night was the best I've ever seen. Sacrilege to say it, but a team containing Bryan Robson, George Best, Bobby Charlton and the sainted Cantona himself would have difficulty living with the class of 2001.

There is, however, the question of the lack of competitive edge. In truth, the Liverpool defeat apart, games at Old Trafford this season have often resembled training exercises. The exhausting, draining thrill of watching two matched teams slugging it out has not been much of a feature of this season. These days it is the cerebral pleasure of watching football played at its best, the purr of certainty rather than the throaty roar of unexpected success. Different, perhaps, from those early rampaging days of the Ferguson domination, when everything was fresh and new, every victory profoundly felt, the title just something to be dreamed of. But boring? You wish.

Besides, this is not entirely United's fault. It is like blaming Tiger Woods for spoiling golf by being too good, or suggesting Pete Sampras should give Wimbledon a miss to give the rest a chance. United can only be responsible for their own game, it is up to others to match them. They are playing football the way it should be played.

OK, the detractors say, what about the team? Where is the character of the past? Where is the snap and snarl of Hughes, the arrogance of Schmeichel, the intellectual pretensions of Cantona? Fabien Barthez's bald pate is about as far as it goes for interesting with this lot. It is true that United used to possess a glorious uncertainty, a cavalier element to their make-up that was less a streak than a pathological flaw. Theirs was a capacity for self-destruction as epitomised by their most gifted talent, George Best. Of the many triumphs of his management tenure, the removal of this flaw from the collective psyche is one of Alex Ferguson's greatest achievements. United are no longer unpredictable. Players such as Ryan Giggs, Nicky Butt and Paul Scholes, brought up from childhood in the Ferguson way, are about as likely to go off the rails as a Japanese bullet train. Taught from an early age that the only way, as Ferguson puts it, to realise the genius within them, is to subsume their egos to the collective will, they have already achieved far, far more than their more dilettante predecessors could have dared imagine. Even David Beckham, hovering a year or so ago on the brink of believing his own publicity, was quickly re-focused by his manager, and has become a fantastic player for it. His recent rash of after-match television interviews appear to have been designed to re-establish him as an ordinary, everyday dull old Joe rather than a galloping superstar.

Charisma comes from ego. And the success of this present team is in part a function of its lack of ego. All for one and one for all. Workrate married to sublime skill: the holy grail of football management. Ironic that it has been achieved at United, the club whose merchandise operation would be best placed to exploit the possibilities of a new Cantona. Phil Neville duvet cover anyone? Thought not.

Compared to Paolo Di Canio, Benito Carbone and Stan Collymore maybe they are boring. But no one in their right mind would swap Paul Scholes for all three of these characters of the game.

There is just one chink of light for those who have simply added boring to the long list of complaints about United dominance these past few years. Liverpool were at their absolute best in 1988, when John Barnes, Peter Beardsley and the rest played a football unmatched until this United team got to work. And it came almost at the end of their long period of ascendancy: two years later it was gone, lost, over. The comet burned brightest at the end. And the sudden decline happened because of a change of management. Sir Alex Ferguson retires in 18 months time; United haters will be praying history repeats itself. Until then, some of us are happy to be bored.

webTitle: Yahoo halts sale of Nazi memorabilia

fields.headline: Yahoo acts to halt sale of Nazi memorabilia
fields.standfirst: Nov 20: Yahoo ruling hailed as landmark case
fields.trailText:
10.45am: Yahoo is to block the sale of Nazi memorabilia on its websites in the wake of a ruling from a French court, writes Polly Sprenger.
Nov 20: Yahoo ruling hailed as landmark case
fields.body:
Yahoo is to halt the sale of Nazi memorabilia on its websites in the wake of a ruling from a French court.

For the first time the company will employ staff and use software to actively monitor what is posted on its site in a bid to stamp out "hateful and offensive" material.

The move comes after pressure was applied on Yahoo by lobby groups including the Simon Wiesenthal Centre.

"We are being more proactive on the Yahoo side to stamp out anything in violation," said Brian Fitzgerald, senior producer for Yahoo Auctions.

But the company denied that the decision was a result of November's court ruling, in which French judges decided that the auction of Nazi memorabilia violated French law, claiming that it merely reflected a change in attitude.

French judges ruled that even though the company is incorporated in the US, it should be held accountable under the same rules that govern French internet companies' activities.

Yahoo appealed against the decision in the US courts shortly before Christmas, but has decided to halt the sale of the offending items in the meantime.

A company spokesman said that Yahoo had simply decided it didn't want to "promote hatred or glorify hatred and violence".

Yahoo also announced that it will begin charging a listing fee for its auctions for the first time, hoping to combat revenue lost to falling online advertising sales.

webTitle: Money up, attendance down in final box office tally

fields.headline: Money up, attendance down in final box office tally
fields.trailText: After a lacklustre summer, Hollywood's Christmas blockbusters help to make 2000 a record year, but poor attendance figures show another side to the story
fields.body:
The final box office figures for 2000 are being regarded with relief by Hollywood chiefs, who have seen their worries over a flat summer allayed at the last minute by a bumper crop of Christmas hits.

Despite the lack of a mammoth smash such as 1999's The Phantom Menace, the studios fared well in 2000, particularly in the closing weeks when the Dr Seuss adaptation How the Grinch Stole Christmas roared through the pack to become the year's most successful film. It was a good year for Universal studios, Disney, and Mel Gibson, who saw all three of the movies he featured in - What Women Want (pictured), The Patriot and Chicken Run - sail pass the $100m (£66.56m) mark.

But beneath the initially rosy picture lie faint signs of a downturn. In terms of cash flowing into the studio coffers, 2000 was a record year for Hollywood, $7.7 billion (£5.12 billion) in the US alone, but only because of the hike in ticket prices. Audience figures are actually down by some 3%.

The dip in attendance is compounded by a poor showing in the international markets, which are expected to account for some $6 billion (£3.99 billion) in total, down 10% on 1999. This, insiders say, is due in part to the strength of the dollar and devaluation in Europe, which is estimated to have wiped as much as 15% off worldwide grosses. Mulling over the mass of figures, Chuck Viane, Disney's head of distribution, admitted that: "It's off a shade, but it was still a good year."

According to Exhibitor Relations, the ten most successful films of 2000 are as follows:

1. How the Grinch Stole Christmas (aka The Grinch)
2. Mission: Impossible II
3. Gladiator
4. The Perfect Storm
5. Meet the Parents
6. X-Men
7. Scary Movie
8. What Lies Beneath
9. Dinosaur
10. Erin Brockovich

webTitle: Johnston Press acquires four regional weeklies

fields.headline: Johnston Press acquires four regional weeklies
fields.trailText: 10.15am: Newspaper publisher Johnston Press has snapped up four Lincolnshire-based regional newspapers, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Newspaper publisher Johnston Press has snapped up four Lincolnshire-based regional newspapers.

The weekly titles are the Horncastle News series, the Louth Leader series, the Skegness News and the Market Rasen Mail.

Johnston would not give a price for the deal, but revealed that last year the titles racked up sales worth £1.8m under previous owner Mortons Media.

"This is a first class group of weekly newspapers with an excellent fit with our existing titles in the area," said Tim Bowdler, Johnston Press chief executive.

Because Johnston's titles have a combined circulation of over 500,000, the deal has to be cleared by Stephen Byers, Trade and Industry secretary.

The Edinburgh-based company owns nearly 200 titles and 54 websites and expects full-year profits to exceed analysts' estimates.

Johnston Press has teamed up with US newspaper giant Gannett and Guardian owner Guardian Media Group in a bid for Regional Independent Media, owner of the Yorkshire Post.

The companies have agreed that Gannett, parent company of UK publisher Newsquest, should bid for all of RIM and sell off some of the titles to its partners.

However, the protracted courtship has hit the rocks recently, with RIM saying it will talk to individual bidders but not to a consortium.

Venture capital firm Candover is the majority shareholder in RIM and will only get a high price for its stake through an auction.

As the only significant independent regional newspaper publisher, Johnston has been mentioned as a possible takeover target following several years of consolidation in the industry. Today's acquisition will boost the price tag of a much-admired company.

webTitle: Gunners herald fresh start for Carlisle

fields.headline: Gunners herald fresh start for Carlisle
fields.trailText: Ian Atkins squints up at the television and punches in the stocks and shares index on his teletext remote. "I'm not doing too badly at the moment," he says as columns of coloured numbers flash across the screen. "As long as you don't look at the league table, that is."
fields.body:
Ian Atkins squints up at the television and punches in the stocks and shares index on his teletext remote. "I'm not doing too badly at the moment," he says as columns of coloured numbers flash across the screen. "As long as you don't look at the league table, that is."

Temporarily ensconced in the world of personal finance, the Carlisle United manager is spared grim reality. His side are six points adrift at the foot of the Nationwide League. But on Saturday the club who for the past two seasons have avoided demotion from the league only on the final Saturday entertain Arsenal in the third round of the FA Cup.

"Managing here would have been a challenge even for Arsène Wenger," he smiles. "When I arrived in the summer, someone high up in the club told me that if we finished second from bottom this season the board would probably offer me a 10-year contract. I didn't believe him, but I do now."

Yet today may provide a new dawn for Carlisle. Stephen Brown, a 47-year-old Canadian-born businessman and former commercial manager of the Scottish non-league club Gala Fairydean, is fronting a consortium which has bought heavily into the club and has pledged to finance an ambitious development of Brunton Park and supply Atkins with belated funds to shore up the makeshift squad.

Though the takeover does not signal the end of the Knighton era in Cumbria - Mark Knighton, son of Michael Knighton, who previously owned 93% of the club, will be invited on to the board - it is appropriate that Arsenal's visit draws a veil over the former chairman's direct involvement. In August 1989, Knighton Sr ball-juggled on the Old Trafford pitch after launching an audacious bid to buy Manchester United, where he was a director until 1992. The Gunners provided the opposition that day as well.

Knighton's subsequent purchase of the Cumbrians sparked a nine-year rollercoaster which rose as high as the Second Division and two Wembley appearances, via a close encounter with aliens on the M62, before sinking almost as low as the Conference. He resigned as a director of CUFC Holdings - formerly Knighton Holdings, the company that controlled United - in December 1999 and, last September, was disqualified from becoming a director of any company for five years for financial irregularities at a preparatory school he owned in Huddersfield.

There is never a dull moment with Knighton around, but the murky intrigue since he put the club up for sale last summer has derailed Carlisle's season. Internal politics have wreaked havoc; the board's £2m rescue package was rejected last month, and two directors were escorted out of Brunton Park by bouncers after being denied access to documents by Andrea Whittaker, the club's financial controller and a director of both United and CUFC Holdings.

"Working under the shadow of trustees hasn't been easy," says Andrew Jenkins, a former United chairman who has been a director for 40 years. "At the start of the season we thought we'd be in for a scrap with the way the club was set up. We had owners and direc tors here; everything was in constant limbo."

The uncertainty prevented Atkins adding to a squad scarred by last season's relegation scrap. "I came here because of the potential," he says. "I knew it was going to be difficult with a takeover in progress, but by August we'd seen 50 triallists and only had six contracted senior players. We had to cobble a team together.

"We've had 12 players on monthly contracts, most of whom were with us last season but whose deals expired in the summer. We lost one lad, Anthony Carss, on the Friday before a game when I found out he'd signed for Oldham. We could never prepare properly because the team might disappear.

"I do feel a little let down - there were other jobs I could have taken - but it was difficult because nobody, not even the board who appointed me, seemed to know what was going on."

Since enjoying success on a shoestring at Northampton - the Cobblers rose from the basement in 1997 and narrowly missed being promoted to the First Division in the play-offs the following year - Atkins has become a reluctant trouble-shooter, called in by Doncaster and Chester to sort out doomed footballing messes. Indeed, while his current players were revelling in last-day euphoria, Atkins experienced the trauma of relegation to non-league in May.

"They stayed up, but one of the biggest problems we've had is a lot of the players have been here for the last two years," he says. "They've seen all this before and it's difficult to wipe away that losing mentality. If I turn this round and keep us in the league it will be a massive achievement."

But, rather than baffle his players with stories of his heyday, on Saturday he is likely to remind them that, nine years ago, Wrexham knocked Arsenal out of the FA Cup a year after finishing bottom of the league.

"The likes of Tony Adams and Lee Dixon have seen all this before, but most of the other players have not," Atkins adds. "They may not be used to conditions in this neck of the woods. This is a reward to the supporters: they've got one of the best sides in Europe, if not the world, coming to Carlisle.

"Nine times out of 10 they will beat you, but there's always that one chance. It's happened to them before; it can happen again."

webTitle: Capital Radio London appoints Vidler as managing director

fields.headline: Vidler takes the helm at Capital Radio London
fields.standfirst: Dec 20: Capital set to sign Vidler
fields.trailText: 10am: Capital Radio has appointed Andria Vidler as managing director for Capital Radio London, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Capital Radio has confirmed the appointment of Andria Vidler as managing director for Capital Radio London, ending weeks of speculation.

Ms Vidler was head of marketing and business development for BBC Sport from 1998 until her departure before Christmas.

She will take responsibility for Capital Group's two flagship stations, 95.8 Capital FM and Capital Gold, and will focus on developing new events across the group.

webTitle: Arafat rejects Clinton peace plan

fields.headline: Arafat rejects Clinton peace plan
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText:
Palestinian leader leaves Washington as Israel braced for more violence

Special report: Israel & Middle East
fields.body:
The Palestinian leader was leaving Washington today after the US president failed to convince him to accept his peace proposals.

Refusing to abandon his peace effort, the US president, Bill Clinton, is planning telephone diplomacy with Palestinian, Israeli and Arab leaders. "We need to hear back very quickly," the White House said as time was running out on the president's elusive peace pact.

More than three hours of meetings with Yasser Arafat at the White House yesterday yielded a renewed promise from the Palestinian leader to try to curb the violence that has swept away the goodwill needed for an accord.

White House spokesman Jake Siewert said: "In the end, words don't matter here. Deeds do."

The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, said his focus had now shifted from pursuing a negotiated settlement with Mr Arafat - which he said had "no real chance" - to containing terrorism.

"I think everyone understands that we have a very narrow window of opportunity here," Mr Siewart said. He did not claim any progress on inducing Mr Arafat to accept a US outline for a negotiated settlement, but added: "We are going to continue our work."

He said the meetings were useful and productive and said "we will have more discussion with the players in the region."

He said that thanks to Mr Clinton, Mr Arafat had "specifically agreed to end or stop or reduce acts of violence". Mr Arafat had promised cooperation in countering terrorism, to intensify efforts to stop the shootings and to arrest those responsible.

More than 350 people, mostly Palestinians, have died in violence in the Middle East in the last three months.

Hassan Abdel Rahman, chief representative of the Palestine Liberation Organisation in Washington, said the meetings had been useful. "There will be further discussions," he said. "

Palestinian officials said that Mr Arafat had concentrated on the issues of Jerusalem and Palestinian refugees, insisting also on reconfiguring the Palestinian state that would emerge from an accord.

Mr Barak has accepted President Clinton's outline for a settlement on condition that the Palestinian leader also agrees.

The US president-elect, George W Bush, said that Mr Clinton was "giving it the very best shot he can, and I certainly hope it works".

webTitle: Napster masters harmony with leading indie label

fields.headline: Napster masters harmony with leading indie label
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Starting the year on a high note, Napster, the developer of the popular and controversial song-swap website, said it formed an alliance with Edel Music, one of the world's largest independent music labels. By Sue Zeidler.
fields.body:
Starting the year on a high note, Napster, the developer of the popular and controversial song-swap website, said it formed an alliance with Edel Music, one of the world's largest independent music labels.

A spokeswoman for Napster said the alliance marked its second deal with a member of the world's recording industry after Bertelsmann in October broke ranks with other global music companies suing Napster for copyright infringement.

Bertelsmann said it would drop its lawsuit once Napster offered a secure, fee-charging service, and invited other labels to join the alliance.

German-based Edel, a full service independent label which produces compilations and distributes many acts, including Carl Cox, Jennifer Paige and Phunky Data in the UK, said it would allow master recordings and musical compositions it owns or controls to be used for file sharing under the new service Napster is developing.

"We are very happy to be working with Edel as we evolve toward our new model," Hank Barry, chief executive officer of Napster, said. "We are delighted that a progressive and successful label like Edel has stepped forward and recognised that the interests of music lovers and music makers are both enhanced by the service that Napster is developing."

Edel, which recently reported poor results and cut its 2000 earnings forecast, said it would work with Napster to promote further acceptance of the new Napster business model among interested parties. Edel will advise Napster on its efforts to address the concerns of artists, songwriters, and record and publishing companies.

"This is a very logical step for a company like ours," said Michael Haentjes, Edel's chief executive officer.

"We welcome Napster's commitment to protect the interests of artists, songwriters and other rights holders through their new business model, and we will support any activity that provides for fair compensation for everyone involved. This agreement makes clear that Edel is on the forefront of new technologies and innovative marketing."

Bertelsmann yesterday welcomed the latest development. "For Napster, this is a major step forward. Edel Music is Europe's most successful independent label of the last decade. We are delighted that Edel Music has sent such a forward-looking signal with its willingness to cooperate," said Andreas Schmidt, president and chief executive officer of Bertelsmann e-Commerce Group. "We would also like to explicitly invite the other music labels to support Napster."
Reuters

webTitle: Letsbuyit faces abyss as rescue talks fail

fields.headline: Letsbuyit faces abyss as rescue talks fail
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Online retailer Letsbuyit.com was staring into the abyss last night as crisis talks aimed at securing the company's long term future failed to arrive at any positive conclusion, writes John Cassy.
fields.body:
Online retailer Letsbuyit.com was staring into the abyss last night as crisis talks aimed at securing the company's long term future failed to arrive at any positive conclusion.

Executives from the UK based, Dutch-registered firm were locked in discussions with officials appointed by an Amsterdam court to see if additional funding could be found or whether the business should be wound up. Shares in Letsbuyit slumped almost 70% when they resumed trading yesterday after being suspended at the end of last week, and analysts warned that it was unlikely a buyer would come forward.

"I'd be very surprised if they find [a buyer]," said Heidi Fitzpatrick, an internet analyst at Lehman Brothers.

"You just have to look at the financials to see that it's a pretty hopeless case."

The company, which allows consumers to pool their buying power to purchase cheaper electrical goods, is reported to have just €18m (£11.4m) in cash left and needs about €80m to survive.

webTitle: Fashionable attention paid to Boo's buyer

fields.headline: Fashionable attention paid to Boo's buyer
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Fashionmall.com, an American fashion portal which bought the bankrupt Boo.com last year, has started the year in vogue as a takeover target, writes Jane Martinson.
fields.body:
Fashionmall.com, an American fashion portal which bought the bankrupt Boo.com last year, has started the year in vogue as a takeover target.

The New York company said yesterday it was seeking more information about a takeover offer made at the end of last week by GenesisIntermedia, a consumer products marketing group.

The offer came just a day after a much lower bid from Narax, a mergers and acquisitions boutique, was promptly dismissed by its target.

Anne-Marie Forehand, vice-president of Fashionmall, said the company would consider the GenesisIntermedia offer once more was known about it. The company has promised to announce its official response within 10 days of the bid being officially launched.

The GenesisIntermedia offer values Fashionmall at about $7 a share, or $52m (£34.6m) for the entire company. The bid was made in a letter to Ben Narasin, chief executive and largest shareholder in Fashionmail. At the same time Genesis announced it had bought 7%of its target on the open market.

Fashionmall hit the headlines in October when it bought failed Boo.com after the sports e-tailer had gobbled £80m of investors' cash.

The US fashion portal paid £250,000 for Boo's brand, logo right to use its domain name after the e-tailer went into receivership and gave Kate Buggeln the job of reviving the site.

In a statement Fashionmall.com said it was "not seeking to sell itself" but would consider the bid.

Shares in the company, a marketing portal for clothing retailers such as Banana Republic and Talbots, fell by a third yesterday to below $3 amid disappointment about the delay as well as profit taking after a sharp increase in the shares last week.

Narax, which is based in Beverly Hills, made an unsolicited offer last Thursday which valued the fashion site at $3.50 in cash, or about $26m. That bid represented a 40% premium to Fashionmall's shares on Wednesday but a significant discount to the record high of $8.75 reached in November 1999.

Fashionmall, which boasts some $35m of cash in hand, dismissed the Narax bid, going so far as to suggest that the financing for such a deal was not in place.

Mr Narasin, a fashion designer who founded the company six years ago, said he had twice tried to contact the head of Narax, Michael Savage, with little success. "It was strange," he told the New York Times. "You'd think they'd want to communicate with me if they wanted to do a deal."

The unsolicited bid was immediately followed by the rival share and cash offer from Genesis, which operates the Centerlinq shopping mall information network. Its machines allow shoppers to enroll in rewards programmes and access online services.

In its statement Los Angeles-based Genesis stressed potential synergies between its services and those of Fashionmall. Centerlinq claims to reach 35m consumers a month.

webTitle: Paul Hamlyn - the discreet philanthropist

fields.headline: The discreet philanthropist
fields.standfirst:
I'm proud of my contribution, says millionaire ex-publisher

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: I'm proud of my contribution, says millionaire ex-publisher.
fields.byline: Steven Morris, Tania Branigan and Nicholas Watt
fields.body:
Yesterday morning when the newspapers were brimming with speculation about Labour's secret benefactor, he was sitting in bed in his French mansion enjoying a simple breakfast and discussing what to do for the best with one of his closest friends. Though he has donated generously to Labour in the past, Lord Hamlyn was not at all keen to be revealed as the man who had bolstered the party's coffers to the tune of £2m.

He has always shunned the spotlight where possible, preferring to get on with amassing a huge fortune in publishing and making charitable donations, mainly to the arts. Perhaps more importantly, he is very ill, suffering from cancer and Parkinson's disease, made worse by a bout of pneumonia. But knowing that his continuing anonymity was causing embarrassment to Labour - and that the truth would eventually come out - the 75-year-old peer gave permission for his identity to be disclosed. After all, he said, he was not ashamed of the donation but proud.

Admission

The belated admission came as no huge surprise to friends of the multi-millionaire. Lord Hamlyn, an anti-establishment tycoon whose family fled the Nazis, was suspicious of the left but has found a political home in Tony Blair's New Labour.

Lord Hamlyn, who donates £4m a year to philanthropic causes, has increased his donations in recent months after making a fortune on a property deal in central London. The peer has rented out Robert Maxwell's former Mirror headquarters in Holborn Circus, which has been renovated by the architect Norman Foster, to Sainsbury's for a reputed £16.8m a year. Designer Sir Terence Conran, an old friend of Lord Hamlyn's, said: "The office property market has smiled upon Paul Hamlyn and allowed him to be generous."

Lord Hamlyn told friends that he netted a substantial profit on the building, which he bought in 1999 for £40m, after his original tenants, Andersen Consulting, pulled out. The firm, which was paying around £10m a year in rent, had to pay a severance fee. A fierce bidding war between Sainsbury's and Goldman Sachs pushed the rent up to £16.8m.

While the political storm has been brewing Lord Hamlyn has been at his French base in the Provence hills, where he met with his old friend Lord Gavron, former chairman of the Guardian Media Group, parent company of the Guardian, and himself a Labour party donor. Lord Gavron visited the tycoon yesterday when they discussed what Lord Hamlyn should do. Lord Gavron said: "It was the first day he could have really talked about it. On Monday and the day before he was much more ill. He said he had been in touch with London. They were keen to release his name and what did I think?" The pair agreed that it was best he agree. After all, said Lord Gavron, his friend knew that journalists would keep digging until they had discovered the donor's identity.

Lord Hamlyn dislikes publicity. "He's very shy," said Lord Gavron. "Once he knew it was going to come out he spoke to various people involved. He said: 'If you have to say it's me, I'm not ashamed - I'm proud of it.' He has never made it a secret that he supports the Labour Party."

He was born in Berlin in 1926, the youngest of four children. His father, Richard Hamburger, was a Jewish paediatrician who fled with his family in 1933, and settled in St John's Wood, north London. Lord Hamlyn was sent to a progressive boarding school in Hertfordshire. His father died when he was 16 and within two years he had left school and changed his name. "It was really tough for a kid being called Hamburger," he said.

He worked as an office boy at Country Life and then for a bookshop. During the war he was sent to the Welsh coalmines as a Bevin boy - an alternative to serving in the armed forces. At 22, he started his publishing business from a barrow in Camden market, north London, with an inheritance of £350 from his grandfather.

Richard Charkin, chief executive of Macmillan Publishing, who worked alongside him at Reed International, said: "He's the best marketeer I know in the book industry. He has that great ability to put himself in the role of the customer and understands the value for money concept in publishing - he invented it."

Created

He created and sold two publishing empires to build a personal fortune estimated at £230m. In the 70s he joined Rupert Murdoch at the News of the World Organisation - as it was then - as managing director. Though he did not stay long, a friendship endured.

As well as his French home, he has a fabulous modern house in Chelsea. He is a partner in the upmarket restaurant Bibendum with Sir Terence Conran. The two have the same corner table and compete for it.

Sir Terence said: "He and his wife have all these wonderful houses. They certainly don't live a frugal life. He's very fond of his helicopter as well." Yet twice-married Lord Hamlyn once told an interviewer he had three racehorses but did not really approve of them - he only had them because this was expected of him. Giving some of his fortune away seems to have been a solution. "If you have been as lucky as I have and the sums of money are as enormous as they are it seems to me unthinkable if some of it didn't go to people who need it," he said. He and the charitable foundation into which he ploughed £50m of his personal fortune, have spent a fortune bringing the arts to the people. He has given generously to the British Museum and Bodleian Library in Oxford but has also ploughed money into helping the less well off buy cut-price ballet and opera tickets.

And then there is politics. Like his old friend Rupert Murdoch, he is no fan of the establishment. One friend said yesterday: "I suspect that part of his pro-Labour stance is that he is very much anti-Conservative." When asked what was needed to make him withdraw the controversial book Spycatcher - the autobiography of senior intelligence officer Peter Wright which Margaret Thatcher tried to ban - he replied: "A dukedom." In truth, friends say he loves taking on the status quo.

Lord Owen, a close friend, said: "For a short time during the eighties, like a lot of people who were interested in the SDP, he slightly shifted from Labour. When Labour started to recover around 1987 he moved back towards them. He's been a good supporter of Tony Blair in particular."

Though he is not a close friend of the prime minister, the Blair family have been his guests at the opera. Before the last election he spoke to Labour strategists about the best way of marketing the party. He was made a life peer two years ago, though it was stressed then that the award recognised his charity work, rather than his hefty contributions to Labour coffers.

Talk about it
Should political donors be named?
