webTitle: Donation that triggered 48 hours of chaos

fields.headline: Donation that triggered 48 hours of chaos
fields.standfirst:
Backlash from MPs prompted response from Number 10

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Backlash from MPs prompted response from Number 10.
fields.body:
The revelations in the Sunday Telegraph on New Year's Eve that Labour had received a new £2m donation from a leading businessman could not have come at a worst time for the party leaders. Tony Blair was at his Chequers country retreat; Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's press secretary, was relaxing with his children at his north London home, and Labour's general secretary, Margaret McDonagh, was enjoying the Portuguese sunshine.

The result was 48 hours of chaos, and a potential crisis to rival the Bernie Ecclestone affair, when it was revealed that the Formula One boss had given £1m to Labour party coffers, just after securing an exemption from an advertising ban for motor racing.

It did not help that the latest mystery donor, revealed yesterday as Lord Hamlyn, was seriously ill and in France.

The story - thought to have originated from business sources - revealed that the party's chief fundraiser, Lord Levy, had persuaded a businessman to part with £2m for Labour's election kitty.

The money appeared - in one MP's words - "to have been lying under Labour's Christmas tree" for some time and not declared to the general public. Yet Labour was pledged to implement the recommendation of Lord Neill, the public standards watchdog, to declare details and provenance of all donations - and had made great play of the Tories' reticence to disclose who was funding their party.

Worse, news of the donation leaked out only six weeks before Lord Neill's recommendation becomes law with the new political funding act coming into force. It looked suspiciously like an attempt to avoid pre-election embarrassment by delaying publication of the size of the new donation until the party's accounts come out in October - nearly six months after Tony Blair's preferred election date pencilled in for May 3.

The result was a bout of speculation in the media - suggesting it could be anybody from Robert Bourne, whose company is preferred bidder for the Millennium Dome, to a big donation from the anti-hunting movement.

The turmoil continued unabated on New Year's Day - and it was not just the Tories and Liberal Democrats who were pointing accusing fingers at Labour. The intervention yesterday morning by two former ministers, Peter Kilfoyle and Glenda Jackson, and Clive Soley, chairman of the parliamentary Labour party, who all condemned Labour's failure to disclose the donor, was particularly hurtful to the leadership.

Mr Soley, who objected sotto voce to the Ecclestone donation (later repaid by an apologetic Mr Blair), was particularly noisy this time - despite suffering from a sore throat. Apparently, he had received a a lot of telephone calls from angry Labour backbenchers furious that their party would lose the credit they had won in supporting the public disclosure of donors. His straight-talking appearance on television elicited a strongly worded telephone call from Labour's HQ at Millbank.

But by then it was out of Millbank's hands. Alastair Campbell was back in Downing Street, and had talked to Tony Blair. His advice was similar to that when dealing with the Ecclestone scandal - kill the story by naming the donor and stop media speculation in its tracks. A quick call was made to France with a statement already prepared for Lord Hamlyn.

Millbank's objections - it had wanted to keep the deal secret until the Labour party's accounts were published - were overruled and Margaret McDonagh was informed by telephone that their joint biggest donor, rivalling Lord Sainsbury - was to come out in the open. It was done in time for the one o'clock news bulletins.

Talk about it
Should political donors be named?

webTitle: Devolution pressures bear on Westminster

fields.headline: Devolution pressures bear on Westminster
fields.trailText: With the House of Commons losing many of its powers since devolution, how long until it becomes a purely English parliament? By Robert Hazell
fields.body:
The Guardian's monarchy debate has opened up a raft of wider constitutional questions, including not just the role of the monarchy but also the role of parliament in the light of devolution. How much is Westminster still the parliament for the whole of the UK; and how much a parliament for England? Our new book, The State and the Nations, exposes for the first time the extent to which Westminster already operates as an English parliament, and its potential to develop this role further.

Post-devolution, some have suggested that there should be a separate English parliament to match the Scottish parliament and the Welsh and Northern Ireland assemblies. This is not a realistic option.

Those who demand one are in effect demanding a full-blown federation, in which the four historic nations would form the component parts. But there is no successful federation in the world where one of the parts is greater than around one-third of the whole. England, with four-fifths of the population, would be hugely dominant: even more dominant than Prussia in the old Germany. Nor would it meet the demands for representation coming from the English regions: to them, an English parliament looks like another form of London dominance.

Nor is there any strong public demand: the Campaign for an English Parliament has attracted little public following during its weekly vigils in Parliament Square. When asked in last year's British Social Attitudes survey, 62% of the English said it would be best for England to be governed as it is now, with laws made by the UK parliament, while only 18% said it would be best for England to have its own parliament. And, intriguingly, 30% said they viewed the Houses of Parliament as English, or more English than British: while 27% viewed parliament as equally English and British.

The English may have been uttering a greater constitutional truth than they knew. For buried within Westminster is an English parliament which devolution is beginning to disclose. Before devolution we had a three-in-one parliament, and it was clear when Westminster was operating as the legislature for Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. Post-devolution we are developing a four-in-one parliament, and it will need to become clearer when Westminster is operating in English mode. English business is transacted through the work of the select committees; through the new standing committee on regional affairs (which will be open only to English MPs); through questions to ministers on English matters; through Westminster Hall, which provides a further forum for English debates; and through English legislation.

At present, this English business is mixed up with other business. But if we just take the scrutiny function of Westminster, we can see how parliament is developing a sharper territorial focus. Among the select committees we have found four committees whose membership consists solely of English MPs. Three are on subjects you would expect - education and employment, health, and home affairs - matters in which Scottish, Welsh and Northern Ireland MPs no longer have an interest, because these subjects are now largely devolved. And if we look at the government departments which those select committees scrutinise, we find that their ministers are all MPs from English constituencies.

Eight Whitehall home departments are now "English" ministries, and the only departments with ministers from Scotland and Wales (apart from the Scottish and Welsh Offices) are the all-UK departments: the Treasury, Foreign Office, DfID, Social Security, DTI. In terms of English business, the main committees whose work included a significant English element are health, education and employment, environment, transport and the regions, and home affairs.

Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland not only have their select committees; each also has a grand committee consisting of all the MPs for the territory. Up to now there has been no English equivalent to the territorial grand committees. But in April the House of Commons agreed to revive the standing committee on regional affairs, consisting of 13 members from English constituencies, with power to consider "any matter relating to regional affairs in England". Not a big or powerful committee; but it would be the first English committee. And Margaret Beckett has indicated that the committee could expand its role if pressure for English forums at Westminster grows.

I do not want to overstate these developments. What our book describes is a series of tentative and sometimes unwitting steps in which Westminster is responding to devolution. There has been no strong lead from the government, and no clear sense of Westminster's new role. The clearest vision so far has come from the Wakeham commission on Lords reform, which proposed that a reformed House of Lords could represent the nations and regions of the UK, like the second chamber in federal systems.

If further reform of the Lords takes place on these lines, the Lords could claim to be the chamber representing the nations of the UK, including elected members from the regions of England. We would have created a quasi-federal parliament, with an English parliament nestling within it; but we dare not yet speak its name.

Robert Hazell is director of the Constitution Unit, School of Public Policy, University College, London. The State and the Nations: The First Year of Devolution in the UK, is published by Imprint Academic, £14.95.

webTitle: Tories stir council openness rebellion

fields.headline: Tories stir council openness rebellion
fields.trailText: The government is set for an embarrassing confrontation in the House of Lords over proposed changes to the openness regime for English councils that the Tories believe could create "a breeding ground for inefficiency and corruption".
fields.body:
The government is set for an embarrassing confrontation in the House of Lords over proposed changes to the openness regime for English councils that the Tories believe could create "a breeding ground for inefficiency and corruption".

The Tories plan to canvass support among returning cross bench and Liberal Democrat peers for what they hope will be a full-scale revolt.

The proposals, published last month, will see city mayors and local authority cabinets taking only "key decisions" - spending or cutting "significant" amounts of money, or decisions that affect two or more wards - in public. The vagueness of the definition is likely to mean that, in many cases, the council itself may decide which decisions were key.

The Tories claim this will restrict the rights of voters. They want to see the status quo maintained, and have promised to re-introduce it when they return to power.

The shadow environment minister, Archie Norman, said: "Before the election, Tony Blair promised to make government more open. But obsessed with control freakery, Labour are now creating a new culture of secrecy in local councils."

The changes were laid before parliament on December 19 as a statutory instrument - a legal add-on to last year's Local Government Act. Opposition parties have 40 days to challenge such instruments.

Council openness has been a touchy subject for the past year. Ministers wanted to see many more decisions taken behind closed doors, but were forced to climb down under pressure from journalists and opposition parties, and to do a deal with the Liberal Democrats to pass the local government bill through a sceptical Lords.

The Local Government Association defended the new openness regime. Assistant director John Rees said: "Local government is used to taking far more decisions than any other public body in the open. But it is the case that there are issues that benefit from being discussed in private or without undue publicity being given to them at an early stage."

webTitle: Ministers claim cancer success

fields.headline: Ministers claim cancer success
fields.trailText: Waiting times for diagnosis and treatment of various types of cancer have been slashed in some areas by cutting bureaucratic delays and inefficiencies, according to a government report. Sarah Boseley reports
fields.body:
Waiting times for diagnosis and treatment of various types of cancer have been slashed in some areas by cutting bureaucratic delays and inefficiencies, according to a government report.

Pilot schemes have shown how much can be done by taking a rational look at the way patients are referred through the system - from GP to a consultant for diagnosis and then for treatment. In Birmingham, patients who used to wait for eight weeks for the results of a bowel cancer biopsy now get them within a fortnight.

But the big improvements in the nine pilot areas indicate how much there still is to do elsewhere. Gordon McVie, director general of the Cancer Research Campaign, said the report showed that the waiting times for certain treatments in some hospitals had been "truly shocking".

In West London, women with breast cancer used to wait for eight to 11 weeks to see a consultant. Now they can see one at the next available clinic.

The health secretary, Alan Milburn, said the progress made in the nine areas meant that the UK would soon lose its reputation as the laggard of Europe for cancer treatment. "By 2010 our five year survival rates will compare with the best in Europe," he said

Prof McVie said: "I applaud the government for telling it as it is, warts and all," in going public on the "sorry situation" in the UK, as well as on the improvements. "There is now nothing to stop this plan being rolled out to all cancer centres."

The report, by the national patients' action team, was published on the Department of Health website as Mr Milburn announced at Newcastle general hospital how the next tranche of cancer funding, heralded in the national cancer plan last year, will be spent.

The government has promised £570m a year more for cancer care by 2004. Mr Milburn said £87.5m of this would be spent on following guidance on treatment of cancers of the stomach, pancreas and oesophagus. That guidance aims to save 18,000 lives through earlier diagnosis and better, more efficient treatment.

"By December 2001 there will be a maximum one month wait from urgent referral by a GP to treatment for testicular cancer, all children's cancers and leukaemia," he pledged. "There will be a maximum one month wait from diagnosis to treatment for breast cancer."

webTitle: Beenz.com warns of further job cuts

fields.headline: Beenz.com warns of further job cuts
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Beenz.com became the latest internet company to be hit by the dot.com shake-out by warning of further redundancies, writes Polly Sprenger.
fields.body:
Beenz.com became the latest internet company to feel the chill wind of a market shake-out by warning of further redundancies.

The company, which operates an internet "loyalty points" service for a network of online shopping services, laid off 26 staff before Christmas.

Chief executive officer Charles Cohen today warned of more cuts to come.

He said that he will be conducting a review of Beenz's 10 offices worldwide to assess their viability over the next three months.

Last month's cuts were in Beenz's San Francisco and New York offices, and the company is looking for 18 London workers to accept voluntary redundancy.

The company, which also has offices in Taiwan, Korea, Tokyo, Hong Kong, Singapore, France, Italy, and Australia, will be the focus of considerable scrutiny in the first months of 2001.

"[The cuts] are being done in a very disciplined way making sure that we don't lose the value that we've built in our Beenz network," Mr Cohen said.

Beenz has maintained healthy cash reserves since it closed a round of financing for $40m (£27m) last summer. Getting funding of that size in such a tepid financing climate won the company respect from the internet industry.

The company's customers are other internet ventures who use the reward points systems to lure customers to their sites.

With so many dot.coms failing, being acquired or simply running low on cash, Beenz, once a darling of the industry, faces considerable challenges.

"You would sign a contract with someone on a Friday and pick up the phone on a Friday to find they'd gone out of business," Mr Cohen said.

The ones that haven't folded are not spending as much as they did.

Beenz will now take its loyalty scheme to offline companies. The technology the company has been working on for six month will be unveiled over the next few months.

The latest product is called Reward Codes, and places a code on packaging of offline goods that consumers can use to redeem award points online.

Once the consumer redeems the points, information is fed back to the company about when and where the product was purchased. Beenz purchased the patent from a German company last summer.

webTitle: Aides tell Blair not to risk TV debate

fields.headline: Aides tell Blair not to risk TV debate
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is being urged not to risk a televised election debate with William Hague for fear that such a contest might allow the Conservative leader to "do a George W Bush" by exceeding low expectations of the challenger.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is being urged not to risk a televised election debate with William Hague for fear that such a contest might allow the Conservative leader to "do a George W Bush" by exceeding low expectations of the challenger.

Downing Street is determined to resolve the question well ahead of the expected May 3 election to prevent it becoming a distraction from campaign issues. But Mr Blair's advisers remain sharply divided over their response to Mr Hague's challenge to a debate which Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, would like to join.

Advisers such as Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, and Philip Gould, Mr Blair's private pollster, are hostile to a debate. Mr Gould's fears were confirmed when he saw George W Bush, now president-elect, do better in his three TV debates with vice-president Al Gore than many voters had expected.

Some of the prime minister's intimates, including his press secretary, Alastair Campbell, believe the advantages of a debate watched by millions outweigh the risks, though they acknowledge that it is less of a novelty in parliamentary systems where politicians routinely square up to each other across the dispatch box.

Unlike previous abortive negotiations for a British version of American election debates, this time the broadcasters have taken the initiative. The BBC and ITV have proposed two live debates between the three leaders in prime time on Sunday evenings. They hope to garner a 10m audience.

Mr Campbell went as far as to call TV debates "a perfectly good thing in principle" in a rare public speech in December. "My hunch is that at some stage it will happen," he said.

But other insiders believe the argument is now running the other way and that, as in 1997 when a desperate John Major proposed a session with the novice Blair, Labour will find an excuse to say no.

"We will seek the time and opportunity to withdraw from the negotiations with dignity," one insider has predicted.

Mr Hague is recognised as a formidable debater. But Mr Blair has the advantages of office and the Whitehall machine to expose his rival's policy flaws.

What aides are said to fear is a Hague performance that impresses floating voters who have shown no signs of warming to him.

webTitle: EToys shuts down European operations

fields.headline: EToys shuts down European operations
fields.trailText: 3.30pm: Online toy retailer eToys closed down its European operations today with the loss of 74 jobs, writes Polly Sprenger.
fields.body:
3.30pm: Online toy retailer eToys closed down its European operations today with the loss of 74 jobs, writes Polly Sprenger.Online toy retailer eToys has closed down its European operations with the loss of 74 jobs.

In a bizarre goodbye note, the company chose Bob the Builder to announce the closure of its UK site today.

Beneath a picture of the happy-go-lucky, dungaree-clad children's favourite, the company stated: "Can we fix it? No we can't! Sadly, eToys packs up its toy chest on January 19th".

The company tactlessly added: "But to thank-you for all your custom, we're offering 50% off the original price of all stock! Click here to find out more".

The news comes only two weeks after internet research firm NetValue named eToys as the most successful online toy retailer this Christmas, grabbing 370,000 unique visitors in November and December.

EToys, which launched in the UK in October 1999, blamed its "disappointing recent performance" for the decision to shut down its UK business. The site will cease trading on January 19.

Christmas customers wishing to return purchases are recommended to contact eToys before February 9 if they want a refund.

EToys had warned that such a move was possible as early as December, saying that projections for future sales were poor, and that it would probably be forced to explore a merger or restructuring.

The Californian company said at the time it would soon run out of money, perhaps by spring, and called for "additional, substantial capital infusion".

Its share price sank to 25 cents on the December announcement, valuing the group at $31m.

The company launched a shutdown sale for all items on its UK site on December 29, knocking down prices by at least 50%.

EToys had warned that such a move was possible as early as December, saying that projections for future sales were poor, and that it would probably be forced to explore a merger or restructuring. The Californian company said at the time it would soon run out of money, perhaps by spring, and called for "additional, substantial capital infusion". Its share price sank to 25 cents on the December announcement, valuing the group at $31m. The company launched a shutdown sale for all items on its UK site on December 29, knocking down prices by at least 50%.

webTitle: Recession fear lifts euro

fields.headline: Recession fear lifts euro
fields.standfirst:
Downturn in US manufacturing hurts the dollar

Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Downturn in US manufacturing hurts the dollar.
fields.byline: Mark Atkinson and Jane Martinson in New York
fields.body:
Europe's single currency celebrated its second birthday yesterday by surging to a five-month high against the dollar amid fresh evidence that the US economy could be sliding towards recession.

With new figures showing the downturn in US manufacturing is deepening, the euro climbed to 94.86 cents, confirming its status as the currency of choice for investors at the start of new year trading in America and Europe.

In the US, the National Association of Purchasing Managers report - which measures manufacturing activity - fell for the fifth consecutive month to 43.7 in December, its weakest reading since April 1991 when the US economy was emerging from recession.

In the closely watched index, every number above 50 indicates expansion for the manufacturing sector; every number below contraction.

"The manufacturing sector is definitely struggling at this point," Norbert Ore, chair of NAPM's manufacturing busi ness survey committee, said. Ari Fleischer, press secretary for President-elect Bush, said: "It's a troubling report ... which indicates for the fourth month in a row there is a weakness in the economy."

US investors fled the stock market on the first trading day of the year yesterday as the figures emerged. The Nasdaq composite index was down 5% at midday at 2,338 points. The index slid 39% last year, the worst performance in its 29-year history.

The Dow Jones industrial average fell less than 1% to 10,698 points at midday.

The NAPM's figures were mirrored by a monthly snapshot of manufacturing activity in the eurozone, published by Reuters, registering the slowest growth for 18 months.

However investors concluded that the outlook for the US economy and the dollar was even gloomier.

"It's a sweet revenge for the euro. The last two years everybody dumped the euro, but now it's the star again," said Gilles Borrel, head of global treasury sales at Westdeutsche Landesbank in Paris.

The euro jumped by half a cent immediately after the NAPM was published, taking it within striking distance of 95 cents.

"A lot of work has been done already and the euro's trend is extremely impressive," said Brian Kiely, technical strategist at Royal Bank of Scotland Financial Markets in London. "Our focus now is parity and $1.03, which we might even see in the next two months."

The currency's recovery on the foreign exchanges prompted a renewed outbreak of conflict between opposing sides in Britain's euro membership debate, with pro-euro campaigners calling on their opponents to acknowledge that 2001 would be a bumper year for euro member countries.

Kenneth Clarke, former chancellor and patron of Britain in Europe said: "Growth will probably slow down a little but I expect the average level of growth in the eurozone to continue to exceed the growth in the British economy.

"My only really confident prediction for the new year is that none of this will be reflected in the anti-European campaigning of our more hardline Eurosceptics in this country."

The anti-euro lobby quickly replied that strong eurozone growth was irrelevant to the currency debate. Dominic Cummings, campaign director of Business for Sterling, part of the "no" campaign, said: "It would be good news if the euro economies grow faster and we hope they do, but their recovery has partly been driven by the falling euro and there is a danger that a rising euro will choke their recovery."

webTitle: Pressure on oil firms as stores cut petrol price

fields.headline: Pressure on oil firms as stores cut petrol price
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Petrol prices were cut by at least a penny a litre last night as supermarkets fired the opening shots in a potential forecourt price war.
fields.body:
Petrol prices were cut by at least a penny a litre last night as supermarkets fired the opening shots in a potential forecourt price war.

The move followed anger that the oil companies, which reported record profits just before Christmas, had failed to cut prices in line with the falling cost of crude oil.

David Handley, chairman of Farmers for Action and leader of the fuel terminal blockades which brought Britain to a near standstill in September, yesterday said protesters were ready to return to the fray.

"I think it's absolutely disgusting. In view of the vast profits they're making and the pressure from government, they ought to be doing something substantial to ease pressures on motorists. We are looking at doing something in the short term but with the weather and the railways, the question is whether we would have public support."

Crude oil prices fell by almost a third in December, bringing the wholesale price of a litre of unleaded petrol down to 11p. The oil companies are enjoying their best forecourt profit margins in months, to the anger of ministers who have demanded price cuts.

"The government has made clear its view that consumers should reap the benefits of the reduction in oil prices," a senior DTI source said.

There is further bad news on the horizon for motorists after Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil exporter, yesterday called for heavy cuts in global crude production, which will send prices back up.

A Saudi official said Opec, the 11-member oil exporters' cartel, needed to cut production by 1.5m barrels a day. Kuwait, another Opec member, will push for even bigger cuts at the cartel's meeting in the Austrian capital, Vienna, on January 17.

Helen Liddell, the energy minister, will meet oil firms in the coming weeks to urge them to follow the lead taken by the supermarkets.

Industry analysts say there is scope for forecourt cuts of at least 2p a litre but retailers are delaying the reduction in an attempt to claw back losses made during the blockades.

Sainsbury's and Tesco cut their fuel prices by 1p last night, bringing the average price of a litre of unleaded petrol to 77.8p at Sainsbury's and 78p at Tesco.

Martin Hooper, Sainsbury's general manager for petrol, put pressure on the company's rivals by highlighting falling world prices. "With the price of fuel continuing to fall there is no reason for prices not to come down," he said.

"Consumers can rightly enjoy the lowest prices at the pumps for six months and if crude oil continues to fall there is always the possibility of further decreases."

Some motorists could see bigger cuts in some areas as the supermarkets battle to remain competitive, according to a Tesco spokesman. "Our pricing policy pledges that we will stay in line with local retailers, so in some areas it will mean a bigger drop than 1p."

A Shell spokesman refused to discuss possible price cuts but said the firm had reduced the price of petrol and diesel at its motorway and trunk road service stations last week.

A BP spokeswoman said: "Across our network of 1,500 branded petrol stations, unleaded is 78.9p a litre. It was 79.9p in December. This reflects what's been happening in the international market. We always keep an eye on what our competitors are doing on the forecourts."

webTitle: Frost meets Castro: the show they silenced

fields.headline: Frost meets Castro: the show they silenced
fields.standfirst: Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: The Foreign Office effectively blocked a 1969 television interview that David Frost wanted to carry out with Fidel Castro because it feared it might prove "an inspiration to the revolting students" in Britain at the time.
fields.body:
The Foreign Office effectively blocked a 1969 television interview that David Frost wanted to carry out with Fidel Castro because it feared it might prove "an inspiration to the revolting students" in Britain at the time.

Confidential Foreign Office papers released yesterday at the public record office show that Whitehall civil servants were even prepared to tell David Frost that he could put an end to any career plans he had to work in the United States if he went ahead with the interview.

The idea had been secretly initiated by Lord Stokes, the chairman of British Leyland, after a visit to Cuba in May 1969. Castro had bought a large consignment of British Leyland buses, one of the few big export orders ever won by the state car company. Lord Stokes returned from Havana and claimed that Castro had become a reformed character and the chances of a rapprochement with the west and the United States had improved. He believed a Frost interview would be a useful device to help Castro to "continue to improve his image".

Lord Stokes had written to the British ambassador in Havana to tell him that he had suggested the idea to David Frost, whom he said he knew well, and the television interviewer had "responded enthusiastically".

The Foreign Office was less enthusiastic. "An exercise involving David Frost and Fidel Castro would put us in a highly unpopular light in the rest of Latin America and the United States," said one confidential Foreign Office minute.

The civil servants were also worried that if Frost conducted an aggressive and hostile interview it could prove counter-productive: "Frost's interviews being unpredictable, the result might be a detraction from Fidel Castro's public image, which would have an adverse impact on Anglo-Cuban relations."

They thought they might suggest to Frost that he could "easily jeopardise his chances of finding further work in the United States."

But the crucial factor, according to the confidential Foreign Office file, was that they did not want to encourage "student devotees of Che Guevara in this country".

"There seems a danger that David Frost might, in interviewing Castro, concentrate more on the mythology of Castro (an inspiration to the revolting students) than on the reality," minuted one Foreign Office civil servant. The file concludes by saying that Frost should be officially discouraged. It seems from the file that this was enough to prevent the interview going ahead, although there is no evidence it was directly banned.

webTitle: Call for councils to slash best value service reviews

fields.headline: Call for councils to slash best value service reviews
fields.trailText: Local government minister Hilary Armstrong has called for local authorities to reduce the number of best value reviews and focus on simpler, more strategic programmes to aid the inspectorate. Dermott Calpin reports
fields.body:
Local government minister Hilary Armstrong has called for a drastic reduction in the number of best value service reviews being undertaken by councils and for the introduction of a new-style 'risk based' inspection service as part of an overhaul of the work of the audit commission.

Ms Armstrong is concerned that councils have drawn up plans for more than 4,000 separate best value reviews of the services they provide and has warned: "I think this is too many to carry through. We need simpler, more strategic review programmes."

Though the first anniversary of the regime is not due until April 1 2001, there is already real concern that many councils have become mired in the fine detail of service reviews and have missed the opportunity to develop more joined up and strategic approaches to their work.

The great irony is that many of the local leaders who have consistently expressed fears that best value would become too bureaucratic and over regulated are likely to find it is councils that are in danger of making the process far more complicated than necessary.

Ms Armstrong wants councils to focus more clearly on the number and type of reviews they are proposing as part of best value.

"Ideally, an authority's review programme should be built around a mix of service-specific reviews and strategic reviews based on recognisable themes - reviews that are more likely to make a real and lasting difference," she said.

"I hear too many stories about reviews of tiny aspects of services. Not only are these unlikely to reflect the strategic and corporate focus which best value requires, they make inspection programming very difficult.

"Smaller reviews have their place, but they must produce strategic benefits. There are a great many authorities who are doing great things with best value and service delivery but there are also authorities which are failing to take advantage of these opportunities," she said.

The minister's concerns have been echoed by the powerful best value inspectorate forum for England which includes Mike Tomlinson from Ofsted; Wendy Thomson, director of inspection at the audit commission; Sir David O'Dowd from the inspectorate of constabulary; Chris Bull from the benefits fraud inspectorate; Denise Platt from the social servicesiInspectorate and Graham Meldrum from the fire service inspectorate.

Members of the forum are responsible for coordinating inspection work and say councils should keep the number of service reviews as low as possible to make sure the inspectorates are able to complete their work and to avoid duplication.

So far only 29 best value inspection reports have been published, and some of the reports from the first full year of inspections are unlikely to be released before this summer.

New research by the improvement and development agency, due to be published later this month, has shown that many councils continue to face problems breaking out of the "fixed mindset" of local government and developing service reviews that challenge the traditional departmental organisation of services.

In a review of the work of the audit commission by the House of Commons environment transport and regional affairs select committee published in June last year said: "We are alarmed at the current and future impact of a developing culture of over-inspection in the public sector. This burden seems particularly acute for local authorities."

However, the formal government response published just before Christmas has reinforced its commitment to the work and role of the commission and said that inspection has: "An important and enduring role in the improving the performance of key public services."

Though it agrees with MPs that audit and inspection should be "effective and proportionate", with closer links between the different inspectorate services, the government also says self-improvement and peer review by councils "is not a substitute for inspection".

It was also a message Ms Armstrong delivered to a recent conference on the role of the inspectorates when she stressed: "I make no apologies for being a strong enthusiast for rigorous audit and inspection of services."

She did acknowledge: "I want to see a move to risk-based inspections, where the depth of inspection varies according to the service being inspected, and the perceived risks."

"I also want to see the inspectorate forum succeed in bringing together the new and existing regimes, in sharing information between inspectorates and with auditors, and in coordinating inspection programming," said Ms Armstrong.

In the longer run, there is considerable pressure building around the question of who audits the auditors and how the work of the audit commission can be made more open. There are concerns, too, that as the inspection role develops on behalf of government and the prospects for direct intervention at a failing authority increase, this will undermine and weaken the traditional independence of the commission.

The five-yearly financial management and policy review by the School of Public Policy at Birmingham University has put forward a series of proposals to streamline the organisation and develop a new set of performance indicators to measure the efficiency of the audit commission.

In response, the government has accepted, in principle, that the commission should hold an annual open meeting and make greater use of the internet to provide more summary reports of its work. Consultations are also promised on the number of governing commissioners and moves to reduce local authority and health service representation. An independent review of the commission's work is scheduled for 2002.

For the moment however, with best value barely one year old, the official line is: "The government takes the view that the new audit and inspection functions arising from best value need to settle down before setting in hand the proposed review. It will accordingly re-consider the timing of the proposed review in 2002."

webTitle: Bush finalises his mixed bag of a cabinet

fields.headline: Bush finalises his mixed bag of a cabinet
fields.standfirst:
New White House team has inclusive look, but critics fear hardliners' influence

Special report: the US elections
Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: New White House team has inclusive look, but critics fear hardliners' influence.
fields.body:
George Bush put the finishing touches to his cabinet yesterday, producing an administration team blending old-school pragmatic conservativism with rightwing radicalism on key domestic issues, tempered by the striking ethnic diversity of the lineup.

That diverse image was reinforced when the president-elect announced his last three cabinet nominees. As transport secretary he proposed Norman Mineta, a Japanese-American and a Democrat whose family was interned by the US government during the second world war. Spencer Abraham, an Arab-American senator from Michigan, was named energy secretary, and Linda Chavez, one of several Hispanic-Americans in the Bush entourage, was nominated labour secretary.

The 14 cabinet nominees include four women and two blacks, a degree of variety which compares well with the first Clinton administration eight years ago.

Despite the cabinet's inclusive appearance, however, resistance to the new administration continued to focus on Mr Bush's nominee for attorney general, John Ashcroft, a radical conservative.

There is also expected to be tough questioning by environmentalists during confirmation hearings for Gale Norton, the interior secretary-designate who is a committed proponent of private property rights against government conservation priorities in battles over the creation of nature reserves.

Tommy Thompson's nomination as secretary of health and human services is also likely to draw opposition from abortion rights groups, who are concerned over his fierce anti-abortion stand while governor of Wisconsin.

Critics, meanwhile, have portrayed the foreign policy team - including Colin Powell as secretary of state, Donald Rumsfeld as defence secretary, Condoleezza Rice as national security adviser (not at present a cabinet-level position) and Dick Cheney as vice-president with a clear coordinating portfolio - as a throwback to the cold war era. Each of them served in earlier Republican administrations and all are opponents of the kind of humanitarian intervention pioneered under Mr Clinton.

However, in appointing Mr Rumsfeld, a successful businessman as well as a government veteran, Mr Bush favoured pragmatic manage ment skills in national security issues over ideological zeal. He rejected rightwing demands for the appointment of Dan Coats, a conservative former senator whose priority would have been to reverse Clinton-era measures promoting tolerance of gays in the armed services.

Yesterday's nominations were clearly intended to give the new cabinet a more progressive complexion. Mr Bush said Mr Mineta's appointment demonstrated he would run "an administration who recognises talent wherever we see it, regardless of political party."

Pointing out that there was "no such thing as Republican or Democratic highways" Mr Mineta said that while remaining faithful to his Democratic principles, he would seek out common ground to build bipartisan policy.

Linda Chavez, a veteran of the Reagan administration, reminded journalists that her father was a house painter, making her keenly aware of the "dignity of manual labour" and vowed to work to improve workforce skills and to pro mote safe working conditions.

The only discordant note of the day came with the nomination of Spencer Abraham, the outgoing senator from Michigan. Mr Bush said Mr Abraham, the grandson of Lebanese immigrants, shared his belief in the need to meet rising energy demands with "new domestic exploration and production", a presumed reference to Mr Bush's proposals to look for oil in a national wildlife refuge in Alaska.

Mr Bush lost the popular vote in the November elections to the outgoing vice-president, Al Gore, by half a million votes, but he said yesterday that that would not modify his programme.

He pointed out that he had won the vote in the electoral college, which formally selects the president. He said: "I believe the reason I'm standing here is because of the agenda I articulated during the course of the campaign, and I intend to take that agenda, that I tried to spell out as clearly as I could to the American people, to the halls of Congress."

 Mr Bush is due to convene an economic forum in Austin, Texas, today, to hear from business leaders and economists about the health of the nation.

The meeting will hear from the chairman of General Electric, Jack Welch, and the chief executive of Wal-Mart, Lee Scott. Mr Bush hopes to persuade them of the merits of his proposed $1.3 trillion tax cut.

Who's who in new administration:

Spencer Abraham, Energy

Arab-American who supports Bush's proposal to open up Alaska for oil prospecting

John Ashcroft, Attorney general

A controversial appointment. Hardliner on social issues like abortion and affirmative action

Linda Chavez, Labour

Former head of Centre for Equal Opportunity, a conservative thinktank on racial affairs

Don Evans, Commerce

The Texas oilman has been raising money for Bush campaigns since 1978

Norman Mineta, Transportation

Japanese-American California Democrat. Made commerce secretary by Clinton in July

Gale Norton, Interior

A conservative who backs property owners over the federal creation of nature reserves

Paul O'Neill, Treasury

A friend of Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, the US central bank

Roderick Paige, Education

Impressed the president-elect as schools superintendent in the troubled city of Houston

Colin Powell, Secretary of state

Chairman of joint chiefs of staff under first President Bush. Most popular political figure in US

Anthony Principi, Veterans affairs

Veteran of four Republican administrations and defence secretary under President Ford

Committed pro-life, seen by pro-choice women as a sign Bush will limit right to choose

fields.bodyText: George Bush put the finishing touches to his cabinet yesterday, producing an administration team blending old-school pragmatic conservativism with rightwing radicalism on key domestic issues, tempered by the striking ethnic diversity of the lineup. That diverse image was reinforced when the president-elect announced his last three cabinet nominees. As transport secretary he proposed Norman Mineta, a Japanese-American and a Democrat whose family was interned by the US government during the second world war. Spencer Abraham, an Arab-American senator from Michigan, was named energy secretary, and Linda Chavez, one of several Hispanic-Americans in the Bush entourage, was nominated labour secretary. The 14 cabinet nominees include four women and two blacks, a degree of variety which compares well with the first Clinton administration eight years ago. Despite the cabinet's inclusive appearance, however, resistance to the new administration continued to focus on Mr Bush's nominee for attorney general, John Ashcroft, a radical conservative. There is also expected to be tough questioning by environmentalists during confirmation hearings for Gale Norton, the interior secretary-designate who is a committed proponent of private property rights against government conservation priorities in battles over the creation of nature reserves. Tommy Thompson's nomination as secretary of health and human services is also likely to draw opposition from abortion rights groups, who are concerned over his fierce anti-abortion stand while governor of Wisconsin. Critics, meanwhile, have portrayed the foreign policy team - including Colin Powell as secretary of state, Donald Rumsfeld as defence secretary, Condoleezza Rice as national security adviser (not at present a cabinet-level position) and Dick Cheney as vice-president with a clear coordinating portfolio - as a throwback to the cold war era. Each of them served in earlier Republican administrations and all are opponents of the kind of humanitarian intervention pioneered under Mr Clinton. However, in appointing Mr Rumsfeld, a successful businessman as well as a government veteran, Mr Bush favoured pragmatic manage ment skills in national security issues over ideological zeal. He rejected rightwing demands for the appointment of Dan Coats, a conservative former senator whose priority would have been to reverse Clinton-era measures promoting tolerance of gays in the armed services. Yesterday's nominations were clearly intended to give the new cabinet a more progressive complexion. Mr Bush said Mr Mineta's appointment demonstrated he would run "an administration who recognises talent wherever we see it, regardless of political party." Pointing out that there was "no such thing as Republican or Democratic highways" Mr Mineta said that while remaining faithful to his Democratic principles, he would seek out common ground to build bipartisan policy. Linda Chavez, a veteran of the Reagan administration, reminded journalists that her father was a house painter, making her keenly aware of the "dignity of manual labour" and vowed to work to improve workforce skills and to pro mote safe working conditions. The only discordant note of the day came with the nomination of Spencer Abraham, the outgoing senator from Michigan. Mr Bush said Mr Abraham, the grandson of Lebanese immigrants, shared his belief in the need to meet rising energy demands with "new domestic exploration and production", a presumed reference to Mr Bush's proposals to look for oil in a national wildlife refuge in Alaska. Mr Bush lost the popular vote in the November elections to the outgoing vice-president, Al Gore, by half a million votes, but he said yesterday that that would not modify his programme. He pointed out that he had won the vote in the electoral college, which formally selects the president. He said: "I believe the reason I'm standing here is because of the agenda I articulated during the course of the campaign, and I intend to take that agenda, that I tried to spell out as clearly as I could to the American people, to the halls of Congress."  Mr Bush is due to convene an economic forum in Austin, Texas, today, to hear from business leaders and economists about the health of the nation. The meeting will hear from the chairman of General Electric, Jack Welch, and the chief executive of Wal-Mart, Lee Scott. Mr Bush hopes to persuade them of the merits of his proposed $1.3 trillion tax cut. webTitle: Bush to force through divisive justice chief

fields.headline: Bush to force through divisive justice chief
fields.standfirst:
Liberals will fight rightwinger known for campaign against black judge and support for anti-abortion extremists

Special report: the US elections
Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: Liberals will fight rightwinger known for campaign against black judge and support for anti-abortion extremists.
fields.body:
President-elect George Bush's controversial choice for the post of attorney-general - the anti-abortion, pro-execution John Ashcroft - came under fierce attack yesterday from blacks and liberals, straining the new administration's promise to bring the spirit of bipartisan cooperation to Washington.

Mr Ashcroft is a rightwinger from Missouri who so enraged opponents in his home state that they came out in droves in November to elect a dead man (the Democrat, Mel Carnahan, who died in a plane crash during the campaign), in his place.

The anti-Ashcroft effort backfired however, as his defeat made the conservative politician available for the justice department, viewed by rightwing activists as the key prize in the cabinet.

Most Washington observers believe that Mr Ashcroft will survive his confirmation hearing in an evenly divided Senate, but it will not be without a fight.

"He is far and away the most troubling choice," Senator Charles Schumer, a New York Democrat, said. "The question is: Will Senator Ashcroft enforce the law of the land on things that he is morally opposed to?"

Abortion rights campaigners have expressed doubts that Mr Ashcroft would pursue prosecutions against anti-abortion militants trying to prevent women attending family planning clinics.

They also fear he might add to the pressure on the supreme court to overturn the land mark Roe vs Wade verdict, guaranteeing the right to an abortion.

As a senator, Mr Ashcroft pushed for an amendment to the constitution which went further than the demands of many pro-life activists, banning abortions even in cases of incest or rape.

He won a courage and integrity award from the American Life League, one of the most militant anti-abortion groups which picket family planning clinics.

His critics also point out that he rented out his fundraising contacts list to Linda Tripp, a key prosecution witness in President Clinton's impeachment at a time when as a senator, he was technically a juror in Mr Clinton's trial.

But the most fervent opposition to Mr Ashcroft's nomination will come from black American groups who accuse him of playing the race card in Missouri. They will make the case of Ronnie White the central exhibit in the confirmation process.

Mr White was the first black member of the Missouri supreme court, and was widely expected to rise to a place on a federal district court in 1999, until Senator Ashcroft launched an all-out campaign against him, denouncing him as pro-criminal. Mr Ashcroft went as far as to say the judge had shown "a tremendous bent toward criminal activity".

Even by Missouri's standards, Mr White was fairly hawkish on crime, voting to uphold the death penalty in 41 out of 52 appeals.

In 10 other cases he voted with the majority of the court to reverse a sentence because of legal errors in the original trial.

Senator Ashcroft focused on the one capital case in which Justice White had been the lone dissenter.

The case involved a black Vietnam veteran, Brian Kinder, who was convicted of killing three police officers and a sheriff's wife in what he said was a post-traumatic flashback. Mr Kinder had demanded the trial judge, Earl Blackwell withdraw himself because he was up for re-election and had made some racially charged remarks to explain his defection from the Democratic to the Republican party.

Despite the fact that Mr White had won the endorsement of the Missouri police association, Mr Ashcroft predicted that if he was allowed to sit on a federal court, the judge would "use his lifetime appointment to push law in a pro-criminal direction".

The New York Times columnist, Anthony Lewis, has argued that Senator Ashcroft characterisations of Justice White's career were "vicious falsehoods", and that he was therefore unfit to hold the office of attorney-general.

Nan Aron, the head of the Alliance for Justice, a civil rights pressure group, promised: "Ronnie White will figure prominently in this debate. this was an example of Ashcroft engaging essentially in a hate crime against an eminently qualified African-American solely for political gain."

The Bush transition has taken the precaution of putting together a dossier on the White case, defending Senator Ashcroft's actions.

"He is very well respected by his colleagues on both sides of the aisle, " Ari Fleischer, the Bush White House spokesman, said. "We're very confident on full consideration when people hear Mr Ashcroft, he's going to be in good shape. "

Mr Ashcroft has refused to comment on the issue, saving his remarks for the stormy confirmation hearings. But he published a fierce defence of his record on race issues last year, arguing he had supported numerous black causes.

His critics however, point to the fact that he is a fervent opponent of affirmative action and has accepted an honorary degree from Bob Jones University, a Protestant fundamentalist college in South Carolina which banned interracial dating until recently.

In 1988 he was one of two members of a 40-member civil rights commission who refused to sign the panel's final report, which advocated more government effort to alleviate the plight of minorities.

In a 1998 interview he also hailed a rightwing magazine, Southern Partisan, for its "heritage of defending Southern patriots" and for "helping to set the record straight" on the Civil War.

The magazine specialises in articles by apologists for the slave-owning Confederate states in the Civil War, and once marketed a T-shirt emblazoned with Abraham Lincoln's portrait and the words of his assassin: "Thus always to tyrants."

During the Republican primary elections, the Bush campaign criticised a consultant in the John McCain camp for contributing to the same magazine.

The nomination of judges and judicial officials often provides the most contested battlefields in the formative months of a presidency.

Congress has blocked most of President Clinton's judicial nominations since Republicans seized control of the legislature in 1994.

Earlier, Democrats united to block one of President Reagan's nominees to the US supreme court, Robert Bork, and later tried unsuccessfully to stop President Bush's equally conservative nominee, Clarence Thomas.

It looks as if they may fail again this time around. Mr Ashcroft's southern charm has won some friends across the aisle, like senators Joseph Biden and Russ Feingold, who have already said they would back him.

But the fight is almost certain to cast a bitter pall over a presidency which Mr Bush has promised will help mend the nation's ideological divides.

webTitle: Dons overcome by the full Mooney

fields.headline: Dons overcome by the full Mooney
fields.standfirst:
Watford 3
Mooney 12 20, Noel-Williams 36
Wimbledon 1
Gayle 11
fields.trailText: Recent history suggests that Watford will not finish the year in the same division as they began it and a second successive victory, which further dims the memory of their abysmal run, will revive their promotion hopes for 2001.
fields.body:
Recent history suggests that Watford will not finish the year in the same division as they began it and a second successive victory, which further dims the memory of their abysmal run, will revive their promotion hopes for 2001.

Graham Taylor's team were forced to come from behind last night but their response was so emphatic that they had scored three times themselves before the interval. The losing habit - seven defeats in eight matches culminating in the Boxing Day submission at Fulham - looks to have been expunged.

Wimbledon board the team coach with confidence these days having racked up seven wins away from home. They passed the ball around well enough in the opening stages, were ahead on 10 minutes after a strike of startling accuracy and power from Marcus Gayle but quickly fell behind.

After a fine pass from Jason Euell, Gayle finished off a counter-attack that had arisen from slack control by Neil Cox. But the Watford defender made amends 60 seconds later, flighting a corner from the right that Tommy Mooney eventually headed home.

Eight minutes later Mooney was there again at the far post to turn in Cox's curving centre.

Tommy Smith's pace and invention were causing Wimbledon much anxiety down the right and Watford should have made more of two delicious crosses that he swung over in quick succession.

Before half-time the Dons' defence had been breached again when Gifton Noel-Williams picked up a ball that should have been cleared. The 20-year-old demonstrated great composure to angle his drive beyond Kelvin Davis.

Wimbledon emerged for the second half some time ahead of the home side, which suggested the message to them from Terry Burton had been short and sharp.

The manager sent on Patrick Agyemang, one of the club's home-grown contingent, and with his enthusiasm, swift turns and speed he tried hard to convince the visiting fans that the outcome was not the formality it appeared to be.

A whipped-in ball from the left was only inches in front of Neal Ardley, then a determined run saw the young substitute firing off target. At the other end Davis, fortunate not to be dismissed for a wild lunge on Smith, saved twice from Noel-Williams.

Watford (4-4-2): Chamberlain; Cox, Ward, Page, Robinson; Smith, Nielsen, C Palmer, Kennedy; Mooney, Noel-Williams.
Wimbledon (4-5-1): Davis; Holloway, Williams, Gier, Hawkins; Ardley, Roberts (Agyemang, h-t), Andersen, Francis, Gayle; Euell.
Referee: D Laws.

webTitle: Rome can't hold a candle to West Ham for Di Canio

fields.headline: Rome can't hold a candle to West Ham for Di Canio
fields.trailText: Paolo di Canio will not leave West Ham for Lazio because he feels "too English" and would love to follow his good friend Gianluca Vialli into Premiership management, his agent said yesterday.
fields.body:
Paolo di Canio will not leave West Ham for Lazio because he feels "too English" and would love to follow his good friend Gianluca Vialli into Premiership management, his agent said yesterday.

Rumours have been rife that Di Canio will rejoin Lazio since Roberto Mancini, the Roman club's assistant coach, expressed interest in the striker last week and Di Canio responded by saying it would be "fantastic" to return to his boyhood idols.

Di Canio's absence from the West Ham team at Old Trafford on Monday, apparently because of illness, further fuelled the speculation. But as the Italian transfer window opened yesterday, Di Canio's agent Matteo Roggi joined West Ham's manager Harry Redknapp in playing down talk of a transfer.

"If something happens it will be in the last 29 days of January but for the moment I would say Paolo to Lazio is absolute rubbish," said Roggi, who stressed that Di Canio was so ill on Monday that he was unable to speak. "I know Lazio are interested in him. They like him as a player but they also like lots of other players.

"We renewed the contract with West Ham [to 2003] in November. Don't forget Paolo would love to stay in England and become a manager like Vialli.

"He was born in Rome and has always been a Lazio supporter, so put yourself in his shoes: obviously he has to say he would love to play for Lazio. But I don't think he will move back to Italy. He feels too English now."

Ole Gunnar Solskjaer and Ronny Johnsen have been suspended from the Norwegian national team after failing to agree a sponsorship deal with the country's FA.

The two Manchester United players, along with the Spurs striker Steffen Iversen, have refused to sign the £25m four-year deal because they would then be precluded from signing other, possibly more lucrative, individual sponsorship contracts.

"I would like to reach an agreement with them," Iversen said, "but the way they have tried to force us to sign is unbelievably stupid."

webTitle: Jones ready to move in at Molineux

fields.headline: Jones ready to move in at Molineux
fields.trailText: David Jones will begin today the task of reviving his managerial career at Wolverhampton Wanderers, a club who have done little for the CVs of his immediate predecessors.
fields.body:
David Jones will begin today the task of reviving his managerial career at Wolverhampton Wanderers, a club who have done little for the CVs of his immediate predecessors.

Wolves have refused to confirm the identity of the man who will follow Graham Turner, Graham Taylor, Mark McGhee and Colin Lee and become their fifth manager in six years, until a media conference scheduled for this morning. But Jones has been favourite since he was interviewed late last week.

The Wolves directors were impressed with the 44-year-old's desire for success and keenness to return to management after he was given leave of absence by Southampton to defend himself against charges of child abuse, of which he was cleared.

His odds became even shorter when he was spotted in the Turf Moor directors' box on New Year's Day watching Wolves defeat Burnley 2-1, and then when he cancelled an engagement to be a summariser for Radio 5 Live last night at Tottenham's gamewith Newcastle. Not only did he want to avoid media questioning at White Hart Lane, he wanted to spend the night in Wolverhampton so he would be on time this morning.

Jones has wasted little time in returning to football since he was acquitted last month. Neither has he been short of choice. Having left Southampton last January and then been paid off by them when Glenn Hoddle established himself at the Dell, he has also been linked with vacancies at Norwich, filled last night, and Barnsley.

He is understood to have turned down the chance to succeed Dave Bassett at Barnsley and has now pipped him for the job at Molineux. Bassett's reputation for getting clubs promoted attracted Wolves, a club out of the top flight for 17 years, but by choosing Jones they are taking a longer-term view rather than opting for a Bassett-style quick fix.

After Lee's sacking just before Christmas the caretaker John Ward guided Wolves to three wins in his four matches. He too was interviewed. But now with Jones's former right-hand man at Southampton, Dennis Rofe, expected to follow the new manager, Ward's days at Molineux may be numbered.

Norwich have appointed Nigel Worthington as manager on a 2-year contract. He took temporary control after Bryan Hamilton resigned and lost only one of his six games in charge. His immediate task is to take on his former club Sheffield Wednesday at Hillsborough in the FA Cup on Saturday.

Aston Villa's £9.5m signing Juan Pablo Angel has been granted a work permit until the end of the 2004-5 season. But the Colombian striker has been registered too late for the FA Cup tie against Newcastle on Saturday and will probably make his debut the following weekend at home to Liverpool.

John Toshack has signed a deal to coach Spain's Real Sociedad until 2003. The San Sebastian club will pay St Etienne £200,000 compensation.

webTitle: Bookie pays out on United 16 games early

fields.headline: Bookie pays out on United 16 games early
fields.trailText: Sir Alex Ferguson may not be willing to admit it but all Premiership title bets are off. With Manchester United 11 points clear and counting, one bookmaker has declared the championship race over and is paying out already.
fields.body:
Sir Alex Ferguson may not be willing to admit it but all Premiership title bets are off. With Manchester United 11 points clear and counting, one bookmaker has declared the championship race over and is paying out already.

"We might as well let the punters have their cash for the January sales," said the Manchester-based Fred Done. "The title is over and the way United are playing they could probably win the Boat Race at the moment."

There are still 16 games for United to play but an unmistakable air of anticlimax has descended on an increasingly forlorn league that should be squirming with embarrassment. It seems the highest echelon in English football cannot even muster a two-horse race from 20 teams.

"I decided on Monday, even before United beat West Ham, that I might as well start paying out now," said Done. "I'll be parting with around £150,000, although I would have to double that in pay-outs if, say, Liverpool or Arsenal ended up winning it. But let's be realistic, there's no way in the world it's going to come to that, is there?"

Ferguson will recall how Arsenal retrieved a 12-point deficit three seasons ago but the chances of a repetition are becoming weekly more unlikely. For all the manager's exaggerated caution, a seventh title in nine years is little more than a formality.

Done took the same calculated gamble two-thirds of the way through last season and United went on to win the league by 18 points, although a bookmaker playing with fire is bound to get fingers burned.

"I did the same with United in 1998 and paid out £300,000 only for Arsenal to put an incredible run together. That cost me another £200,000, so I ended up losing the thick end of £500,000. But it won't happen this year. I've been watching United for 20 years and this is the best team I've ever seen."

Meanwhile Arsène Wenger, the manager of United's only credible challengers, may have his appeal against a 12-match touchline ban heard by the end of the month. The Arsenal manager received the punishment in October after being charged with using "threatening behaviour and physical intimidation" towards the fourth official Paul Taylor at Sunderland on the opening day of the season.

The ban was suspended as a result of his appeal and it is understood that Wenger will call on witnesses, including the Arsenal striker Thierry Henry, to back his argument that he was merely trying to prevent a more serious incident breaking out in the tunnel.

webTitle: Three off as Spurs hit home

fields.headline: Three off as Spurs hit home
fields.standfirst:
Tottenham Hotspur 4
Doherty 27, Anderton 30pen, Rebrov 35, Ferdinand 77
Newcastle United 2
Solano 23, Dyer 49pen
fields.trailText: That Tottenham ended their slump last night after recovering from a goal down was somewhat lost in the mayhem. With three sendings-off and three penalties - one missed by Spurs - this remarkable match had Bobby Robson fuming at the fourth official and George Graham's head filled with more than the joy of an overdue win.
fields.byline: Jon Brodkin at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
That Tottenham ended their slump last night after recovering from a goal down was somewhat lost in the mayhem. With three sendings-off and three penalties - one missed by Spurs - this remarkable match had Bobby Robson fuming at the fourth official and George Graham's head filled with more than the joy of an overdue win.

By the time Les Ferdinand headed in a Darren Anderton free-kick to secure Spurs' win Nol Solano and Kieron Dyer had seen red for Newcastle and Tottenham had seen their goalkeeper Neil Sullivan take an early bath. Newcastle's run without a win in London now stretches to 22 matches.

Graham had been not just expecting but demanding victory after the 3-0 capitulation at Ipswich on Saturday. He made it clear before kick-off that he had spelt out "some home truths".

Yet, despite enjoying plenty of early possession, Tottenham, unbeaten at home in 10 league games, initially looked more laboured than inventive. Without Steve Carr, who was out with a groin strain, Spurs offered few dangerous crosses from the byline and there was nothing to test Newcastle's goalkeeper Steve Harper.

Anderton's half-hearted appeal for a penalty under a challenge by Alain Goma was as close as Spurs got as Newcastle harried and looked to use the pace of Dyer and Shola Ameobi, their makeshift forward line, on the counter- attack. Just when Graham must have felt there was at least plenty of effort to console him, Newcastle went ahead.

Tim Sherwood gave away possession and, when Ameobi burst past him and played a neat pass to Solano, the Peruvian finished emphatically from just inside the box.

If Newcastle felt their opponents, already low on confidence, would cave in, they could not have been more wrong. Within two minutes Sergei Rebrov had twice been denied by Harper; within quarter of an hour Spurs had not just scored three times but missed a penalty and, in the middle of that, Solano went from hero to zero and was sent off.

Young Gary Doherty, a forward at Ipswich but shifted into the back three here by Graham, was at the centre of much of a remarkable passage of play. Three minutes after Solano had scored he equalised with his first league goal for the club, heading in a Stephen Clemence cross.

No sooner had Newcastle absorbed that blow than the second arrived. The referee Steve Bennett awarded a penalty when Gary Speed shoved Anderton off the ball and, once fierce Newcastle protests had subsided, Anderton sent his spot-kick to Harper's right.

With Newcastle in disarray and Spurs riding on a wave of new-found belief, a second penalty followed shortly when Doherty's header from a corner was handled by Solano on the line.

Solano was dismissed and Robson was involved in an angry exchange with the fourth official Andy D'Urso, clearly unhappy that Bennett had ignored Newcastle appeals for a penalty at 0-0 when Ledley King challenged Christian Bassedas.

His anger must have subsided slightly when Harper saved Anderton's effort with a leg but it was only a temporary reprieve. When Doherty played a neat pass to Rebrov, the Ukrainian made nonsense of his poor form and the decision to drop him at Ipswich by curling a brilliant shot with the outside of his right foot beyond Harper and in via a post. As half-time approached only a fine save denied Rebrov an equally spectacular second.

Anyone who thought half-time would calm things down was in for a shock. Less than two minutes after the interval Dyer burst from near the halfway line and fell under a challenge from Sullivan.

Bennett pointed to the spot for a third time, sent off Sullivan to reduce the game to 10-a-side and Dyer scored from the spot to give Newcastle a chance of redeeming themselves as Graham withdrew Oyvind Leonhardsen and sent on Ian Walker.

Five minutes later Bennett was reaching for his red card again. Dyer was the recipient this time, seemingly for foul and abusive language towards one of the referee's assistants, who drew Bennett's attention to an incident after Dyer felt he should have had a free-kick.

Tottenham Hotspur (3-5-2): Sullivan; Doherty, Perry, Campbell; Leonhardsen (Walker, 48min), Anderton (Young, 83), Sherwood, King, Clemence; Rebrov, Ferdinand.

Newcastle United(4-4-2): Harper; Barton, Goma, Hughes, Griffin (Glass, 69); Solano, Acuna, Speed, Bassedas; Dyer, Ameobi (Lua-Lua, 69).

Referee: S Bennett.

webTitle: Solicitors may be freed to chase business

fields.headline: Solicitors may be freed to chase business
fields.trailText: The Law Society is considering lifting a ban on solicitors cold calling potential clients, raising the spectre of ambulance-chasing lawyers buttonholing accident victims in their hospital beds.
fields.body:
The Law Society is considering lifting a ban on solicitors cold calling potential clients, raising the spectre of ambulance-chasing lawyers buttonholing accident victims in their hospital beds.

The restriction on direct approaches to prospective clients was one of the few limitations on solicitors' freedom to advertise left in place when the total ban on advertising was lifted in the mid-1980s.

Solicitors, along with barristers and accountants, are under pressure from the office of fair trading, which is looking to dismantle the professions' remaining restrictive practices. The OFT report is due to go to ministers at the end of this month and is expected to be published in February.

A Law Society working party was already reviewing the profession's code of conduct when the OFT review was set up.

Alison Crawley, head of professional ethics at the society, said the only other advertising restriction - comparative advertising on quality and price which names a competitor firm and paints it in an unflattering light - could also go. Such advertising was considered unprofessional in the 1980s.

Rules banning solicitors from paying referral fees to third parties, such as estate agents, for introducing clients could also be scrapped. The working party favoured removing the ban but requiring the solicitor to tell the client about the fee, Ms Crawley said.

She confirmed that there were concerns that scrapping the rule against cold calling could lead to ambulance chasing. But some solicitors feel that if unqualified and unregulated claims assessors can approach prospective clients direct, then solicitors, who are qualified and regulated by the Law Society, should be allowed to do so.

Others feel that cold calling should be allowed for work such as conveyancing and will drafting, but not for personal injury cases and divorce. One possibility would be to retain the ban for those categories.

Ms Crawley said entrepreneurial City law firms wanted the ban lifted so they could compete with merchant banks, who had no hesitation in ringing prospective clients to offer their services. "Solicitors involved in financial services can't get work like other people in financial services."

webTitle: Teens turn to bootleg booze

fields.headline: Teens turn to bootleg booze
fields.trailText: Nearly half of youngsters under 17 know where to buy bootleg beer, according to a survey published today.
fields.body:
Nearly half of youngsters under 17 know where to buy bootleg beer, according to a survey published today.

The study, carried out for the Brewers and Licensed Retailers Association, showed 46% of 15 to 17-year-olds know where to buy illegal beer.

About 37% of 15 to 17-year-olds said they had local contacts who would sell them some kind of illegal alcohol - and one in 10 had bought beer from bootleggers.

The research also showed that the younger the teenager the more likely they were to know where to get illegal booze.

More than half of 15-year-olds said they could buy illegal beer from a contact, compared with 26% of 17-year-olds. And 35% of 15-year-olds compared with 24% of 17-year-olds said they could buy alcohol locally from someone's house or garage.

The study also showed there was no difference in awareness of the illegal booze trade between youngsters in the suburbs and their counterparts in the inner cities.

Rob Hayward, chief executive of BLRA, said the study showed the scale of the huge problem of the sale of bootleg alcohol to underage drinkers. "Bootlegging is an organised crime that damages the brewing and pubs industry by distorting competition, damages the taxpayer by denying revenue to the Treasury and damages young people by placing alcohol in the hands of underage drinkers.

"We now need a concerted and coordinated effort to end the illegal traffic in beer."

He called for a reduction in duty rates on alcohol to choke off demand. The gap on duty on beer between the UK and France is 29p a pint.

The survey of 501 15 to 17-year-olds was carried out by research organisation MRSL.

Press Association
