webTitle: Bylaw banning public drinking to go national

fields.headline: Bylaw banning public drinking to go national
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: An innovative bylaw aimed at reducing drunken assaults has been hailed such a success it will be used as a blueprint for countrywide legislation.
fields.body:
An innovative bylaw aimed at reducing drunken assaults has been hailed such a success it will be used as a blueprint for countrywide legislation.

Police in Manchester said the bylaw, which allows them to seize bottles and glasses of alcohol from people drinking in public places, has led to a reduction in assaults over Christmas and new year and contributed to a 10% drop in crime in the city centre.

On New Year's Eve, police took alcohol from 56 people. It was the first time the bylaw, introduced in September, was tested in Manchester at a big event.

There were 16 arrests, mostly for minor offences and at least 20,000 people were on the streets. All 56 people who were challenged gave up their drinks without protest. If they had refused, they could have been prosecuted and fined up to £1,000.

A Home Office spokeswoman said legislation would be introduced in the police and criminal justice bill, which has yet to be published, which will replace the bylaws by banning the consumption of alcohol in specific public places.

She said the aim was to simplify the bylaws introduced by local authorities, which would make it easier to enforce. The police would also be given powers to arrest people consuming alcohol in public places who refused to hand it over.

The bylaws have been more successful than other law and order initiatives introduced over the past 18 months, such as anti-social behaviour orders and child curfew orders.

Chief Inspector Garry Shewan, of Greater Manchester police, said: "It definitely made a big difference on New Year's Eve. The bylaw was incredibly well observed ... We feel it was a tremendous success."

"Nobody refused to hand over their drink when they were challenged by the police. People understood the relevance of the bylaw."

He said in previous years in Albert Square, where 8,500 people gathered, there had been problems with broken glass as a result of drinking in public.

This year he said there was less drunken loutish behaviour and no one used bottles as offensive weapons. He said there were 47 assaults reported this year compared with 52 assaults during the same period, December 22 to January 2, last year.

"In the last three or four months we have seen a tremendous change and we do not see gangs of young people roaming round from bar to bar with bottles in their hands," he added.

He was encouraged that the Home Office was planning to introduce similar legislation across the country.

Pat Karney, Manchester city councillor, said the message was getting through to the minority of trouble makers - that they would not be tolerated.

"For the first time, I could detect a growing maturity of young people who were celebrating the new year," he said. "Although we want to encourage people to celebrate, we don't want Manchester to become an urban Ibiza.

"We are prepared to go further and to ban people from the city for life if they cause problems such as drinking and fighting."

He said the city centre felt less threatening at midnight on New Year's Eve because of the bylaw.

"Jack Straw has lavished praise on this effort to try to stamp out the yob culture. He knows our approach is working," he added.

Liverpool city council was the first local authority to give police the powers to seize open bottles, cans and glasses of alcohol in specific public places. The bylaw was introduced in July last year and hailed a success by police.

webTitle: Building a presidential legacy

fields.headline: Quick, bring me a pen
fields.standfirst: On Bill Clinton's bogus efforts to build a presidential legacy overnight
fields.trailText: On Bill Clinton's bogus efforts to build a presidential legacy overnight
fields.body:
Freud quite rightly pointed out that we are not capable of imagining our own deaths, but that fact does not prevent people from picturing their own funerals, or designing suicide notes to make survivors feel sorry, or lavishly picturing how much they will be missed and mourned when they are "gone". The current babble about presidential "legacy" strikes me in much the same way. History will evolve its verdict in time; meanwhile, the effort self-consciously to condition a legacy seems bogus by definition.

In Clinton's case, the bogusness is enhanced by a flurry of executive orders and stroke-of-a-pen decisions, whereby he enacts things that he didn't have the guts to do in eight years of office. Having pardoned a few crooks (that bit presumably came naturally) he suddenly pardoned two non-violent narcotics offenders, gave an interview to Rolling Stone saying that he had his doubts about the war on drugs, rammed through some pro-labour and pro-environmental provisions, and announced that after all the US would sign the Rome Treaty setting up an international court to try war criminals. (The last action was taken a few hours before the New Year deadline.)

The crooks to one side, I am glad in principle to see all these decisions and I'd have been glad if Clinton had also responded to the appeal for a last-minute moratorium on the death penalty. (He didn't have the nerve, or do I mean the face, for that.) However, the means and the method seem so opportunistic and surreptitious, as well as smacking of an "Order in Council" or monarchical decree, that they tend to degrade the causes they favour. The opportunism can even have a negative effect, because although the pardons cannot be undone, the Rome Treaty can, and it is quite reasonable constitutionally for an incoming administration and a new congress to announce that it can't and won't be bound by a last-minute fiat. One can even picture certain Republicans seizing the lucky chance to repudiate the treaty as a matter of principle rather than of expediency.

It sounds amazing, and indeed it is amazing, but the opposition to the treaty thus far has been very candid: we don't want an international legal agreement governing war crimes because we may want to commit a few. This admission, that War Crimes 'R Us, might have been cloaked in a more seemly garb. However, there it is. The US under Clinton vetoed the United Nations resolution that would have beefed up the UN protection force in Rwanda before the genocide. It then supported the short-lived French military intervention on the side of those who committed the genocide. It nominated Slobodan Milosevic as a "partner in peace" at Dayton, and issued him a safe-conduct to the Ohio meeting while agreeing to his demand that Kosovo be left off the agenda. It managed to remain officially tight-lipped about all the court decisions concerning General Pinochet, even though investigations persist into his role in the murder of several American citizens. Almost the last words heard by General Suharto of Indonesia (before he, too, wisely opted to become a senile invalid) were the words of the Clinton spokesman who described him as "our kind of ally".

As with the landmines treaty, where Clinton also took a unilateralist and rejectionist position, the view seems to be that we won't discard any tactic we might feel we need. Obviously, one isn't a superpower for nothing, and there is the future to think about. However, I think the present evident nervousness about war crimes has also to do with the past, and the ways in which this past is legally as well as morally inescapable.

The proposition is about to be tested in two ways. It is quite probable that within a few weeks we will see General Ariel Sharon installed as prime minister of Israel. An Israeli commission of inquiry has already found him "indirectly responsible" for war crimes committed in Lebanon in 1982; an international tribunal could not possibly have come to such a lenient conclusion from the known facts. (The main "known fact" actually doesn't do the Palestinians much credit; their militia and its allies had destroyed the Christian Lebanese town of Damour a few years previously; the Phalangist unit released by Sharon into Sabra and Shatila camps was called the Damour Brigade and was composed of extremist survivors of that atrocity; Sharon's self-evident guilt thus also bespatters at least the military leadership of his victims. But these questions are supposed to be complicated.) American law as it stands prohibits the US government from giving aid to any country that harbours a wanted war criminal. Saudi Arabia is forgiven for sheltering Idi Amin, which it does to this day, on the presumable grounds that Riyadh gives aid to the American economy rather than the other way about. But these distinctions will become less fine once a boastful sponsor of bloody pogroms becomes the main recipient of Washington's military and economic subventions.

Then there is the spectre of Pinochet himself, and his chief death-squad organiser Manuel Contreras. In the past few months alone, it has been disclosed that Contreras (who is already in a Chilean jail) had enjoyed a full year on the CIA payroll. It has also been announced that certain highly placed people in the state department knew of the operation, code-named "Condor", whereby Pinochet colluded with fellow-dictators in Brazil, Argentina and Uruguay to conduct bombings and assassinations well beyond their own borders. One of those bombings took place in downtown Washington, a few hundred yards from where I live, at rush hour on September 21 1976. It murdered Orlando Letelier, a leading Chilean dissident, and his American friend Ronni Moffitt. It remains the only such act of state-supported terrorism ever to have occurred in the capital. Give American law credit for one thing: it is very slow and convoluted but it has an unstoppable quality. As I write, the mills are still grinding. The justice department is becoming less neutral, the FBI feels that it knows who issued the order, the ugly question of obstruction of justice and withholding of evidence is becoming more salient. At long last, the judicial arm may be about to assert itself. If and when it does - not to keep you in suspense much longer - a very famous American pundit may find himself somewhat embarrassed, not to say compromised.

I opened by saying that we cannot imagine our own deaths; this need not inhibit us from being strict and exact with those who enjoy imagining and encompassing the death of others.

fields.bodyText: Freud quite rightly pointed out that we are not capable of imagining our own deaths, but that fact does not prevent people from picturing their own funerals, or designing suicide notes to make survivors feel sorry, or lavishly picturing how much they will be missed and mourned when they are "gone". The current babble about presidential "legacy" strikes me in much the same way. History will evolve its verdict in time; meanwhile, the effort self-consciously to condition a legacy seems bogus by definition. In Clinton's case, the bogusness is enhanced by a flurry of executive orders and stroke-of-a-pen decisions, whereby he enacts things that he didn't have the guts to do in eight years of office. Having pardoned a few crooks (that bit presumably came naturally) he suddenly pardoned two non-violent narcotics offenders, gave an interview to Rolling Stone saying that he had his doubts about the war on drugs, rammed through some pro-labour and pro-environmental provisions, and announced that after all the US would sign the Rome Treaty setting up an international court to try war criminals. (The last action was taken a few hours before the New Year deadline.) The crooks to one side, I am glad in principle to see all these decisions and I'd have been glad if Clinton had also responded to the appeal for a last-minute moratorium on the death penalty. (He didn't have the nerve, or do I mean the face, for that.) However, the means and the method seem so opportunistic and surreptitious, as well as smacking of an "Order in Council" or monarchical decree, that they tend to degrade the causes they favour. The opportunism can even have a negative effect, because although the pardons cannot be undone, the Rome Treaty can, and it is quite reasonable constitutionally for an incoming administration and a new congress to announce that it can't and won't be bound by a last-minute fiat. One can even picture certain Republicans seizing the lucky chance to repudiate the treaty as a matter of principle rather than of expediency. The US under Clinton vetoed the United Nations resolution that would have beefed up the UN protection force in Rwanda before the genocide. webTitle: Dead cow dumping causes Spanish uproar

fields.headline: Dead cow dumping causes Spanish uproar
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Overwhelmed by new sanitation rules stemming from Europe's mad cow scare, Spanish authorities have provoked an uproar by dumping dead cows in an abandoned mine near a village.
fields.body:
Overwhelmed by new sanitation rules stemming from Europe's mad cow scare, Spanish authorities have provoked an uproar by dumping dead cows in an abandoned mine near a village.

The regional government in Galicia, where Spain's two confirmed cases of mad cow surfaced in November, said yesterday that the remains of some 100 cows which died in accidents or of natural causes have been placed in a disused quartz strip mine just outside Lanza in La Coruna province and covered with quicklime.

The dispute comes as officials in another agricultural region, Castile-Leon, reported two suspected cases of the illness yesterday.

Officials in Galicia said the mine burial technique conforms with EU health regulations. They did not say how many dead animals would eventually end up in the mine.

Residents in Lanza are worried that the carcasses will poison streams or ground water.

Lanza, with a population of about 500, falls under the jurisdiction of Mesia, whose mayor, Jose Fraga, appealed to the Galician government to halt the operation.

The mine is 300 metres from one of the houses in Lanza and half a mile from a primary school, Galician agriculture department spokesman, Manuel Cruz, said.

The Spanish government said carcasses must be turned over to local agricultural authorities and incinerated. The problem is that Galicia has about a million cattle and only one incinerator, Mr Cruz said. "It simply can't cope," he said.

 France launched an ambitious programme yesterday to test all 20,000 or so cows over 30 months old slaughtered each week for mad cow disease, six months ahead of an EU deadline. In November, the EU decided that all cows over 30 months old must be tested before entering the food chain.

webTitle: Graft testimony hits Philippines leader

fields.headline: Graft testimony hits Philippines leader
fields.trailText: A bank executive in the Philippines told the impeachment trial of President Joseph Estrada yesterday that while the trial was already underway her boss at the bank ordered her to cover up the fact that Mr Estrada was the holder of a multi-million dollar account listed under a false name.
fields.body:
A bank executive in the Philippines told the impeachment trial of President Joseph Estrada yesterday that while the trial was already underway her boss at the bank ordered her to cover up the fact that Mr Estrada was the holder of a multi-million dollar account listed under a false name.

Clarissa Ocampo, the senior vice-president of Equitable PCI Bank, testified before the senate's impeachment court that George Go, a friend of Estrada's, told her in mid-December to prepare documents to replace original papers showing the account belonged to a certain "Jose Velarde". Mr Go was chairman of PCI at the time.

She said the name Jose Velarde, linked to at least one other large transaction, was an alias used by President Estrada at her bank.

The testimony was some of the most damaging to date. Ms Ocampo had told a hearing of the impeachment court last month that she saw Mr Estrada sign a $10m (£6.8m) loan to the company of a friend, using the Velarde name, from a hidden account.

Taking the stand yesterday, Ms Ocampo said she was told on December 11 to prepare documents to show that the account's owner was Jaime Dichavez, a businessman and close friend of Mr Estrada.

The main trial started on December 7 with prosecutors alleging that Mr Estrada hid illicit fortunes under the fictitious name Jose Velarde.

Mr Go resigned as bank chairman in mid-December, saying he wanted to distance his bank from any suspicion of involvement in corruption.

Ms Ocampo also shocked those at yesterday's Senate trial by testifying that the signing of the new documents by Mr Dichavez on December 13 took place in the office of a prominent lawyer in President Estrada's defence team at the trial, Estelito Mendoza.

The lawyer acknowledged yesterday that Ms Ocampo and the others were at his office on that day but said he was not involved in the signing of bank documents.

Ms Ocampo said she decided to testify because she feared an attempt on her life to keep her quiet. She said she now lives in hiding. She became more frightened, she said, after five bomb attacks last Saturday killed 15 people and injured more than 100 in Manila.

President Estrada is on trial on charges of bribery, graft, betrayal of public trust and violation of the constitution. It is the country's first impeachment trial. A conviction on any charge by two-thirds of the 22-member Senate would force him from office.

The president publicly declared assets of $700,000 (£475,000) in 1999. He has a monthly salary of $1,000 as president. AP

webTitle: Assad weds bride from Britain's Syrian community

fields.headline: Assad weds bride from Britain's Syrian community
fields.trailText: Syria's young president, Bashar Assad, has married a young Syrian woman who grew up in London, the state newspaper Tishreen reported yesterday.
fields.body:
Syria's young president, Bashar Assad, has married a young Syrian woman who grew up in London, the state newspaper Tishreen reported yesterday.

In a brief front-page story accompanied by a large photograph of the president - but none of his bride - the paper said that President Assad and Asma al-Akhras had a New Year's day ceremony.

Speculation had been rife that the 35-year-old president was preparing to marry - or perhaps already had married - and much of the talk had focused on Ms Akhras, who is in her 20s.

She is the daughter of a Syrian cardiologist practising in London and from a prominent family in the town of Homs, 100 miles north of Damascus.

Tishreen, the only Syrian newspaper published yesterday, provided few details, saying only that Ms Akhras had a degree in computer science from a British university.

It did not say where the wedding was, or whether the bride was from the minority Alawite sect that controls the government. She is believed to have spent most of her life in Britain, where Mr Assad qualified as an eye doctor.

The president's late father and predecessor, Hafez al-Assad, strictly separated his private and public life, keeping his wife out of the limelight.

But the younger Assad has been more open, and his bride may take a more public role.

webTitle: International news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Bangladesh toll heads for 250
fields.body:
Bangladesh toll heads for 250

The death toll in the Bangladesh ferry disaster rose to 176 yesterday after dozens more bodies were washed ashore along the Meghna river where the vessel sank last Friday.

More than 70 people were missing, presumed dead after the ferry, carrying 400 passengers, and another passenger vessel collided in thick fog.
AP, Dhaka

Five missing in Pyrenees snow

Spanish rescue teams using helicopters yesterday recovered the body of a skier killed in an avalanche in the Pyrenees, but five others were still missing. The confirmed death toll in the past week stands at seven after violent weather hit the region.
AP, Madrid

Trial for Khmer Rouge leaders

Cambodia's national assembly passed a draft law yesterday to bring to justice leaders of the Khmer Rouge regime of the 1970s in a tribunal made up of Cambodian and international judges, officials said.
AP, Phnom Penh

Sect members die in custody

Four more members of the outlawed Falun Gong sect have died in police custody, bringing to at least 92 the death toll in China's 18-month crackdown, a human rights group said yesterday.

Three were beaten to death and the fourth was pushed from the sixth-floor window of a police station, the Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy said.
AP, Beijing

Algerian attacks claim nine lives

Four young children were among nine people killed in three attacks in Algeria over the New Year. The children's deaths and the murder of one other person in Djelfa, 155 miles south of Algiers, have been blamed on Islamic militants.

Elsewhere, two men died in bomb blasts and a journalist and an armed militant were killed in separate attacks.
AP, Algiers

Doomed sheep kills owner

An Egyptian sheep destined for sacrificial slaughter avoided its fate by pushing its owner to his death from a three-storey building in Alexandria.

Police said the sheep, which was tethered on the rooftop, butted Waheeb Hamoudah, 56, as it was being fed.
Reuters, Alexandria

webTitle: Risk of cervical cancer from chlamydia

fields.headline: Risk of cervical cancer from chlamydia
fields.trailText: A sexually transmitted disease that infects thousands of women in Britain is strongly linked to cervical cancer, scientists said yesterday.
fields.body:
A sexually transmitted disease that infects thousands of women in Britain is strongly linked to cervical cancer, scientists said yesterday.

Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common sexually transmitted organism in Britain, accounting in 1999 for 24,311 known new infections in men and 32,544 in women.

But because most cases show no symptoms, the actual number of infections is thought to be up to 90% greater.

The most serious threat from chlamydia is that it can make women sterile but other long term effects include pelvic inflammatory disease and ectopic pregnancy. Findings reported by Finnish scientists suggest it may also play a role in triggering cervical cancer.

One specific chlamydia strain, known as serotype G, is associated with a 6.6-fold increase in cancer risk, according to the study published yesterday in the Journal of the American Medical Association.

Women infected with two other strains had their chances of contracting cervical cancer increased by 3.8 and 2.7 times. Exposure to more than one strain raised the overall risk.

The investigators collated the results of blood tests given to 530,000 women in Finland, Norway and Sweden.

This data was matched to national cancer registries in each country. The scientists, led by Tarja Anttila from the national public health institute in Oulu, Finland, and Jorma Paavonen, from the University of Helsinki, then focused on 128 women who developed invasive cervical cancer at least 12 months after donating a blood sample.

The researchers looked for any association between the presence of antibodies identifying 10 different chlamydia strains and the development of squamous cell carcinoma, the most common form of cervical cancer.

According to the public health laboratory, the number of diagnosed chlamydia infections has soared by 76% since 1995.
Press Association

webTitle: Militants hold gun to Arafat's head

fields.headline: Militants hold gun to Arafat's head
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Islamic militant group, Hamas, issued a deadly threat yesterday to the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, warning that it would turn its campaign of terror against him should he agree to a peace deal with President Bill Clinton.
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill  in Ramallah, West Bank
fields.body:
The Islamic militant group, Hamas, issued a deadly threat yesterday to the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, warning that it would turn its campaign of terror against him should he agree to a peace deal with President Bill Clinton.

The leader of Hamas on the West Bank, Hassan Youssof, in an interview with the Guardian, accompanied the chilling warning with a prediction that Mr Arafat would be forced to reject the proposed settlement.

Until now, Hamas, the most feared of the Palestinian guerrilla groups, has struck only against Israeli targets. Although it has long opposed Mr Arafat's peace negotiations, it is now threatening to extend its campaign of violence to the Palestinian Authority leadership.

Mr Youssof said the political danger for Mr Arafat was that he could end up being confronted not only by Hamas but also a breakaway from his own organisation, Fatah, which he claimed had established strong links with Hamas since the uprising began in September.

The Hamas warning adds to the already enormous pressure on Mr Arafat, who met Mr Clinton in Washington last night to discuss the US peace plan.

Mr Youssof said all three key elements of the proposed peace settlement - the fate of the Palestinian refugees, the future of the Jerusalem holy site and the territorial division - were unacceptable.

He added: "As a Palestinian organisation, we refuse any agreement that does not give the Palestinian people three things: the right of its refugees to return to their homes; all of Jerusalem; and gets all settlers out of the West Bank and Gaza." The US proposals offer none of those.

Mr Youssof, 49, who has been jailed by Israel and the Palestinian Authority, hinted strongly that Israel could expect a return to suicide bombings, a campaign that created terror in Israel between 1994 and 1996. "Hamas will not stop fighting and bombing until the occupation is over," he said.

Israel has suffered two big bomb explosions in the last week, one in Tel Aviv and the other, on Monday night, in the coastal town of Netanya in which more than 30 people were wounded. Israeli police said that one of those it believed to be responsible for planting the bomb was in a critical condition.

Hamas described the bombing as the "holy right" of the Palestinian people but did not accept responsibility, which was claimed by a previously unknown group, the Vanguard of the Popular Army. Hamas often denies responsibility in order to avoid retaliation or a crackdown.

Hamas, which was partly financed by the Islamic terrorist Osama bin Laden until he had to flee from Sudan in 1996, was founded in 1987, during the first intifada.

The first Hamas suicide bomber killed eight Israelis when he rammed a car filled with explosives into a crowd in northern Israel in April 1994. The casualty rate over the next two years was high, as was the psychological toll on Israelis because the willingness of the bombers to die meant they could strike almost anywhere.

The campaign was brought to an end when Mr Arafat, under pressure from Israel, jailed about 900 members of Hamas, most of them since released. Mr Arafat worked against Hamas with the CIA and Israeli intelligence, Mossad.

Mr Youssof said he could not predict what individual cells of the Izzedine al-Qassem, the armed wing of Hamas, were plotting but he regarded suicide bombings as a justifiable Palestinian response to Israel's use of all the weapons in its arsenal other than nuclear and chemical weapons.

"We have a rule from the Koran and Mohammed that we should not kill any animal or people. [But] we use this kind of bombing to frighten them into stopping killing our people and children."

If, as Mr Youssof expects, Mr Arafat has no choice but to reject the deal because of the division it would create among Palestinians, he predicted that Hamas would join forces with Fatah - the biggest grouping within Mr Arafat's Palestinian Liberation Organisation - and other Palestinians in a united and bigger effort against Israel.

"Fatah is now with Hamas," he said.

Confronted by Israelis killing Palestinians, Mr Youssof said the Palestinians had no choice: "If people go to your home to kill one or two of your kids or throw you out on to the streets, will we give them roses or will we fight?"

Hamas had been increasingly isolated within Palestinian society because of its opposition to the peace process that led to the Israeli-Palestinian agreement at Oslo in 1993. But support for Hamas has increased since the latest intifada began in September, especially in universities.

Mr Youssof said the strength of feeling against the peace negotiations would be underlined in huge demonstrations planned for tomorrow in the West Bank.

"Seven years of negotiation with Israel did not give us anything of our rights but it has doubled the number of [Israeli] settlements, closed down our economy, destroyed homes, and given them control of the whole of Jerusalem."

Israel blames Mr Arafat for the resurgence of Hamas violence because he released many of the group's members from jail soon after the latest intifada began.

Palestinian Authority leaders claim that, although they did release them from jails because they were under threat from Israeli helicopter attacks, almost all of them have been rearrested. Part of the reason Mr Arafat threw open the jails was because of demonstrations in favour of the release of Hamas in places such as Nablus.

However, Mr Youssof said that of the 120 held in Palestinian Authority jails before the intifada, only 25 had been rearrested. More than 1,200 Hamas members are held in Israel.

He admitted that the alliance of the Palestinian, Israeli and US intelligence agencies had weakened Hamas. Its bomb-makers and others with technical experience had been singled out and assassinated. But Mr Youssof said Hamas would emerge stronger from the intifada.

He added: "As a Palestinian organisation, we refuse any agreement that does not give the Palestinian people three things: the right of its refugees to return to their homes; all of Jerusalem; and gets all settlers out of the West Bank and Gaza." The US proposals offer none of those. Mr Youssof, 49, who has been jailed by Israel and the Palestinian Authority, hinted strongly that Israel could expect a return to suicide bombings, a campaign that created terror in Israel between 1994 and 1996. "Hamas will not stop fighting and bombing until the occupation is over," he said. Israel has suffered two big bomb explosions in the last week, one in Tel Aviv and the other, on Monday night, in the coastal town of Netanya in which more than 30 people were wounded. Israeli police said that one of those it believed to be responsible for planting the bomb was in a critical condition. Hamas described the bombing as the "holy right" of the Palestinian people but did not accept responsibility, which was claimed by a previously unknown group, the Vanguard of the Popular Army. Hamas often denies responsibility in order to avoid retaliation or a crackdown. Hamas, which was partly financed by the Islamic terrorist Osama bin Laden until he had to flee from Sudan in 1996, was founded in 1987, during the first intifada. The first Hamas suicide bomber killed eight Israelis when he rammed a car filled with explosives into a crowd in northern Israel in April 1994. The casualty rate over the next two years was high, as was the psychological toll on Israelis because the willingness of the bombers to die meant they could strike almost anywhere. The campaign was brought to an end when Mr Arafat, under pressure from Israel, jailed about 900 members of Hamas, most of them since released. Mr Arafat worked against Hamas with the CIA and Israeli intelligence, Mossad. Mr Youssof said he could not predict what individual cells of the Izzedine al-Qassem, the armed wing of Hamas, were plotting but he regarded suicide bombings as a justifiable Palestinian response to Israel's use of all the weapons in its arsenal other than nuclear and chemical weapons. "We have a rule from the Koran and Mohammed that we should not kill any animal or people. [But] we use this kind of bombing to frighten them into stopping killing our people and children." If, as Mr Youssof expects, Mr Arafat has no choice but to reject the deal because of the division it would create among Palestinians, he predicted that Hamas would join forces with Fatah - the biggest grouping within Mr Arafat's Palestinian Liberation Organisation - and other Palestinians in a united and bigger effort against Israel. "Fatah is now with Hamas," he said. Confronted by Israelis killing Palestinians, Mr Youssof said the Palestinians had no choice: "If people go to your home to kill one or two of your kids or throw you out on to the streets, will we give them roses or will we fight?" Hamas had been increasingly isolated within Palestinian society because of its opposition to the peace process that led to the Israeli-Palestinian agreement at Oslo in 1993. But support for Hamas has increased since the latest intifada began in September, especially in universities. Mr Youssof said the strength of feeling against the peace negotiations would be underlined in huge demonstrations planned for tomorrow in the West Bank. "Seven years of negotiation with Israel did not give us anything of our rights but it has doubled the number of [Israeli] settlements, closed down our economy, destroyed homes, and given them control of the whole of Jerusalem." Israel blames Mr Arafat for the resurgence of Hamas violence because he released many of the group's members from jail soon after the latest intifada began. Palestinian Authority leaders claim that, although they did release them from jails because they were under threat from Israeli helicopter attacks, almost all of them have been rearrested. Part of the reason Mr Arafat threw open the jails was because of demonstrations in favour of the release of Hamas in places such as Nablus. However, Mr Youssof said that of the 120 held in Palestinian Authority jails before the intifada, only 25 had been rearrested. More than 1,200 Hamas members are held in Israel. He admitted that the alliance of the Palestinian, Israeli and US intelligence agencies had weakened Hamas. Its bomb-makers and others with technical experience had been singled out and assassinated. But Mr Youssof said Hamas would emerge stronger from the intifada. Useful links Yasser Arafat's office Ehud Barak's office Palestinian National Authority Israeli government Hamas

webTitle: Diary: Matthew Norman

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: While so-called rivals look forward to the year ahead and return to the aching drudgery of attempting to fill the space with "stories", the Diary continues its kamikaze mission into a uniquely undistinguished past. As noted here already, 2000 was a depressingly thin year - but there was one regular feature which almost caught the imagination. In Carry On Up The Cabinet, we sought to cast New Labour in the genre which somehow seems to suit it best. These are the results.
fields.body:
While so-called rivals look forward to the year ahead and return to the aching drudgery of attempting to fill the space with "stories", the Diary continues its kamikaze mission into a uniquely undistinguished past. As noted here already, 2000 was a depressingly thin year - but there was one regular feature which almost caught the imagination. In Carry On Up The Cabinet, we sought to cast New Labour in the genre which somehow seems to suit it best. These are the results.

 The irksome but essentially harmless vacuity of Jim Dale makes him a shoo-in for Mr Tony Blair, but Cherie proved more troublesome. Suggestions included Anita Harris, Sally Geeson, the brilliant impressionist Ronnie Ancona and Carry On Cleo star Amanda Barrie, but eventually a reader offered up a masterstroke: Cherie will be played by Charles Hawtrey. Cherie's father Tony Booth appears as himself, and for no other reason than to dredge up that misspent youth again, Alastair Campbell will be portrayed by porn movie legend Ben Dover, making his long awaited mainstream debut.

 Although Charles Hawtrey was also a popular choice for O'Mandy Mandelson, a shared gift for nostril-flaring, telling leaders of loyalist paramilitaries to "Stop messin' about!" and mild persecution mania ("Infamy, infamy, they've all got in for me," as O'Mandy declared the day he was sacked as trade secretary) swings it for Kenneth Williams. As for Gordon Brown, although many favoured Hattie Jacques, the similarity in shape, gait and comic patter strongly suggests Frankie Howerd.

 Ms Jacques was also proposed, by Graham Garden among others, for John Prescott. The notion of the deputy PM being played by Hingist Pod, the British transport mastermind in Carry On Cleo who invented the square wheel, was too surreal and sometimes you have to go with the manageable, however obvious, so the part goes to the late Terry Scott.

 Happily, some casting decided itself. Sid James's cheekie chappiness is made for Ken Livingstone, while the imperious stridency of Penelope Keith makes her a natural Margaret Jay. Dora Bryan has the camp northern charm of Betty Booth-royd. Roy Kinnear is tubby Euro policy blabbermouth Roger Liddle, Reg Varney is a ringer for Tony Banks and Macaulay Culkin will portray the public health minister Yvette Cooper.

 Rounding up other central members of the project, Jack Douglas plays Jack Straw; Jeff Tracy, badger-like boss of International Rescue on Thunderbirds, is Alistair Darling; and Bernie Bresslaw is David Blunkett. Joan Sims will be Mo Mowlam, while Una Stubbs will double up as employment minister Tessa Jowell and, for any flashback sequences, Harriet Harman. Sadly, Alan Milburn, Stephen Byers and Geoff Hoon are too dull to bother with, while no one can remember enough about dear old Andrew Smith to have any ideas at all.

 Finally, by way of plugging the thumbnail sketches that will appear here tomorrow and Friday, we come to Turncoat of Turncoats candidates. Barbara Windsor plays Clare "Bomber" Short, while Stephen Lewis from On The Buses is Lord Gus Macdonald ("I 'ate you, reprivatisation of the railways, I 'ate you ..."). Gareth Hunt, so fondly remembered for his amusing hand-shaking gesture in the Nescafe commercials, will of course be Peter Hain. Don Warrington (medical student Philip in Rising Damp) hams it to the skies for Paul Boateng. The part of my friend Barbara Roche goes to Russ Abbott's onetime sidekick, Bella Emberg. And last, but hardly least, acting on the assumption that the brownest of all New Labour noses will shortly return to fighting weight, Hattie Jacques is booked for Son Simon.

webTitle: Comment:  Paul Hamlyn's donation to Labour

fields.headline: Why didn't they just publish and be damned?
fields.standfirst:
Paul Hamlyn's donation to Labour should never have caused such a fuss

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Paul Hamlyn's donation to Labour should never have caused such a fuss.
fields.body:
So, it ended more as a tale of naivety than knavery, another classic lesson for a political party in how not to conduct its affairs. After three days of procrastination, Labour yesterday finally identified its latest £2m donor. The truth - Lord Hamlyn, publisher, philanthropist and long-time Labour supporter - was far less painful than the speculation. So why did they try to hide it? Why did they try to slip this one in before the deadline of February 16, after which the identity and sum of all large gifts will have to be declared?

It falls into that very human impulse - getting away with it, while breaking no rules. Thousands of people do it all the time - it's the difference between tax avoidance and tax evasion. Paul Hamlyn has certainly done nothing wrong. He thinks his beneficence is helping democracy. He thought, especially in the light of a serious illness, that he was entitled to anonymity. His friends in the party should have told him this was no longer possible.

The problem is expectation. After years of Tory sleaze, this Labour government was expected to be more ethical and more transparent. This is what the prime minister said in August 1997, issuing a new code of conduct for ministers: "We are all here to serve, and we must all serve honestly, and in the interests of those who gave us our positions of trust." Three months later the Bernie Ecclestone and the formula one tobacco saga was revealed.

It is harder to be open when you're running short of money - or when you think you're running short of money. At Millbank Tower and at the Tories' Smith Square HQ, they have been trying to devise ever more intricate ways of balancing the books. Long before they lost power, the Conservatives were finding it harder to convince blue chip companies there was anything to be gained from opening their coffers. Hence the reliance on Michael Ashcroft and a few other individuals. Tony Blair's complicated relationship with the trade unions has made life harder for Millbank's money-gatherers. Union donations are coming in again for the election, but not as quickly or as generously as the party would like. New Labour's wooing of the City in the mid-90s still leaves a number of generously-minded big companies, but fewer than before. Hence, the reliance on Lord Sainsbury and a few other individuals.

A year ago, Labour came clean with David Sainsbury's £2m, and that story died within a day. Part of the reason for acting so promptly was the knowledge - in the light of the Ecclestone revelations - that Millbank is a leaky place. "Anyone who thinks that we could carry another £2m donation all the way to the election without it getting out is guilty of gross naivety," said one minister.

It was Tony Blair who asked Lord Neill's committee on standards in public life to investigate the funding of political parties. John Major had refused to do this. The committee's report of October 1998 was largely accepted by the government, and it is this legislation which comes into effect in six weeks time. Three measures stand out - the formation of an electoral commission, a limit of £20m per party in election spending, and the requirement that the names and amounts of all donations over £5,000 be declared.

Laudable though the changes are, they won't be enough. In the long-term, state funding will be the only option. The committee looked at state funding in a number of countries, concluding that although the issue is "finely balanced", it thought best to hold off. In their submission to the committee, the Liberal Democrats came up with a scheme - artfully designed to help medium-sized parties - in which any party with more than 5% of the vote would get £2m, with a further £10m distributed between the parties in proportion to the national vote.

The Tories and Labour opposed the idea of state funding. But now in Downing Street and at Millbank there are signs of change. Several key figures who were opposed to state funding are now wavering. Intriguingly, Labour's general secretary, Margaret McDonagh - no great advocate of constitutional reform - is now suggesting there is a "persuasive argument for state funding of political parties". Tony Blair is said to be, "on balance against, but persuadable".

He can be persuaded. One of the arguments against state funding is that it divorces politics from voters - no more community tombolas, no more effort to bring new members on board. Yet, apart from a blip before the last election, membership is on a steady downward spiral. The reasons for people deserting political parties are many, but not being able to give money is hardly one of them. In any case, small contributions would not necessarily have to be banned. Schemes could be devised allowing parties to top up the money they get from the state with membership dues, or by other local means. There could be an element of matching funding - as long as the private money was openly declared. There could be extra money for research, or as in Germany for party-based think tanks.

As for the biggest objection - that taxpayers' money should not go to political activity - it would surely be less invidious than seeing the major parties dependent on the largesse of a few people. If these individuals are motivated purely by philanthropy, let them donate to the thousands of charities whose needs are greater than a political party rustling up the cash for another billboard advert. When Lord Hamlyn said in his statement: "Our democracy depends on vibrant political parties and for years the Conservatives had a virtual monopoly on large donations from individuals", he was missing the point. Labour supporters did not want their party to emulate the Tories.

One of Tony Blair's unique selling points in 1997 was his pledge to reinvent politics. That required constitutional and behavioural change. Progress, to put it charitably, has been patchy. Now he is letting it be known that too much of the first term's agenda was devoted to the constitution; the second term will all be about public service delivery. Yet the two are linked. The government expresses constant frustration that its achievements in, say, education and employment, are not appreciated enough. They blame that on the media. Maybe, instead, they should look inwards, and ask themselves why the government's credibility ratings, in opinion polls, are not as high as they might be.

Voters are more likely to believe a claim by a minister, on any issue, if they feel the government to be fundamentally honest. If anything is to be learned from this maladroit episode it is that open politics and successful politics are one and the same thing.

JKAMPFNER@aol.com

Polly Toynbee is away

webTitle: Turks find survivor of 30-hour sea ordeal

fields.headline: Turks find survivor of 30-hour sea ordeal
fields.trailText: A 27 year old man from Bangladesh was rescued from rocks off the southern coast of Turkey yesterday, nearly 30 hours after the sinking of a cargo ship in which he and about 70 other illegal migrants were travelling.
fields.body:
A 27 year old man from Bangladesh was rescued from rocks off the southern coast of Turkey yesterday, nearly 30 hours after the sinking of a cargo ship in which he and about 70 other illegal migrants were travelling.

"There was a very strong wind," he said. "I saw other people trying to swim after the accident, but I think they are all dead."

The Turkish authorities believe at least 50 people died on board the Georgian-registered ship, the Pati. Many of them were locked inside the hold and trapped as the stricken vessel broke in two.

Helicopters and ships scoured the disaster area yesterday near the popular seaside resort of Antalya. More than 30 people - including the ship's Greek captain - were rescued on Monday, and the authorities were astonished that they found anyone else alive more than a day later.

The man rescued yesterday identified himself as Abu Kalam Ajad from Bangladesh. He said he wanted to go to Athens. He told local officials that he and his fellow migrants had been picked up by the crew of the Pati shortly after it left Antalya bound for Greece in heavy seas.

When the ship sank, he said, he swam ashore amid scenes of panic. More than a full day later a rescue plane spotted him huddled in a rocky cove. Naval commandoes in a rubber dinghy brought the bewildered and exhausted man to safety.

"I should have died too," he said, "I'm still not sure how I survived."

Local officials believe it was a combination of good fortune and the fact that he smeared oil on his body to protect himself from the cold. He has bruises on his limbs and face, but his overall condition is good.

Last night the search for further survivors was called off as darkness fell and rough seas returned. Several body parts were recovered from the sea during the day, and officials say they will resume operations to remove dead bodies from the wreck this morning.

"Divers have found there is no air left in the hold of the ship," Can Karaca, a local coast guard commander, said.

The Pati was supposed to have left Antalya empty, after being unable to collect a consignment of cement. Its human cargo, picked up secretly under cover of night, was probably far more valuable.

The migrants aboard the ship were nearly all from countries in south Asia - most of them from India and Pakistan. They were just one small part of a human wave which washes through Turkey every week on its way to the European Union.

People smuggling is a massive business, and is run by highly organised gangs.

Would-be migrants pay thousands of pounds for the chance of making the hazardous journey to the West, where they believe they have the chance of a better life.

webTitle: Comment: Israel simply has no right to exist

fields.headline: Israel simply has no right to exist
fields.standfirst:
Peace might have a real chance without Israelis' biblical claims

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Peace might have a real chance without Israelis' biblical claims.
fields.body:
Several years ago, I suggested in my students' union newspaper that Israel shouldn't exist. I also said the sympathy evoked by the Holocaust was a very handy cover for Israeli atrocities. Overnight I became public enemy number one. I was a Muslim fundamentalist, a Jew-hater, somebody who trivialised the memory of the most abominable act in history. My denouncers followed me, photographed me, and even put telephone calls through to my family telling them to expect a call from the grim reaper.

Thankfully, my notoriety in Jewish circles has since waned to the extent that recently I gave an inter-faith lecture sponsored by the Leo Baeck College, even though my views have remained the same. Israel has no right to exist. I know it's a hugely unfashionable thing to say and one which, given the current parlous state of the peace process, some will also find irresponsible. But it's a fact that I have always considered central to any genuine peace formula.

Certainly there is no moral case for the existence of Israel. Israel stands as the realisation of a biblical statement. Its raison d'être was famously delineated by former prime minister Golda Meir. "This country exists as the accomplishment of a promise made by God Himself. It would be absurd to call its legitimacy into account."

That biblical promise is Israel's only claim to legitimacy. But whatever God meant when he promised Abraham that "unto thy seed have I given this land, from the river of Egypt unto the great river, the Euphrates," it is doubtful that he intended it to be used as an excuse to take by force and chicanery a land lawfully inhabited and owned by others.

It does no good to anyone to brush this fact, uncomfortable as it might be, under the table. But that has been the failing with Oslo. When it signed the agreement, the PLO made the cardinal error of assuming that you could bury the hatchet by rewriting history. It accepted as a starting point that Israel had a right to exist. The trouble with this was that it also meant, by extension, an acceptance that the way Israel came into being was legitimate. As the latest troubles have shown, ordinary Palestinians are not prepared to follow their leaders in this feat of intellectual amnesia.

Israel's other potential claim to legitimacy, international recognition, is just as dubious. The two pacts which sealed Palestine's future were both concluded by Britain. First we signed the Sykes-Picot agreement with France, pledging to divvy up Ottoman spoils in the Levant. A year later, in 1917, the Balfour Declaration promised a national home for the Jewish people. Under international law the declaration was null and void since Palestine did not belong to Britain - under the pact of the League of Nations it belonged to Turkey.

By the time the UN accepted a resolution on the partition of Palestine in 1947, Jews constituted 32% of the population and owned 5.6% of the land. The "promise" breeds an arrogance which institutionalises the inferiority of other peoples and generates atrocities against them with alarming regularity. It allows soldiers to defy their consciences and blast unarmed schoolchildren. It gives rise to legislation seeking to prevent the acquisition of territory by non-Jews.

A state based on so exclusivist a claim to legitimacy cannot but conceive of separation as a solution. But separation is not the same as lasting peace; it only pulls apart warring parties. It does not heal old wounds, let alone redress historical wrongs.

What name that coexistence will take is less important than the fact that peoples have forgiven and that some measure of justice has been restored. Jews will continue to live in the Holy Land - as per the promise - as equals alongside its other rightful inhabitants.

webTitle: First women join German combat units

fields.headline: First women join German combat units
fields.trailText: For the first time the German military opened its ranks to women in combat units yesterday, accepting 244 female recruits who previously would have been confined to medical or musical regiments.
fields.byline: Michael Krechtig in Dülmen, north-west Germany
fields.body:
For the first time the German military opened its ranks to women in combat units yesterday, accepting 244 female recruits who previously would have been confined to medical or musical regiments.

The move to an equal-opportunity Bundeswehr comes less than a year after a young German army engineer, Tanja Kreil, won a case before the European Court in Luxembourg, which ruled that Germany's laws restricting the role of women in the armed forces violated EU laws against discrimination.

She withdrew her application in the summer without explanation. But since parliament changed the law in October, making it possible for women to serve in tank battalions, as fighter pilots or on submarines, more than 1,900 women have applied to join, either as commissioned or non-commissioned officers.

The reform brings Germany into line with other Nato members, including France, Britain and the US - though some countries still keep women out of infantry combat units and submarine crews.

Yesterday, 151 women reported for duty in the army, 76 in the air force and 17 in the navy - for the first time facing the same basic training as men.

"Basic training will certainly be a difficult job, but that's why I'm here," said Aysun Yazici, 18, reporting for duty at the barracks at Dülmen in the north-west.

Putting on her backpack, Silvia Siebenhar, 23, who left her job in a bakery, said that as a member of the forces "you can help people, you'll be needed and can learn a lot. And I'm someone who needs action."

The idea has yet to be embraced by average Germans. The leading weekly, Der Spiegel, ran a story headlined: "What to do when women cry?" But it also reported that male soldiers felt female competition would make them work harder.

Many conservatives argue that the shifting of tasks to include peacekeeping and crisis management has already put the army under stress. AP

webTitle: 'Bias' claim delays hearing into fatal fire at Queensland hostel

fields.headline: 'Bias' claim delays hearing into fatal fire at Queensland hostel
fields.trailText: In the latest shock to families devastated by the backpackers' hostel fire last June in Australia, the committal hearing of the alleged arsonist has been delayed after claims the magistrate was biased.
fields.body:
In the latest shock to families devastated by the backpackers' hostel fire last June in Australia which claimed 15 lives, including those of six Britons, the committal hearing of the alleged arsonist has been delayed after claims the magistrate was biased.

Michael Halliday was asked to stand down by the defendant's lawyer, Craig Chowdhury, after he had expressed his condolences to the family and friends of those killed in the midnight blaze at Childers in Queensland. After Mr Halliday refused, Mr Chowdhury took the matter to the supreme court, which could delay the committal hearing until at least Thursday.

The magistrate also dismissed an application by Mr Chowdhury to ban the media from the court after he claimed some previous reporting had been inflammatory and prejudicial.

Robert Long, 37, appeared at Brisbane magistrates court charged with arson and the murder of Western Australian twins Stacey and Kelly Slarke, 22. He has entered no plea. He is also charged with unlawfully wounding and attempting to kill a police officer during his arrest after a five day manhunt.

The two women were among six Britons, four Australians, one Irish national, two Dutch, one Korean and a Japanese who died when the 100-year-old timber Palace Backpackers hostel burst into flame on June 23. About 70 backpackers who were working as fruitpickers, escaped.

Mr Halliday defended having expressed his sympathy to the court at the start of proceedings: "I am acutely aware of my duty and role and in particular, the right of an accused person to a hearing of a completely unbiased tribunal. I believe that my expressions, so made, do not infringe upon or compromise such a role and are not intended to do so."

But Mr Chowdhury claimed the statement was inappropriate and that there was a reasonable concern that the magistrate was not impartial.

"I have never heard any judicial officer from the bench in such a public manner express sympathy for the victims' families," he said.

However, Michael Byrne QC, prosecuting, said the magistrate's stand was one of human emotion. "The law does not require judicial officers ... to be inhuman or to lack human emotion."

webTitle: Thirty years on, Ibrox recalls a day of disaster

fields.headline: Thirty years on, Ibrox recalls a day of disaster
fields.standfirst: A fan's stumble at the end of a Glasgow derby match led to 66 deaths. Yesterday Rangers unveiled a memorial to the dead
fields.trailText: A fan's stumble at the end of a Glasgow derby match led to 66 deaths. Yesterday Rangers unveiled a memorial to the dead.
fields.body:
It had been a good-natured game for a Rangers-Celtic clash. No trouble in the capacity crowd and two fine goals just as the match drew to a close and the terraces started to empty.

Then somebody slipped. A simple stumble on the steep incline of Ibrox stadium's stair 13 started a deadly spiral as hundreds more lost their balance and fell, crushed against each other and the buckling handrails.

Sixty-six people died and more than 140 were injured in Scotland's worst football disaster on January 2, 1971, and yesterday, 30 years to the day, Ibrox and Glasgow remembered.

John Findlay, 75, had been heading down stair 13 at the Rangers end of the ground when a friend pulled him clear. He joined thousands of other fans and families at yesterday's memorial service at Ibrox when a statue was unveiled to commemorate the dead. "My friend was a tall guy and he saw what was happening down in the front of us and he shouted, we're going to get crushed and he dragged me out of the crowd," said Mr Findlay. "I saw people lying on the ground and some of them were still moving. But then I looked up at stair 13 there was just a mass of bodies. They were dead."

Sixty-six deaths and each one as cruel as the next. An eight-year-old boy; an 18-year-old girl, football daft, who had defied her father to attend the game and was the only female victim; five teenagers from the small Fife town of Markinch, four of them from the same street.

Josephine McLeay's husband, Richard, 27, died along with his younger brother, John, 23. She did not find out until the following day that her husband was among the victims.

"He lived and died for Rangers," she said yesterday. "He was a terrific supporter and with today's memorial I feel he is at peace now. I never really had a chance to say cheerio to him but I felt I have done that today." Her daughter, Audrey, 31, who was one when her father was killed, joined her at the service. "It gave me a chance to say goodbye to my dad," she said.

The players that day, most of whom were unaware of the horror unfolding as they left the pitch, spent the following weeks at funerals and hospital bedsides.

The grass they had played on became a temporary morgue, bodies taken from the terraces laid out in rows as the light started to go. Frantic families were taken to the central police station in the early hours of the following day to hear an officer read the roll call of the dead.

John Greig was Rangers captain for the match and it was his statue that was unveiled as the memorial, the stone beneath bearing the names of all those who perished.

"The club is a big family and when a thing like that happens you take it personally," he said. "It took us a long time to get over it but to this day, every year, I still feel something. You live with the feelings."

The tragedy was not the first to hit the club. In the 1960s two fans were killed and more than 80 injured in two separate crushes on the same steps. On April 12, 1902, during a Scotland-England international, 25 people were killed when the west terracing of the ground collapsed. Their names are also on the memorial stone.

Rangers officials vowed that the events of January 1971 would never happen again and Ibrox was steadily redesigned and rebuilt, making it one of the safest football grounds in Europe.

John Findlay said the stadium itself was the real memorial to those who lost their lives.

"The ground will be the legacy for all of them," he said. "I came here today to remember and to say thank you."

webTitle: Leader: Labour shares the nation's priorities now

fields.headline: Better late than never
fields.standfirst:
Labour shares the nation's priorities now

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Labour shares the nation's priorities now
fields.body:
Liberation took a long time to come, but it finally arrived in April last year. The long-term spending boost to social policy which Labour introduced then was historic, ending an era stretching back two decades. "Public expenditure," declared the opening sentence of Margaret Thatcher's first white paper in 1979 "is at the heart of Britain's present economic difficulties". What followed through her years of stewardship proved how true she was to that bleak conclusion.

By the time New Labour at last saw the light, public services were deeply demoralised and financially impoverished. For over a decade under Margaret Thatcher, they were publicly derided for the way they spent money rather than made it. Even the people's priorities, such as education and health, for which polls showed large majorities in favour of major investment, continued to be denied the resources they needed. The final insult was New Labour's stubborn adherence to Tory spending targets for its first two years - targets the Tories would never have stuck to.

But all has now changed. We have had not one, but two comprehensive spending reviews. Together, they account for the largest sustained increase in social policy spending ever envisaged. It is not just the size of the increase - health spending rising at twice its historic rate - but the length of the programme. For the first time in a generation, education and health administrators can plan ahead. The second review has guaranteed increases - a real terms rise of one third for the NHS - through to 2004.

Politics has changed too. Labour is rightly bragging about the size of the increases. Tony Blair called a special Downing Street press conference in November where in pre-election mood he said what he should have said long before: "Who can seriously doubt that Britain has been chronically underinvested in for over 20 years? We have the fourth biggest economy in the world. Yet we do not have the fourth best public services. I lay the blame for that firmly at the door of underinvestment."

Even more fascinating is the Tory response. Labour's initial spending review was dubbed "irresponsible and reckless". But by last July's second review, even they were promising to match Labour pound for pound in increases for health and education - although they remained committed to spending cuts of between £8bn and £16bn to other unspecified services. By last month, Mr Hague was talking about spending reductions that would come from "savings - not cuts to public services". He must have known this was nonsense.

Public spending is reinstalled as a public virtue. But Labour faces two other problems. First, given the two-year delay at the start, there will be little sign of the benefits from these big increases between now and the election. It takes three years to train a nurse and seven years for a doctor. And as Nigel Lawson ruefully noted when chancellor, the problem with increased education expenditure is that its returns are not apparent within the life term of even the longest-lived administration.

Labour's second problem is the dire state of public services which it inherited. Far too many teachers, social workers and health staff have been forced to work amid dilapidation and squalor. Even Labour's historic increases will need to last for more than a decade to turn round two decades of financial squeeze. A third challenge has already been anticipated by Gordon Brown: the need to ensure the extra money is well spent. No chancellor has done more to put in place proper monitoring arrangements.

There are plenty of reforms in Labour's record of which they can be rightly proud. They have started to reverse the brutal widening of inequality that occurred under the Tories - the threefold increase in child poverty. Over 1.2m of the 4.4m children living in poverty will be lifted out by 2002. Even more boldly, Labour is committed to lifting them all out by 2020. There has never been a period with so many social experiments - 18 separate taskforces tackling urban regeneration, a flurry of special initiatives to deal with the socially excluded (rough sleepers, truants, children in care), a clutch of new programmes to help families under pressure.

Mainstream services have made major advances. In education, the most notable has been the improvement in English and maths in primary schools, where Labour introduced daily literacy and numeracy hours. In law 'n' order, a new emphasis on prevention - including helping 2m poor householders to reinforce their property - has drastically reduced burglaries and car thefts. The government's 10-year health plan won the endorsement of all the major players - medics, managers and nurses.

But there is plenty more to do. Education ministers have still not provided a coherent plan for non-academic 14-year-olds. Their under-funding of universities has been shameful. The Home Office has honoured the first but not the second half of the party's mantra: tough on crime, tough on its causes - and has been absurdly timid in reforming our outdated drug laws. Vigilance is needed if the anti-racist reforms that followed the Lawrence inquiry are to succeed.

The Conservatives pose no threat. They remain incoherent, initially conceding they needed to become more caring, but now reverting to hardline policies that will only alienate them further from the centre ground. Labour has done much to deserve a second term. First because of the way it has made Britain a fairer society. Second, so that its many fascinating social experiments can have a proper trial. Successful projects need time for consolidation and expansion - and for failures to be weeded out.

webTitle: Arthur Smith: A quick one

fields.headline: A quick one
fields.trailText: It's been a tough gig but, so far in 2001 I have succeeded in not giving up smoking.
fields.body:
It's been a tough gig but, so far in 2001 I have succeeded in not giving up smoking. Every time a stop-smoking commercial came on before New Year's Eve, I bravely fumbled for a fresh Consulate (don't ask) and contrived to light it before the strap-line. By similar feats of willpower I have managed to avoid buying any cut-price furniture.

The still-smoking-no-settee success has jettisoned me into further campaigns of self- improvement. Harry tells me that I have revived the ancient pagan tradition of "making New Year's Resolutions". Good. My principal ambitions concern language. Never again will I use the word "shag". It was all right in the era of Bridget Jones and Austin Powers, although, even then, it was never as effective as when Shakespeare, hilariously, changed his name briefly to Shagspeare in 1952. Now the word is scattered throughout conversations and TV scripts. It's curious - shag has been lurking around for years doing its job unpretentiously, never complaining about the brief, flashy career of bonk. But over the last couple of years it's got dressed up and started hanging out with its mates, wicked and pants. It's too much. I urge you to denounce shag and put it where you once put screw.

My other linguistic resolution concerns a catch phrase that has insinuated itself into social situations in a short amount of time. I refer to: "You are the weakest link, goodbye." It's a guaranteed laugh when the repartee is poor. In fact it's become so common that you say it as soon as you arrive at an event to make sure you get in first. You might try for a change greeting your hostess with: "I am the weakest link, hello." As a semi-professional comedian, I have to maintain standards so I shall henceforth eschew the dread Robinsonism.

I've noticed that my resolutions involve me not doing stuff that I wasn't going to do anyway so here's something more positive. I'm going to retrain as a Latin teacher in a provincial public school. And the only shag I will have will be the sweet brown tobacco in my pipe.

webTitle: Leader: There is nothing to beat a straight answer

fields.headline: A benefactor unmasked
fields.standfirst:
There is nothing to beat a straight answer

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: There is nothing to beat a straight answer
fields.body:
In the nick of time, Labour's mystery donor has come to the aid of the party. The man who gave £2m was yesterday revealed to be the publisher Lord Hamlyn, who was happy to admit to it. Since he is seriously ill and clearly has nothing to gain in the way of governmental reward, it may not be so easy now for the Conservative party to continue to use this affair as an emblem of Labour sleaze.

Which is just as well, since as late as yesterday morning Labour still seemed intent on making things worse by failing to honour the lesson it should have learned from the Bernie Ecclestone case. Which is this: at times like these, do not try to wriggle your way out of trouble; come as clean as you can, as soon as you can. To hear Alan Milburn on the Today programme maintaining that he knew nothing recalled some of Gordon Brown's misjudgments at the height of the Ecclestone crisis.

Still, now we know what we needed to know; and better still, we know that this kind of problem should not occur again, since from February 16, all donations to national funds worth more than £5,000 will have to be declared. In the light of the Conservative invocation of sleaze this week, it is worth remembering why. The requirement to declare substantial donations and the equally necessary and overdue £20m ceiling on party election spending were recommended by the Neill committee, set up by John Major to safeguard standards in public life. When the committee first wanted to look at this issue, the Conservatives blocked it. It was only when Labour came to power that reform became possible. When Tories snipe at Labour for dodging the February 16 deadline, they hope we will forget that, had they had their way, there would have been no deadline at all.

There is a broader issue here for the parties to reflect on. With the level of company and union donations falling, both main parties are more than ever desperate to persuade private donors to give substantial sums. Labour badly needs its Lord Hamlyns to help make up the shortfall when the unions fail to provide what the party has asked for; even now, doubts remain about how it can raise the £20m the new rules allow. But what is this spending for? On past evidence, a lot of it goes to promulgate half-truths and lies which electors are mostly too smart to fall for. Since both parties keep promising wars against waste, it seems odd that they do so little to curb their own. The party which made most progress in the 1997 campaign was not the Conservatives (£28.3m) or Labour (£25.7m) but their impoverished cousins the Liberal Democrats (£2.3m).

Suggestions have now resurfaced that Labour may soon look again at the case for public funding of political parties. If so, the public might fear it was being invited to subsidise wilful extravagance. And in harbouring such a suspicion, it would, of course, be entirely right.

webTitle: Barak warns of Middle East war

fields.headline: Barak warns of Middle East war
fields.standfirst:
Israeli prime minister casts gloom on chances for peace as Arafat meets Clinton to discuss US proposal

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israeli prime minister casts gloom on chances for peace as Arafat meets Clinton to discuss US proposal.
fields.body:
The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, warned yesterday that the Middle East was facing an all-out war unless the Palestinians ended their attacks on Israelis.

He expressed strong scepticism about the chances of the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, accepting the peace proposals put forward by the US president, Bill Clinton, and said he doubted that a deal could be done before Israel's election for prime minister on February 6, long after Mr Clinton leaves office.

Mr Arafat met Mr Clinton in Washington last night to seek more details about his plan.

Amid continued bombing and shooting on the West Bank and the Gaza Strip yesterday, including the killing of a Palestinian farmer by Israeli troops, Mr Barak said the belligerence created by the Palestinian uprising "might deteriorate into a full-scale confrontation in the region", and even endanger Israel's peace pacts with Egypt and Jordan.

He warned Mr Arafat at the weekend to accept the US plan or Israel would unilaterally impose a separation between itself and the Palestinian Authority. The prospect of Israel annexing huge chunks of the West Bank in such a move risks drawing in states such as Syria, Lebanon and Iraq.

Mr Barak said: "We do not want it, but we have to prepare ourselves for it."

He said he would not go to Washington to discuss peace until the Palestinians ended the violence. At the same time, in response to the bombing of the Israeli coastal town of Netanya on Monday night, he said all contact with the Palestinian Authority was at an end.

"The behaviour of Arafat and his positions, and the difficult terror attacks of the last few days - and in some of them members of the [Palestinian] Authority were involved - [mean] we cannot continue the contacts and talks with the Palestinians," Mr Barak said.

The Palestinian leadership, which is under huge pressure from all parts of Palestinian society to reject the proposals, yesterday issued detailed criticisms of Mr Clinton's plan.

Palestinian negotiators said the proposals "fail to satisfy the conditions for a permanent peace, reward Israel for illegally settling areas of the West Bank and rebuff the rights of Palestinians to return to Israel".

After the talks at the White House, Mr Arafat is due to discuss the plans with other Arab leaders in Cairo tomorrow.

His foreign affairs minister, Nabil Shaath, said: "First, we have to have the American clarifications, then we'll discuss it in Cairo, and after that we take the decision, unless these clarifications comply with our demands. But I think this would be very difficult."

Given the hostility among Palestinians towards the US peace proposals, Mr Arafat will find it almost impossible to accept them.

As well as the death of the Palestinian farmer, two Israeli soldiers were wounded yesterday by bombs in Jewish settlements.

The Israeli army has cracked down on the West Bank over the last few days, sealing off many Palestinian towns and villages.

In one of many confrontations in the West Bank and Gaza, the army yesterday bulldozed a Palestinian house in Ein Yabrud village, directly opposite the Jewish settlement of Ofra where a rightwing Israeli extremist was shot dead on Monday.

Haythem Abdel Aziz, aged 42, a carpenter, said he and his four young sons were having breakfast when Israeli troops arrived to bulldoze his home, which looks out on Ofra.

Standing amid the rubble, he said: "What do I do now? They have destroyed my fridge, my stove, my washing-machine, the chairs, everything. Fifteen years of work bulldozed in 15 minutes."
