webTitle: Analysis: Shrinking Westminster

fields.headline: Shrinking Westminster
fields.standfirst:
With the House of Commons losing many of its powers since devolution, how long until it becomes a purely English parliament?

Special report: Parliament
Special report: what is Britain?
fields.trailText: With the House of Commons losing many of its powers since devolution, how long until it becomes a purely English parliament?
fields.body:
The Guardian's monarchy debate has opened up a raft of wider constitutional questions, including not just the role of the monarchy but also the role of parliament in the light of devolution. How much is Westminster still the parliament for the whole of the UK; and how much a parliament for England? Our new book, The State and the Nations, exposes for the first time the extent to which Westminster already operates as an English parliament, and its potential to develop this role further.

Post-devolution, some have suggested that there should be a separate English parliament to match the Scottish parliament and the Welsh and Northern Ireland assemblies. This is not a realistic option.

Those who demand one are in effect demanding a full-blown federation, in which the four historic nations would form the component parts. But there is no successful federation in the world where one of the parts is greater than around one-third of the whole. England, with four-fifths of the population, would be hugely dominant: even more dominant than Prussia in the old Germany. Nor would it meet the demands for representation coming from the English regions: to them, an English parliament looks like another form of London dominance.

Nor is there any strong public demand: the Campaign for an English Parliament has attracted little public following during its weekly vigils in Parliament Square. When asked in last year's British Social Attitudes survey, 62% of the English said it would be best for England to be governed as it is now, with laws made by the UK parliament, while only 18% said it would be best for England to have its own parliament. And, intriguingly, 30% said they viewed the Houses of Parliament as English, or more English than British: while 27% viewed parliament as equally English and British.

The English may have been uttering a greater constitutional truth than they knew. For buried within Westminster is an English parliament which devolution is beginning to disclose. Before devolution we had a three-in-one parliament, and it was clear when Westminster was operating as the legislature for Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. Post-devolution we are developing a four-in-one parliament, and it will need to become clearer when Westminster is operating in English mode. English business is transacted through the work of the select committees; through the new standing committee on regional affairs (which will be open only to English MPs); through questions to ministers on English matters; through Westminster Hall, which provides a further forum for English debates; and through English legislation.

At present, this English business is mixed up with other business. But if we just take the scrutiny function of Westminster, we can see how parliament is developing a sharper territorial focus. Among the select committees we have found four committees whose membership consists solely of English MPs. Three are on subjects you would expect - education and employment, health, and home affairs - matters in which Scottish, Welsh and Northern Ireland MPs no longer have an interest, because these subjects are now largely devolved. And if we look at the government departments which those select committees scrutinise, we find that their ministers are all MPs from English constituencies.

Eight Whitehall home departments are now "English" ministries, and the only departments with ministers from Scotland and Wales (apart from the Scottish and Welsh Offices) are the all-UK departments: the Treasury, Foreign Office, DfID, Social Security, DTI. In terms of English business, the main committees whose work included a significant English element are health, education and employment, environment, transport and the regions, and home affairs.

Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland not only have their select committees; each also has a grand committee consisting of all the MPs for the territory. Up to now there has been no English equivalent to the territorial grand committees. But in April the House of Commons agreed to revive the standing committee on regional affairs, consisting of 13 members from English constituencies, with power to consider "any matter relating to regional affairs in England". Not a big or powerful committee; but it would be the first English committee. And Margaret Beckett has indicated that the committee could expand its role if pressure for English forums at Westminster grows.

I do not want to overstate these developments. What our book describes is a series of tentative and sometimes unwitting steps in which Westminster is responding to devolution. There has been no strong lead from the government, and no clear sense of Westminster's new role. The clearest vision so far has come from the Wakeham commission on Lords reform, which proposed that a reformed House of Lords could represent the nations and regions of the UK, like the second chamber in federal systems.

If further reform of the Lords takes place on these lines, the Lords could claim to be the chamber representing the nations of the UK, including elected members from the regions of England. We would have created a quasi-federal parliament, with an English parliament nestling within it; but we dare not yet speak its name.

Robert Hazell is director of the Constitution Unit, School of Public Policy, University College, London. The State and the Nations: The First Year of Devolution in the UK, is published by Imprint Academic, £14.95.

webTitle: Labour's £2m donor is Hamlyn

fields.headline: Labour's £2m donor is Hamlyn
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair intervened personally yesterday to defuse a potentially damaging scandal over Labour funding by insisting that the multimillionaire publisher Lord Hamlyn be named as the mystery donor who gave £2m to the party.
fields.body:
Tony Blair intervened personally yesterday to defuse a potentially damaging scandal over Labour funding by insisting that the multimillionaire publisher Lord Hamlyn be named as the mystery donor who gave £2m to the party.

Amid a growing outcry on the Labour backbenches, the prime minister accepted advice from his press secretary, Alastair Campbell, to kill off speculation which threatened to land the party with its biggest funding row since Labour accepted - and then returned - £1m from the formula one boss, Bernie Ecclestone.

Lord Hamlyn, 74, who had hoped to remain anonymous because he is suffering from cancer, pneumonia and Parkinson's disease, was contacted in France and asked to agree a statement saying he was proud to be a long-standing supporter of the party and to have donated the cash.

Just after midday yesterday, the peer, who is at his home in the Luberon area of Provence, issued a statement on Labour notepaper in which he said: "Having followed the debate on donations to the Labour party for the past few days, I'm happy to make public that I recently made a £2m donation to the party. Under the existing legislation I'm under no obligation to disclose the sum I have donated but I'm happy to do so. I have said nothing until now because I'm overseas recovering from serious illness."

His statement was designed to bring to an end a damaging row in which senior Labour backbenchers and ex-ministers rounded on the leadership for appearing to repeat the mistakes of the 1997 Ecclestone affair. The health secretary Alan Milburn underlined unease at cabinet level by refusing to offer any defence of the Labour leadership on Radio 4's Today programme.

Within minutes of the announcement, ministers took to the airwaves to boast that Labour is more open than the Conservatives on funding. However, the former transport minister Glenda Jackson, who was scathing about the anonymous donation, said last night that she was still not satisfied. She said Labour should not accept such large donations.

The party leadership recognised that it had to act yesterday as the original decision to allow Lord Hamlyn to remain anonymous ran against the spirit of new funding laws - enacted in response to reports by Lord Nolan and Lord Neill on standards in public life, which come into force on February 16. Under the laws, donors' names will have to be identified along with the amount they have given.

Lord Hamlyn made the donation, which was banked in December, under Labour's existing rules - which would have identified him only as one of many donors who gave more than £5,000 to the party and would not have revealed the size of his donation.

The peer, who gave £500,000 to Labour before the 1997 election and in the two years after it, was named in the party's first list of donors which was published in 1995.

Labour's u-turn on identifying Lord Hamlyn failed to impress the Conservatives. Andrew Lansley, the shadow cabinet office minister, stood by his earlier criticism that it was hypocritical of Labour to take such a large and anonymous donation.

"In Labour's case we can see that large donations have in the past secured influence over policy," he said, with reference to the Ecclestone affair in which the formula one boss won an exemption from a ban on tobacco advertising in the sport. "Labour cannot be trusted not to give influence for large donations."

Ministers dismissed Mr Lansley's criticisms last night, pointing out that the Conservatives are over-reliant on their controversial treasurer Lord Ashcroft. They also point out that Lord Hamlyn, who has already made his millions, has no interest in influencing government policy for his own benefit.

Lord Hamlyn, who donates millions of pounds a year to philanthropic causes, has increased his donations in recent months after making a fortune on a property deal in central London.

The peer has rented out Robert Maxwell's former Mirror headquarters in Holborn Circus, which has been renovated by the architect Norman Foster, to Sainsbury's for a reputed £16.8m a year.

The peer, who gave £500,000 to Labour before the 1997 election and in the two years after it, was named in the party's first list of donors which was published in 1995. Labour's u-turn on identifying Lord Hamlyn failed to impress the Conservatives. Andrew Lansley, the shadow cabinet office minister, stood by his earlier criticism that it was hypocritical of Labour to take such a large and anonymous donation. "In Labour's case we can see that large donations have in the past secured influence over policy," he said, with reference to the Ecclestone affair in which the formula one boss won an exemption from a ban on tobacco advertising in the sport. "Labour cannot be trusted not to give influence for large donations." Ministers dismissed Mr Lansley's criticisms last night, pointing out that the Conservatives are over-reliant on their controversial treasurer Lord Ashcroft. They also point out that Lord Hamlyn, who has already made his millions, has no interest in influencing government policy for his own benefit. Lord Hamlyn, who donates millions of pounds a year to philanthropic causes, has increased his donations in recent months after making a fortune on a property deal in central London. The peer has rented out Robert Maxwell's former Mirror headquarters in Holborn Circus, which has been renovated by the architect Norman Foster, to Sainsbury's for a reputed £16.8m a year. webTitle: Ministers retain dome entertainment option

fields.headline: Ministers retain dome entertainment option
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: The government is keeping its options open to keep the Millennium Dome as an entertainment attraction, in case the Legacy consortium fails in its bid to turn the £1b tent into "Knowledge City".
fields.body:
The government is keeping its options open to keep the Millennium Dome as an entertainment attraction, in case the Legacy consortium fails in its bid to turn the £1b tent into "Knowledge City".

But last night ministers closed ranks with Legacy -the "preferred bidder" in the sale of the dome - and rejected pleas to reopen the bidding by Tory and Liberal Democrat MPs and other opponents of the Legacy plan.

"If Legacy fails we will still have an option to turn it into a visitor attraction," said one minister as the dome's media critics claimed incorrectly that crucial infrastructure such as escalators was being removed from the dome. In fact only rented equipment such as lighting and gantries is being removed, to save money.

None of the dome's £50m contents will be sold before February 27, and then only if Legacy's negotiations with English Partnership, the responsible government agency, succeed. The deadline for these talks is February 15.

Last night Legacy, a consortium headed by the property developer Robert Bourne, with the heavy backing of Dublin-based Treasury Holdings, reaffirmed its commitment to its bid and predicted "a satisfactory conclusion".

Ministers are determined not to be caught out again after the dome's huge cost overruns, and have inserted a clawback clause into Legacy's contract to ensure a share of any windfall profits from projects such as luxury housing.

Ken Livingstone, London's mayor, also weighed in yesterday by saying that so much public money had been swallowed by the dome that up to 50% of any homes built on the Greenwich site must be affordable by ordinary buyers.

The pro-dome campaigner Simon Jenkins urged ministers to avoid a premature "fire sale" at Greenwich merely because Labour wanted to be free of a major embarrassment ahead of the coming election.

Mr Jenkins and the Tory culture and transport spokesmen, Peter Ainsworth and Bernard Jenkin, want P Y Gerbeau, the dome's exhuberant chief executive, to be allowed "at least a year to see what he can do" to keep the dome alive now that it is belatedly being seen as a success.

"John Prescott has a clear duty to reopen the bidding now. There are many organisations showing an interest in bidding, but Mr Prescott is locking them out for political reasons," Mr Jenkin complained.

Though some ministers doubt that Legacy has the experience to pull off its ambitious vision, they insist that it emerged from an open competition after the Nomura consortium's bid foundered last November. To allow late-comers to join the bidding now would be wrong, they say.

Legacy wants to use the dome's vast space to house lightweight and flexible office and exhibition facilities that will attract professional services, IT firms and even academic research bodies. Up to 9,000 people could work there, said Legacy's public relations agency, Bell Pottinger.

webTitle: Tories plan Lords revolt over council openness

fields.headline: Tories plan Lords revolt over council openness
fields.standfirst: Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: The government is set for an embarrassing confrontation in the House of Lords over proposed changes to the openness regime for English councils that the Tories believe could create "a breeding ground for inefficiency and corruption".
fields.body:
The government is set for an embarrassing confrontation in the House of Lords over proposed changes to the openness regime for English councils that the Tories believe could create "a breeding ground for inefficiency and corruption".

The Tories plan to canvass support among returning cross bench and Liberal Democrat peers for what they hope will be a full-scale revolt.

The proposals, published last month, will see city mayors and local authority cabinets taking only "key decisions" - spending or cutting "significant" amounts of money, or decisions that affect two or more wards - in public. The vagueness of the definition is likely to mean that, in many cases, the council itself may decide which decisions were key.

The Tories claim this will restrict the rights of voters. They want to see the status quo maintained, and have promised to re-introduce it when they return to power.

The shadow environment minister, Archie Norman, said: "Before the election, Tony Blair promised to make government more open. But obsessed with control freakery, Labour are now creating a new culture of secrecy in local councils."

The changes were laid before parliament on December 19 as a statutory instrument - a legal add-on to last year's Local Government Act. Opposition parties have 40 days to challenge such instruments.

Council openness has been a touchy subject for the past year. Ministers wanted to see many more decisions taken behind closed doors, but were forced to climb down under pressure from journalists and opposition parties, and to do a deal with the Liberal Democrats to pass the local government bill through a sceptical Lords.

The Local Government Association defended the new openness regime. Assistant director John Rees said: "Local government is used to taking far more decisions than any other public body in the open. But it is the case that there are issues that benefit from being discussed in private or without undue publicity being given to them at an early stage."

webTitle: Software star delivers body blow

fields.headline: Software star delivers body blow
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: E-commerce software company Intershop Communications - one of the stars of Frankfurt's Neuer Markt - delivered a further body blow to hi-tech stocks yesterday when it warned its performance in 2000 would fall well short of earlier forecasts.
fields.body:
E-commerce software company Intershop Communications - one of the stars of Frankfurt's Neuer Markt - delivered a further body blow to hi-tech stocks yesterday when it warned its performance in 2000 would fall well short of earlier forecasts.

Investors wreaked savage revenge for disappointed expectations, slashing Intershop's share price by more than two thirds. The fallout from the Intershop earnings warning spread through the sector, with the Nemax 50 - the Neuer Markt's benchmark index - slumping by almost 10%.

SAP, for instance, which is Europe's biggest software company, saw its shares fall more than 8% as the market digested the implications of Intershop's warning of a slowdown in IT purchasing in the last quarter of 2000.

"It is really terrible news, and just shows how vulnerable the market is at the moment," said one German share trader.

Intershop is one of the world's leading providers of software for online shopping. It was founded by an east German entrepreneur in his 20s - Stephan Schambach - in the early 1990s. Although generating half its revenues in the US, Intershop retains strong ties with east Germany where its latest product, Enfinity, was developed by a team of more than 100 programmers.

The company gave warning yesterday that it now expects fourth quarter revenues between €28m and €30m, compared with earlier estimates of €40m to €50m, and a net loss of around €30m - sharply higher than analysts have been expecting.

The news made the shares fall by as much as 70%, to €9.85. Deutsche Bank cut its rating on Intershop from "market perform" to "underperform", and said the company's management credibility had been damaged. It warned that the fall in Intershop's share price made it a potential takeover target.

Intershop sought to reassure investors that the revision to its revenue forecasts were not the results of competitive pressures or related to long term prospects for its software.

"The current shortfall is primarily related to the global slowdown in IT purchasing patterns and the lengthening sales cycles that have pushed companies' anticipated fourth quarter e-commerce capital expenditures into 2001," said the chief financial officer, Wilfried Beeck.

Although Intershop's sales in Europe were still growing the company had hit problems in the US and Asia.

"While we have seen continuous growth in Europe, especially in Germany and the UK, revenues in the US and Asia suffered significantly from a market wide softening in technology spending," he said.

Intershop's announcement prompted Deutsche Bank to cut its rating on the company to "underperform" from "market perform".

Michael Fraikin of fund manager Invesco said that in the longer term he expects the shares to lose the valuation premium they have held relative to market competitors such as Broadvision.

"I think it will have a long term effect," he said.

"One might have guessed that things may not have been going as well as they had before, but the extent was certainly surprising."

webTitle: George Carman: The will to win

fields.headline: The will to win
fields.trailText: Working on a case with George Carman was an education. He made it clear when he thought that work was not being done properly. But when work was done well he was generous in his appreciation and, in a team of lawyers, he liked to be a chairman rather than a dictator.
fields.body:
Working on a case with George Carman was an education. He made it clear when he thought that work was not being done properly. But when work was done well he was generous in his appreciation and, in a team of lawyers, he liked to be a chairman rather than a dictator. He talked through the case, listening to and absorbing the view of everyone from the pupil barrister to the senior partner of the solicitors. When the day of the trial came, everything was arrayed and ready in his mind.

In an age of specialisation Carman was, perhaps, the last great generalist of the English bar and, in a highly competitive world, he remained at the top for nearly 30 years. At different times, he was the leading practitioner in three very different fields. A Manchester personal injury silk was transformed by the 1979 Jeremy Thorpe trial into the foremost criminal lawyer of the day.

For the next 10 years, he was the great defender. Shortly after the Ken Dodd tax affair, he began to do libel work. In the 1990s, he became the most respected and feared libel advocate in a generation. He appeared in almost every defamation case of note, and continued to do a wide range of other work: shipping, licensing, family law and commercial arbitration.

Carman's most famous skill was as a cross-examiner. In this area he had few equals and no superiors. His questions were short and clear. When the witness stumbled, George would strike: few recovered. His ability as a cross-examiner stood on deeper foundations.

The most striking feature of his legal work was his extraordinary clarity of mind. When he absorbed information - often apparently by a kind of osmosis from conversations of clients and colleagues - it was arranged in a series of mental compartments. This information was drawn out in exactly the right order for a cross-examination or speech.

The dazzling advocacy sometimes blinded observers to his talents as a lawyer. Great advocates are not always good lawyers; Carman was both. He was as comfortable addressing a bench of judges as he was addressing, to use his phrase, a "British jury". His clarity of mind was matched by a clarity of language. His simple and direct phrases would seize the attention of both judge and jury.

Last but not least among his qualities as a lawyer was his will to win. After nearly 50 years in practice at the bar, he retained his focus on the fact that it was his job to win the case for the client.

Carman was never a member of the establishment. His political conservatism was tempered by a grammar schoolboy's mistrust of privilege. He was a meritocrat, a product of the postwar social revolution. One of his strongest beliefs was that the bar should remain a meritocracy which served the public.

As an advocate and as a man, he is irreplaceable. His was a combination of talent and experience which is unlikely to recur.

webTitle: Neuer Markt

fields.headline: Neuer Markt
fields.standfirst:
Hi-tech index brought low

More net news
fields.trailText: Hi-tech index brought low.
fields.body:
Even by the standards of equity markets rich in technology stocks, the Frankfurt Neuer Markt 's fall from grace has been spectacular.

At the March peak its leading index, the Nemax 50, nearly climbed above 10,000. Now it is within hailing distance of 2,500 without any certainty that it has finally found a floor.

The Neuer Markt was the most successful of a series of initiatives by European bourses keen to lure hi-tech stocks to market. So great was its popularity that it was seen as a significant part of the deal that was to have been the merger of the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges.

In part the fall reflects what has happened to the Nasdaq index - barometer of investor sentiment towards the hi-tech sector - according to Thomas Effler, an analyst at Commerzbank in Frankfurt. But it has its own peculiarities.

"The Neuer Markt is still quite a young market compared to the Nasdaq," he said. "Private investors are a driving force which is one reason why it went up so significantly."

There have been corporate shocks too with companies like Infomatec and Gigabell running into problems, though it was a profits warning from EMTV - a Munich company with rights to the Muppets and televising Formula One - which attracted attention.

It has not been all bad news. The number of Neuer Markt debuts held up last year (133 compared to 132 in 1999) - though there is no shortage of stories of companies which quietly shelved plans to list because of the turbulence. The market has attracted some big players, including chipmaker Infineon, Deutsche Telekom's internet subsidiary T-Online and online bank ComDirect.

Mr Effler believes some stocks will disappear but there will be plenty of investor interest in the market this year. "As a market it is going to mature." He reckons it will be between 2,650 and 3,400 this time next year, though he adds: "We are quite cautious compared with some of our competitors' forecasts."

webTitle: Praise for George Carman QC, a court showman

fields.headline: Cobra with a touch of compassion
fields.standfirst: Praise for court showman who delighted clients and public - and daunted victims
fields.trailText: Praise for court showman who delighted clients and public - and daunted victims.
fields.body:
It was a mark of the esteem in which George Carman QC was held that even some of those brought down by arguably the greatest courtroom advocate of the 20th century lined up to pay tribute to him yesterday.

"George Carman QC was meticulous in preparation, formidable in combat and he had the coiled spring of a cobra when he had an unexpected surprise," said Jonathan Aitken, the disgraced former cabinet minister whose courtroom struggle with the diminutive QC led to his imprisonment for perjury and perverting the course of justice. "After the battle, he was the quintessence of a chivalrous knight errant, displaying compassion, grace, humour and generosity of spirit."

Roy Amlott QC, chairman of the Bar Council, said it was a tragedy that Carman, who was diagnosed with prostate cancer last year, should have died so soon after his retirement. "He was undoubtedly one of the greatest advocates of our time and one of the few members of the bar who has become a household name through his work as an advocate."

Ken Dodd, the comedian who was successfully defended by Carman when he faced charges of tax evasion, said he was "very sad" to hear of his death. "George Carman was a very good friend and a brilliant advocate. He was a very passionate man with a wonderful sense of humour. He will be sorely missed."

Lord Irvine, the Lord Chancellor, described him as an outstanding trial lawyer of the old school and a gifted and deadly cross-examiner. "These skills, honed in criminal courts, were turned to devastating account in all the major libel trials that marked the climax of his long career."

But for a man who was so clearly the leader in his particular field, perhaps the most surprising element of Carman's career was just how late he rose to legal superstardom.

After studying law at Oxford - he graduated in 1952 with first class honours - followed by a pupillage in London, Carman plied his trade as a criminal barrister in the relative obscurity of the northern circuit. He became a QC in 1971, but it was not until until 1979, when Jeremy Thorpe's solicitor, David Napley, chose Carman to defend the former Liberal party leader on charges of conspiracy to murder, that he cemented the reputation that would see him become the most sought-after libel lawyer in the business.

His closing address to the jury, in which he ended by saying that Thorpe had won millions of votes from the people of Britain but now came the 12 most precious votes of all - "yours and yours and yours" pointing to each member of the panel in turn - will go down as one of the most dramatic in legal history. Thorpe was acquitted and Carman never looked back.

From the austere surroundings of Manchester crown court his new stage became the rather grander Royal Courts of Justice in the Strand, and whoever the litigant might be, it was always Carman who ended up being the star.

He may have only stood 5ft 3in tall, but from Gillian Taylforth, the EastEnders actress who sued the Sun over reports that she had performed oral sex on her fiance Geoff Knight in their Range Rover in a layby on the A1, to Jonathan Aitken in his disastrous libel action against the Guardian, he struck fear into the hearts of all those he "Carmanised".

His reputation was such that many litigants are said to have been put off suing simply after receiving letters from solicitors informing them that Carman had been retained to defend the action.

"Whatever award is given for libel, being cross-examined by you would not make it enough money," the South African journalist Jani Allan, who sued over allegations that she had slept with the neo-Nazi leader, Eugene Terre' Blanche, famously put it.

Carman had a stage whisper that could be heard halfway down the Strand, something that he used with devastating effect to put off the other barrister in mid stride.

Desmond Browne QC, Neil Hamilton's barrister during the disgraced former minister's ill-fated libel battle against Mohamed Al Fayed in 1999, finally cracked after being subjected to a litany of audible insults about the line of questioning he was taking.

"The noises off really are becoming intolerable," he told Mr Justice Morland. But the judge, clearly amused by Carman's antics, responded: "You'll just have to do your best Mr Browne."

The diminutive QC's cross-examinations were eagerly anticipated by the press benches in much the same way as boxing fans might look forward to a heavyweight title bout. His ability to produce the soundbite that would invariably dominate the front pages of the next day's newspapers was legendary.

Queues for the public gallery would start forming along the gothic corridors of the Royal Courts of Justice from the early hours of the morning when "Gorgeous George" was due to perform.

Always something of an outsider, Carman never became part of the legal establishment and never became a judge, saying he would find it hard to keep quiet on the bench and preferred the "blood and sand of the arena".

Brought up a devout Roman Catholic, he went to a seminary where he contemplated becoming a man of the cloth, although his obvious interest in women - he was married and divorced three times - might have prohibited that.

He retired from the bar in August on medical advice after being diagnosed with prostate cancer. But he attacked it with his customary gusto, demanding that the government bring the amount of spending on cancer research into line with the leading European countries and the United States.

fields.bodyText: It was a mark of the esteem in which George Carman QC was held that even some of those brought down by arguably the greatest courtroom advocate of the 20th century lined up to pay tribute to him yesterday. "George Carman QC was meticulous in preparation, formidable in combat and he had the coiled spring of a cobra when he had an unexpected surprise," said Jonathan Aitken, the disgraced former cabinet minister whose courtroom struggle with the diminutive QC led to his imprisonment for perjury and perverting the course of justice. "After the battle, he was the quintessence of a chivalrous knight errant, displaying compassion, grace, humour and generosity of spirit." Roy Amlott QC, chairman of the Bar Council, said it was a tragedy that Carman, who was diagnosed with prostate cancer last year, should have died so soon after his retirement. "He was undoubtedly one of the greatest advocates of our time and one of the few members of the bar who has become a household name through his work as an advocate." Ken Dodd, the comedian who was successfully defended by Carman when he faced charges of tax evasion, said he was "very sad" to hear of his death. "George Carman was a very good friend and a brilliant advocate. He was a very passionate man with a wonderful sense of humour. He will be sorely missed." Lord Irvine, the Lord Chancellor, described him as an outstanding trial lawyer of the old school and a gifted and deadly cross-examiner. "These skills, honed in criminal courts, were turned to devastating account in all the major libel trials that marked the climax of his long career." But for a man who was so clearly the leader in his particular field, perhaps the most surprising element of Carman's career was just how late he rose to legal superstardom. After studying law at Oxford - he graduated in 1952 with first class honours - followed by a pupillage in London, Carman plied his trade as a criminal barrister in the relative obscurity of the northern circuit. He became a QC in 1971, but it was not until until 1979, when Jeremy Thorpe's solicitor, David Napley, chose Carman to defend the former Liberal party leader on charges of conspiracy to murder, that he cemented the reputation that would see him become the most sought-after libel lawyer in the business. His closing address to the jury, in which he ended by saying that Thorpe had won millions of votes from the people of Britain but now came the 12 most precious votes of all - "yours and yours and yours" pointing to each member of the panel in turn - will go down as one of the most dramatic in legal history. Thorpe was acquitted and Carman never looked back. From the austere surroundings of Manchester crown court his new stage became the rather grander Royal Courts of Justice in the Strand, and whoever the litigant might be, it was always Carman who ended up being the star. He may have only stood 5ft 3in tall, but from Gillian Taylforth, the EastEnders actress who sued the Sun over reports that she had performed oral sex on her fiance Geoff Knight in their Range Rover in a layby on the A1, to Jonathan Aitken in his disastrous libel action against the Guardian, he struck fear into the hearts of all those he "Carmanised". His reputation was such that many litigants are said to have been put off suing simply after receiving letters from solicitors informing them that Carman had been retained to defend the action. "Whatever award is given for libel, being cross-examined by you would not make it enough money," the South African journalist Jani Allan, who sued over allegations that she had slept with the neo-Nazi leader, Eugene Terre' Blanche, famously put it. His ability to produce the soundbite that would invariably dominate the front pages of the next day's newspapers was legendary. Queues for the public gallery would start forming along the gothic corridors of the Royal Courts of Justice from the early hours of the morning when "Gorgeous George" was due to perform. Always something of an outsider, Carman never became part of the legal establishment and never became a judge, saying he would find it hard to keep quiet on the bench and preferred the "blood and sand of the arena". webTitle: Lo makes familiar pitch with a difference - revenues

fields.headline: Lo makes familiar pitch with a difference - revenues
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: There is something familiar about Sonia Lo's sales pitch for eZoka.com. Her ambitious, funkily named internet start-up is looking for extra funds for a European rollout.
fields.body:
There is something familiar about Sonia Lo's sales pitch for eZoka.com. Her ambitious, funkily named internet start-up is looking for extra funds for a European rollout.

Ms Lo is targeting small businesses, using the net to lower companies' running costs by pooling their buying power to achieve better deals for telephony, travel and insurance.

Twelve months ago, eZoka would have been hailed as another brilliant idea waiting to print money. But with the European internet sector seemingly in crisis at the start of the new year and venture capital firms backing fewer dot.coms, might her idea, although a business to business (B2B) operation, suffer the same fate as the ailing consumer site, Letsbuyit.com?

Ms Lo, 33, formerly a high-flyer at Lord Hollick's United News & Media, disagrees that there might be such a risk. Unlike Letsbuyit, where the price of goods falls in line with the number of people buying them, eZoka customers are guaranteed wholesale prices and cash rebates depending on how much they spend.

"We have only been trading a short time but we are already generating real revenues on a real business plan," she said. "Our break even point is in sight, and we only need minimal funding to achieve it."

The Korean-American says there are 18m small businesses with fewer than 250 employees in Europe. Ms Lo plans to bring these disparate and traditionally difficult to capture players together by teaming up with regional trade bodies and chambers of commerce.

She says their combined purchasing power will enable eZoka to secure big savings from blue chip suppliers.

"People tend to be seriously loyal to their affinity groups and, if those groups are explaining to their members the sort of benefits we offer, the chances are they will switch to us," she said. "Building a brand that would attract a similar loyalty would cost millions. We're happy to co-exist with chambers of commerce."

When eZoka signs up the North-east Chamber of Commerce or networking club First Tuesday, the chief executive of that group will send members details of the eZoka programme and preferential rates offered by suppliers including Vodafone, Amerada, Toshiba and the Woolwich.

Members will then be encouraged to visit the trade association's website and log on to an own-brand version of the eZoka trading platform.

By the end of December 375,000 clients had joined the service. The company, seeking £10m for expansion, expects to break even in the second quarter of next year. Former Mirror Newspapers chief David Montgomery has joined as a non-executive director to ensure costs are tightly controlled.

webTitle: Obituary: John Midgley

fields.headline: John Midgley
fields.standfirst: Perceptive commentator whose analysis brought clarity to a turbulent world
fields.trailText: Perceptive commentator whose analysis brought clarity to a turbulent world.
fields.body:
A fine journalist, John Midgley, who has died in Washington aged 89, inspired respect and love in equal measure. He cherished his friends; an abiding image of his last years is of him pushing a walking-frame on which he had balanced glasses and a bottle of welcoming champagne.

A few years ago, he said of his career: "All I've done is to look at what was going on, what was being written, what was being said, what was being done, and try to offer readers of whatever paper I was working for the opportunity to understand these events and try to help by explaining them."

That was typically Midgley - cool, clear and objective, with an understated manner that disguised the passionate interest in the world and its occupants that underpinned his always rational analyses. Although an exceptionally happy third marriage and the responsibilities of stepfather hood curbed his wildness, he never became conventional or respectable; his intellectual curiosity, cultivation, sense of humour and ironic wit were with him to the end. Though his body latterly caused him many nuisances, he became old neither in head nor heart.

A scholarship child from a lower middle-class Manchester family, Midgley was educated at William Hulme's grammar school and Trinity College, Cambridge, where he switched from history to modern languages. By then he had developed his life-long political attitudes.

As he put it in 1993: "I'm in favour of the international rule of law and the forms of international life that allow people to get on with their business without being thumped around ... and I believe the existing social order is lousy and ought to be fixed." In domestic affairs, he believed government's job was to protect the weak against the strong; in foreign affairs, he was broadly anti-militarist and anti-imperialist, and, from as early as 1932, ferociously anti-fascist. Yet, being by instinct a sceptic, he was never attracted by communism, whose adherents he thought combined bigotry with intellectual slavishness.

After Cambridge, Midgley freelanced for the then Manchester Guardian before being taken under the wing of the editor AP Wadsworth, who made him de facto labour correspondent. Passionately anti-appeasement, he travelled when he could in central Europe and helped refugees in Britain. His war was spent with military intelligence, his last posting being as a lieutenant-colonel at the British control commission for Germany, where he witnessed Stalinist opportunism at first-hand.

After a spell as the Manchester Guardian's German correspondent, he moved to the Economist. Though nominally the industrial specialist, he wrote about both domestic and foreign politics, until, in 1951, he was lured to the Times by the deputy editor, his friend Donald Tyerman, first as foreign leader writer and then as German correspondent.

Midgley's understanding of the complexities of cold-war politics led to his appointment in 1956 as foreign editor of the Economist, where he encouraged young journalists, but was brutally direct in his criticisms of what he considered to be sub-standard work.

His analytical and clarificatory gifts greatly enhanced the paper's reputation. Typical was an article in which - admitting that the Economist had misread the 1962 Cuban missile crisis - he wrote that, far from foreign policy being like a game of chess, "The board is a patch of fluid afloat on the waters of time; the pieces, the vehicles of power, change their attributes without proper notice; and no contestant ever sees all of the board."

Much loved by many of his colleagues and admired for his decency, integrity, well-furnished mind, moral courage and the high quality of his writing, Midgley incurred the disapproval of others, not least because of what some perceived as a rather messy private life and a disgraceful enjoyment of wine, women and bon viveurship.

From 1963 until 1976, when he was awarded the CBE, Midgley was Washington correspondent of the Economist and, for a time, also its American editor; he continued to write for the magazine until just before his death. Apart from the distinction of his journalism, he played a vital role in training young journalists, to whom he was as benevolent and quietly loyal as he was initially apparently stern. He travelled well into old age, latterly living partly in Mexico.

Midgley's marriages to the late Evelyn Daniels (by whom he had a son, Stephen) and the late Tania Stanham ended in divorce. He is survived by his son, three step-children and by Elizabeth (née Becker), an American whom he married in 1970, and who shared his innumerable friends, intellectual interests, moral perspectives and sense of the ridiculous.

webTitle: £174m to improve classroom discipline

fields.headline: £174m to improve classroom discipline
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government yesterday allocated £174m to one of the hardest policy challenges it has set itself: to curb classroom misbehaviour and truancy at the same time as it seeks to push up standards in state schools.
fields.body:
The government yesterday allocated £174m to one of the hardest policy challenges it has set itself: to curb classroom misbehaviour and truancy at the same time as it seeks to push up standards in state schools.

The money, announced by the school standards minister, Jacqui Smith, is £43m more than last year. It would permit schools and education authorities in England to fund a range of innovative projects of the kind pioneered in cities such as York, she said.

The schemes will include truancy sweeps and watches in town centres, parental awareness projects and units in schools where hard core disruptive pupils can be taught, possibly on a one to one basis.

Ms Smith said: "Too many children are missing school and cutting their chances of success in life. Some schools are raising attendance levels, but more needs to be done to reduce significantly the 50,000 pupils away from school without permission on any given day."

Tony Blair and the education secretary, David Blunkett, have repeatedly stressed the importance of higher classroom standards as essential to the social and economic well-being of young Britons, especially in the socially excluded classes.

But they have also called for both tougher discipline in the classroom and a curb on the ready exclusion from school of troublemakers - youngsters who sometimes graduate from bullying to drugs and petty crime.

The two goals are often hard to reconcile, especially in schools under most pressure from poverty and social breakdown. Ministers committed to "joined up" solutions have established a social inclusion pupil support standards fund to administer the £174m.

Signs of success they cite include a 67% cut in youth crime in York since the council's education department used standards fund grant aid to launch a truancy watch scheme in the city centre.

Youngsters who skip school, often - though not always - without their parents knowledge or consent, congregate in such places. The absence of visible school uniforms in many schools makes the truant officers' task of detection more difficult.

Ms Smith said the new funds added to resources available to schools in most of England's urban areas through the government's excellence in cities programme. It would relieve teachers of the burdens that unruly pupils could impose by increasing numbers of learning mentors and on-site units for disaffected children.

The move coincides with a leaked memo, written by the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, which stresses the need for Labour's election strategy to be more radical than in 1997 in committing a second Blair government to tackle poverty as it affects both individuals and communities.

The drive for higher standards in primary schools, undertaken by Mr Blunkett, would be extended to secondary level.

Since the chancellor, Gordon Brown, has dismayed some voters by quietly redistributing wealth via "stealth taxes" - designed not to offend Middle England voters - support for a more overtly radical stance from Mr Mandelson will provide new year cheer for loyal but disaffected Labour MPs and activists.

One long touted scheme that may be revived would benefit precisely those youngsters most vulnerable to missing out on the benefits of a full education: a £1,000 "individual development account". Costing £700m a year, it would amount to a savings scheme, started at birth.

webTitle: 'Killer shrimp' threatens native species in Britain's rivers

fields.headline: Pink peril threatens native species in Britain's rivers
fields.trailText: A freshwater "jaws", described by scientists as a killer shrimp, is about to invade Britain's rivers, threatening to wipe out weaker native species.
fields.body:
A freshwater "jaws", described by scientists as a killer shrimp, is about to invade Britain's rivers, threatening to wipe out weaker native species and eat its way through the population of damsel flies, waterboatmen and other insect populations vital for healthy fish life.

The pink peril is from the former Soviet Union and has reached as far as the Netherlands. Colonies are expected to be found in the UK at any time.

Jaimie Dick, from Queen's University, Belfast, said the species is also a threat to the ecology of the Great Lakes in North America, as it seems tougher and better able to survive than competitors.

The threat from the shrimp which originates from the Black, Caspian and Azov seas region, has been confirmed by putting it in large aquariums with other species, including North American shrimps that have already invaded Europe but can coexist with local species.

The newcomer, Dikerogammarus villosus, simply attacks everything it comes across, even managing to kill water boatmen, often not bothering to eat them, just fatally wounding them with a bite through their body armour. It wiped out all 10 species put in the tanks, including blue tailed damsel flies, water hoglice and fish leeches. The shrimp has much larger and more powerful jaws than its British and American rivals.

Dr Dick says in a paper being presented today at the British Ecological Society meeting in Birmingham that the ability of D villosus "to capture, consume and often simply mortally injure" a range of species, even those with shells, "leads us to predict the local extinctions of species".

The pink peril is particularly successful because it can tolerate changes in water temperature, oxygen levels and salinity, is not fussy about what it eats, and breeds rapidly.

It arrived in western Europe having travelled 2,000 miles up the river Danube through the Main Danube canal and into the Rhine. The invader appeared on the German-Dutch border in 1994 and by 1998 had reached Amsterdam.

When it came into contact with the native shrimp (Gammarus duebeni) and another previously successful invader, the North American Gammarus tigrinus, it began attacking them and has wiped them out in many areas.

When Dr Dick began his experiments by putting the new shrimp and other freshwater species in the same tanks he thought some of the potential prey species had escaped. In fact very rapidly and beyond all expectations the pink peril had killed and shredded them. Fragments of the prey were found at the bottom of the tank.

Research into the effect of invaders on native species is an important new area of research, according to the scientists involved. Up to now scientists have measured the results when often it was too late to assess what really happened or what could have been done to prevent the worst effects.

The invaders often take over ecosystems, as the Zebra mussel did when it colonised the Great Lakes after being transported in the bilge water of cargo boats from the Black Sea.

Dr Dick says that with invasions of alien species expected to have serious effects on freshwater biodiversity in the next 100 years, information about their potential impact can be used in management strategies to prevent and control attacks.

webTitle: Don't burst the dot.com bubble

fields.headline: Don't burst the dot.com bubble
fields.standfirst:
New technology takes a breather

More net news
fields.trailText: New technology takes a breather.
fields.body:
Another day, another dot.com in trouble. Yesterday it was the turn of Intershop to feel the wrath of investors after it warned it would miss fourth-quarter forecasts for earnings and revenues.

A good thing, you might say. The more dot.coms turn into dot.bombs, the quicker investors will come back to reality, albeit it with a nasty bump. New technology has not rewritten fundamentally the laws of economics or of business modelling. A profit in the hand is still worth of flock of overinflated price/earnings ratios in the bush. That is fair enough - to a point. But those who retained a healthy scepticism in the face of all the dot.com hype, not to say hysteria, should not now overdo the schaudenfreude.

E-business and the infrastructure needed to underpin it are vital to the global economy. It is easy to draw comparison with the great railway booms. Huge fortunes were made and lost but rail networks usually got built, feeding industrialisation. The chances are e-business will go the same way; that the infrastructure will arrive despite the fads and foibles of fund managers and private investors.

But the nature of the finished product could be profoundly affected by how well the investment community keeps its nerve. Dot.commery has been characterised by youthfulness, exuberance and dynamism - not, it has to be said, untinged by greed. But if the sector finds itself completely cold shouldered by once-bitten, twice-shy investors, that could change. Brightness and brashness could give way to the forces of bureaucracy and conservatism as the sector consolidates around big corporate players initially left flat footed. It could easily become bogged down in a safety first mentality that would be as inappropriate as many of last spring's stratospheric valuations. To misquote Alan Greenspan, what we need now is an outbreak of rational exuberance.

Euro appeal

The sight of the euro climbing to a five-month high against the dollar on the first day of European and American trading was too good an opportunity for Britain's pro-EMU lobby to resist. Buoyed by the currency's resurgence and the eurozone's relatively bright growth prospects, Britain in Europe challenged Eurosceptics to break the habit of a lifetime and admit that the continent does have a good story to tell.

The Eurosceptics' crude caricature of the eurozone as hidebound and sclerotic was always misleading but pro-euro lobbyists should be wary of appearing too gleeful about the currency's new found strength. For it is being driven not so much by Europe's perceived success as America's failure. Yesterday's rally was due to the sharp decline in activity in America's factories in December, which shrank at the fastest rate since April 1991 when the US economy was still emerging from recession, not by the sparkling performance of the euroland economy.

Euroland manufacturers are suffering much less from the downturn in global growth than their US counterparts, according to the monthly snapshot of activity published by Reuters. But the slowest growth for 18 months is hardly something to boast about.

Capital idea

Later this month the Bank for International Settlements will announce its latest proposals on banks' capital adequacy. They are likely to take a more sophisticated approach to the original concept first introduced in 1988.

At present banks have to set aside a minimum amount of their own money linked to the size of their loan book. What the BIS is suggesting is that capital adequacy measures take account of the degree of risk attached to loans and to engage in general "market discipline", which essentially means the banks making public more information about how risky their loans are and how well they are cushioned against potential losses.

The significance of this last change will not be lost on Don Cruickshank, who conducted a review of competition among UK banks more than a year ago. One of the recommendations of his report was that the financial services authority should require UK banks to anticipate the additional disclosure provisions being proposed by the BIS.

In its response yesterday, however, the FSA appears to have decided it prefers to keep in step with the BIS.

Mr Cruickshank will no doubt take heart that regulators are thinking on similar lines even if the practical impact will arrive a little later than he would like. Mr Cruickshank is accustomed to not getting all his own way. The Treasury, for example, listened to his suggestion that the behind-the-scenes payment system should have a new regulator but gave the powers to the office of fair trading rather than the new body, Paycom, he recommended. Still, half a loaf is better than no bread.

webTitle: Magic mushrooms thrive as weeds wane

fields.headline: Magic mushrooms thrive as weeds wane
fields.trailText: An estimated 100,00 of the most potent magic mushrooms known to science, were discovered growing in a vast carpet on a racetrack in the south of England.
fields.body:
Hippies would have thought they were hallucinating. The horses would have failed a dope test. Geoffrey Kibb was amazed but stone cold sober and knew a scientific phenomenon when he saw one.

Mr Kibb discovered the holy grail of the 1960s hippie culture, the most potent magic mushrooms known to science, growing in a vast carpet on a racetrack in the south of England. He estimated there were 100,000 of them, enough to blow the mind of an entire town.

He reported his findings to fellow researcher Peter Shaw, an expert in fungi. To him the field of wavy-capped magic mushroom (Psilocybe cyanes-cens) was confirmation of an astonishing colonisation of Britain by exotic species of mushroom - an invasion innocently caused by gardeners anxious to keep weeds at bay.

Dr Shaw says that by spreading wood chips over the ground gardeners create the perfect habitat for fungi of all sorts. The wavy-capped magic mushroom, "a particularly aggressive species" and a native of the Pacific north-west of America, is now firmly established in gardens, parks and any other place where wood chips are used for weed control.

About 10 species of mushroom are eaten for their hallucinogenic qualities. Psilocybe cyanescens is identified by its wavy cap, purple brown spore print and rapid blueing of stem and cap on bruising, although there are poisonous species of similar appearance.

The blueing reflects the high psilocin/psilocybin content of the fungus (which as any old hippie will tell you is the bit that makes you fly). Dr Shaw is presenting his findings today at the British Ecological Society meeting in Birmingham where he is inviting amateur mycologists to hunt down other rare species.

On his way to work at the University of Surrey Dr Shaw passes a roundabout in Leatherhead. "The roundabout was mulched in 1999 and in May 2000 a flush of creamy-yellow fungi came up."

They turned out to be four different exotic varieties growing in the wood chips - one of which, Agrocybe putaminium, had only been recorded once before in Britain, at Kew gardens. "The wood chips were bought from a commercial supplier in Essex, but how they acquired their strange fungal flora is still unclear."

The bad news for magic mushroom hunters - deliberate growing of magic mushrooms for use is illegal but mere possession is not - is that this is not the time of year for fruiting.

But out of sight the roots from which they grow are spreading rapidly. Dr Shaw's theory is that suppliers keep vast heaps of wood chips in nurseries, allowing aggressive fungi to colonise..

Wood chips and bark chips make a better habitat than the original decaying wood on which the fungi grow. This is because the root structure does not have to force its way through a hard surface but glides between the chips.

Because of his Leatherhead experience and other discoveries Dr Shaw says there are bound to be exotic species not thought to exist in Britain growing happily in gardens, and some have already transferred to the wild - the magic mushroom has been been found growing on trees in Burnham Beeches, Buckinghamshire.

webTitle: Woman killed by car park landslides

fields.headline: Woman killed by car park landslides
fields.standfirst:
'They waved to show they were all right. Five minutes later there was a second slide ...'

Weather watch
fields.trailText: 'They waved to show they were all right. Five minutes later there was a second slide ...'
fields.body:
An elderly woman was killed and her husband was seriously injured yesterday when their car was sent crashing on to a beach as landslides struck a car park below cliffs on the coast of north Wales.

Four other cars were hit by the landslips on the 120ft sand and clay cliffs near the village of Nefyn, a popular holiday resort on the Lleyn peninsula, but no one else was hurt.

A German couple, in Wales for a new year holiday, saw their camper van battered and said they had had a miraculous escape.

Council officials reported that the cliffs had been made unstable by three months of torrential rain followed by several days of sub-zero temperatures.

Two cottages had been damaged in another slip a few weeks ago. One of the cars damaged yesterday belonged to an insurance company's loss adjuster who had arrived to inspect damage.

It is believed the couple had driven down a narrow, winding road with their dog - which survived the tragedy - to a car park at Lon Y Traeth where they sat admiring panoramic views over the Irish sea.

Their silver-coloured vehicle was struck by the first slip and pushed towards bollards at the edge of the car park. The second slip struck the car five minutes later and forced it and a Mitsubishi Shogun to plunge a further 30ft on to the beach.

Eyewitnesses described the vehicles being pushed around "like toy cars".

Rescuers pulled the man from the car but his wife was trapped. Emergency teams later cut her body free.

The woman's body was taken away by lifeboat and her husband was flown by helicopter to hospital in Bangor. His injuries were described as serious but not life threatening.

A level student Owain Jones, 17, from Nefyn, said he had been walking on the beach with a friend and her mother. "I heard a sort of rumble. I looked up at the cliff and it started to slide down," he said. "At that moment I turned round and shouted a warning.

"The car with the couple in was pushed into a barrier and trapped by mud to one side of it. They waved to show that they were all right."

Mr Jones said he dialled 999 on his mobile phone.

"Five minutes later, there was a second slide. I heard another rumble and more mud pushed down around the cars.

"The car with the couple in was pushed over the edge and down on to the beach. The [Shogun] somersaulted over the edge down on to the beach. Two other cars and a camper van were pushed around in the car park like toys. Some people tried to get down to the beach to help the couple in the car and got the man out.

"I think if it happened 10 seconds earlier, I could have been killed myself."

Local resident Sue Diamond said her friends Fiona and Ian Munro saw the landslides as they walked along the beach. "Fiona told me the woman who died had passed their dog to them as the car began sliding in the second slide.

"Fiona managed to take the dog but the couple could not escape, perhaps because their seatbelts were still on."

Harald Schmid and Sabine Telakoff, from Cologne, described how they were taken by surprise as the first slide struck. "Sabine saw it first," said Mr Schmid. "She cried out and then I saw it. The earth was running over my shoes."

"Luck has been on our side today," added Ms Telakoff."

The couple had planned to return to Germany yesterday but were forced to stay overnight in a hotel. Last night their red van lay crushed against the car park barrier with a white Audi and another car. The Shogun and the remains of the car in which the woman died were still on the beach, washed by the sea.

Local cliff paths had been closed for several days before yesterday's slips. "This was bound to happen because the cliff face is in such a perilous state," said retired teacher John Llewellyn Evans. "What can you possibly do when the earth is saturated after 100 days of incessant rain?"

A spokeswoman for Gwynedd council said: "The problem with all the coast in that particular area is that it is composed of clay and sand, so you can imagine the effect of tremendous rain over the last few months."

"Our biggest problem was the incoming tide," said Edward Shaw of Gwynedd fire service. "After the rescue, there were further slips while we were working and at one point we had to withdraw."

• Melting snow and torrential rain yesterday ratcheted up the chances of more severe flooding across Britain, with official warnings rising above 30 and gloomy forecasts for at least the next week.

Soaked ground in the west country led to warnings on almost all rivers in Devon and Dorset, with a severe flood alert on the river Axe at Axminster in Devon.

Flooding also hit the southern lowlands of Scotland and downpours on the Pennines started a slow but ominous rise in river levels in Yorkshire, Lancashire and the north east. Other warnings were imposed in Sussex, Cambridgeshire and along the river Severn in Worcestershire and Gloucestershire.

Six thousand homes in Ayrshire were left with empty pipes after frost caused a mains burst. Bursts also left 2,000 homes in Northern Ireland without water.

Forecasts warned that unsettled weather would be the pattern until well into next week, with snow on high ground, and rain and strong winds across the country.

29 December: Britain slithers to a halt in the snow

webTitle: George Carman dies at 71

fields.headline: George Carman dies at 71
fields.standfirst: Most famous barrister of his generation loses cancer battle
fields.trailText: Most famous barrister of his generation loses cancer battle.
fields.body:
George Carman QC, the most famous courtroom advocate of his generation, died yesterday aged 71 after a lengthy battle with prostate cancer .

The celebrated barrister, who appeared in many of the most noted libel cases of the last 10 years, winning the majority of them, finally lost a four-and-a-half year battle with the disease. His illness only became public knowledge last September, after he was forced into sudden retirement on medical advice.

Mr Carman, who first came to prominence defending the former Liberal leader Jeremy Thorpe on charges of conspiracy to kill and incitement to murder, moved to the libel courts late in life. But he built up an unrivalled reputation - becoming the QC newspapers called first when a libel writ was in the offing.

He appeared for or against so many famous clients and adversaries that his name, unusually for a barrister, became as recognisable as theirs. His son, Dominic, said yesterday: "George was a small man but with his stage as a courtroom and his audience as the jury he was a giant among men."

He said his father's death had come sooner than expected. A few weeks ago he had spoken of a possible comeback, representing Sir Richard Branson against his unofficial biographer Tom Bower.

"He regretted enormously not being able to act for Richard Branson in his case. He was really looking forward to the challenge. His spirits were always in the courtroom. That is where he lived and that is where he came to life."

Ian Hislop, editor of Private Eye, said Mr Carman would be remembered for turning "the courtroom into melodrama". He added: "He was the first who understood it was about playing to the jury rather than convincing the judge. He was also almost fantastically lucky - he always had a surprise, an ace up his sleeve.

"He made the law seem interesting, which it isn't, and he played his part with enormous relish." His name became a threat in itself, he said, for those considering libel action.

In private life he was also very good company, said Mr Hislop. "He was very unpompous and very funny."

Alan Rusbridger, editor of the Guardian, said: "Every editor reached for George Carman when a writ arrived. He was the best jury advocate of his generation. Libel is such a lottery you could never be guaranteed to win, but with George on your side you certainly narrowed the odds."

Mr Carman represented the Guardian in the libel action brought by Jonathan Aitken which led to the former Conservative minister's imprisonment for perjury and perverting the course of justice.

In his last high profile victory, a year ago, he successfully defended the Harrods owner Mohammed Al Fayed, who was sued by Neil Hamilton over allegations that the former Tory MP took cash for asking parliamentary questions. Mr Carman famously described Mr Hamilton as "on the make and on the take".

Another leading QC, Anthony Scrivener, called Mr Carman "simply the best cross-examiner in the business".

One adversary, Jani Allan, the South African journalist who sued over allegations that she had had an affair with the neo-Nazi leader Eugene Terre-blanche, told him: "Whatever the award for libel, being cross examined by you would not make it enough money."

Mr Carman, who was divorced, died at his home in Wimbledon, south-west London. His close friend, Karen Phillips, said: "I am just glad he has gone quickly and he has not suffered at all and it's been very very peaceful."

Roy Amlot QC, chairman of the Bar Council, said: "He was undoubtedly one of the greatest advocates of our time and one of the few members of the bar to become a household name through his work."

Cases that hit the front pages:

Jeremy Thorpe trial, 1979

The Liberal leader was accused of conspiring to murder Norman Scott, a former model who claimed to have had a homosexual relationship with the North Devon MP. The prosecution alleged the plot was hatched to stop Scott jeopardising Thorpe's political career. But Carman argued the MP's career was already in shreds. The jury returned a verdict of not guilty.

Sonia Sutcliffe v News of the World, 1990

The wife of the Yorkshire Ripper lost her libel claim over News of the World allegations that she had an affair with a Greek holiday company chief who resembled her husband

During the hearing, Carman claimed she had courted the press for financial gain before listing the £334,000 damages she had obtained in actions against newspapers. His verdict of her that "she danced on the graves of her husband's victims. She is a clever, confident, cold and calculating woman... The truth and Sonia do not make good bedfellows," was enough to convince the jury.

Gillian Taylforth v the Sun, 1994

One of Carman's most celebrated victories, the EastEnders actress lost her libel over a report that she had performed oral sex on her fiance in a layby on the A1 after the QC produced one of his famous 11th-hour rabbits from a hat: a video of Ms Taylforth holding a bottle proclaiming to her fellow partygoers "I give good head".

When the jury foreman read out the verdict she collapsed and had to be stretchered out of court.

Jonathan Aitken v the Guardian, 1997

In one of the most spectacular collapses in legal history, the former cabinet minister was imprisoned for perjury and perverting the course of justice after it emerged he had lied under oath about who had paid for a weekend stay at the Ritz hotel in Paris.

Once again Carman unveiled a last minute exocet - this time travel documents from British Airways that showed his wife - whom he claimed had paid the bill - and daughter were never in Paris that weekend but actually in Switzerland. Aitken had also got his daughter to sign a false witness statement verifying his version of events.

Neil Hamilton v Al Fayed, 1999

George Carman's last great libel victory came after Neil Hamilton, the former Tory MP, sued Mohamed Al Fayed, over allegations that he had taken up to £50,000 in cash from the owner of Harrod's to do his bidding in Parliament.

Carman destroyed Hamilton in the witness box, lovingly re-creating every morsel of food and sip of vintage champagne the former minister and his wife, Christine, enjoyed during a free visit to Fayed's Ritz hotel in Paris.

His description of Hamilton as a man "on the make and on the take" and "a man with no honour left," were enough to persuade the jury to find against the former MP.

Mr Carman famously described Mr Hamilton as "on the make and on the take". Another leading QC, Anthony Scrivener, called Mr Carman "simply the best cross-examiner in the business". One adversary, Jani Allan, the South African journalist who sued over allegations that she had had an affair with the neo-Nazi leader Eugene Terre-blanche, told him: "Whatever the award for libel, being cross examined by you would not make it enough money." Mr Carman, who was divorced, died at his home in Wimbledon, south-west London. His close friend, Karen Phillips, said: "I am just glad he has gone quickly and he has not suffered at all and it's been very very peaceful." Roy Amlot QC, chairman of the Bar Council, said: "He was undoubtedly one of the greatest advocates of our time and one of the few members of the bar to become a household name through his work." Cases that hit the front pages: Jeremy Thorpe trial, 1979 The Liberal leader was accused of conspiring to murder Norman Scott, a former model who claimed to have had a homosexual relationship with the North Devon MP. The prosecution alleged the plot was hatched to stop Scott jeopardising Thorpe's political career. But Carman argued the MP's career was already in shreds. The jury returned a verdict of not guilty. Sonia Sutcliffe v News of the World, 1990 The wife of the Yorkshire Ripper lost her libel claim over News of the World allegations that she had an affair with a Greek holiday company chief who resembled her husband During the hearing, Carman claimed she had courted the press for financial gain before listing the £334,000 damages she had obtained in actions against newspapers. His verdict of her that "she danced on the graves of her husband's victims. She is a clever, confident, cold and calculating woman... The truth and Sonia do not make good bedfellows," was enough to convince the jury. Gillian Taylforth v the Sun, 1994 One of Carman's most celebrated victories, the EastEnders actress lost her libel over a report that she had performed oral sex on her fiance in a layby on the A1 after the QC produced one of his famous 11th-hour rabbits from a hat: a video of Ms Taylforth holding a bottle proclaiming to her fellow partygoers "I give good head". When the jury foreman read out the verdict she collapsed and had to be stretchered out of court. Jonathan Aitken v the Guardian, 1997 In one of the most spectacular collapses in legal history, the former cabinet minister was imprisoned for perjury and perverting the course of justice after it emerged he had lied under oath about who had paid for a weekend stay at the Ritz hotel in Paris. Once again Carman unveiled a last minute exocet - this time travel documents from British Airways that showed his wife - whom he claimed had paid the bill - and daughter were never in Paris that weekend but actually in Switzerland. Aitken had also got his daughter to sign a false witness statement verifying his version of events. Neil Hamilton v Al Fayed, 1999 George Carman's last great libel victory came after Neil Hamilton, the former Tory MP, sued Mohamed Al Fayed, over allegations that he had taken up to £50,000 in cash from the owner of Harrod's to do his bidding in Parliament. Carman destroyed Hamilton in the witness box, lovingly re-creating every morsel of food and sip of vintage champagne the former minister and his wife, Christine, enjoyed during a free visit to Fayed's Ritz hotel in Paris. His description of Hamilton as a man "on the make and on the take" and "a man with no honour left," were enough to persuade the jury to find against the former MP. webTitle: Branson's Lottery appeal endangers brand

fields.headline: Move on, Sir Richard
fields.standfirst:
Lottery appeal endangers brand

Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText: Lottery appeal endangers brand.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson should establish a Virgin charitable foundation instead of contesting Camelot's successful bid to run the National Lottery, according to a leading brand consultancy.

Wolff Olins believes Sir Richard risks damaging his brand if he mounts a legal challenge to the decision.

The warning comes as Sir Richard faces several setbacks in his sprawling business empire. As well as his People's Lottery syndicate's failure to win the lottery licence, Virgin's bid to run the east coast mainline appears to have been scuppered and his airline is in dispute with unions over recognition.

Robert Jones, the consultant director at Wolff Olins, ranks Virgin as one of the best brands in the world and believes the millionaire entrepreneur should forget his ambition to run the lottery.

"There's an opportunity to seize the high ground and do something new and different and exciting," he said. Setting up a Virgin Foundation could be an answer.

"This would attach the Virgin name to other good causes. He needs to do it quickly," Mr Jones said, cautioning Sir Richard against taking on Camelot in the courts.

Virgin has one charitable foundation, Virgin Healthcare, which hands out around £500,000 a year to causes supporting the wellbeing of young people, such as Parents against Tobacco.

A Virgin spokesman said it was unlikely Sir Richard would set up a high profile fund because of Virgin's existing foundation. He denied that the failed lottery bid had damaged the Virgin brand, emphasising that the People's Lottery has been Sir Richard's personal interest.

"If anything, losing the lottery has actually enhanced the Virgin brand and Sir Richard's image because people thought it was a very honourable defeat," the spokesman said.

"Research carried out before the lottery commission's decision showed only 13% of people wanted Camelot to win but 67% wanted the People's Lottery to win.

"The decision on whether to appeal or not will be based on rational legal ad vice and have nothing to do with how it may or may not affect the Virgin brand."

The People's Lottery expects answers on Friday to questions it submitted to the lottery commission as to why Camelot was awarded the licence. It will make a decision about whether to appeal based on those responses, and a formal announcement is expected over the weekend or early next week.
