webTitle: At this price? - Supermarkets

fields.headline: Supermarkets
fields.trailText: Food retailers have been among the main and, some would say, most unlikely, beneficiaries, of the great technology sell-off.
fields.body:
Food retailers have been among the main and, some would say, most unlikely, beneficiaries, of the great technology sell-off. The sector rose nearly 47% last year - the best performance of any sector of the British market according to HSBC Securities - as investors looked for safety amid the technology stocks storm.

The sector's defensive qualities have been in demand again in the past month, due to fears that the global economy is bound for slowdown thanks to recession in the US.

But as any tech investor will tell you, excessive share price outperformance can blind you to the facts. So it is worth investors reacquainting themselves with the basics of the sector.

Food retailing is a mature industry with little organic growth. In fact in Britain it is, and has for some time been, a zero sum game - growth comes from pinching market share from your rivals.

But as the HSBC Securities report points out, grocers are trading on the kind of rating that would suggest the industry is entering a new era of higher long term growth.

In fact if anything, the opposite is true.

The competitive environment has been relatively benign since the competition commission report in October but things are starting to change. Asda is expected to go on the offensive this year - US parent Wal-Mart is said to be unhappy with its sluggish growth - and Tesco is expected to reinforce its leading position.

With Safeway starting to come up against tough like for like sales comparables, and Sainsbury yet to deliver an increase in sales, the market is going to require positive newsflow - possibly in the shape of consolidation - if present valuations are going to to hold.

While pockets of value still exist - Somerfield looks undervalued compared with its asset base and Wm Morrison should be a strong perfomer - food retailers appear to be past their best. Reduce.

webTitle: Saddam Hussein, the great survivor

fields.headline: The great survivor
fields.standfirst:
For 10 years the west has spent billions enforcing no-fly zones, policing sanctions and funding opposition groups but, as the anniversary of the Gulf war approaches, Saddam Hussein is still in power - and stronger than ever. How does he do it? Brian Whitaker reports

Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: For 10 years the west has spent billions enforcing no-fly zones, policing sanctions and funding opposition groups but, as the anniversary of the Gulf war approaches, Saddam Hussein is still in power - and stronger than ever. How does he do it?
fields.body:
Holding a rifle in one hand and a cigar in the other, Saddam Hussein fired into the air, a signal to the world that he is back - with a bang.

The puffs of tobacco and gun smoke from the presidential reviewing stand on Sunday marked the start of a military parade, the likes of which Iraq has not seen for more than 10 years.

Jet fighters flew in formation and helicopter gunships hovered over central Baghdad. More than 1,000 Russian-made tanks, together with artillery and surface-to-surface and anti-aircraft missiles, rumbled through Grand Festivities Square in a four-hour march-past.

It could almost have been a flashback to the old days of the Soviet Union, with the Iraqi leader in period costume: blue three-piece suit and black, wide-brimmed hat.

But among the uniformed naval, infantry and paramilitary units on parade there was, perhaps, a sign of things to come: white-hooded figures with only their eyes showing - allegedly volunteers for martyrdom in the struggle against Israel.

To one side, a giant poster showed Iraqi horses trampling an Israeli flag in front of the Dome of the Rock, with Saddam looking on, god-like, from the sky.

By January 16, the 10th anniversary of what the west calls Desert Storm and what Iraq calls the Mother of Battles, Saddam will have seen off four American presidents: Carter, Reagan, Bush Sr and Clinton.

It was supposed to be the other way round. Getting rid of Saddam has been official US policy for years and, by any normal standards, it should have succeeded long ago.

The devastating war over Kuwait came hot on the heels of a bloody eight-year conflict with Iran, and the damage continues through sanctions and America-British bombing of the no-fly zones.

Throughout Saddam's 20-year rule, Iraqis have known only four years without war or sanctions. That would be enough to bring down most leaders, and yet as the familiar faces of the US administration that tried to destroy him return to Washington, Saddam will be strutting across their TV screens, ready to needle them once more. It's not surprising that he looked pleased with himself during Sunday's parade: it was a firm reminder to the world that he has pulled off one of the most remarkable feats of political survival in modern times.

There was a moment, in 1991, when he seemed about to fall, but his forces bounced back from their humiliation in Kuwait, crushing revolts in the Kurdish north and the Shi'ite south of Iraq.

Two years ago, President Clinton signed the Iraqi Liberation Act, which made available £58m to opponents of the Baghdad regime. Since then, the problem has been how to spend the money.

The opposition Iraqi National Congress (INC) has made little headway since 1996, when Saddam wiped out its power base in northern Iraq, under the noses of the Americans. Fortuitously, this provided a morale-boosting victory for the Iraqi army just as it was beginning to show signs of disaffection with the regime.

The INC, which includes Kurdish, monarchist, Islamist and independent elements, has been beset by internal squabbles and the Americans have never been totally happy with its leader, Dr Ahmed Chalabi, who was once at the centre of a banking scandal in Jordan.

More direct forms of insurrection, meanwhile, have so far failed. It is virtually impossible to organise a successful coup, according to one opposition leader. "The moment you get three people involved they all tell Saddam about it," he said. "That's because each one knows that if he doesn't tell Saddam, the other two will."

The money donated to the opposition is nothing compared with the cost of policing the no-fly zones, where 450 tonnes of bombs have been dropped in the past two years, mainly by the Americans. In total, Britain has spent £800m on maintaining the no-fly zones, while the American presence - 200 aircraft, 19 warships and 22,000 personnel - has been costing around $1bn a year.

Although this containment policy may have helped to keep Iraq in check, Saddam has effectively discredited it by highlighting the deaths of innocent shepherds and other civilians caused by the bombing. Two recent events have contributed to Saddam's newfound buoyancy. One was the arrival in Baghdad of a hijacked Saudi airliner in October. It might have been the cue for a confrontation, reminiscent of the human shield crisis of 1990, but that didn't suit Iraq's new international image. All the passengers were released unharmed and kindly sent on their way, allowing Saddam to bask for a few days in the unfamiliar glow of international adulation.

In Israel and the occupied territories, meanwhile, the gathering uprising triggered by Ariel Sharon's visit to Jeruselem's Temple Mount was doing more for Saddam's popularity in the region than any PR campaign could. While political realities force other leaders - in Egypt and Jordan, for example - to take a more cautious stance, much to the frustration of public opinion, Saddam is free to increase his stature through ostentatious preparations for an imaginary battle.

Bad news from Israel is good news for Saddam. It is largely because of Israel that Iraq is now back in the Arab fold. The Arab League summit, last October, needed to show unity in its support for the Palestinians and had no option but to invite Iraq - for the first time since the invasion of Kuwait.

Saddam has also pledged $881m from oil revenues to support the Palestinian uprising. Some of this is going to the families of dead Palestinians, in lump sums of several thousand dollars.

Sunday's military parade followed a Christmas message in which Saddam called on Christians, as well as Muslims, to take "the path of jihad, without which we cannot attain our aspirations of establishing right, justice and peace and delivering humanity from the evils of aggressors, criminal killers".

More than six million Iraqis, including two million women, have already signed up for the struggle to "put an end to Zionism". Nobody dares to ask how, exactly, this will be achieved. For the moment it is, almost certainly, a fantasy to please the masses.

Today, the official picture from Baghdad looks brighter than at any time in the past 10 years. Thinly-disguised "humanitarian" flights from abroad arrive almost daily, Iraqi Airways is operating again (even in the no-fly zones) and oil production has recovered to pre-war levels.

Ordinary Iraqis can see changes, too. Food rations are up, power cuts are less severe, drinking water and sewage services are slowly improving.

We hear less now about the malnutrition, the lack of medicines and the dying children. Those problems are still there - Iraq's health ministry blamed sanctions for more than 10,000 deaths last month - but Saddam's message has changed: it is no longer that sanctions are a disaster, but that they are so full of holes we might as well abandon them.

Resistance to sanctions takes two forms. One is simply to flout them, though some of this illicit trade is stopped by patrols in the Gulf. But despite seizures, supporters of the regime still manage to acquire new cars or the latest computers. One London-based Iraqi recently brought back a much-coveted PlayStation2 for his son from Baghdad: "It's cheaper there, and there's no waiting list," he said.

At another level, there are what the Americans describe as Iraq's "salami tactics" - picking at weak points in the rules of sanctions, preferably in ways that cause disagreement between the US and other countries. For example: what, precisely, makes a flight to Baghdad "humanitarian"?

In a region where political symbolism is often valued more than hard facts, Saddam's defiant stance against sanctions plays well to the masses. It has certainly embarrassed the west, but it is largely theatre - like the missiles on display last weekend which looked menacing enough but which actually had ranges under 150 kilometres and therefore complied fully with UN arms-control restrictions.

While Iraq continues to protest about sanctions, it shows no willingness to end them on the UN's current terms. But as Britain and the UN have been making conciliatory noises about sanctions, many Arabs believe George W Bush will feel compelled to adopt the hard line his father took. Colin Powell, the new Secretary of State, who was Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff under Bush pere, declared immediately after his nomination that he hoped to "re-energise" sanctions. Bush himself has said that he wants sanctions to be tougher - an idea that many experts dismiss as unrealistic. Meanwhile, there is still no sign of repentance or regret from Baghdad over the invasion of Kuwait. Iraqi soldiers are currently being paid to write short memoirs for inclusion in a book to mark the 10th anniversary of the Mother of Battles.

Sanctions may not have achieved their goals, but there is little doubt that Saddam's campaign against them has kept him out of serious mischief. In his battle with the Security Council he needs international support and, so long as that battle continues, he is not going to risk losing support through military adventures.

Once sanctions have gone, it may be a different matter. Even if Iraq meets the weapons inspection criteria, there will be little to stop it re-arming. Intelligence sources suggest that Iraq's nuclear programme is continuing and that it may be between five and 10 years from developing a usable nuclear weapon.

Saddam still hankers after leadership of the Arab world, and the history of his rule suggests that he sees only one route to achieving that and to ensuring the survival of his regime: through conflict.

The despots who won't say die

webTitle: Market forces: Taking counter measures

fields.headline: Taking counter measures
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: Roll up, roll up. It is time to place your bet in the great Christmas retailing game. The rules are very simple - try to predict which retailers performed well over Christmas - and the rewards can be spectacular. But hurry, the game starts on Thursday when jeweller Signet, up 2p to 52.25p, releases its trading update.
fields.body:
Roll up, roll up. It is time to place your bet in the great Christmas retailing game. The rules are very simple - try to predict which retailers performed well over Christmas - and the rewards can be spectacular. But hurry, the game starts on Thursday when jeweller Signet, up 2p to 52.25p, releases its trading update.

Although it might seem strange to those outside the Square Mile, the four-week trading period that covers festive season and the start of the January sales has a marked impact on retailers' share price.

A number of them will see their share prices move up or down by 20% in the weeks following their trading updates. The trick is to guess how many and which, and dealers spent yesterday trying to do exactly that.

On the basis of yesterday's movements, the betting is favouring Dixons, up 11p to 235p. The electronics retailer is due to report interim figures next Wednesday and market professionals reckon the results statement will contain some some good news on Christmas trading.

Others said to have performed well in the past four weeks are Carphone Warehouse, 1.5p higher at 198.5p, which market sources claim had an outstanding Christmas. The tills are also said to have have been ringing at GUS, 4.5p stronger at 530p, thanks to its luxury goods label, Burberry. As usual, Next, though off 18p at 787p, is also said to have turned in a good performance.

Overall, most analysts expect Christmas to have been average, although opinions are divided on Marks & Spencer. If recent leaked sales figures are correct - clothing sales down 16% in the six weeks to December 16 - then things look bad. But the stock improved 4.25p to 190.25p yesterday, suggesting some punters are prepared to take a gamble. Apparently margins at M&S may be better than expected.

In the wider market, the first trading session of the year was characterised by another bout of volatility. In thin trading, leading shares opened lower before recovering and then collapsing late in the day after more worrying US economic data appeared.

The culprit this time was a the weakest manufacturing report in almost 10 years, which seemed to support the bearish predictions that the US economy, and therefore the world economy, is heading for recession.

After trading in a 106-point arc, the FTSE 100 came to settle 47.8 points lower at 6,174.7. Elsewhere, the Techmark 100 was off 76.39 at 2,487.66.

Market turnover was poor, just topping 1.25bn. While most fund managers are back at their desks following the Christmas break, dealers do not expect any significant activity until next week. By then the market should have an idea of just how bad things are on the other side of the Atlantic. Friday's US labour report for December will be crucial.

Aside from the retailers, the only stocks to end higher yesterday were those tagged in the weekend broadsheets as "ones to watch in 2001". In time-honoured fashion, dealers marked up those tipped to go higher and retail investors bought them regardless. Proving popular were Stagecoach, 4p stronger at 70p, and Boots, 28p better at 637p.

Media display group Photobition also managed to buck the trend, rising 9.5p to 107p on news that its chief executive, Eddie Marchbanks, recently acquired 90,000 shares.

The rules are very simple - try to predict which retailers performed well over Christmas - and the rewards can be spectacular. But hurry, the game starts on Thursday when jeweller Signet, up 2p to 52.25p, releases its trading update. Although it might seem strange to those outside the Square Mile, the four-week trading period that covers festive season and the start of the January sales has a marked impact on retailers' share price. A number of them will see their share prices move up or down by 20% in the weeks following their trading updates. webTitle: City briefing

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
Taxi maker in shake-up
Railtrack boss Muttram quits
French fine Adidas €2.4m
ICI sales raises £52m in cash
Three arrested in City burglary
Mersey Docks adds 300 jobs
fields.body:
Taxi maker in shake-up

London taxi maker Manganese Bronze has a new chairman after a management shake-up designed to get the firm's share price back on track.

Chairman Hugh Lang is stepping down and will be replaced by the chief executive, Jamie Borwick, six weeks after Manganese warned that profits for the full year will be significantly below market expectations.

"Having been the chairman for more than eight years, it is time for a change and Jamie Borwick is my natural successor," Mr Lang said.

One of Mr Borwick's focuses will be the firm's share price which has been in reverse for almost a year. In February last year the shares were changing hands at 270p but have fallen steadily since. Last night the shares closed down 2.5p at 125p.

Railtrack boss Muttram quits

Railtrack Group said Rod Muttram has resigned his position as a director of Railtrack Group plc, Railtrack plc and Railtrack Holdings in order to take up the position of chief executive at Railway Safety.

Railway Safety, a not for profit body wholly owned by Railtrack, was established after a Department of the Environment Transport and the Regions review after the Ladbroke Grove accident.

The review recommended that Railtrack's safety and standards directorate be established as a separate organisation to increase demonstrable independence of its activities and separation from Railtrack's commercial interests.

French fine Adidas €2.4m

German sportswear and equipment maker Adidas-Salomon yesterday said a French court had fined it €2.4m (£1.5m) for anti-competitive practices. Adidas said the court had ruled against a contract from the early 1990s with the French soccer league association giving it exclusive supplier rights to equip all the teams in the French first division.

Competitors Nike and Umbro filed suit in 1995 after Adidas' earlier attempt to equip all the teams in France's Ligue Nationale de Football with the Adidas emblem.

A spokesman for Adidas said that the firm had not made any similar attempts since then and that it now was concentrating its marketing efforts on several top French teams.

ICI sales raises £52m in cash

Imperial Chemical Industries said it would raise about £52m in cash after the sale of its UK-based methanol business and its share of the joint venture company Phillips-Imperial Petroleum.

The disposals end the company's interest in petrochemicals production in the UK. ICI will use the proceeds of the transaction to reduce its debt, the company said.

Three arrested in City burglary

City detectives investigating a burglary at Deutsche Bank's offices in Hounsditch at the end of November have charged three people.

Anthony Mannigan, 29, John Sheehan, 20, and a 17 year old youth, all from Islington, are due to appear before City of London magistrates tomorrow morning.

Mersey Docks adds 300 jobs

Mersey Docks & Harbour plans to create over 300 jobs on the Medway in Kent by building a £2m pre-delivery inspection centre for imported Peugeot cars and a £1.5m fruit packing plant. The inspection unit will deal with 200,000 cars a year from France, Spain and Italy.

webTitle: Shop staff stumble over new Steps single

fields.headline: Shop staff stumble over new Steps single
fields.trailText: The pop group Steps has found itself on the back foot after a sales error left its latest single floundering at the bottom of the charts.
fields.body:
The pop group Steps has found itself on the back foot after a sales error left its latest single floundering at the bottom of the charts.

The quintet's new track, The Way You Make Me Feel, missed the new year top 40 after several shops inadvertently sold copies a week early, despite instructions to hold on to them.

Sales put the single at number 72, the lowest chart entry for the group, which has had a string of top 10 hits including the number one track Tragedy.

A Steps spokesman said yesterday: " Stocks were sent out before Christmas because of the logistics of getting them out over the holiday period.

"What some hungover staff have done is looked through their stockrooms and thought: 'There are some Steps singles. We'd better put these on display.' "

The bungle has resulted in only 980 copies being sold so far. With its earlier single Stomp, the group reached number one.

The spokesman admitted that the sales returns for the new record could mean that not many people wanted to buy it, but he thought that was unlikely. "All it means is that a few people have spent their Christmas vouchers early," he said. "It's obviously going to be quite a high riser."

The single is expected to be the highest climber of the week when the charts are unveiled on Sunday, and could even signal the end of Bob the Builder's reign over number one.

webTitle: UK news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Racist attack victim dies
Woman jailed for school theft
Weakest Link is top T-shirt
Jobs advice for women
'Sickie' days off under the duvet
fields.body:
Racist attack victim dies

An Algerian man who was repeatedly stabbed in an apparently racist attack after leaving a restaurant with his wife in central London died yesterday, Scotland Yard confirmed. Djamale Daikha, 38, of north London, was taken to hospital just after midnight on New Year's Day.

In a separate incident, a 19-year-old man has been arrested in connection with a racist attack in Southwark, south London, on Christmas Eve which left Turkish asylum seeker Cumali Sinangili, 41, in a "critical" condition in hospital. The man, who attended a south London police station voluntarily in connection with the incident, was bailed to return on January 8.

Woman jailed for school theft

A former school secretary and mother of two who stole more than £6,000 in dinner money was jailed for six months yesterday. Eileen Ashton, 56, of Wallasey, Wirral, was said to have stolen from Prenton primary school, Wirral, to "make ends meet" after her husband left her and maintenance payments ceased.

Judge Ian Trigger said the background to the crime was "extremely sad", but he had a public duty to impose a jail sentence.

Weakest Link is top T-shirt

TV host Anne Robinson's cruel catchphrase on BBC's The Weakest Link has proved a fashion hit by gracing the year's best-selling T-shirt.

The shirt, with the slogan "You are the weakest link, goodbye" has topped charts compiled by retailer HMV. The catchphrase, Whassup, from the Budweiser ads, was runner-up.

Jobs advice for women

Women wanting to return to work after having children or those keen to find a new career will be offered advice at a government-led jobs fair next month.

Seminars will be held on CV writing, interview skills, setting up in business and training and education opportunities at Women Unlimited in London on February 13. Anyone wanting to attend should register on 0870 7511484 or via a website, womenunlimited

'Sickie' days off under the duvet

The British tradition of having a "sickie" - ringing in sick as an excuse to take a day off - could be replaced by legitimate "duvet days", if an American idea catches on in the UK.

Some US firms allow employees about four days off a year, to be taken at a moment's notice. They are called "duvet days" because most people only use the time off to spend a few extra hours in bed.

webTitle: Boys' lethal game in launderette driers

fields.headline: Boys' lethal game in launderette driers
fields.trailText: A family launderette chain has axed its late night opening after catching schoolboys playing a potentially lethal game of dare inside revolving tumble drier drums.
fields.body:
A family launderette chain has axed its late night opening after catching schoolboys playing a potentially lethal game of dare inside revolving tumble drier drums.

Closed circuit security cameras at two launderettes in Tenby, west Wales, caught youngsters as young as 10 putting 20p into the drying machines and then climbing inside.

Schoolboy friends then held the machine door closed while the youngster inside span round in the rising heat for up to five minutes in a dare to see who could stay inside the longest.

A company spokesman Stuart Fecci, 36, said: "We knew something was up because we had eight nylon cogs inside the drums, which pop when the machines are overloaded, go within two weeks.

"They cost £200 each to replace but they break very rarely so when eight went in one go we knew something was up.

"But this has nothing to do with money - it is costing us much more in lost business to close early. We just don't want anyone to put their lives in jeopardy.

"These tumble driers operate for a maximum eight minutes for 20p, and nobody could survive inside for that long. They give off heat equal to a three bar electric fire.

"They are also gas heated which means that they produce carbon monoxide, which is harmless to clothes but deadly to humans. There are three large paddles inside which could be very dangerous."

He said that as a result of the CCTV footage he had traced two of the youngsters involved and spoken to their parents. He has also reported the matter to the police.

Press Association

webTitle: Industry struggles to maintain growth

fields.headline: Industry struggles to maintain growth
fields.trailText: British manufacturers increased output for the 21st month in a row in December, but analysts said growth in the sector was still subdued and warned about the effects of a deteriorating world economy.
fields.body:
British manufacturers increased output for the 21st month in a row in December, but analysts said growth in the sector was still subdued and warned about the effects of a deteriorating world economy.

The index from the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply, a composite measure designed to provide an overall view of the manufacturing economy, was 51.3, unchanged from the previous month.

Any reading above 50 denotes expansion, below 50 contraction. Output increased at the fastest rate for nine months, according to the institute.

But export orders were weak, and analysts said the sector would be in danger if the world economy turned down. "The key danger is that the slowdown in global demand will hit manufacturers' exports hard, dragging manufacturing output potentially back into recession, similar to the situation facing the sector at the end of 1998," said John Butler, UK economist at HSBC Markets.

Manufacturers continued to shed labour in order to boost productivity in the face of sluggish demand - a gloomy omen with the jobs index at 48.2 in December compared to 49.1 in November.

But there was some good news in the survey which showed that falling oil prices have checked fuel and raw material price rises.

Separate figures from the Bank of England suggested that shoppers went on a pre-Christmas spending spree. The Bank's first estimate of the amount of notes and coins in circulation showed a 1.5% rise in December.

webTitle: Comment:  US president signs up  for war crimes tribunal

fields.headline: Hypocrite to the last
fields.standfirst:
The US president has suddenly signed up to the plan for an international war crimes tribunal

Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: The US president has suddenly signed up to the plan for an international war crimes tribunal.
fields.body:
On Sunday, in a move that took everyone by surprise, the United States suddenly reversed its previous policy and signed a treaty to establish a permanent international criminal court. The decision was taken by Bill Clinton at the last possible moment, only hours before the deadline set by the United Nations was due to expire. With other last-minute signatories, the total of countries that have declared their support for the Rome treaty now stands at 139, bringing the ultimate goal of a global system of justice a little closer to reality.

The international criminal court (ICC) would be the first standing tribunal with jurisdiction to try individuals on charges of genocide, war crimes and other crimes against humanity. It would be a permanent version of the ad hoc tribunals set up at Nuremberg in 1946, to try Nazi war criminals, and more recently in the Netherlands and Tanzania to hear cases involving human rights abuses in former Yugoslavia and Rwanda respectively.

While countries as diverse as Chile, Argentina, Senegal, Zimbabwe and Sierra Leone were quick to sign the treaty, the Clinton administration has opposed it ever since it was negotiated in Rome in 1998. In doing so, it lined itself up against some of its chief allies in Europe and alongside some of the world's most notorious torture states, including China. On Sunday, the news that the US had abruptly changed its mind prompted a similar change of heart in Israel; the Israeli announcement overturned an earlier vote against signature by the Israeli cabinet, confirming the enormous influence the United States continues to exert on its embattled ally in the Middle East.

So that's the good news. The bad news is that Clinton's decision stops a long way short of ratifying the treaty, a step that must be taken by 60 countries before the court can be set up in the Netherlands. (To date, 27 nations have done so, clearing almost half the hurdles in what often seems a painfully slow and bureaucratic process.) Even worse is the fact that his decision is not legally binding without Senate approval. The incoming Republican administration is firmly opposed, with George W Bush's nominee for defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, warning only last month that "American leadership in the world could be the first casualty" of the court.

The likely response of the Senate was revealed on Sunday when Jesse Helms of North Carolina, the rightwing Republican who chairs the foreign relations committee, called Clinton's action "as outrageous as it is inexplicable". He claimed it was "a blatant attempt by a lame-duck president to tie the hands of his successor", adding ominously: "Well, I have a message for the outgoing president. This decision will not stand."

Clinton knows this perfectly well, and took the unusual step of declaring that he would neither submit the treaty for Senate approval nor recommend that his successor do so. And while Bush's hands are tied to some extent - he cannot reverse Clinton's action - he can declare that the US will never ratify the treaty. He can also encourage the Senate to reject it, leaving Democratic members - including the outgoing president's wife - to defend it in an atmosphere of overwhelming hostility and growing American isolationism.

In that sense, Helms's accusation about Clinton's motives contains some truth. Indeed it does not go far enough, for it is clear that the 42nd president is casting about for grand gestures that will stand as his memorial. With peace in the Middle East as far away as ever, it seems likely that his abrupt volte-face on the ICC is more about looking good than a genuine conversion to what the president described at the weekend as a reaffirmation of "our strong support for international accountability".

That support might look a bit more convincing if Clinton had signed the treaty two years ago, along with the 73 world leaders who did so in the six months after the Rome conference, instead of caving in to pressure from the Pentagon. Until last weekend, his public position was not easy to distinguish from that of his Republican opponents, who distrust the ICC because they have not been able to secure a promise that no American will ever have to appear before it. Helms announced some time ago that the treaty would be "dead on arrival" in Congress if it failed to exclude the future indictment of a single American soldier.

For a country whose troops perpetrated the My Lai massacre in Vietnam, and which is currently supplying money, weapons and military advisers to an army with a dismal record of human rights abuses in Colombia, this is a real anxiety. While the most obvious targets of the ICC would be generals and former heads of state, it would also have a duty to examine the conduct of less well-known individuals. It is not beyond the realms of possibility that this might one day include American soldiers serving with the Colombian armed forces or under the aegis of the UN in one of the world's trouble spots.

Such a prospect has, until now, worried the outgoing president just as much as it does Helms or Rumsfeld. Like them, Clinton is committed to a policy that treats his fellow-citizens as hugely more valuable, and correspondingly less accountable, than those of other nations. One of the results has been ineffectual interventions in countries such as Rwanda - where Clinton turned up in 1998 and belatedly apologised for failing to prevent genocide four years earlier - and a preference for hi-tech air wars. In Kosovo, it became clear that this policy protects American forces at the cost of unacceptable civilian casualties on the ground.

Clinton's Nato allies have put up with this situation to keep the US on side in a whole string of peace-keeping operations. (Privately, supporters of the Blair government even go so far as to admit that Britain's acquiescence in the bombing of Iraq is a quid pro quo for American support elsewhere, particularly in the Balkans.) This means that Clinton has got away with what is really a form of American neo-imperialism, and has now turned his mind to ensuring that things stay that way in the future. He could scarcely have enjoyed a greater stroke of luck than the incoming Bush administration, which can be relied upon to enhance his thoroughly undeserved liberal reputation.

Clinton has not even left office and the nostalgic profiles are already being written, a process that can only be accelerated by the conduct of his Republican opponents. That the creation of an international system of justice is too important to be a pawn in this unsavoury game hardly matters; Clinton has had eight years to do great things and failed in almost every respect, from reforming health care to the redistribution of wealth. In the dying days of his administration, what else should we expect from this most unscrupulous of politicians but showy and essentially empty gestures?

Moralities: Sex, Money and Power in the 21st Century by Joan Smith will be published by Allen Lane in May.

Jonathan Freedland is away

In that sense, Helms's accusation about Clinton's motives contains some truth. Indeed it does not go far enough, for it is clear that the 42nd president is casting about for grand gestures that will stand as his memorial. With peace in the Middle East as far away as ever, it seems likely that his abrupt volte-face on the ICC is more about looking good than a genuine conversion to what the president described at the weekend as a reaffirmation of "our strong support for international accountability". That support might look a bit more convincing if Clinton had signed the treaty two years ago, along with the 73 world leaders who did so in the six months after the Rome conference, instead of caving in to pressure from the Pentagon. Until last weekend, his public position was not easy to distinguish from that of his Republican opponents, who distrust the ICC because they have not been able to secure a promise that no American will ever have to appear before it. Helms announced some time ago that the treaty would be "dead on arrival" in Congress if it failed to exclude the future indictment of a single American soldier. For a country whose troops perpetrated the My Lai massacre in Vietnam, and which is currently supplying money, weapons and military advisers to an army with a dismal record of human rights abuses in Colombia, this is a real anxiety. While the most obvious targets of the ICC would be generals and former heads of state, it would also have a duty to examine the conduct of less well-known individuals. It is not beyond the realms of possibility that this might one day include American soldiers serving with the Colombian armed forces or under the aegis of the UN in one of the world's trouble spots. Such a prospect has, until now, worried the outgoing president just as much as it does Helms or Rumsfeld. Like them, Clinton is committed to a policy that treats his fellow-citizens as hugely more valuable, and correspondingly less accountable, than those of other nations. One of the results has been ineffectual interventions in countries such as Rwanda - where Clinton turned up in 1998 and belatedly apologised for failing to prevent genocide four years earlier - and a preference for hi-tech air wars. In Kosovo, it became clear that this policy protects American forces at the cost of unacceptable civilian casualties on the ground. Clinton's Nato allies have put up with this situation to keep the US on side in a whole string of peace-keeping operations. (Privately, supporters of the Blair government even go so far as to admit that Britain's acquiescence in the bombing of Iraq is a quid pro quo for American support elsewhere, particularly in the Balkans.) This means that Clinton has got away with what is really a form of American neo-imperialism, and has now turned his mind to ensuring that things stay that way in the future. He could scarcely have enjoyed a greater stroke of luck than the incoming Bush administration, which can be relied upon to enhance his thoroughly undeserved liberal reputation. Clinton has not even left office and the nostalgic profiles are already being written, a process that can only be accelerated by the conduct of his Republican opponents. That the creation of an international system of justice is too important to be a pawn in this unsavoury game hardly matters; Clinton has had eight years to do great things and failed in almost every respect, from reforming health care to the redistribution of wealth. In the dying days of his administration, what else should we expect from this most unscrupulous of politicians but showy and essentially empty gestures? Moralities: Sex, Money and Power in the 21st Century by Joan Smith will be published by Allen Lane in May. Jonathan Freedland is away

webTitle: Regulator gets tough over rail repair plan

fields.headline: Regulator gets tough over rail repair plan
fields.standfirst:
As frustration mounts over delays, Railtrack is given January 18 deadline to produce details of how it will restore national network

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: As frustration mounts over delays, Railtrack is given January 18 deadline to produce details of how it will restore national network.
fields.body:
Railtrack was last night issued with an enforcement order by the rail regulator compelling it to produce specific rail recovery plans by January 18.

Tom Winsor has acted after complaints from the 25 train operating companies that Railtrack's national recovery plan following the Hatfield rail crash in October was inadequate.

Mr Winsor could take legal action against Railtrack if he thought that it was ignoring his demands for action to restore the network as soon as possible. He is reluctant to get into a legal battle at this stage, but Railtrack could face fines if it refuses to respond.

The regulator's decision coincided with a report from a passenger group saying that public confidence in the railways had sunk to "probably its lowest point ever".

Wendy Toms, chairwoman of the rail passengers' committee for southern England, said that Railtrack could not abdicate its responsibility for ensuring the overall quality and safety of the infrastructure. "There are signs that passengers are reaching the end of their patience. Those with a choice of whether or not to travel by train are forsaking rail in droves and travelling by car or coach if their journey is short."

George Muir, director general of the Association of Train Operating Companies, which represents organisations like National Express, Virgin and Stagecoach, said: "We don't yet have a return to a normal plan for each operator. That is what the passengers need." The association said that the companies needed detail to plan their timetables after the end of January.

Mr Winsor said that the companies had yet to receive adequate plans from Railtrack, which had to be produced after consultation with the train operators and the health and safety executive.

He said: "The operators require these plans, as well as route by route information, so that they can plan their services with confidence. They must be able to make an assessment of the adequacy of those plans to deliver a reliable service."

The action stems from a meeting between Railtrack, the train companies and the regulator on December 15.

Rail passengers were subjected to delays and cancellations yesterday as Railtrack failed to complete two big re-signalling projects on time. Railtrack said it had been hampered by bad weather and technical issues.

Mr Muir said that it was imperative that Railtrack restored at least 80% of the network to normal by the end of the month. He said that most regional services in Scotland and Wales were back to normal, that the London commuter services were very mixed, and that inter-city services were very chaotic. Some 8,000 of the 18,000 trains that operate daily on the network were running normally.

John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, visited Railtrack headquarters yesterday, to praise staff who had seen more than 80 speed limits removed over Christmas.

Mr Prescott said: "I am delighted to see that Railtrack has exceeded its target and has replaced more than 40 miles of track, having planned to do 30 miles." He said the industry was on target to meet its commitment to restoring 85% of services by the end of January.

webTitle: Just a little longer, Leeds travellers told

fields.headline: Just a little longer, Leeds travellers told
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: "At least we get a mystery tour of south Leeds," Ms Moore, a student, said before the bus headed off to the nearest southbound railhead at Wakefield. Her disrupted day was just one of thousands in England's biggest financial and legal centre outside London, which faces another five days almost entirely without trains.
fields.body:
The Yorkshire Eagle rail support bus stood at what Leeds commuters have nicknamed Pavement One yesterday, its engine chugging as Kirsty Moore heaved her rucksack into the luggage hold.

"At least we get a mystery tour of south Leeds," Ms Moore, a student, said before the bus headed off to the nearest southbound railhead at Wakefield.

Her disrupted day was just one of thousands in England's biggest financial and legal centre outside London, which faces another five days almost entirely without trains. Snow, gales and unexpected glitches to the £165m Leeds City station improvement have led to another delay in Railtrack's hopes of reopening one of the north's busiest transport hubs.

The Confederation of British Industry in Leeds said many firms had decided not to start "properly" again until Monday, largely due to the stranglehold on transport into the city. Mike Cartwright, of the Leeds, Bradford and York Chamber of Commerce, said video-conferencing had enjoyed a boom, with flights to London vulnerable to poor weather at Leeds-Bradford airport.

"You can't blame them for the weather, I suppose," said Ahmed Khan, a telesales canvasser who had bussed in from Dewsbury. "They're doing their best, but it's a bit hard for us, coming on top of the delays we've had all autumn."

Above the constant queue of chartered coaches, Balfour Beatty engineers continued the work on new station roofs and signalling gantries on round-the-clock shifts. The company has 350 staff committed to reopening Leeds City fully on Monday, after missing two previous targets.

"We apologise and ask travellers to bear with us," said a spokesman for the project. "It wasn't until the end of December, with the freezing temperatures and high winds, that we realised we couldn't meet today's deadline."

Railtrack's Yorkshire region has started a 100-day countdown to a fully functioning local rail service, after its delay in responding to a letter from Graham Hall, chairman of Yorkshire Forward, the regional development agency, warning of serious economic damage and demanding clear information on how long disruption was expected to last. Yorkshire Forward said yesterday: "We welcome the fact that a target has now been set."

webTitle: Hungarian pop star dies in gun accident

fields.headline: Hungarian pop star dies in gun accident
fields.trailText: Jimmy Zambo, one of Hungary's best-selling pop stars, died yesterday in a freak gun accident.
fields.body:
Jimmy Zambo, one of Hungary's best-selling pop stars, died yesterday in a freak gun accident.

Zambo, 42, accidentally shot himself in the head at his home in a residential district of Budapest, the state news agency MTI reported. He was a keen hunter and owned several guns.

Police said Zambo was with his wife and three friends, and they had been drinking when he fired his gun, a 9mm Beretta, out of the window.

A police spokeswoman said the reason why he fired this first shot was being withheld at the family's request.

The fatal shot went off when Zambo removed the clip, but failed to realise that a bullet was in the gun's chamber.

He was rushed to hospital but doctors could not save his life.

First reports spoke of suicide, but the spokeswoman told MTI it was an accident.

Zambo, whose real first name was Imre, started his career in the State Radio Children's Choir, and from 1982 to 1986 he worked in the United States in various clubs. All his albums were best-sellers, and since March 2000, he had had his own show on RTL-Klub, a commercial station which enjoyed high ratings.

Zambo is survived by his wife and three sons.

webTitle: Last night's TV

fields.headline: Battle stations
fields.trailText: Sword Of Honour | Brookside | The 1940s House
fields.body:
Rather than being good for absolutely nothing, war is really quite handy for the purposes of entertainment. Sword Of Honour (Channel 4), William Boyd's adaptation of Evelyn Waugh's trilogy, is on the whole, quite an impressive piece of television.

From its beginnings in sun-bleached Italy through the verdant English countryside to the inky darkness of night-time reconnaissance missions, there is a touch of the epic about this retelling of Guy Crouchback's experiences of the second world war. Daniel Craig was magnetic as the man in search of meaning, Crouchback, and a talented ensemble included Robert Pugh as a barking mad brigadier and Richard Coyle as a chancer of an officer.

Fortunately, both managed to lift their characters beyond caricature, as did Megan Dodds (just), lumbered as she was with the vampish Virginia, who was doing her bit for the war effort by sleeping with everyone in the British army.

Yet for all the quality acting, beautiful set pieces and smooth direction, Sword Of Honour was lacking something. After a weak, lethargic beginning, it picked up considerably; but where Waugh's books put Crouchback's quest to the fore, William Boyd's adaptation gets a little too caught up in the period (so much so, there are points at which one expects French and Saunders to appear with marcel waves and martinis) and the comic aspects of the novels. An exploding commode, anyone? There were hints of Crouchback's quest for moral purpose - his moments at the tomb of a crusader who never made it to Jerusalem, his strangled Catholic guilt, his yearning to fight a just fight - but they were never made quite explicit enough, demanding instead a rather laborious sifting through layers of wartime drama conventions. This isn't a demand for drama with no depth. Rather, it is a request that drama with depth is well-constructed.

What could have been a thorough introspective look at the effect of war - and life - on one man was (perhaps necessarily) broadened out, and subsequently lost some of the impact of its source material.

Having said that, as a television drama, Sword Of Honour - like the fabulous and underrated North Square - demonstrates that Channel 4 can sometimes show the big boys how it is done.

After all, you can't beat a good conflict. Just ask Ray and Jessie, Manor Park's resident geriatric lovers in Brookside (Channel 4), whose big day threatens to be overshadowed by Ray's cantankerous mother, Kitty. Instead of threatening to smother her with a pillow in the night, or asking Max to derail her chair lift when she's right at the top, Ray the Generic Soap Old Man (cf EastEnders' Jim) and Jesse the Muppet (cf Rolf the Piano Player) just grimace at each other across the room. Heavens, it's like they've been married for years. And all the while, Kitty - who bears a striking resemblance to the witch from Chorlton And The Wheelies - shuffles along creating havoc, but alas, no genuine drama, like a Fury in support tights.

What weird masochists the Hymer family are. They have opted to live their lives in The 1940s House (Channel 4). This being wartime, it is a 30s semi with a bomb shelter and a vegetable patch out back. Their foray into 40s living - no TV, no pizzas, no equal rights for women - comes hot on the heels of The 1900 House which, bizarrely, was considered at the more worthy end of reality TV and not simply voyeuristic Schadenfreude like Big Brother. How that conclusion is reached is anyone's guess, but howsoever it was, you can bet crampons and nylon rope were involved. Whatever, it proved enough of a successful, respectable "social experiment" that its premise - currently going down a storm in America - has been repeated.

The 1940s House is better than its predecessor, though only because it didn't have that awful woman in it bemoaning the lack of shampoo and crying. (Really, she should have been thankful no one in the family had been given consumption as part of the "social experiment", but some people don't know hardship.)

At the moment, even with the digging and the frumpy frocks, the Hymers are in good spirits. We'll see how long that lasts. Whether this time tourism ("Go see how the other half used to live!") isn't slightly distasteful wasn't really discussed.

War? That's entertainment.

webTitle: Dutch fire toll climbs to 10 with 17 fighting for life

fields.headline: Dutch fire toll climbs to 10 with 17 fighting for life
fields.standfirst: Independent inquiry into disco tragedy promised
fields.trailText: Independent inquiry into disco tragedy promised.
fields.body:
A 13-year-old girl was among the 10 young people so far confirmed dead after a disco in a harbourside party complex burst into flames during a New Year's celebration, the mayor of the Dutch village of Volendam said yesterday.

Frank Ijsselmuiden told a news conference that the girl had died in hospital on Monday evening. Yesterday afternoon a tenth victim died at a burns centre, and with 17 people still in very serious condition there could be more deaths, the mayor said.

The blaze left 184 injured, of whom 90 needed treatment at burns centres across the Netherlands, and in Belgium and Germany.

The names of the dead, all under 25 years old, were published in the churches of this Roman Catholic fishing village, where everyone knew someone at the crowded party in the Little Heaven disco and cafe, located in a three-storey wooden house on the quayside.

Queen Beatrix planned to visit victims in Amsterdam's AMC hospital with the deputy prime minister, Annemarie Jorritsma, before an evening memorial service took place in Volendam.

The village's churches held special services and youth centres opened their doors to give survivors a place to meet and share their grief.

Wim Keizer, a city councillor who has been a teacher for 40 years, knew the youngest victim, Liesbeth Buijs, and Nico Kwakman, 24, who died after running back inside to try to save others: "I knew them all. It's incomprehensible," Mr Kiezer said.

The legal drinking age for beer in the Netherlands is 16, but minors are often allowed into nightclubs or bars where ages are rarely checked. Late last year, the Dutch parliament approved a law with tougher penalties for establishments that serve under-age drinkers.

Investigators tried to piece together the events leading up to the deadly blaze in the quaint 16th century village 15 miles north of Amsterdam.

The nightmare began just after midnight as hundreds of revellers were toasting the new year. Overhead Christmas decorations caught fire, instantly filling the disco with thick smoke. Some eyewitnesses blame sparklers, others recall an explosion.

In the darkness there was panic. Fire department officials said only one emergency exit was found open when they arrived at the scene. On Monday, the mayor said at a press conference that it seemed some exits had been blocked.

Many of the youngsters escaped by jumping from the top floor. Others were trampled in the chaos.

Public prosecutors launched a preliminary inquiry to determine if fire regulations had been met. Dutch television quoted city officials saying that it could be weeks before they decide whether to conduct a criminal investigation.

The deputy interior minister, Gijs de Vries, said the government would commission a separate independent inquiry into the calamity.

webTitle: Watch this

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Lifeboat | Desert Bloom | Das Boot: The Director's Cut | All That Jazz
fields.body:
Lifeboat

(Alfred Hitchcock, 1944)

6pm, FilmFour

A group of survivors from a torpedoed liner, adrift on a lifeboat: they include William Bendix's twitchy sailor, Tallulah Bankhead's uppity journo, and hardnut John Hodiak. Then they pull aboard a a German (Walter Slezak) from the U-boat that sank them... Hitchcock talked John Steinbeck into writing the story,

to pose democratic values against rabid Nazism; the result is a tense, claustrophobic battle of wills, and an interesting comparison with Das Boot (below).

Desert Bloom (pictured)

(Eugene Corr, 1985)

4pm, 9.30pm, Sky Cinema

Set in Nevada, 1950, the time and place for many an A-bomb test, though most of the explosions are domestic ones. Jon Voight is an embittered, alcoholic second world war veteran at odds with a female household:

wife JoBeth Williams and three daughters, of whom Annabeth Gish is the eldest. But when the girls' sexy aunt Ellen Barkin arrives, fission is inevitable.

Das Boot: The Director's Cut

(Wolfgang Petersen, 1981)

8pm, FilmFour

Petersen's account of a wartime U-boat crew hunting Allied shipping in the north Atlantic, based on a submariner's autobiography, is sweatily authentic and at times almost unbearably tense. The camera roves through the confined spaces of the war machine, but the focus is firmly on the grizzled, gaunt fighting men themselves, led by the haunted Jurgen Prochnow; and the advantage of this epic, extended version is that we come to know them better.

All That Jazz

(Bob Fosse, 1979)

11.30pm, FilmFour

Song and dance man Fosse's grand autobiographical movie. Giuseppe Rotunno's photography is superb and the dancing - particularly the hallucinatory operating room numbers - quite stunning; but the meat of the movie is in Roy Scheider's performance as the self-centred, maniacally driven, sex-and-death-obsessed Joe Gideon. All in all, a hell of a testimony to Fosse's wild talent.

Jon Voight is an embittered, alcoholic second world war veteran at odds with a female household: wife JoBeth Williams and three daughters, of whom Annabeth Gish is the eldest. But when the girls' sexy aunt Ellen Barkin arrives, fission is inevitable. Das Boot: The Director's Cut (Wolfgang Petersen, 1981) 8pm, FilmFour Petersen's account of a wartime U-boat crew hunting Allied shipping in the north Atlantic, based on a submariner's autobiography, is sweatily authentic and at times almost unbearably tense. The camera roves through the confined spaces of the war machine, but the focus is firmly on the grizzled, gaunt fighting men themselves, led by the haunted Jurgen Prochnow; and the advantage of this epic, extended version is that we come to know them better. All That Jazz (Bob Fosse, 1979) 11.30pm, FilmFour Song and dance man Fosse's grand autobiographical movie. Giuseppe Rotunno's photography is superb and the dancing - particularly the hallucinatory operating room numbers - quite stunning; but the meat of the movie is in Roy Scheider's performance as the self-centred, maniacally driven, sex-and-death-obsessed Joe Gideon. All in all, a hell of a testimony to Fosse's wild talent.

webTitle: Random views

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What pets are watching on television
fields.trailText: What pets are watching on television
fields.body:
Seesaw (Elspeth Edwards, Twickenham):

"Well, Seesaw is a black cat, about three, and he's never watched anything apart from Christmas last year. He got catnip for a present and seemed to get stoned immediately. So he watched all of the Ali G Christmas speech with me and my youngest daughter and he was entranced. He's never displayed such interest before, because it's just a box to him - well, not a cardboard box, which he would always sit in."

Fluff (Neil Sawyer, Teddington):

"Fluff is a nine-year-old Collie dog who's just had a hip operation at the vets. Yes, he's fine, a bit wobbly. Has he ever watched TV? He always watches Emmerdale and Coronation Street, but that's because he has an early tea and gets hungry again - so he watches soaps at that sort of time, to get my attention. He's quite a large dog, yes. Eats a lot."

Felix (Bryn Evans, Kingston upon Thames):

"My cat - he's dead now - used to watch Elvis on the television whenever he was on. He sat riveted to the whole of Jailhouse Rock once, and I hadn't seen anything like it before, he showed no interest before that. None at all. A very intelligent cat. Oh, he liked Lionel Richie as well. Always went quiet when he was on the radio."

Kim (Dylan Robertson, Cheltenham):

"Our dog was a lovely Lassie sort, but she never watched anything at all."

Cindy (Michael Cousins, Portsmouth):

"Cindy was my cat, a black one, and she watched Tarzan on Saturday mornings with Ron Ely, who was also in Manimal. I only watched Manimal once, so I can't tell whether Cindy liked it. I used to tie her legs together with tape, and so she didn't get a chance to develop a TV fixation because she was always trying to escape. She may have been in pain, yes. I was eight."

webTitle: Investors miss out on football's winning streak

fields.headline: Investors miss out on football's winning streak
fields.trailText: British football may be attracting more television money than ever before and the first £100,000 per week player contracts are on the horizon but investors are missing out on the boom, according to new figures.
fields.body:
British football may be attracting more television money than ever before and the first £100,000 per week player contracts are on the horizon but investors are missing out on the boom, according to new figures.

Of the 27 stock market-listed football clubs in England and Scotland only four saw their share prices rise during 1999: Arsenal, Bradford, Leicester City and Manchester United.

Even success does not appear to pay. Shares in Ofex-listed Manchester City, which was promoted to the Premiership, slumped 53%, while Leeds Sporting 's price fell 39% despite the club qualifying for the lucrative European Champions League for the first time.

The Ninth Floor, backer of Swansea City, was worst hit, falling 69%.

Bradford City was the biggest winner, climbing 46%, after the club held on to its place in the top league.

Even money machine Manchester United, which secured record-breaking sponsorship deals with Vodafone and Nike, and appointed a new investor-friendly chief executive, could only muster an annual 9% gain.

The research comes at the end of an eventful year for British football which saw record television contracts awarded and a European Union challenge to the legality of the player transfer system.

Oliver Butler, editor of Soccer Investor magazine which compiled the figures, said they illustrated a "malaise" in the sector. "There was a bit of an explosion at the beginning of the year with media deals taking place and that helped to boost some shares.

"Although more money may have been coming in, the big fact was that a lot of it was going straight out again into players' pockets in the form of wages. The situation was also not helped by the uncertainty over the transfer system and NTL pulling out of their pay-per-view deal with the Premier League.

"The most important issues for the next 12 months are whether clubs can really keep a rein on players' wages and how they cope with the resolution over the transfer system."

The figures will make particularly interesting reading for Enic, the leisure company that last month bought a large stake in Tottenham after a two-year courtship. It believes that football clubs remain a solid investment.

 Enic shares fell 30% to 119.5p last year.

webTitle: Fiat considers floating Ferrari

fields.headline: Fiat considers floating Ferrari
fields.trailText: Fiat is considering floating its Ferrari sports car business in an effort to retain staff who are being wooed away by competitors, an industry source confirmed yesterday.
fields.body:
Fiat is considering floating its Ferrari sports car business in an effort to retain staff who are being wooed away by competitors, an industry source confirmed yesterday.

Floating Ferrari would allow the management to reward highly valued staff with stock options and giving them a chance to share in the company's successes

Many will be keen to hold a stake in the Italian firm which last year sold a record number of its luxury cars - more than 4,000 - and won the formula one championship for the first time since 1979.

A spokesman for Fiat yesterday refused to comment directly on "press speculation" about the float but said an interview with Ferrari chairman Luca Cordero di Montezemolo provided a "very comprehensive" picture of Fiat's position.

In the interview - published last week- Mr Montezemolo said 2000 was a great year for Ferrari but added that the company's success was bringing new challenges. "The headhunters are swirling around Ferrari making offers for our best people", he said. "We've already lost two."

He recently persuaded Fiat to sanction a round of large bonus payouts for highly valued staff, but these offers were rapidly being dwarfed by lures from rivals. Floating Ferrari on the stock market would enable staff to receive share options as part of their pay.

Fiat chairman Paolo Fresco is also reported to favour a Ferrari flotation.

However, an imminent stock market placing seems unlikely because Ferrari has yet to complete the relaunch of the Maserati, another sports car Fiat hopes to return to favour. Maserati losses contributed to a fall in Ferrari's net profits from €8.1m (£5m) in 1998 to €5.8m in 1999.

Ferrari plans to make Maserati its volume sports car, increasing output from 2,000 to 10,000 over the next four years.

Despite the plans, some experts say floating Ferrari could bring the business further problems. "What are they going to gain from it, $200m to $300m?" said one industry observer. "They'd just end up with 30% or 40% being public, with another public company under Fiat. It would be a very messy structure."

Others have seen Ferrari's exemption from Fiat's share-swapping deal with General Motors in March as evidence that a flotation has been considered for some time. Under the deal, the US motor group took a 20% stake in most of the Fiat group in exchange for Fiat taking a 5.1% stake in GM.

webTitle: Buyback hoist for Regalian stock

fields.headline: Buyback hoist for Regalian stock
fields.trailText: Regalian Properties yesterday pledged to return capital to shareholders if talks being held with potential suitors eventually collapse.
fields.body:
Regalian Properties yesterday pledged to return capital to shareholders if talks being held with potential suitors eventually collapse.

The company, which refused to disclose how much would be returned, said it was considering both share buybacks and a special dividend.

It also confirmed the sale of its Marble Arch Tower complex in London to industry rival Marylebone Warwick Balfour for £69.2m.

In a statement to the stock market, Regalian said: "In the event that no acceptable offer is forthcoming, the company proposes to return capital to shareholders. A further announcement will be made as soon as practicable."

Shares in Regalian were trading up 3% at lunchtime before settling back to end the day up 1p at 42p, just 0.5p shy of its year's high and well clear of its 23p low. MWB slipped 1p to 232.5p as the London markets closed last night.

Regalian first announced it was in potential takeover talks at the beginning of last month. Speculation has mounted of a 45p a share bid which would value the company at £90m.

It is not known how many parties are interested in buying Regalian but interest is thought to have been shown by a management team led by Lee Goldstone, the son of company founder David.

A Regalian spokesman last night declined to comment on what price had been discussed or when a further announcement is expected to be made.

Analysts said many property companies were trading at a discount to their net asset value and a buyback was a popular way of boosting the share price.

Marble Arch Tower, housing a business centre, gymnasium and multiplex cinema, is located at the western end of Oxford Street.

In the year to March 31 2000, the net rental income from the Tower was £990,000; its sale is estimated to result in a post-tax profit of £11.5m. Regalian recorded pre-tax profits of £8.2m for the six months ending September 30, 2000, up from a £1.2m loss over the same period the previous year.

webTitle: 2,000 workers go to save Korean building firm

fields.headline: 2,000 workers go to save Korean building firm
fields.trailText: Hyundai Engineering & Construction, South Korea's biggest builder, yesterday said it would axe 2,000 jobs from its 7,200 workforce in a further desperate move to reduce its debts and save itself from bankruptcy.
fields.body:
Hyundai Engineering & Construction, South Korea's biggest builder, yesterday said it would axe 2,000 jobs from its 7,200 workforce in a further desperate move to reduce its debts and save itself from bankruptcy.

The company, part of one of the country's biggest conglomerates or chaebols, underlined the continuing depth of crisis in the former tiger economy with another bout of restructuring to cuts its debt to 3,500bn won (£1.8bn) by the end of this year from 4,400bn won last year.

Its plans, announced at a new year ceremony, see a cut of 37 executive posts, about 40% of the total, the spinning off of its engineering and steel structure operations and the outsourcing of its HQ management and company cafeteria.

Hyundai has come under strong pressure from South Korea's president, Kim Dae-Jung, to slim down drastically despite fierce union resistance to the scale of the job losses entailed - at least an estimated 200,000 in the current round.

President Kim said on Monday: "If we fail to complete restructuring because of fear of the pain, we will not be able to avoid devastation. But if we can overcome today's pain and complete reform ... we will be able to make a great leap forward tomorrow."

Last November Hyundai was forced to put up for sale the ranch of its founder, Chung Ju-yung, and other buildings and land under plans to avert bankruptcy by raising 1,300bn won, and last week creditors agreed to roll over more of its debts until June.

The construction business has forecast pre-tax profits of 400bn won this year after two years of losses since the Asian financial meltdown. It predicts sales of 7,800bn won, up about 10% from last year, and a 13% rise in new orders to 9,800bn won.

Observers believe President Kim will not allow the company to go bust because it is important to his "sunshine policy" of co-operation with communist North Korea through a series of investments there.

webTitle: Jack Lyons to appeal for third time

fields.headline: Lyons to appeal for third time
fields.trailText: Jack Lyons, convicted a decade ago for his role in the Guinness share support scheme, is to be given a chance to attempt to clear his name.
fields.body:
Jack Lyons, convicted a decade ago for his role in the Guinness share support scheme, is to be given a chance to attempt to clear his name.

In his 80s and understood to be in poor health, Lyons' application to appeal against his conviction in one of the biggest City scandals of the 1980s was submitted to the court of appeal by the criminal cases review commission yesterday.

It will be the third time Lyons has taken his case to the court of appeal and comes after the European court of human rights ruled in September that Lyons and two of his fellow convicts were denied a fair trial in 1990.

Lyons, a financier, was convicted in August 1990 of charges related to the Guinness takeover of Distillers, along with Gerald Ronson, chairman of Heron International, and Anthony Parnes, a trader. In September, the Strasbourg court of human rights ruled that all three had been denied a fair trial, in line with a judgment four years earlier in the case of Ernest Saunders, who was chairman of Guinness. Saunders was jailed for five years but released after 10 months after being diagnosed as an Alzheimer's sufferer. Lyons, stripped of his knighthood after the original verdict but spared a prison sentence because of poor health, first had an appeal against his sentence heard in 1991, when the size of his costs was reduced to £300,000 from £440,000.

In November 1995, after the home secretary referred his conviction to the court of appeal, one of his convictions, involving conspiracy to contravene Prevention of Fraud (Investments) Act was quashed. The latest referral to the court of appeal follows Lyons' application to the criminal cases review commission in October 2000. His original conviction was for false accounting, theft and conspiracy to contravene the Prevention of Fraud (Investments) Act and conspiracy to contravene the Companies Act.

The review commission did not publish its reasons for referring the conviction.

At the time of the court of human rights verdict, Lyons said: "I welcome this judgment so that I may yet be able to enjoy a little of my retirement without the cloud of injustice hanging over me."

webTitle: Cammell cuts 189 jumbo liner jobs

fields.headline: Cammell cuts 189 jumbo liner jobs
fields.trailText: Cammell Laird, the troubled Merseyside-based shipbuilding and repair company, yesterday announced a further 189 redundancies - in effect halving the workforce at its Birkenhead yard.
fields.body:
Cammell Laird, the troubled Merseyside-based shipbuilding and repair company, yesterday announced a further 189 redundancies - in effect halving the workforce at its Birkenhead yard.

The job cuts, in addition to 250 announced before Christmas, are a direct result of the decision by Italian cruiseline Costa Crociere in November last year to order its ship, Costa Classica, to turn around en route for Birkenhead, where it was to undergo a £51m conversion.

The Italians, citing delays to Cammell's work on increasing the ship's length under a process known as jumboisation, have threatened to take the contract to arbitration but senior executives from both companies met in Genoa last week to discuss various proposals to resolve their dispute.

A decision on such a deal is due by the end of this month, raising hopes that the Costa Classica - which turned back off the cost of Spain - will enter the Birkenhead yard later this year when the summer season of cruises is over.

Cammell had hoped to stave off further redundancies by winning short term contracts on top of those from P&O and Irish Ferries before work can start on a £350m government-backed project to build two cruise ships for US line, Luxus. Most of the government's aid package is said to be in place.

webTitle: Pass notes: Trude Mostue

fields.headline: No: 1792 Trude Mostue
fields.trailText: The foxy Norwegian blonde off the telly! Yes it's lovely Trude Mostue, beloved of bird-watchers everywhere.
fields.body:
The foxy Norwegian blonde off the telly! Yes it's lovely Trude Mostue, beloved of bird-watchers everywhere.

Bird? This is the Guardian, not some fly-by-night lad-mag! I'll thank you to take Pass notes seriously, and not drag it into the gutter with such derogatory language. I was merely referring to the fact that she presents Vets in Practice on the BBC.

Oh. Right. She is a bit of a sex kitten though. Is she, er, available? Funny you should ask. As a matter of fact she is. Although she might be nursing a broken heart.

Oh no! She hasn't fallen victim to some evil love rat has she? No, no. But she has split up with Brian Poulsen, the luscious Danish engineer and model she was just wild about.

How absolutely beastly for her. Yes, and poor Trude had to spend the festive season alone.

Well, a dog is not just for Christmas. Even if he is a great Dane. True. Perhaps it was just puppy love? Perhaps they were aping co-stars Emma and Joe Inglis who recently announced that they were to divorce after just two years of marital bliss?

That's 14 dog years. But hardly donkey's.

They sound a bit flighty, these vets. Yes indeed. For weeks after Trude ditched former boyfriend, computer expert Patrick Evans, she was slobbering all over Brian, and it wasn't long before they had set up their own little love-nest in sunny Bristol.

Hardly a pause. You mean paws.

No I don't. So where did it all go wrong? Trude, 32, said that her busy celebrity vet workload was to blame. "I just don't have time," said the Scandinavian beauty.

Well, a Norwegian would. It's probably an animal instinct.

Still there's plenty more fish in the sea . Or at Bristol Aquarium, Clifton, Bristol BS8 3HA, tel: 0117 9738951, open 9pm-5pm, seven days a week.

But are they still good friends? I assure you, they're pedigree chums.
