Hardly a pause. You mean paws. No I don't. So where did it all go wrong? Trude, 32, said that her busy celebrity vet workload was to blame. "I just don't have time," said the Scandinavian beauty. Well, a Norwegian would. It's probably an animal instinct. Still there's plenty more fish in the sea . Or at Bristol Aquarium, Clifton, Bristol BS8 3HA, tel: 0117 9738951, open 9pm-5pm, seven days a week. But are they still good friends? I assure you, they're pedigree chums.

webTitle: Suddenly it's hype to be an analyst

fields.headline: Suddenly it's hype to be an analyst
fields.standfirst: News Analysis Investors have paid dear for Wall Street's neglect of old-fashioned equities research
fields.trailText: News Analysis Investors have paid dear for Wall Street's neglect of old-fashioned equities research.
fields.body:
Of all the rude awakenings the bear market has brought to investors, perhaps the most severe has been realisation of how wrong Wall Street's research analysts were last year on the stocks they follow. While the US market sank to its worst performance in more than 10 years, many of them kept right on smiling and saying "buy".

How can so many who are paid so much to scrutinise companies have blown it so spectacularly for their investor customers?

The answer lies in a subtle but significant change in the way Wall Street analysts do their work - and how they are rewarded for it. That shift brought riches and stardom to many securities analysts and cost investors billions in losses.

Although brokerage stock gurus are still called analysts, their day-to-day pursuits involve much less analysis and much more salesmanship than before.

"The competition for investing banking business is so keen that analysts' 'sell' recommendations on stocks of banking clients or potential banking clients are very rare," said Arthur Levitt, the chairman of the US securities and exchange commission. "Whether this is an actual or perceived conflict, clearly, in the minds of many institutional buyers, brokerage firm analysis has diminished credibility."

Robert Olstein, a mutual-fund manager with 32 years ' experience analysing companies' financial results, said: "Instead of providing investors with the kind of analysis that would have kept them from marching over the cliff, analysts prodded them forward by inventing new valuation criteria for stocks that had no basis in reality and no standards of good practice."

Investors look to analysts to advise them on whether to buy or sell a stock at its current price. Until the mid-1990s, that is how most analysts approached their work.

Today there is almost no such thing as a "sell" recommendation from Wall Street analysts. Of 8,000 recommendations covering the companies in the Standard & Poor's 500 index, only 29 are "sells", according to Zacks Investment Research in Chicago. On the other hand, "strong buy" recommendations number 214.

Many investing veterans contend the quality of research has sunk to new lows, the result of shifting economics in the brokerage business which pushed many researchers to put relationships with the companies they follow ahead of investors.

The sharp reduction in levels of share-trading commission are one factor. Because analysts' recommendations helped generate trades and commissions, research departments paid for themselves. But as commissions de clined Wall Street firms looked elsewhere for ways to cover the costs of research.

The lucrative area of investment banking was an obvious choice. Analysts soon began going on sales calls for stock underwritings, debt offerings and other investment banking deals. In this world, negative research reports carried a cost, not a benefit.

"Research analysts have become either touts for their firm's corporate finance departments or the distribution system for the party line of the companies they follow," said Stefan Abrams, chief investment officer for asset allocation at Trust Co of the West in New York. "Not only are they not doing the research, they have totally lost track of equity values."

In the past few months, as former stock market favourites crashed to earth, many top analysts remained maddeningly upbeat.

Consider Mary Meeker at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, who became known as Queen of the Internet for her prognostications on e-commerce companies. In 1999, as internet stocks soared and new companies were taken public in droves, she made $15m, according to news reports.

Now that internet stocks are in pieces on the ground, she still rates all 11 she follows as "outperform" even though as a group they are down an average 83%. Of the 11 companies she remains positive on, eight had securities underwritten by Morgan Stanley.

Ms Meeker declined to comment. But Ray O'Rourke, a Morgan Stanley spokesman, said her picks had been made for the long term. Moreover, he said, Ms Meeker warned investors last March that internet stocks were volatile.

Asked whether Ms Meeker's non-stop optimism had anything to do with Morgan Stanley's role as an investment bank, Mr O'Rourke said: "It is what it is. But you shouldn't be surprised necessarily to see 'outperforms' on the companies, because we've been very vigorous on the companies we've chosen to bring public." - New York Times

webTitle: Letters: I'll drawl you a diagram

fields.headline: I'll drawl you a diagram
fields.trailText: It's the same old story isn't it? In a nutshell, we've had all and sundry who, by and large, and with all due respect, can't see beyond the end of their noses. They're in their ivory towers telling us that cliches are nothing to write home about.
fields.body:
It's the same old story isn't it? In a nutshell, we've had all and sundry who, by and large, and with all due respect, can't see beyond the end of their noses. They're in their ivory towers telling us that cliches are nothing to write home about (Call me old fashioned, but ... G2, January 2).

I say hold your horses. I might rock the boat and ruffle some feathers, but in this day and age, the conventional wisdom smells fishy to me. Indeed, you might think I've got bigger fish to fry or that I've a got a chip on my shoulder, but cliches are meat and drink to me.

Sure, they can stick out like a sore thumb, but mark my words (and let me say this loud and clear) a good, bad or indifferent cliche, time and time again, can warm the cockles of your heart.

I could bang on about this until the cows come home, but at the end of the day, when the chips are down, a cliche is par for the course. I realise that I've got my work cut out but there's no two ways about it: to some, cliches might stink to high heaven, but I'll use them until hell freezes over.
Graham Hopkins
Denby Village, Derbs

 The recent letters about Bristolian "l" miss an important point. This intrusive "l" is exactly parallel to the inclusive "r" of estuary (standard?) English. Both occur only before a vowel, so that "drawing" becomes either "drawling" or "drawring". So the names in the letter of January 2 would, by the same token, be Sandrar, Verar and Normar in the south-east. Neither is more comic or incorrect than the other.
FR Palmer
Wokingham, Berks

webTitle: Letters: The homeless left out in the cold

fields.headline: The homeless left out in the cold
fields.trailText: Jeevan Vasager's thoughtful piece about homeless people (January 1) is most welcome. This NHS service for people with drug and alcohol problems can endorse the concerns expressed by Crisis.
fields.body:
Jeevan Vasager's thoughtful piece about homeless people (January 1) is most welcome. This NHS service for people with drug and alcohol problems can endorse the concerns expressed by Crisis. Our clinic has always had good relations with local and Londonwide housing agencies, but this year we have found it very difficult to refer to hostels because their direct-access beds are monopolised by the rough sleepers' unit. The unit accepts only sleepers in the open, counted at fixed sites over a period of time; but many of the "hidden homeless", including our client group, feel it safer to stay on roofs and stairwells, in derelict buildings, and to move around nightly.

This situation is complicated by the worrying failure of the appeal by the Winter comfort housing workers against conviction and imprisonment for vicarious liability for drugs activities by clients at their day-centre, a judgment which will force many housing services to turn away homeless drug users.

Shaks Gosh (Letters, January 2) is correct that many temporary residents in Crisis hostels - possibly a majority - are having to be discharged with nowhere to go. She is also correct that there is a likelihood some will die, of cold, or of worsened illnesses. Despite being knowledgeable housing workers, our team are not optimistic that we can avoid these tragic and preventable outcomes for all our own vulnerable clients.
Lorraine Hewitt
The Stockwell Project
t@loltone.force9.co.uk

 As one of the volunteers working at the Crisis shelter over Christmas, I was angered and disappointed by Jeremy Swain's comment's (Charity 'wrong' over winter homeless crisis, January 1). I helped to draw up the list of 75 people and the only criterion we used was whether we honestly believed these people would spend that night on the streets.

It would be a shame if the government succeeded in cynically deflecting criticism from itself on to a charity that brought together hundreds of volunteers and homeless people in an atmosphere of warmth and respect, even if it was only for a week and even if we could do nothing for the 75 (at least) people who left us to sleep in the open.
Liza Schuster
Woodford, Essex

webTitle: Letter: Bishop of Kingston on Jubilee 2000

fields.headline: A debt to Bill Peters too
fields.trailText: I was pleased to see your leader on the excellent work of Jubilee 2000 (December 30), and the subsequent corrective of Professor Tordoff concerning Professor Martin Dent. May I presume to add a further corrective?
fields.body:
I was pleased to see your leader on the excellent work of Jubilee 2000 (December 30), and the subsequent corrective of Professor Tordoff concerning Professor Martin Dent. May I presume to add a further corrective? Bill Peters, a former diplomat, was very much a partner of Dent's in this visionary work, indeed he may be said to have preceded Dent's interest. Immediately after retiring from the Diplomatic Service in 1983 he began work on an international campaign for the cancellation of unrepayable debt, and has traversed the world several times in pursuit of this mission.

In 1989 Peters became chairman of the United Society for the Propagation of the Gospel, an international Anglican mission agency, which celebrates its tercentenary this year, and encouraged the society under my secretaryship to become one of the early advocates of the remission of third world debt, and incidentally, one of the first organisations to join the putative Jubilee 2000 coalition.

While Dent's work has been recognised through the recent well-earned honour, it would be singularly remiss for the role and work of Bill Peters to go unacknowledged.
Rt Rev Peter Price
Bishop of Kingston

webTitle: Letters: C4 Chief executive on Business TV

fields.headline: Business TV
fields.trailText: The Guardian is all about strong opinions and we of course respect that. However I find it incredible that George Monbiot can say "Channel 4's science and public health programming has been dominated by the view that big business has our best interests at heart."
fields.body:
The Guardian is all about strong opinions and we of course respect that. However I find it incredible that George Monbiot can say "Channel 4's science and public health programming has been dominated by the view that big business has our best interests at heart" (Big business, as seen on TV, December 14).

In the past three years Channel 4 programmes have regularly questioned the behaviour or policies of "big business". Dispatches recently investigated British Airways policy on pilots drinking and flying. This was followed by an investigation into Ford Motor Company and the sometimes fatal occurrence of "sudden acceleration" in Ford cars. In April, Channel 4 and the Guardian jointly investigated BNFL, regarding safety concerns over nuclear waste transportation.

On public health programming, I point to seasons such as Stop Go Home, Generation Sex, Eating Disorders, Embarrassing Illnesses or Why Doctors Make Mistakes. Not one of these seasons contains a single programme that would remotely substantiate Mr Monbiot's statement.

The implication that Channel 4 has an agenda that benefits "big business" is absurd.
Michael Jackson
Chief executive, Channel 4

webTitle: Letters: Labour and taxation

fields.headline: No more Mr Nice Guy
fields.trailText: The government need look no further than Polly Toynbee's column (What Labour needs is clear red water, December 29) for what its supporters are looking for.
fields.body:
The government need look no further than Polly Toynbee's column (What Labour needs is clear red water, December 29) for what its supporters are looking for. No more pussyfooting around in an attempt to find "something for everybody"; having secured its first term in office and successfully shed its reputation for financial incompetence, Labour now needs to be bold. Let it be honest about the consequences of further tax cuts. Let it expound the virtues of a wisely spent tax rise.

Countless surveys have shown that many people would willingly pay more tax if they thought they had a greater say in how it was being spent. Let Labour heed these findings and show the country what a difference a tax increase can make to schools, hospitals and law and order. By introducing some honesty and integrity into politics, it will gain the nation's respect and, thereby, a mandate to put some truly worthy policies into effect.
Ann Nicholls
Matlock, Derbs
trans@ann-nicholls.com

 Polly Toynbee is right to identify taxation as the battleground on which Labour must fight the next election, but to do this successfully will require the party to fundamentally change its relationship with big business. Labour's first term has been characterised by an almost slavish adherence to whatever taxation policies big business believes are best for the economy.

The most damaging example of this was the government's fight to introduce an effective energy tax to combat climate change, which was all but lost following a vociferous campaign by the Confederation of British Industry. Now, with the chance of a second term, Labour must have the courage of its convictions to introduce new taxes if it believes there is a clear social or environmental need, whatever the opinion of big business. After all, if the party hasn't got the stomach for a fight, it won't matter what taxation policies are in its manifesto.
Nicholas Milton
London
nicholasmilton@hotmail.com

 So, "things which people value most can only be bought collectively". But this amounts to socialism, the word which cannot be spoken.
John Ashwell
Eastleigh, Hants

 That the Liberal Democrats, Scottish National party and Plaid Cymru can be described as left of New Labour comes as no surprise, considering how far it has moved to the right (Labour looks for business backing, January 2). A different question is the emergence of a socialist challenge to Labour which has regularly scored between 5% and 12% in council and parliamentary byelections. John Curtice of the Centre for Research into Elections notes "... the fifth by-election in a row in which a candidate standing under a socialist label has passed the 5% threshold. It is easily the best record for the far left in post-war Britain."
Anna Chen
London Socialist Alliance
a.chen@virgin.net

 Matthew Engel may be right that the Tories are on their way out as a dominating force in British politics (Comment, January 2), but his analysis is based on one assumption: that we keep the abhorrent first past the post electoral system. I never thought I would say this, but we need a Conservative opposition, just as we need Green MPs. Proportional representation is the only system that can provide a more balanced parliament, representing all shades of opinion.
Bert Bruins
Exeter Green party
b.bruins@virgin.net

 Engel should not forget Ernest Bevin's famous remark about the Tories: "They are like vermin - you can keep them down for a while, but they'll always come back."
John White
Baldock, Herts

webTitle: Letters: The letter of the law

fields.headline: The letter of the law
fields.trailText: Suzon Forscey-Moore (Letters, December 29) refers to "judges delivering one ruling in the courtroom and a different one in writing". This is an issue of fundamental importance to the integrity and coherence of the legal system. Law is interpreted in England on the basis of precedent. One can only be sure of a precedent by studying the texts, normally official transcripts and subsequent commentaries. But if an official transcript is different from what was said - and recorded - in court, then the validity of any analysis of this text is null.
fields.body:
Suzon Forscey-Moore (Letters, December 29) refers to "judges delivering one ruling in the courtroom and a different one in writing". This is an issue of fundamental importance to the integrity and coherence of the legal system. Law is interpreted in England on the basis of precedent. One can only be sure of a precedent by studying the texts, normally official transcripts and subsequent commentaries. But if an official transcript is different from what was said - and recorded - in court, then the validity of any analysis of this text is null.

To give one example from 1985: I heard a judge say to a jury, "I order you - I am giving you an instruction - to find that Miss X's contract was breached." In the official transcript these words are removed. In their place is a completely invented passage, saying that since this is a matter of fact, it is for the jury to decide whether this contract was breached. This is correct in law, but it is not what the judge said in court - which one must presume, had a large bearing on the eventual verdict.

I asked the lord chancellor to make a simple comparison between the words recorded on tape in the mechanical recording office and the text of the official transcript. Despite many subsequent letters, this was not, so far as I am aware, ever done.

In my submission to the Woolf committee I drew attention to the dangers and put forward an inexpensive solution: instead of one tape recorder in the court, there should be three. At the end of each day a reel (or disk) should be given to each party, with one being retained by the court. Since all parties would now have an original recording, any attempt at falsification would become quickly apparent.
Salaam Blackmore
Basel, Switzerland
blackmore@balcab.ch

 Your report (Previous convictions may be revealed to juries, January 1) revealed the usual antagonists - with civil rights groups saying it would undermine the fundamental presumption of innocence and the Association of Chief Police Officers highlighting a need for change. What needs to be remembered is what currently happens.

In brief, who is questioned when no one falls under incidental suspicion? As the criminologist David Matza explained, those who have previous convictions are already much more "at risk" of being questioned and processed through the criminal justice system. The danger is that we may be losing the one good chance of sifting the evidence without prejudice.
Prof Keith Soothill
Lancaster University

As the criminologist David Matza explained, those who have previous convictions are already much more "at risk" of being questioned and processed through the criminal justice system. The danger is that we may be losing the one good chance of sifting the evidence without prejudice. Prof Keith Soothill Lancaster University

webTitle: A country diary

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: Wenlock Edge
fields.trailText: Wenlock Edge
fields.body:
"I walk the lanes of Wenlock/And dream about the night/Where every leaf is shrivelled/And every berry bright." Tonight is the longest of the year. It's warm, considering, and foggy. The moon is in hiding. There are faint whispering sounds and trickling water in the dark green mysterious spaces under leafless hedges. The berries of dogrose, bryony and holly are bright - or they would be if it was not so dark. This time last year they had been stripped by thrush tribes from the north - redwings and fieldfares. This year perhaps there are fewer visitors, or they are not so hungry yet. Other birds hide in the hedges and trees, settled in for the long night; even the owls are speechless.

There is a strange melancholy across the fields and woods, a blankness behind the fog, as if the landscape has been replaced by a landscape painting, big and empty. Out there are rivers, towns, cities, oceans, but you'd never guess. There are parties and miseries. There are lights in the distance: homes where people watch television, cars going down to the pub or somewhere. Tonight is grave, quiet, deep and wet, and wrapped around by gaunt and ghostly trees. Tonight the year is on the change and another shrivelled leaf drops to the earth.

After tonight, the world will brighten as if recovering from a hangover; the first stirrings of spring will scratch the echoing ruins of winter. After tonight, the floods will recede and foxes discover a middle way into the hearts of their murderers. The great wooded wave of Wenlock Edge is poised, darker than the night, to crash down into the plain but instead it stays here, enduringly.

webTitle: Court circular

fields.headline: Court circular
fields.standfirst: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.body:
Those still nursing their New Year's hangovers might like to bask in the warm glow of schadenfreude this week, with news of former Beverly Hills 90210 starlet Shannen Doherty 's festive arrest for drink-driving. To wit, the famously volcanic Doherty, latterly to be found in occult sitcom Charmed, stumbled blearily onto the wrong side of the law last Thursday, when the California Highway Patrol observed her "weaving" across the Ventura Freeway just north of Los Angeles. On being pulled over, the actress then refused to submit to a breathalyser test, before adjourning to county jail to give a blood sample. Now seemingly en route to adding to a criminal CV already well-seasoned with nightclub fist-fights, drunken melees in LA car parks, and court-ordered trips to anger management, Doherty - who has yet to release any comment publicly - will be sent for arraignment in a fortnight...

An even less happy start to 2001, meanwhile, for Nick Navarro, the one-time Florida sheriff whose obligatory 15 minutes in the spotlight first came with his arrest of sex-obsessed 2 Live Crew rapper Luther Campbell on public obscenity charges back in 1991. Now, however, it looks like a clear case of biter bit for the hapless Navarro, the subject of a hefty copyright infringement suit from Campbell's music publishers Lil' Joe Music, after his autobiography The Cuban Cop included a number of the rapper's profanity-packed lyrics while detailing the decade-old ruckus (which ended, incidentally, with the entire case being dismissed). "We believe [Navarro] published the words to these songs to sell more books", Campbell's attorney Cary Lubetsky told reporters. "Any profits from this book are statutorily due to the Lil' Joe companies."

webTitle: Hear this

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Stealing The Glory: The Conquest Of The North Pole | The Countryside Debates
fields.body:
On 6 April 1988, Matthew Henson was re-interred with full military honours in Arlington National Cemetery, a belated recognition of his true place in US history. On the same date 81 years earlier, he had become the first American to reach the North Pole, a feat long credited to Admiral Robert Peary. As Colin Salmon explains in Stealing The Glory: The Conquest Of The North Pole (11.0am, Radio 4), Henson's problem was that he was black. In 1907 that was quite the wrong hue for any American hero.

With many fields devastated by floods and the meat markets in turmoil, Britain's farmers are going out of business in their thousands. Against this background Edward Stourton chairs the first of The Countryside Debates (8.0pm, Radio 4). This opener comes from the Royal Agricultural College in Cirencester where a score of experts consider the proposition that farming and food production should not be the main activity of the countryside.

webTitle: Death Row prisoners made theatre history

fields.headline: Escape from the electric chair
fields.standfirst: How wrongly convicted Death Row prisoners made theatre history.
fields.trailText: How wrongly convicted Death Row prisoners made theatre history.
fields.body:
Steve Earle, the roots rocker and political activist, is in ebullient form. "Hey," he calls out across the crowd making its way into the theatre. "I didn't realise they let pinkos in here." In fact, this being the reading of a script about Death Row, the auditorium in the United Nations building in New York is peopled exclusively by pinkos.

Earle, who spends much time campaigning against the death penalty, is a guest at the latest outing for The Exonerated. The script is based on interviews with some of the 87 innocent people convicted and then released from Death Row in the US. The biggest star on the stage tonight is Debra Winger, and any Broadway producer would envy the names who have volunteered their services for previous readings, a list including Richard Dreyfuss, Steve Buscemi and, inevitably, the him and her of New York actorly liberalism, Susan Sarandon and Tim Robbins.

The tenor of the evening in the Dag Hammersjold theatre is set by the hosts, Gabriel Byrne and Marisa Berenson, reading condemnations of the death penalty by Albert Camus, Arthur Koestler and the Dalai Lama. But the worthiness of the purpose is frequently contradicted by The Exonerated itself, a script that is rich in what can only be described as gallows humour.

"I know it doesn't mean anything, but there were some people in there who were really guilty," says one prisoner. "I was so sure I was getting out in the summer I had [fake] suntan brought in," says another, a petty wiseguy who could have been raised on repeats of The Sopranos. "Might as well look good when I get out."

Yet another, a yoga instructor whose husband took 13 minutes to die in the electric chair in Florida while flames shot from his head, asks: "How could this happen to me? I was a hippie, I was a peace-and-love person. I'm a vegetarian." The stories, by turns animated, flat, matter-of-fact and conversational, illuminate not just the mechanics of injustice but questions of class and race, too. "Like I often say, if you're a black man in the south you might as well have done it because your ass will be found guilty." Others are grim little parables, cousins to the short stories of Raymond Carver but offering more obvious consequences.

This is not what young actors Jessica Blank and Erik Jensen bargained for when they set out on the project. "A good friend warned us at the beginning of this process: 'It might be the same thing over and over - I was framed, they were wrong, I was freed and now I'm bitter.' And to be honest, we expected variations on that theme. What we discovered, however, was not nearly as disheartening and far more profound."

The idea hit the couple when they attended a conference at Columbia law school in Manhattan early last year - which was more than one of the participants, a man in jail in Illinois, was able to do. He made a call to the workshop and talked about how he was tortured by his interrogators but was still in prison.

The prisoner's testimony stayed with them and they made contact with 40 of the 87 wronged inno cents, crossing the country by car for six weeks last summer. The play is based on 11 of those statements. "Honestly, we'd go into these interviews like jaded New Yorkers and come out completely wrecked," says Jensen. "It was profoundly affecting. Before we took the trip, I think I was blindly patriotic. But this made me question everything."

Richard Dreyfuss, perhaps getting carried away by his passion for the material, adds: "Some of the stories are just so overwhelming. It's one of those things where you want to get up at the end and strangle the people who did this to the innocent."

The Exonerated, in its present form, is played by 11 volunteer actors sitting in a line on chairs, batting back and forth tales that blend horror and the mundane; the format means that it is sometimes hard to follow the overlapping narratives. There are plans for a more fully realised production in the spring and performances elsewhere, such as Texas and Florida - places where executions are a less abstract concern than in New York. Earle, convinced that art can make a difference, lumbers on to the stage at the United Nations at the end of the night and says: "This is what happens when we are able to be big enough to admit that we were wrong."

webTitle: Interview: Rebecca Gilman, playwright

fields.headline: Racists like us
fields.standfirst: Rebecca Gilman has never been one to shy away from difficult subjects. Her latest play explores the secret prejudice of respectable liberals. She talks to Lyn Gardner
fields.trailText: Rebecca Gilman has never been one to shy away from difficult subjects. Her latest play explores the secret prejudice of respectable liberals. She talks to Lyn Gardner.
fields.body:
When her new play Spinning Into Butter opened in Chicago last year, Rebecca Gilman was scared - very scared. "I didn't know what to expect. I worried that people might be indifferent or blase, but I was more worried that some might start yelling and throwing things." Gilman's concerns were more than just first-night jitters, for Spinning Into Butter is a play by a white woman about that most incendiary of subjects: race and racism. In particular it looks at the way we invent new vocabularies to hide our old prejudices.

In the event, that first-night audience was so stunned that you could have heard a pin drop. Since then, Spinning Into Butter, which opens in London at the Royal Court this week, has caused a real stir in the US: it has been likened to Oleanna, David Mamet's play about sexual harassment and political correctness, engendered fierce argument and divided audiences. The Chicago run was extended three times, and eventually, due to pressure from the audience, every performance was followed by a discussion.

The title of the play comes from The Story of Little Black Sambo, Helen Bannerman's much-reviled children's book, published in 1898. Bannerman tells of a black boy who has his clothes stolen by tigers while walking in the forest. The tigers dress themselves in his clothes but then start arguing over which is the grandest of them all. Eventually they get so angry that they remove the garments and start chasing each other around the tree. Little Black Sambo retrieves his clothes and watches while the tigers chase each other so fast that they spin themselves into butter. Then he gets a spoon, scoops up the butter, puts it on his pancakes and gobbles it down.

In Spinning Into Butter it is the administration of a liberal arts college situated in New England that gets itself in a whirl when one of its very few black students starts receiving racially motivated threats. Immediately, and without reference to the student in question, senior staff start forming committees and demanding public meetings in which racism will be denounced. Only one, Sarah Matthews, a young dean who we have already seen trying to secure another minority student a much-needed scholarship, has doubts. She believes that before any meetings are held, the threatened student should be consulted, and argues that such public forums are useless anyway. "All you do is talk about racism, and then you heave this collective sigh of white guilt, and then everyone feels better, and then they drive downtown in their Saabs and buy sweaters," she says.

But her blustering, pompous colleagues are not going to let this opportunity to bolster their reputations slip by, and soon it is Sarah who is coming under pressure. In the play's second-act climax, which has so shocked American audiences, this apparently decent, liberal, well-meaning woman suddenly says the unsayable and confesses to the unthinkable. Sarah admits that she finds black people frightening, lazy and stupid. If she has to choose between sitting next to a black man on a train or standing up, she'll stand up. This is a woman who has taken "every class on African American literature and theory" but is still a racist.

"All I learned was how to appreciate black people," Sarah says. "The way you might appreciate a painting or a good bottle of Bordeaux. I studied them to figure them out. Like Sanskrit. But that's no different from hating them. It is called objectification. And it relies on keeping the object of your investigation at bay. It relies on knowing one or two really well-educated black people. Because when you come face to face with a lot of just regular black people, you can't aestheticise them any more. They're too damn scary."

Gilman agrees that part of the power of the play comes from the fact that in London, as in Chicago, it is likely to play largely to a white, liberal well-educated audience - people just like Sarah. "I wanted to play with people's expectations of the characters and force them to think about their own buried, unadmitted racism," she says, pointing out that when racists are portrayed on film and TV it is usually as stupid, fat people, which allows educated liberals to disassociate themselves. "It makes it too easy for us," she adds.

She was in part inspired to write the play after reading an American survey in which 80% of people said that they knew a racist but only 5% admitted to racism. "The figures just didn't add up. Someone wasn't being honest."

Like her previous play, The Glory of Living, a terrifying story of a 15-year-old Alabama girl who procures and murders young girls for her husband's sexual gratification, which was staged to great acclaim at the Court two years ago, Spinning Into Butter also has its origins in a true incident. For two years, the Alabama-born and bred Gilman attended a Vermont college where a black student was the recipient of racial threats. It was the attitudes of other students, mostly New Englanders, that really intrigued her.

"People I didn't know would hear I was from Alabama and come knocking on my door and say: 'Tell me about racism in the south.' I'd say: 'Tell me about racism in the north.' It was as though they didn't think racism was their problem." As Sarah facetiously suggests in the play: "If you don't like black people, moving to Vermont can take care of that. Because there aren't any black people here."

Gilman also hones in on the way we use and twist language for our own ends and how easy it is to say one thing while feeling another - something much facilitated by political correctness. "Political correctness has its good sides," says Gilman. "Being self-conscious about how we refer to people is a positive thing. But it is very easy to learn the jargon but not change attitudes. Politicians, corporations and universities are very adept at it."

It can also prevent us from actually engaging with the real issues, as Gilman makes clear in Sarah's confession, in which she announces: "Toni Morrison's Beloved sucks." After the terrible admissions that have come before, the moment has a comic intensity, but as Gilman points out, there is a serious issue at stake here. "You can't talk to people about that book because any discussion about it isn't about its merits but about race. Morrison is an icon. To say that you don't like her writing is to risk being branded a racist. That's absurd."

So far, Gilman has been pleased by the response to Spinning Into Butter. "Almost nobody has shouted during the performances - they've saved their opinions for afterwards. It has got people talking, and that's good, and lots of people have said to me about the play: 'I am glad somebody said that.' " But now she worries that, as the play's reputation precedes it, audiences' expectations are getting out of all proportion with what the play is trying to do.

"I've sometimes felt that people thought that I ought to solve racism in this play. But it's only a play. You can't solve racism with a single play, any more than you can solve it with a 10-point bullet plan.

 Spinning Into Butter is at the Royal Court Theatre Upstairs, London SW1 (020-7565 5000), from January 5.

webTitle: Oz, the ultra-violent prison drama

fields.headline: The wizards of Oz
fields.standfirst: Oz, the ultra-violent prison drama from the makers of The Sopranos, is one of US television's most innovative and talked-about shows. But over here it has only ever gained cult status. Why? Ed Barrett investigates
fields.trailText: Oz, the ultra-violent prison drama from the makers of The Sopranos, is one of US television's most innovative and talked-about shows. But over here it has only ever gained cult status. Why?
fields.body:
Welcome to Oswald State Correctional Facility - aka Oz - home to the most violent and unpleasant set of people ever assembled on the small screen. The nihilistic prison drama series in which they appear is due to return to Channel 4 early this year. It is the work of the US cable station Home Box Office - the company that makes The Sopranos. Yet in Britain, it remains one of TV's best kept secrets, despite the fact that it has been created by some of Hollywood's top talent. And stars of the stature of Kathy Bates, Matt Dillon and Steve Buscemi have signed up to direct episodes.

The action takes place in a special maximum security centre, devised by an idealistic and determined prison officer Tim McManus (Terry Kinney), with perspex cells and 24-hour surveillance. Here, prisoners are offered an opportunity to reform. Unfortunately, the inmates soon replicate the ethnic gangs of the old prison, with predictably explosive results.

It's amazing, in many ways, that Oz has survived as long as it has. It is incredibly violent - to a degree which would never be tolerated in mainstream Hollywood or US network television. By comparison, previous "brutal" dramas such Brubaker and Cool Hand Luke look like The Waltons. Indeed, the only prison film to come close to the show's atmosphere came out of Australia - John Hillcoat's Ghosts... Of The Civil Dead, which portrayed a futuristic dystopia inspired by America's high-tech jails.

The previous three series of Oz have featured poisoning, lynching, burning, shooting, beating, eye-gouging and crucifixion. The actors admit they find it tough going sometimes. "I have difficulty watching some scenes", says Edie Falco (better known as Carmela Soprano, who plays the world-weary prison officer Diane Wittlesey). At times even writer Tom Fontana finds it all too much. He claims that he closed his eyes while penning some scenes because, "I didn't want to see myself writing the words I had to produce."

Oz is about political cynicism and a morally bankrupt penal system. The giant, harshly lit sets perfectly complement the bleakness of the script. Much of the drama's strength comes from the character-driven plots. And it pulls off the trick of making storylines, which on paper would seem preposterous, become compelling on screen - a tribute to the actors' powers. Prison psychiatrist Sister Peter Marie (played by West Side Story star Rita Moreno) is a nun with a tragic past. Vern Schillinger (JK Simmons) is a neo-Nazi whose son becomes a drug addict and is imprisoned in the same jail, yet outside his protection. Episodes are topped and tailed by wheelchair-bound Augustus Hill (Harold Perrineau) - a one-man Greek chorus, summing up events in a few pithy sentences.

Oz's real strength, though, is that it is never gratuitous in dealing with the issues inevitably brought up by the brutalising influence of incarceration. Such as the story of Tobias Beecher (Lee Tergeson), a lawyer who killed a child while drink-driving. Alone and vulnerable in Oz with no prospective allies, he teeters on the edge of a breakdown before taking revenge on a fellow inmate and killing a guard. He ends up a brutalised and ruthless man, feared by the same people who once viewed him as a soft touch.

The programme is indisputably Tom Fontana's baby, and its dialogue, tight plotting and remarkable verisimilitude bear tribute to a rare talent. But executive producer Barry Levinson deserves credit too, for enabling such a singular and uncompromising vision to reach the screen. The ensemble acting is superb, and the cast speak warmly of the show's quality and integrity.

Once again, HBO has proved that programmes are only "risky" if they are substandard. Given good writing, directing and acting, anything can become great television. Audience reaction confirms this: Oz is so popular in the US that it boasts its own merchandise, "Newzletter", website and chat room. Dean Winters (Ryan O'Reilly, streetwise survivor par excellence) may describe Oz as "the show about people that you would never want to spend five minutes with in real life". But once you invite this motley crowd into your living room, you soon find that an hour a week is never enough.

webTitle: Family shocked over rower's arrest for killing

fields.headline: Family shocked over rower's arrest for killing
fields.trailText: The mother of a Briton charged with killing his rowing coach on a training trip to France has spoken of her shock and confusion following her son's arrest.
fields.body:
The mother of a Briton charged with killing his rowing coach on a training trip to France has spoken of her shock and confusion following her son's arrest.

Alex Lombardo, 23, was charged with voluntary homicide by French authorities following the death of Marcello Minale, 58, a former Olympic rower and renowned designer.

Mr Minale, thought to be a family friend, was stabbed to death last Friday after a row in the car park of the Montaroux rowing club on Lac de St Cassien, near Cannes, southern France.

Mr Lombardo appeared before a French public prosecutor on Monday and was remanded in custody to await trial. He has been visited by British consular staff and continues to face questioning from French investigators.

Speaking at her home near Newbury, Berkshire, Linda Lombardo offered her condolences to Mr Minale's family.

"We would like to pass on our deepest sympathies and condolences to Marcello's family," she said. "It's been a chaotic last three days for us. I feel as if I don't know whether I'm coming or going."

Mr Minale had been leading a group of 28 rowers, including Mr Lombardo, from the Tideway Scullers on a new year training trip to the lake, which, in contrast to the UK, offers calm conditions in which to train in winter.

In a statement, Mr Minale's sons, Marcello, 34, Manlio, 24, and Massimo, 21, described their "enormous loss".

"The news is a devastating blow to our family and we are still numbed by it. It was only last week that we celebrated a warm and loving Christmas with our father at home," they said. "Some of the young rowers in the party considered Marcello their mentor and he often spoke of the pleasure it gave him to take them under his wing."

Mr Minale and his wife, Roberta, had just celebrated their silver wedding anniversary.

Mr Lombardo was introduced to the rowing club by Mr Minale. He first joined two years ago but let his membership expire and only applied to rejoin in November last year. His membership was ratified in December. He was a "senior three" sculler, the grade above novice, indicating average ability.

Rob Pinckney, 52, a long-standing member of Tideway Scullers, said he was "amazed" by the allegations against Mr Lombardo. "I know Alex. He is the guy they are saying turned on Marcello. He was a new member and only joined about two months ago," he said.

"He's a funny-looking bloke with a sallow face, of slight build and he is bearded. He was often about the club but I do not remember ever chatting to him. I just cannot imagine a series of circumstances which could lead to this. It is all so improbable. I keep wondering if it could have been an accident."

Mr Pinckney, a dental surgeon, spoke warmly of Mr Minale. "He was such a dynamic man. Every morning he would cycle from his home in Ealing to the club and go sculling.

"He always had the latest, most sophisticated boat, often named after his beautiful wife. When he finished with a boat, he would give it to the club.

"He was a thoroughly nice man, an admirable man, whose death will be keenly felt by all of us at the club.

Mr Minale was an award winning designer who founded his interior design company, Minale Tattersfield, with Englishman Peter Tattersfield in 1964, four years after picking up a silver medal rowing for Italy at the Rome Olympics. As a designer his clients included Motorola, Armani, Harrods and Heathrow airport.

In a statement Alex Maranzano, managing director of Minale Tattersfield, said staff were devastated. "Mr Minale always a great source of strength and encouragement to the partners and all team members. He will be greatly missed."

Alec Hodges, a coach, said Mr Lombardo had first come to the club two years ago when he lived in Kingston, west London, and had been introduced to the club by Mr Minale.

"I don't know of any bad blood between them. I haven't heard of Alex losing his temper before but that will all come out in court. You don't flip for nothing, do you?," he said

Italian-born Mr Minale's firm had 18 offices around the world. It has won a number of awards from the Designers' and Art Directors' Association, London, and from the Art Directors' Club of New York.

Mr Minale had published eight books on design and received the D&ADA president's award for his outstanding contribution to the industry.

webTitle: Portsmouth cancel Pulis's contract

fields.headline: Portsmouth cancel Pulis's contract
fields.trailText: Portsmouth have cancelled the contract of manager Tony Pulis for an alleged act of misconduct.
fields.body:
Portsmouth have cancelled the contract of manager Tony Pulis for an alleged act of misconduct.

Pulis was placed on four months' suspended leave and replaced by striker Steve Claridge in the middle of October to allow him to concentrate on fighting a High Court case against his former club Gillingham and their chairman Paul Scally.

The former Bournemouth and Bristol City manager was only appointed at Fratton Park on a four-year deal 12 months ago, but had his contract terminated today by Portsmouth chairman Milan Mandaric and is now seeking advice from the League Managers Association.

The club were unwilling to reveal what the alleged act of misconduct was, while Pulis himself was unavailable for comment on the matter.

webTitle: Theatre review: Beauty and the beast

fields.headline: Beauty and the beast
fields.standfirst:
Polka
London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Polka
London
Rating: **
fields.body:
Nigel Forde's version of Perrault's tale was first produced at the Polka 12 years ago. Unfortunately, theatre, and in particular children's theatre, has moved on from the time when telling the story and spinning out the moral were enough to satisfy the under-12s.

Don't get me wrong, this is a perfectly decent and reasonably enjoyable rendering of Beauty and the Beast, but it is so devoid of either genuine theatricality or subtext that it offers no greater subtlety than the average pantomime. Even the set design is a big, clumsy anachronism.

When one thinks of Laurence Boswell's Young Vic version of the same story a few years back, in which - for a large part of the evening - the Beast was an unseen (but none the less terrible), looming presence in the minds of both Beauty and the audience, it is not surprising that Forde's literal approach seems so uninspiring by comparison.

The whole point of reprising these familiar tales is to make us look at them afresh and to let us glimpse our own reflection in the telling. To mummify them as a series of quaint olde worlde stage pictures is to negate their power. To reduce the story to its most obvious meaning - that you shouldn't judge by appearances - patronises the audience, even its very youngest members. It plays into the hands of those who say that all children's theatre is worthy and dull.

There are some good things here. The music consistently carries the emotion of the narrative and our first view of the Beast - as if glimpsed in a vision or bad dream by Beauty - is a theatrically impressive moment that underlines the power of the unconscious. The mysterious hands that offer hospitality to Beauty and her father in the Beast's castle have some strange magic about them.

But by framing the story as a wager between a good fairy who believes love conquers all and a bad fairy who avows that fear is stronger than love, Forde begins by taking a reductionist approach and carries on very much in the same mode.

Beauty's sisters wouldn't be out of place as a couple of ugly panto dames, while her father is merely an ineffectual, benignly neglectful stock figure - even though the image of the absent father who offers his children material wealth but not his loving presence would be one many children would recognise.

This isn't bad theatre. Many families and school parties will enjoy the experience. But it would be so much better if it embraced the myriad possibilities of both the story and of theatre itself.

 Until February 10. Box office: 020-8543 4888.

webTitle: Jazz review: Courtney Pine

fields.headline: Peace and love with Courtney Pine
fields.standfirst:
Courtney Pine
Jazz Cafe
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Courtney Pine
Jazz Cafe
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Courtney Pine is evolving into one of the great new ambassadors of British jazz. His inclusive approach, which means he can skip happily across the presumed boundaries of style, genre, race and age, was showcased in the second gig of a five-night, sold-out residency at the Jazz Cafe in London.

The seven-piece band was in party mood. As soon as one number finished, the rhythm section (including drummer Robert Fordjour, percussionist Donald Gamble, guitarist Cameron Pierre, Peter Martin on bass and bass guitar and Alex Wilson on keyboards) started up the next without a pause. Sometimes the groove was subtle and quiet, and when the DJ's funky opening set gave way to the live players the predominant mood was spacey and modal.

Pine's is a distinctly British version of jazz-funk, which easily embraces skanking reggae, calypso flavours and what you might call acoustic drum'n'bass (which sounds very close to straight jazz). Trombonist Dennis Rollins is a good front-line foil to Pine, setting off the leader's flights of virtuosity with simple, gutsy solos (using a wah-wah pedal at one point) and blasting out the tunes with easy assurance.

Some of the best pieces employed the quirky but effective combination of soprano sax and trombone, and they play the tricky melodies from memory. The set included several numbers from Pine's recent Back in the Day album, including Power to the People, My Father's Place, Keep it Real and The Jazzstep.

Pine picked up the EWI (electric wind instrument) for an affecting version of Monk's Round Midnight, a synthesised arrangement that recalled Michael Brecker's version of In a Sentimental Mood for Steps Ahead. For another piece he played with rhythmic repeat echoes in the manner of John Surman's pioneering solo gigs. Pine's wide knowledge of the jazz heritage, and the influence of John Coltrane in particular, is never far from the surface, so you might hear a snatch of Softly as in a Morning Sunrise or A Love Supreme erupting from a lengthy saxophone solo. But Pine is keen to assert the local tradition, paying tribute to a rollcall of British players including Joe Harriott, Ernest Ranglin and Ronnie Scott.

His saxophone playing reminded me a little of Don Rendell, who absorbed the lessons of Coltrane after coming of age in an era when jazz was still principally entertainment music. Pine has travelled in a different direction, learning to use elements of pop and dance after starting in more purist territory - but nothing he has learned has been wasted. His unique position on the scene means that an extended "look-no-hands" experiment in saxophone harmonics and circular breathing works as crowd-pleasing spectacle.

The audience, a mix of male and female, young and old, black and white, took it all in, clapping on the off-beat while Pine and Rollins mimed silently for one chorus, joining in with the Zulu jumping, appearing to love every minute. At one point Pine surveyed his loyal subjects and asked for a bit of call-and-response: "I say U, you say K." "UK!" You couldn't ask for a better plea for peace, love and unity this holiday.

webTitle: Art review: Georg Baselitz

fields.headline: Gagosian Gallery goes to the dogs
fields.standfirst:
Georg Baselitz
Gagosian Galleryn
London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Georg Baselitz
Gagosian Galleryn
London
Rating: **
fields.body:
Georg Baselitz, who seemed so significant when he began his immensely successful career as an expressionist painter in Berlin in the 1960s, has turned out to be a remarkably irrelevant artist. And to judge by the drooling self-mockery of his new exhibition at Gagosian, even he seems to know he's now a bit of a bloated joke.

His new paintings are of dogs. Nothing wrong with that. The dog has an honourable history as a subject in painting. Picasso adored his dog Frika, Hogarth painted himself with his pet pug, Lucian Freud's paintings treat dogs better than people. There's even a book, The Dog in Art, by the American critic Robert Rosenblum. Baselitz has probably read it. His paintings joke about the history of the dog in art and what it might expose about the silliness of art. These pictures mock a once-proud animal now domesticated and pampered rotten. Pink paint is thrown around as if by the senile Willem De Kooning. The effect aimed at is a queasy mixture of hard-edged machismo and pink fleshiness, but instead you think of the Andrex puppy.

Much later, you think of Puppy by Jeff Koons. Baselitz, prophet of Teutonic authenticity, seems to have turned into a more brushy version of the great kitschmeister himself. But where Koons has a heartless eye that always makes his irony crisp and telling, poor Georg just seems to be flailing. His paintings are pompous and incredible, and come across not as comments on kitsch but colossal manifestations of it. He seems more interested in the frames - which he himself carved in an Italian Renaissance style.

Of course, you could attempt all manner of subtle readings. Baselitz's paintings have always featured animals, a bestiary signposting his affinity for German romanticism and the Nordic cult of the wild. You might call these latest works cynical images of the contemporary painter as a wild beast curbed. You might see them as confessions of the tastelessness at the heart of painting. But in truth, they are not diagnoses of anything, they are symptoms, shaggy, slobbering and a bit pathetic.

 Until January 20. Details: 020-7292 8222.

His paintings are pompous and incredible, and come across not as comments on kitsch but colossal manifestations of it. He seems more interested in the frames - which he himself carved in an Italian Renaissance style. Of course, you could attempt all manner of subtle readings. Baselitz's paintings have always featured animals, a bestiary signposting his affinity for German romanticism and the Nordic cult of the wild. You might call these latest works cynical images of the contemporary painter as a wild beast curbed. You might see them as confessions of the tastelessness at the heart of painting. But in truth, they are not diagnoses of anything, they are symptoms, shaggy, slobbering and a bit pathetic.  Until January 20. Details: 020-7292 8222.

webTitle: Generation X workers

fields.headline: The young ones
fields.standfirst:
Richard Reeves on Generation X workers

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Richard Reeves on Generation X workers.
fields.body:
The elixir of youth is potent at work. The government is famously obsessed with all things young, to the absurd point at which the prime minister has declared an intention to appoint a permanent secretary under the age of 40 (why 40? Why not go all the way and appoint someone straight from university?), while Ford is giving preferential redundancy deals to the over-40s. At the same time, the dot.com revolution has favoured young people. The risks have often been as high as the rewards, with payment in stock options. This is all very well for a twentysomething whose biggest commitment is their season ticket, but much less appealing to someone with two children and a mortgage. The culture of the new economy, with its frenetic long hours, further suits the footloose young.

Some parts of this economy look like a labour-market version of Logan's Run, the film and TV series in which everyone over 30 is killed. (If you are too young to know about Logan's Run, ask the jaded thirtysomething next to you.)

It has become conventional wisdom that young people - specifically "Generation X", those just old enough to remember Mrs Thatcher coming to power - are different from their older colleagues: more flexible, less loyal, more mobile and less patient than their forebears. A plethora of books and articles has been churned out to help managers deal with the Xers.

In Managing Generation X, Bruce Tulgan dramatises their short-termism: "Xers have had sparse opportunities to experience affiliations of any kind - social, geographical, religious or political. Our own family structures . . . have not been reliable." Tulgan makes an explicit link between social trends, especially the rise of divorce, and a new, more sceptical attitude towards employers. Don't trust anyone, especially anyone over 30, is the motto of the Xers.

Some awful guff gets written about Generation X, such as advice from USA Today on "how to motivate Generation X" that includes "help them carve up the job into bite-size chunks so they can see the day-to-day results" and "move from six-month or 12- month reviews to frequent, accurate, specific and timely feedback". Short of advising that Xers be tucked up in their favourite blanket for an afternoon nap after a glass of milk, it is difficult to see how this advice could be more patronising.

And are young workers really so different? There is good evidence that they are moving jobs quickly and are more sceptical about the role of employers and more self-serving - but it may be that this is what young people are always like. It is critical to be aware of what sociologists call the "cohort effect", where a difference between two groups is simply a reflection of where they are in the life cycle and will disappear over time. There is a big dose of it in employment - older workers were less settled when they were young, too - but it does not explain everything. Workers in their 30s have had as many jobs as workers in their 50s. It looks as if there is a real difference in the willingness of younger workers to hop from job to job.

Workers in their late 40s, 50s and 60s entered the world of work at a time when employment was reasonably secure and unemployment fairly low. The baby boomers began work believing all would be well, then got a rude shock in the recessions of the 80s and 90s. The pain of redundancy was greatest for those who had believed work was a given. It tends to be people from this generation who most lament the death of the "job for life".

Younger workers, on the contrary, shudder at the thought of a job for life. They entered the labour market knowing that security was likely to come only from their own ability to navigate the rapids. Their scepticism, or even cynicism, is simply a reflection of the work-world they know, for today's Generation X workers are the children of the boomers. As many as a third felt the impact of redundancy in their homes long before they thought about work for themselves and when they entered the labour market, the memory of their parents' pain stayed with them. It is often thought to be a terrible thing that younger workers seem to have so little trust. In fact, it is street-smart self-preservation. Scarred by previous waves of redundancy, Generation X has justifiably gone walkabout.

Richard Reeves is director of futures at the Industrial Society. You can contact him at rreeves@indsoc.co.uk.

webTitle: Debunking stress in the workplace

fields.headline: Stressed?
fields.standfirst:
Not any more, you're not. For years, workers have blamed it for every ache and pain, but now some doctors are daring to debunk the stress crisis in the British workplace. Anita Chaudhuri reports

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Not any more, you're not. For years, workers have blamed it for every ache and pain, but now some doctors are daring to debunk the stress crisis in the British workplace.
fields.body:
You might have imagined you could have expected sympathy. If the thought of returning to work after the Christmas and New Year break left you feeling overwhelmed, anxious or even depressed; if you find yourself harbouring feelings of anger, jealousy or resentment towards your colleagues, you might have felt entitled to a little understanding. But you would have reckoned without the burgeoning stress backlash: the small but increasingly vocal number of maverick psychologists who argue that stress, the pre-eminent workplace problem of recent years, does not even exist.

Their unofficial leader is Dr Rob Briner, an occupational psychologist at London University's Birkbeck College. His message: feeling bad at work is normal, and not necessarily even wrong - and now the only place where the concept of stress has any valid currency is in the lucrative, and sometimes damaging, stress management industry.

"Stress has become a trivial concept without a clear set of physical symptoms," Briner says. "We are all so worried about the effect our jobs have on our mental health that we're turning into a nation of emotional hypochondriacs. Stress has been around since the 1950s and if you ask me, it's become the modern equivalent of when people used to say they had 'problems with their nerves'."

The history of industrial relations has been dogged by the mythical search for the happy, productive worker. But, Briner argues: "The reality is that it is not really desirable to be happy and relaxed all the time at work, particularly in professions such as nursing and teaching." Pressed on this point, he will admit that, no, we don't want to see hospitals and schools filled with grumpy staff - but says adrenalin, and the sentiments that accompany it, are frequently helpful in high-pressure professions.

It has long been the predictable view of employers' organisations with all-too-obvious vested interests that the stress crisis in Britain's workplaces has been exaggerated. But now some academic psychologists are starting to doubt that the concept has much validity. As Jo Rick, a research fellow at the Institute for Employment Studies, puts it: "These days, 'stress' is used to describe any negative experience we have at work, from anger and envy to exhaustion. So when we talk about eliminating stress from the workplace, it's pretty meaningless. Surely we shouldn't be looking to remove from our lives ordinary human emotions such as anger?"

This is, of course, still a decidedly minority view. Much evidence seems stacked against it: an Industrial Society survey shows three-quarters of employers see stress as the most important workplace issue of the next few years, while research from Bristol University indicates that one in five workers experiences some form of office stress; figures from the Institute of Stress Management put the cost to British industry at £7bn through 60m lost working days each year. Last month, primary school teacher Janice Howell received a record compensation payment of £254,000, having retired from her job after a nervous breakdown. Earlier last year, Beverley Lancaster, a former draughtswoman with Birmingham City Council, was awarded damages of £67,000 in the first ever British case in which an employer admitted liability for causing stress.

But what does it really mean to suffer from stress? The epidemic has reached such proportions that the Health and Safety Executive recently produced a discussion document which calls for a code of practice on minimising the risk of work-related stress. One might imagine that such an illustrious body would have come up with a snappy definition of the problem, but no: stress, the HSE says, is "a reaction to excessive pressures or other types of demand placed on employees". Which pretty much covers everything from wanting to kill your boss to problems with the vending machine.

In America, too, the stress backlash is gaining momentum: a recent book and inevitable website, The Stress Myth (www.stressmyth.com), from psychologist Serge Doublet, questions the validity of stress as a concept, from 1956, when the term was first coined by psychologist Hans Seyle in his study The Stress of Life, to the present day. "People feel 'stressed' because they believe in the first place that feeling 'stressed' is a legitimate condition," Doublet writes. "Without such a belief, the subjective feeling is not possible. Nevertheless, in everyday language, feelings of being 'stressed' often appear to supplant the use of emotion terms. Instead of feeling 'annoyed', 'worried', 'apprehensive' or 'frustrated', people declare that they are feeling 'stressed', even though it does not necessarily accurately describe what they feel."

There has been little research into how far normal levels of stress in a job can develop into something more harmful, Rick says. "What is harmful is using the term as a catch-all. People then hide behind it instead of tackling the real problem, often to the detriment of their physical health." She cites the case of a man experiencing chest pains. His GP told him he was probably suffering from stress and to take a few days' leave. The pains persisted but the man was happy to carry on working, in the belief that they were stress-induced. A few weeks later, he suffered a heart attack.

Sceptics reserve their strongest feelings for the stress management industry. Alarmed by the size of payouts in the civil courts and by the prospect of criminal prosecutions under the Health and Safety at Work Act, employers are calling in stress-busting professionals to carry out "stress audits", counselling and the teaching of relaxation techniques.

"These people represent a solution in search of a problem," Briner says. "They have a vested interest in scaremongering, in making us fear stress as this great evil of the workplace. Some of the remedies on offer can do more harm than good: if a worker is having problems because they are being made to take on too much work, then there is no point in sending them off for relaxation sessions or therapy, then putting them back in exactly the same conditions. The problem that needs addressing is the volume of work. It's a similar situation with people who have personality clashes with their colleagues. They don't need to learn how to relax, they need to be put on another team."

Briner says his research has led him to embrace the notion of the "post-stress workplace". "There is scant scientific research to link the effects of stress with ill health," he says. "In fact, negative emotions can be rather good for us: they can help the immune system to kick in."

Rick, too, dismisses the link between stress and conditions such as heart disease. "There is no evidence for this because there is no clear diagnosis of what stress is. Even when people do agree a definition, it is almost impossible to pinpoint with certainty that the source of stress comes solely from the workplace."

When our coping mechanisms shut down, a whole range of factors can be involved, from divorce and debt to dealing with children and relatives. Work does not exist in a vacuum. "That's why so many of the stress payouts we have seen recently have been settled out of court," Briner says. "They might not have won their cases if they had been heard because it is incredibly difficult to prove. Even if a person has a nervous breakdown, it is not easy to conclude that the sole cause of that was stress at work."

webTitle: Pop review: Horace Andy

fields.headline: Reggae's answer to Marvin Gaye
fields.standfirst:
Horace Andy
Subterania
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Horace Andy
Subterania
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
The decision by Massive Attack to employ Horace Andy, the veteran reggae singer, on their three albums had none of the ironic intent of such old/new team-ups as Shirley Bassey with Propellerheads. Andy's eerie, haunting tones are perfectly suited to the Bristol act's dolorous beatscapes. Nearly 30 years after his pioneering recordings at the legendary Studio One with Clement "Sir Coxsone" Dodd, Andy is basking in the acclaim of whole new generations, from trip hoppers to ex-punk rockers (the title track of his most recent album, Living in the Flood, was co-written with Joe Strummer).

It is hardly surprising, then, that Andy - born Horace Hinds in Kingston, Jamaica, in 1951 - is revered like a god. At 12.15am, DJ David Rodigan comes on stage to announce him: "Welcome to a living legend," he says. Yet Andy cuts a less than imposing figure. A small man with a smiling face, he wears the sort of patterned open-necked shirt favoured by ageing American tourists and dances across the stage like your dad at a wedding.

None of this quite squares with the sorrowful falsetto of his best work, or the image of the pensive soul caught on the sleeve of Living in the Flood. At one point he pulls the pretty female bassist from his backing band to the front of the stage like a genial uncle, and suddenly the apocalyptic menace of his performance on Massive Attack's Mezzanine is forgotten.

But then, there is more than one side to Horace Andy. For the standard rocksteady lilt of Fever, he plays the libidinous loverman whose louche manner has earned him the nom de disque, Sleepy. For the bass-heavy dub-quake that is Money is the Root of All Evil, he plays the righteous prophet of doom with the Old Testament worldview. On the slight Chat Away Chatterer, his tone is oddly high, his delivery almost comically fast.

It is during After All, however, that the "real" Horace Andy comes to the fore: the tortured romantic whose sweet tenor has spawned legions of lovers' rock lotharios, most of whom miss the ache, the anguish, behind his music. If Bob Marley was the John Lennon of reggae, then Horace Andy is its Marvin Gaye.

webTitle: Art review: Future Perfect

fields.headline: Future Perfect
fields.standfirst:
Cornerhouse
Manchester
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Cornerhouse
Manchester
Rating: ***
fields.body:
This collection of designs, paintings, sculptures and video is taken from the work of 11 international artists who have responded to the more futuristic and fantastical (yet always emphatically functional) aspects of modernist design.

What's immediately striking about the exhibition is that it shows how the modernists' ideas of utopian dwelling-space were contradictory. On one hand, they advocated self-contained one-person living units, ideal for the determinedly solipsistic. Yet they also propagated, in theory at least, a sense of community with the walkways in the sky that were made concrete in 1960s housing estates.

Such estates subsequently became notorious for violence - and one of them, Thamesmead in south-east London, was used by Stanley Kubrick for a scene in A Clockwork Orange, and for this exhibition, Liam Gillick's slide projection, Pain in a Building, tries to revise such associations. His shots of the tree-lined lakeside estate in evening sunlight suggest a tranquil urban pastoral more redolent of a 1960s-built university campus - those other eager recipients of modernist concrete.

It's also entertaining to see models for projects that were not built. In the 1960s, Matti Suuronen, the Finnish designer, devised egg-like pods on stilts for the Futuro team which wouldn't have looked out of place on a Doctor Who set 10 years later. A promotional poster replete with reclining girls and gaudy cushions completes the look, and you begin to see where Habitat and Wallpaper get their retro-design chic.

Also represented is Archigram, the famous 1960s architectural team, whose mutable pack-up-and-leave structures include a cushicle - a cross between a tent and a life raft - which you inflate from a back-pack. Their Walking City in the Desert (Ron Herron) is a photographic print in acid pink of a community of pipes and walkways linking structures that bear bodies like beetles, while their carnivalesque Instant City in a Field (1968) is suggestive of today's Glastonbury festival.

Although it's fun to giggle at futuristic follies, serious issues are implicitly explored, not least the relationships between the individual and the environment, and the individual and the community. And when you exit the white-walled sanctity of the gallery, and make your way along the city's crowded streets - noticing, for once, every building you pass - you'll soon be longing for the warmth and singularity of your pod.

 Until January 21. Details: 0161-200 1500.
